editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO Mr. Feyo John Winter, Doctor of Phy≈øick; Formerly Burgerma≈øter and Coun≈øellor of State in the City of Leeuwarden; As al≈øo Deputy to the States of Frie≈øeland; And Elder of the Walloon Church in the ≈øame Town.
div.p:
I Am bound to you ≈øince a long time with ≈øuch particular Obligations, and my Duty ties me to you with ≈øuch strict Bands, that there is no Man in the World, be≈øides the own Brothers of my
Dear Spou≈øe but I ought to prefer you before him. I have dedicated to them the two first. Books of the World Bewitch'd, and amongst all my Friends, who≈øe Names I intend to prefix to each part of the French Tran≈ølation, I have made choice of you for this, that is, the first of all, and going to be publi≈øh'd. It's above thirty years ≈øince I have the Honour to be acquainted with you, and about fifteen, ≈øince I am allied to you by your Marriage with the Lady Henriette Fullenia, the nearest Cou≈øin of my Spou≈øe, both from Father and Mother's ≈øide. It's likewi≈øe very near twenty years, ≈øince I was ≈øo happy as to ≈øee you a Member of the first College of the States of Frie≈øland, on who≈øe direction the good or had ≈øucce≈øs of my Affairs depended at that time. When occa≈øion has offer'd it ≈øelf, I receiv'd from you Te≈øtimonies of a ju≈øt favour and an ingenious di≈øtinction. Your Marriage tied more ≈øtrictly the Bands of the Friend≈øhip you had for me; and I have had the plea≈øure to ≈øee it lasting to this day. You gave me lately an obliging proof of it, when you were pleas'd to pre≈øent from me to his Highne≈øs,
Prince Henry Ca≈øimir of Na≈ø≈øau, Hereditary Governor of our common Country, &c. my Frie≈øland's Divinity; which I had taken the liberty to dedicate to him. For I was not in a capacity of pre≈øenting it my ≈øelf; becau≈øe the great Employments of his Hig ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈øs calling him at every moment to different parts of his Government, I could not be ≈øure ≈øo much as an hour of the place, where I might meet with him. This circum≈øtance procur'd me the Honour of receiving by the next Po≈øt a Letter from that Prince, containing very expre≈øs Marks of his Affection; in which he al≈øo declar'd, that my Dedication had not been unplea≈øant to him. But I have ≈øtill another rea≈øon that ingages me to pre≈øent you with the Tran≈ølation of this Work, with which you ≈øeem'd very much pleas'd. It's your particular Concern in the Affairs of the Churches, in who≈øe Tongue 'tis written, and in general in all tho≈øe of our Holy Religion: To this you ince≈ø≈øantly apply your ≈øelf with a Zeal worthy of Imitation and Admiration, di≈øcharging ≈øtill in the Walloon Church of your City, the Honourable Function of Elder, which you have formerly
di≈øcharg'd many times; as well as in the Church of your Mother Tongue. Farther, I thought fit to cau≈øe this Treati≈øe to be Tran≈ølated my ≈øelf, le≈øt ≈øome others ≈øhould undertake it, having been advis'd, that the Tran≈ølation of it had been begun in this Town, ‚Ä¢ nd el≈øewhere, without my knowledge; which however is happen'd, but ≈øince the late Synod of North-Holland; the proceedings that were made again≈øt me, having only been of u≈øe to excite the curio≈øity of the publick, as to this matter. And therefore I have prevented the de≈øigns of tho≈øe, who intended to make this Tran≈ølation, and provided at the ≈øame time, le≈øt any ≈øhould appear under my name, without my con≈øent, and my revi≈øing of it, as I may a≈ø≈øert that I have done this. It comes from a Frenchman, who has carefully apply'd him≈øelf to the ≈øtudy of our Tongue, and ≈øeems to me to under≈øtand his own very well. For tho' I am not conver≈øant with it ≈øo far, as to have Tran≈ølated my own Book my ≈øelf: yet I think that I am able to judge, that I ≈øhould not have better ≈øucceeded, nor more expre≈øly have render'd my own Thoughts,
if I had been in a capacity of undertaking it. Be≈øides, this Tran≈ølation being almo≈øt verbal, becau≈øe the quality of the Work required it; It is ≈øo much the more difficult, and worthy that its defects ≈øhould be over-look'd. I think at lea≈øt, that no other difference will be perceived, betwixt it and the Original, but that of the Tongue; no real change having been made in it. I own that ≈øeveral matters of Fact have been added, and in≈øerted in divers places of this Book; but nothing has been left out, ≈øo that the Reader ≈øhall have no occa≈øion of complaining of his Lo≈ø≈øes; but rather of being glad of the new advantages that accrue to him. I al≈øo have added after the Preface, an Abridgement of the whole Work, as a preliminary, that gives a general view and notion of it, including in ≈øub≈øtance, the Contents of the three la≈øt Books, that are to be ≈øucce≈ø≈øively Tran≈ølated; the ≈øecond being already far advanc'd. I only earne≈øtly wi≈øh, that you may be as well ≈øatisfied with my Dedication, as I am with this Tran≈ølation. So that all that I have to do, is to commend you, and all your Friends and
Relations, to the Grace of God, which I heartily beg of you all. But le≈øt any French Copy, of any of the≈øe Four Books, ≈øhould be publi≈øh'd under my name, be≈øides, tho≈øe that are printed in this Townt for Peter Rotterdam, the fir≈øt of which is dedicated to you; I declare that I own no other, but ≈øuch as are ≈øub≈øcribed by me, as this is, wherein I a≈ø≈øure you with my own Hand, that I am,

div.head: A PREFACE, TO THE Whole WORK in General, AND THE Fir≈øt Book in particular.
div.p: IF ever any Author thought the Treati≈øe he was publi≈øhing, needed an Introduction, methinks that I may not only have the ≈øame Opinion of this; but even that I cannot forbear it. Two particular Rea≈øons oblige me to it, one of which concerns the circum≈øtances of what happened during the impre≈ø≈øion of this work, and the other, has relation to it's contents. Both the≈øe Rea≈øons has ≈øomething extraordinary, but the latter e≈øpecially appears ≈øtill more ≈øtrange, becau≈øe of the former; and therefore I intend to give the Reader ≈øome explanation upon both.

Having form'd a de≈øign to write upon the matter treated of in this Book, I begun Eight Years ago in my Preface to the Book of Comets, to give ≈øome hints of what I intend to explain here more particularly. I had cho≈øen for the ≈øubject of my publick Sermons, the Prophecy of Daniel, when I was come to the 11th v. of the 2 Chapter, in which the Magicians confe≈øs, they were not capable
of expounding the King's Dreams; I drew from that Declaration, ≈øuch inferences, as evidently ≈øhow'd what mu≈øt be believed concerning the extent of knowledge, a≈øcribed to the Devil; afterwards judging it convenient to examine his power, and whether it extends as far as is ordinarily ≈øaid; the fir≈øt occa≈øion I had of a≈øcending the Pulpit, I took my Text on Exodus Chap. 8. v. 18th, and examined why the Magicians could not as ea≈øily produce Lice, as Frogs and Serpents. The late Sieur de Tamininga, Lord of Belleingweer, a learned and pious Gentleman, heard my Sermon, and lik'd it extreamly; thinking that if what I had propo≈øed, were printed, it would obtain the approbation of under≈øtanding per≈øons, and inform the ignorant. He exhorted me him≈øelf ≈øeveral times to print that di≈øcour≈øe, and imployed other per≈øons to de≈øire me to do it; but I was ≈øo taken up with other bu≈øine≈øs, as may be judged by the Books I have publi≈øhed, and by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance I have afforded my friends in the Edition of theirs, that I could not an≈øwer his expectation ≈øo ≈øoon, th√¥ never ab≈øolutely denyed to do it. Since that time, I preached twice again on the ≈øame matter, on occa≈øion of the Witch of Endor, whom Saul went to con≈øult, and of the Dev ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ who tormented Job, many per≈øons pre≈øs'd it hard upon me, to publi≈øh my Opinion on this ≈øubject. In 1689, as I was explaining in the Ho≈øpital Church, the 19th and following ver≈øes of the 5th Chap. to the Galatians, I ≈øearched deeper into this matter, expounding the Greek word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which the French and Dutch interpreters have tran≈ølated Poi≈øoning, and the Engli≈øh, Witchcraft. But as I could not compri≈øe in a Sermon, whatever was to be ≈øaid upon this ≈øubject, I referr'd my hearers to a fuller in≈øtruction, in a larger volum that I was going to publi≈øh. I have given an account why it was not undertaken
before, and now I ≈øhall inform the Reader, why it has been ≈øo long in the Pre≈øs.

Going from Francker to Loen, where I was call'd to be a Mini≈øter, I promi≈øed my Book≈øeller H. Nauta, that to keep our old acquaintance, I would give him to print the fir≈øt Treati≈øe I ≈øhould compo≈øe in Holland; almo≈øt as ≈øoon as I was come thither, there appeared a Comet in the Years 1680, and 1681, which gave me occa≈øion to write a Book, Intituled, An Examination of Comets, which I put out in 1683. But as the Book≈øeller de≈øired the Book might be ≈øomewhat larger, and I found it inconvenient to take care of a long impre≈ø≈øion beyond Sea; I obliged him to continue it for that time; promi≈øing him, that, if he ever re-printed the ≈øame Treati≈øe, I would either increa≈øe it; or add ≈øome other to it. I had no occa≈øion to keep to the fir≈øt promi≈øe, no body having ≈øaid or written any thing again≈øt it, that required a more particular explication. And therefore I thought fit to hold my Second promi≈øe, by adding to my Examination of Comets, another tract upon a matter ≈øomewhat relating to it, and on which I had meditated a long time. To that end, I compo≈øed an Examination of Magick, and Witchcraft, that contained very near as many ≈øheets as that of Comets; and I cau≈øed in Autumn la≈øt, a new Edition to be made of the latter, on purpo≈øe to joyn it to this new Treati≈øe. But having ≈øometimes e≈øpecially in November 27th 1689, publickly confuted, in the Pulpit, the common Opinion; two days after, a Book was delivered me coming from England, where it was Printed, and Intituled, A Relation of the di≈øcovery of ≈øome Witchcrafts, in which very many particular things were ≈øaid to be contained. I thought by the reading of it, that it would quickly be tran≈ølated into our Tongue, to ≈øatisfy the curio≈øity of People. And
as my Opinions are directly oppo≈øite to what is laid down in that Book, I perceived it might breed prejudices again≈øt what I had ≈øo freely and openly declared in the Pulpit, and ≈øuch as I ≈øhould ≈øcarce be able to de≈øtroy afterwards; becau≈øe of the apparent ≈øtrength of the proofs brought forth in that work; for that Rea≈øon, I rather cho≈øe to tran≈ølate it my ≈øelf, than to leave it to another, adding ≈øome remarks, fit to open the Eyes of the Reader, by di≈øcovering the grounds on which ≈øuch relations are laid; that he might not thereby be in danger of being confirmed in the vulgar error; but that he might make u≈øe of the≈øe Annotations, until my compleat work concerning Magick and Witchcraft were printed, which was to be, according to my expectation, in the following Months. But be≈øides the inconveniences of the Weather in Winter, and the di≈øtance of the place where it was printed, viz. beyond Sea, together with the Book of Mr. Ain≈øworth, for which the ≈øame pre≈øs was imployed, cau≈øed a great deal of delay; during that time, I had lea≈øure to review my Treati≈øe of Magick, and to increa≈øe it ≈øo, that it became much larger, than that of Comets; be≈øides, the tran≈ølation and publi≈øhing of the Engli≈øh Book, procured me letters from ≈øeveral learned Men, and afforded matter to many Conver≈øations, as well with tho≈øe that were of my Opinion, as with tho≈øe that were contrary to it. Thus having had occa≈øion to ≈øearch deeper into this ≈øubject, to give new explanations of my Opinion, and to confirm them by new Rea≈øons; this works went on always increa≈øing, and the order and di≈øpo≈øition of it was ≈øo far changed; that from a ≈ømall Book it became a bulky Volumn. In the mean while, the impre≈ø≈øion that was made at Leeuwarden, ≈øeem'd to me, not only ≈ølow, but al≈øo very inconvenient, by Rea≈øon of the faults of the Pre≈øs; of which I could not ≈øo well purge
it, but that the fir≈øt Book is ≈øtill full of them. I re≈øolved therefore to print the Second part at Am≈øterdam. Some time pa≈øt, before that could ≈øucceed; however, without any inconveniency to the Book, for the Rea≈øons ju≈øt now alledged. The cau≈øe of this ≈ølowne≈øs being unknown, ≈øome were not afraid to publi≈øh, that I had lo≈øt courage, and dur≈øt not attempt to enter the Li≈øts with the Devil: tho≈øe Rumours, the que≈øtions that were continually put to me, and the writings that were ≈øent me, when my Treati≈øe was ju≈øt coming out, obliged me to publi≈øh the two fir≈øt Books, in which I mentioned ≈øomething of the two la≈øt, that they might the better plea≈øe the Reader. Be≈øides I hop'd, God would give me the Grace to make an end of the whole work, and to add what the Readers might think wanting or convenient. But it could not be performed before the end of 1690, as I intended it, and the Book≈øeller de≈øired it, for his own Intere≈øt; for the Fro≈øt that came in on a ≈øudden, retarded the execution of it; it being not po≈ø≈øible to ≈øend the Three la≈øt ≈øheets to Leeuwarden, and to get from thence tho≈øe that were printed there, by rea≈øon of the Ice that put a ≈øtop to Navigation; ≈øo that I could have no Copy to pre≈øent my friends with. I hoped ≈øtill however that it might be done, but the Fro≈øt continuing, my Book thus imperfect was publi≈øht, and came without my knowledge, into the hands of many People in Friezeland. It was therefore only ≈øeen by piece-meal and without coherency, which gave occa≈øion to ≈øome of the Readers, and others that had heard of it, publickly to pa≈øs heard, judgments upon it; even ≈øome intended, as I am informed, to make me explain my ≈øelf more preci≈øely, had I not done it in the Book it ≈øelf. For at la≈øt, when they read it intire and in order, they all agreed, I had given all the explications that,
could be wi≈øht, either as to the Rea≈øons that had moved me to write it; or as to to the ≈øcope I propo≈øed to my ≈øelf, which appears in the Preface, and in the fir≈øt Chapter of the Book; or as to the nece≈ø≈øity and u≈øefulne≈øs of its publi≈øhing, which I have ≈øhown in the ≈øame Chapter, and the la≈øt but one. They were ju≈øt the places that were wanting, for which Rea≈øon I wrote to the Book≈øeller of Leeuwarden, and forbad him to give out any Copy of this Book, until the whole was compleat. Be≈øides, during the Fro≈øt, I had time to add two Chapters to the end of the Second Book, and to enlarge the Preface, in order to inform the Reader of my Opinions, and the purity of my intentions, which has not proved altogether fruitle≈øs; for I have heard that mo≈øt of tho≈øe, that have read the Preface and the work afterwards, have been ≈øatisfied, as they have told one another and my ≈øelf; whereas tho≈øe that had taken upon them to critici≈øe it, had read but ≈øome loo≈øe parcels of it, or had not read it at all, or perhaps had not ≈øo much as vouch≈øafed to read it.

Things remained a while in that ≈øtate, every one enquiring after the Rea≈øon that hindered the publi≈øhing of my Book, and how it happened that I had none my ≈øelf, ≈øince it had been ≈øold in Friezeland for ≈øome time. The Thaw came at la≈øt, and many Per≈øons arrived with News of the Edition of my Book, but brought no Copies along with them, ≈øave ≈øome privately, and as ≈øtolen goods; then every body wondered, a Book ≈øhould have been put out, in the≈øe Provinces, and it ≈øhould not be found in Holland, where the Author lived; and not only my Brother Pa≈øtors ≈øhould not have ≈øeen it, but I ≈øhould ≈øay, I had none my ≈øelf to pre≈øent them with. At la≈øt I received 26 Copies of it from Leeuwarden, but had ≈øcarce one for my ≈øelf; my friends came and took them away them≈øelves, as they were
≈øowed; and mo≈øt of tho≈øe that ask'd for them, could not get 'em, unle≈øs they came ju≈øt when they were ≈øow'd up. So greedy Men are of Novelties, e≈øpecially when they can hardly get 'em.

Nitimur in vetitum, ≈øemper cupimu≈ø
que negata.
So much we love, and ≈øeek, what is deny'd.
div.p:
However it be, the Book could not be expo≈øed to Sale before the 11th day of March. A long time after I had ≈øent the la≈øt Sheets to Leeuwarden, to Mr. Nauta, Book≈øeller, who had had the Book perfect in his hands for a long time, A Book≈øeller ask'd 50 Copies from him, and thought to receive them ≈øpeedily, but had none ≈øent to him. In the mean while, I find my ≈øelf much perplext. I was de≈øir'd, during two Months, by my be≈øt Friends, to communicate this Work to them, which they had never ≈øeen, and had heard commended; for this rea≈øon I wrote to Mr. Nauta, I would take all the Copies upon me; and pay them at ≈øuch rea≈øonable rates, that he would be ≈øatisfied with it; he need but to ≈øend them to me without delay, with the fir≈øt Ve≈ø≈øel. Then I thought to con≈øult with my Friends, whether I ≈øhould ≈øell the two Fir≈øt Books, that had already appear'd imperfect in Frie≈øland, and el≈øewhere, or whether I ≈øhould keep them until the whole Work was fini≈øhed. The fir≈øt ≈øeem'd to be the be≈øt Advice, to avoid the ≈øu≈øpicion, that I dur≈øt not publi≈øh my Book, or that I was forced to ≈øuppre≈øs it, becau≈øe of many things that were ≈øpread abroad to di≈øcredit it; however, the la≈øt coun≈øel ≈øuited better with my inclinations. I conceived that a Work that was at fir≈øt but a ≈ømal Treati≈øe, th√¥ it had ≈øince been much enlarged, would be more favourably received, and prove of greater u≈øe, if it were given compleat at the ≈øame time to the publick; that the de≈øign and cohering of it
might be better ≈øeen, its Doctrines be more ea≈øily comprehended, and the happy effects it was able to produce be more plainly perceived, which is chiefly done by the la≈øt Part. But as the cau≈øes before alledged, had already once ≈ømother'd this de≈øign, ≈øo they did it again this time; for perceiving by the Letters of Mr. Nauta, it was impo≈ø≈øible to agree with him, as to the price, and that it was unlikely he ≈øhould ever do it, I was at la≈øt forced to give up the Book to him, that I might (with the Ble≈ø≈øing of God,) pur≈øue my de≈øign. So having altogether broken with that Book≈øeller, I have agreed ≈øome Months ≈øince, with another of this City, Mr. Daniel Vanden Dalen, to put divers Pre≈ø≈øes going upon it, and re-print the whole Work, revi≈øed and corrected, that I might ince≈ø≈øantly publi≈øh all the four Parts, one after another, in the form in wnich the Reader now ≈øees them. For as to the 750 Copies which Mr. Nauta had printed of the two Fir≈øt Books, and are mo≈øt of them ≈øtill upon his hands; they being an incon≈øiderble number, that could not go very far, and the ha≈øty Edition of the Book, being as yet imperfect, ≈øeem'd to give room to a new Edition, that the Pulick might be more ≈øpeedily ≈øatisfied. I therefore here pre≈øent the Reader with the Fir≈øt Book, enlarged with a new Chapter, that I thought nece≈ø≈øary to add at the end. I hope, with the Ble≈ø≈øing of God, that the three others ≈øhall ≈øucce≈ø≈øively appear every Month; and I per≈øuade my ≈øelf, that the reading of the Fir≈øt Parts, will excite ≈øome Curio≈øities for the later; and that altogether may invite the Reader to a ≈øerious con≈øideration upon the Contents, and capacitate him to judge more ≈øoundly of this matter than he did, while this Treati≈øe appear'd but in part, and confu≈øedly. This is what I had to ≈øay, as to this Edition, that was made in ≈øuch an
extraordinary manner, and publi≈øh'd without my knowledge.

I come now to treat of my ≈øcope, and what has obliged me to embrace the Opinions I a≈ø≈øert in this Book. In all my Studies I was always inclin'd, not to re≈øt upon probabilities, but to ≈øearch into the whole matter, and to get a clear and di≈øtinct knowledge of what I ≈øhould know. Be≈øides, many ≈øtrange things had happen'd to me in Frie≈øland, upon the fir≈øt Writings I had publi≈øh'd, and experience had a≈ø≈øured me, how little one ought to relye upon the Judgment of Men, e≈øpecially when what they are accu≈øtomed to teach, is call'd in que≈øtion. For is it not wonderful that my Book upon the Catechi≈øm ≈øhould have been unanimou≈øly condemn'd in Frie≈øland, th√¥ among≈øt above 200 Mini≈øters, who con≈øented to that Judgment, none could alledge ≈øo much as one ≈øolid Rea≈øon again≈øt it; and that afterwards it ≈øhould have been twice unanimou≈øly approved of, without any change, as to the Doctrine and the controverted Points, having been made in it? This has confirm'd me in this per≈øua≈øion, that a true Chri≈øtian, e≈øpecially a Doctor of Divinity, ought groundedly him≈øelf to enquire into things, without re≈øting upon the Judgment of others, that he may obtain a full certainty of the object of his Faith, and the matter of his Precepts. Since that time I re≈øolved only to follow the Holy Scripture, and Rea≈øon, in ≈øuch things in which it ought to ≈øupply the ≈øilence of the Sacred Writings, and to a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf by tho≈øe two means, of what I was to believe, and to teach others, without taking the trouble of following the ≈øteps of other Men; never putting Pen to Paper, but to write upon tho≈øe ≈øubjects, the importance of which I was convinced of, or had not been ≈øufficiently explain'd and examin'd. I have therefore endeavour'd to
free, as much as po≈ø≈øible, our Holy Doctrine from ≈øuch errors, as mo≈øt Men appear to me to be taken with; or at lea≈øt, to ≈øet in order, ≈øuch things whic I conceive to be confu≈øed; Whether I was the fir≈øt that di≈øcover'd it, or whether I needed only to promote what had been begun by others. There are other Rea≈øons that have engag'd me in that de≈øign. For having ≈øworn in the Univer≈øity of Franeker, faithfully to maintain the pure Doctrine of the Reformed Church, and defend it both by words and writings, in all nece≈ø≈øary occa≈øions; I may now ≈øay with Prudentius, and as it becomes my Age.

l.hi: Annum cardo rotat, dum fruimur ≈øole volubili.
Quid nos utile tanti ≈øpatio tempor is egimus?
Two ≈øcore years are pa≈øt, the third is running,
Since the Sun's light is upon me ≈øhining;
Old Age comes on, What have I been doing?

div.p:
But it would be too long to enter into particulars, I ≈øhall only ≈øay that I intend to imploy the re≈øt of my Life; fir≈øt, to the Duties and Functions of my Mini≈øtry, which the circum≈øtances and largene≈øs of this Town make more painful than in other places; and than to make an exact enquiry after whatever is fal≈øly believed in the World, and the Erroneous Opinions that are entertained without any other ground then that they are every day told and heard of. For my mo≈øt earne≈øt de≈øire is, to ≈øee Men become more wi≈øe and hone≈øt than they are, th ‚Ä¢ ugh very few ≈øincerely intend it, or at lea≈øt do their Endeavours to attain to that perfection; mo≈øt ‚Ä¢ art choo≈øing rather to believe, and to do, what is
commonly believed and done, than to be at the trouble of freeing them≈øelves from Errors. In the mean while; what pa≈øt in Frei≈øeland, when my fir≈øt Book appear'd abroad, ought to have taught me, how dangerous it is to write upon ≈øuch matters; there being neither favour nor profit to be expected for ≈øuch Authors as rid them≈øelves from all prejudices; and having no regard, either for the Credit or Power of the Faction, who≈øe Sentiments they reject, re≈øolve to follow only what the Scripture teaches, or Rea≈øon dictates to them, and to embrace no Opinions, but ≈øuch as are founded upon tho≈øe two Grounds. Perhaps after my Death the u≈øefulne≈øs of this Undertaking will be known; and tho' I dare not hope that it will be done in my Life time; yet I publi≈øh it my ≈øelf, to learn the Judgment of the publick, to defend my Works, and to enlarge or correct them, according to the Light I may acquire a-new, or that ≈øhall be communicated to me. For methinks, I am more able to do it, and to be Interpreter of my own Words and Thoughts, than tho≈øe that may afterwards adopt my Opinions, and have ≈øome regard for my Memory.

As for the re≈øt, though my intention and ≈øcope may be plainly perceived by the fir≈øt Chapter; yet I ≈øhall add, that no Men in the World are more remote from any Athei≈øtical Sentiments, more per≈øuaded of the Divinity of the Holy Writ, and more di≈øpo≈øed to render to God the Honour and Reverence due to him, than tho≈øe, who as I am, are oppo≈øed to the common Opinion of the Power and Vertue of the Devil. Whoever ≈øhall read this Book with attention, and without partiality, will undoubtedly be per≈øuaded of it; at lea≈øt, I mean, that there is enough to ≈øatisfie tho≈øe that ab≈øolutely reject the Principles of De≈øcartes, concerning the u≈øe of Rea≈øon; and at the ≈øame time ≈øuch as give too
much extent to tho≈øe Principles; and that tho≈øe two Parties will equally approve of the manner in which I di≈øtingui≈øh Spirits from Bodies, and both from God, without however e≈øtabli≈øhing any thing as to their Operations that cannot be proved by plain and nece≈ø≈øary Inferences. So that I powerfully confute the fooli≈øh Errors of Spino≈øa, who confounds God and Nature together. I believe not that there is any Author, who has more ≈øolidly e≈øtabli≈øht the infinite difference that there is betwixt God and the Creature, and the incon≈øi≈øtency of the Properties of Bodies with tho≈øe of Spirits, then I do here; as was nece≈ø≈øary to be done to lay a firm foundation to this work, that is wholly grounded upon that Principle, at lea≈øt as to tho≈øe things that are the object of the Light of Rea≈øon. Be≈øides, I have this internal ≈øatisfaction, that I confirm by an evident proof the Doctrine of our Churches, that tends ≈øtill to dimini≈øh the Honour paid to the Creatures, in order to increa≈øe that which is due to God. This Book witne≈ø≈øes for me that I ≈øet up the Glory, Power, and Wi≈ødom of the Soveraign Ma≈øter of the World, as much as they had been taken from him, to be communicated to the Devil. I bani≈øh from the Univer≈øe that abominable Creature to chain him in Hell, that Je≈øus, our Supream King, may more powerfully and ≈øecurely reign. Though his Empire that is to endure to the la≈øt day, is likewi≈øe to ≈øub≈øi≈øt in the mid≈øt of his Enemies, that are here upon Earth, that is among≈øt the People of the Devil, or ≈øuch in whom Sin keeps ≈øtill imprinted the Image of the Devil. With that intention I am not afraid to explain in my ≈øecond Book ≈øeveral pa≈ø≈øages of the H ‚Ä¢ ly Writ in another Sen≈øe, than they have hitherto been taken: But if by the publi≈øhing of ≈øuch new explications, one aimed not at the Honour of God, and only ≈øought to impair and ≈øtain the Reputation
of tho≈øe that are of contrary Opinion, he ≈øhould take more to heart his own Credit than the Glory of God. As for me, who have formerly been in Opinions contrary to tho≈øe I ≈øpeak of, and which are ≈øtill held by the greate≈øt part of Men; I willingly propo≈øe my pre≈øent Sentiments, but only with a ≈øincere intention of glorifying God, and bringing Truth to Light. I think not therefore to be blameable for not ≈øticking to the vulgar explications, I had formerly follow'd, and preferring before them tho≈øe of ≈øome Per≈øons, who have not done what I now ≈øuppo≈øe to be obliged to do. Yet I am not alone in the≈øe Opinions; for they are agreeable to tho≈øe of many others, ≈øome of whom have appear'd in the World even after me. And though they have produced and a≈ø≈øerted in Writing tho≈øe new Interpretations and Tran≈ølations of the Bible, but by way of Exerci≈øes, and to ≈øhew what ≈øubtilty and parts they acquir'd in their Youth, by the alteration of ≈øuch Expo≈øitions as had learned Men for their Authors; yet as for me, methinks that in my old Age I ought to make u≈øe of my own Eyes, and to ≈øpeak with liberty. As for the re≈øt, if there are among≈øt us, who, to multiply the proofs of our Opinion, and dimini≈øh tho≈øe of the contrary Party, ≈øtretch the Holy Scripture too far, that's their own fault, and not ours. We pre≈øume to be provided with better Arms, to dcfend the Fundamental Truths of the Church. But it mu≈øt be ob≈øerv'd as a general fault, that the reading of the Bible is undertaken with a Mind full of its own prejudices, or tho≈øe of its Ma≈øters; and that 'tis generally explain'd according to tho≈øe Notions, without any other Rea≈øon or Ground but that of chance, or of ≈øome ca≈øes that have occa≈øioned the choice of ≈øuch parts as is then followed. I take the Vail from tho≈øe prejudices, and ≈øhew what Method is to be ob≈øerv'd to undertake the explication
of the Holy Writ, without any prevention. For I hold it for certain, that none would have explain'd ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øages of the ≈øaid Writings as I here treat of, ≈øo as they are u≈øually Interpreted, had he not been imbu'd with a prejudice of the great and extraordinary power of the Devil, or had he not intended to confute ≈øome particular Errors. I have already proofs of it; for ≈øeveral learn'd and pious Per≈øons have very much approv'd of my Method of examining tho≈øe Texts, and the ≈øearching into their Sen≈øe; and having treated in my Sermons of the chief Points of this ≈øubject, I am inform'd that many People ≈øhew a great impatience to ≈øee my Writings upon it. I have frequently been in Conver≈øations, where the mo≈øt important matters, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that are contain'd in my ≈øecond and third Book, were di≈øcu≈øs'd, and they ≈øeem'd partly ≈øatisfi'd with my Explications, and in hopes of being fully convinc'd by tho≈øe they expected from me: I refer my ≈øelf to their Judgment, to know whether their expectation has been deceived or fulfill'd; being per≈øuaded that if they do not agree to ≈øome particulars, yet they will approve of my intention, and contribute their utmo≈øt, that the greate≈øt part of the things I propo≈øe may be receiv'd and reli≈øh'd. If I were ≈øo capricious as to di≈øturb my ≈øelf on account of what may be ≈øaid and believ'd of my de≈øign, and to make more of the number than of the quality of the Readers, I ≈øhould undergo great hard≈øhips: For I doubt not but mo≈øt Men, having little meditated upon this matter, will think that I commit a great Sin in publi≈øhing this Treati≈øe; not however in reference to the fir≈øt Book, where I only relate the various Opinions of the ≈øeveral Nations from very credible Authors, without declaring my own Sentiments, or confuting tho≈øe of others. Neither do I believe that the two la≈øt parts will be found fault with, but only
the ≈øecond, where the mo≈øt important Doctrines are di≈øcu≈øs'd, will rai≈øe ≈øome difficulty, and not plea≈øe every one. It will e≈øpecially ≈øeem ≈øtrange, that I make ≈øo little account of the Devil, and endue him with ≈øuch an incon≈øiderable Power. For matters have been carried ≈øo far, that ≈øome Men think it a piece of Piety to a≈øcribe many Miraculous Effects to the Devil, and to hold for ra≈øh and impious People tho≈øe that cannot believe, that he does what is te≈øtified by thou≈øands of Witne≈ø≈øes. If any contradict their Opinion, he is taken for an Athei≈øt, that is, ≈øuch as denies the Exi≈øtence of one God, tho' he is only guilty of the Crime of not believing two, viz. a good and a bad. But tho≈øe that are of your Mind, de≈øerve them≈øelves to be called Dithei≈øts, or ≈øuch as believe two Gods: [as the Arians] got the name of Trithei≈øts, becau≈øe they believ'd three Gods [of different nature.] If any de≈øire to put a new name upon me, in reference to my Opinions, I willingly yield to that of Monothei≈øts, that is, who believes but one God, and one Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt; upon who≈øe words I wholly tru≈øt, where he ≈øays, Fear not them who kills the Body, but fear him who can de≈øtroy both Soul and Body, Mat. 10.28. I fear him much le≈øs, who has no power either over Body or Soul, and trouble not more my head with the judgments of tho≈øe Judg 6.13. In the name of the Lord the God of ho≈øts, I encounter that Goliah; let's ≈øee who will lend him a helping hand! It any think to have rea≈øons ≈øo ≈øtrong as to confute my Opinion, I de≈øire him to propound them, with as much ≈øoftne≈øs, as I am favourably di≈øpos'd to hear them; but at the ≈øame time I intreat him to ≈øpare to him≈øelf and to me, an unprofitable labour, and to wait till he have read the whole work, from the beginning to the
end, before he makes his objections. By tho≈øe means he ≈øhall perfectly know whether tho≈øe particular and private places which he has read, and with which he had not been ≈øatisfyd, have afterwards been explain'd, and made worthier of his approbation, by the concatenation of the whole Treati≈øe, and the rea≈øons contain'd in it: For it would be trouble≈øome to view and examine again, all the places of my An≈øwers I would quote. So that it mu≈øt not be take ill, if I give none to tho≈øe that ≈øhall follow another Method, and would make me wa≈øte with them the time that can be better ≈øpent.

I may a≈ø≈øure here, that nothing has ben taken off, from what is contain'd in the Edition of Leeuwarden. It's true, ≈øomething has been added in ≈øome places, for the better under≈øtanding of the matter; as may be ≈øeen at the end of the Original, where a whole Chapter has been added, in which, the la≈øt Chapter of the Frie≈øland Edition is compriz'd. It ≈øeeming to me it was convenient to inlarge a little more in that place; more exactly to ≈øhew the u≈øe and de≈øign of the ≈øearch I make in this Fir≈øt Book, after the various opinions of all Nations, and better to di≈øcover the foundation of tho≈øe prejudices, that have ≈øo long kept us from examining the true ≈øtate of the matters contain'd in the following Parts. Many other additions have been made to the French Tran≈ølation, which it is not needful preci≈øely to mark. The curious may compare the Tran≈ølation with the Original.

div.head: AN ABRIDGMENT OF THE Whole Work; What hath been the de≈øign of the Author, and what is his Method.
div.p:
AS the two fir≈øt Books of this work that I publi≈øhed at fir≈øt, have been differently received, for Rea≈øons alledg'd in the Preface; It will not be ami≈øs to repre≈øent to the Reader, what has been properly my de≈øign in the≈øe four Books, that I have Intituled, The World Bewitch'd, nor to ≈øhew what foundation I built upon, and what way I take to find out the truth. For alth√¥ I expre≈øs my ≈øelf clearly enough in the beginning of the work, and in the Preface to the fir≈øt part; I know neverthele≈øs, that is not ≈øufficient to de≈øtroy the prejudice wherewith, the learned them≈øelves appear more bia≈ø≈øed than the Vulgar; which I ≈øhould never have thought; but it ≈øeems at pre≈øent, I have found out the Rea≈øon,
which is, that the mo≈øt part of tho≈øe which do not put them≈øelves to the trouble to pa≈øs through all the Degrees of the Schools, a≈øpire to Sciences and ≈øublime knowledge, but for their particular plea≈øure; they are the People that love liberty, and to whom it matters not, who is the Ma≈øter that in≈øtructs them, provided that they may learn ≈øomething; or if they are greedy of rarities, they have not ≈øo much re≈øpect to the mode, nor to that which is New or Antient, as to the beauty of the matter, and to that of the work. On the contrary, it is with tho≈øe who pa≈øs through the Schools, as with tho≈øe who live in Shops, where every one has his way, every Ma≈øter has his Method in the work he makes. In one Town they make the ≈øame things after one fa≈øhion, and in another, after another; when one is taken up with the mode, he often rejects what is plea≈øing, without any other Rea≈øon, then becau≈øe it is not as commonly u≈øed in the World. And we have a ≈øtrangene≈øs for all novelties, ≈øo long as they have not the common vogue; alth√¥ otherwi≈øe, we might approve them, and have them cheap enough; but as ≈øoon as Cu≈øtom has introduced them, one begins to ≈øeek them out, and to be di≈øgu≈øted at the former. Sciences are ≈øubject to the ≈øame inconveniencies. Tho≈øe that we ≈øend to the Schools, continue in the road which has been mark'd out to them for their exerci≈øes; they endeavour to form them≈øelves upon the model of tho≈øe which have mo≈øt reputation, or of tho≈øe who are the neare≈øt to their fir≈øt prejudices; ≈øo this is di≈øapproving the part they have taken, not to be apt to take any, and to pre≈øerve our own liberty, and thus we expo≈øe our ≈øelves very much; but one runs a greater risk, if willing to a≈øcend higher, and ≈øearch things in their Fountains, it happens at la≈øt, that we find our ≈øelves out of the ordinary Road, and that we are
obliged to take another. Hinc illae lachymae, From thence proceeds all di≈øorders.

The common Opinion of the Devil, of his knowledge, power, and Operations, and of People which are accu≈øed of having commerce with him, began by little and little to become very ≈øu≈øpitious by the help of natural light, which I have common with others, which was ≈øtrengthened and purified by the Scripture; ≈øo after I had well examined it, I was in doubt, whether I ought to maintain it any longer, or abandon it, not only by Rea≈øon of the truth, but al≈øo becau≈øe of the Piety which it ≈øeem'd to contradict: My Con≈øcience it ≈øelf compel'd me to it; for I was obliged to an≈øwer tho≈øe that ask'd me, and to take care of my Conduct, becau≈øe of the di≈øpo≈øition I ≈øaw the People in. It was the Duty of my charge, and every Day occa≈øions offer'd them≈øelves, my pain increa≈øed every moment, by the continual nece≈ø≈øity I found my ≈øelf in, to ≈øpeak and act as others did, or to oppo≈øe the publick with words or actions, which agree not with my Character, which is to be complai≈øant, and to agree with all the World, as much as is po≈ø≈øible. Be≈øides I found not as yet foundation enough to act after an other manner, which made me at fir≈øt re≈øolve to make an exact ≈øearch, after the Original of this common and general Opinion, to know whether it was founded upon truth. But becau≈øe I make this examination, √† priore and not √† po≈øteriore, as they in the Schools, I have propo≈øed the ≈øtate of the Que≈øtion, but at the end of the fir≈øt Book; where I di≈øcovered in the 22th Chapter, how many of the Opinions, which I have related; (which are all tho≈øe that ever were in the World upon this ≈øubject,) The Prote≈øtants have at la≈øt got together, and formed tho≈øe which they retain to this Day. In the 23th Chapter I compare them with the Opinions

div.head: An Abridgement of the Fir≈øt Book.
div.p:
IN the Fir≈øt Book I run over all the World, to find whence this Opinion has its Original. And for this purpo≈øe I have omitted neither time nor place. I ob≈øerve that the ≈øubject ought to be examin'd in two Re≈øpects; In re≈øpect of the Devil, to find what is his Knowledge and Power; and in re≈øpect of Men, to ≈øee what they learn and effect by his means. But becau≈øe the≈øe things are preternatural, or are ≈øo thought to be, and that by con≈øequence they are known only to God, I have judg'd it nece≈ø≈øary, to know what are the Opinions of Men concerning the Divinity, and Spirits in general, either good or bad, and of human Souls ≈øeparated from their Bodies by death, which are al≈øo Spirits: I make a ≈øearch of all the≈øe things, Fir≈øt, in the Books of the Ancients, and afterwards in the Moderns of all Religions, and among≈øt all Nations, di≈øtingui≈øhing them into Pagans, Jews, Mahometans and Chri≈øtians, in reference to the pre≈øent ≈øtate of the World. I begin with the Ancient Pagans, which are for the mo≈øt part Greeks or Romans, known to us by Greek and Latin Books they have le≈øt us: which I treat of in the 2d, 3d, and 4th Chapters; for there are very few Hi≈øtories of other Countries and other People, which are come to our knowledge. There you ≈øee what they believe touching Gods, and Spirits, which are neither Gods nor human
Souls; and as to the e≈øtate of the Souls after death: You read there al≈øo what means they u≈øed to attain that knowledge, and to operate things beyond the power of Nature, by the means of tho≈øe Spirits, ≈øuch as they believe them to be. I come afterwards down to our time, and examine all the Pagans in the World; fir≈øt in Europe, in the 6th, Chapter; after in A≈øin, in the 7th and 8th Chapters; then in Africa, in the 9th Chapter and at la≈øt in America, in the 10th Chapter; which gives me occa≈øion to demon≈øtrate in the 11th Chapter, that the Pagans as well Ancient as Modern, have had a notion of the Divinity, that is all powerful, but that they have a≈ø≈øociated to him, inferior Gods. That the Greeks have often called them Demons, and likewi≈øe Gods, as mo≈øt of the Pagans do at this Day; which Demons, or inferior Gods, have every one their ≈øhare in the Admini≈øtration of the Univer≈øe, directing the affairs of Men under the name and Authority of the Soveraign God, and being as Mediators between him and Men: They conver≈øe al≈øo with the≈øe la≈øt, who can, by their means, know and effect things above the power of Nature. This knowledge gives ≈øome the name of Diviners, and the≈øe Operations cau≈øe others to be called Magicians and Sorcerers; in con≈øequence of which, all the effects that we cannot give a Rea≈øon for, or find the cau≈øe of, are attributed to the≈øe Demons or inferior Gods,

The Souls of the Dead are al≈øo ranked among≈øt the Demons, and according as they have behav'd them≈øelves well or ill upon Earth, the good or evil which happens to Men, is attributed to one or the other. It is that which has given occa≈øion to di≈øtingui≈øh the inferior Gods, into good and bad.

After the Pagans, which know neither the true God nor Religion; I treat of tho≈øe which have the Holy
Scripture among them, of whom the fir≈øt are the Jews, having known God a long time before all the others, and received his Word in the writings of the Old Te≈øtament, where they have learned, that in truth the Souls of Men are immortal, but that there are no Demons, or inferior Gods, ≈øuch as the Pagans fancy. That God alone by him≈øelf rules the Univer≈øe, and that none can have knowledge or produce effects beyond the ≈øtrength of nature, for that belongs to God only. I ob≈øerve farther, that Judai≈øm in the ≈øtate into which it is in≈øen≈øibly fallen, ≈øince the coming of Chri≈øt, and as it is at this Day, is very much mixed with Pagani≈øm, or at lea≈øt very much infected with it; whence proceeds the practices of Divinations and Sorcery, that are in fa≈øhion among≈øt the Jews, Chapter the 13th.

After that I repre≈øent, that the Mahometans who acknowledge but one God, and created Angels good and bad, and the Devil as chief of them. I require proofs of this The≈øis; and becau≈øe this demand is unthought of and extraordinary, and upon which by con≈øequence every one is not prepared, my demand is taken for a Negative. But before I lay my ≈øelf that foundation, which ordinarily is not call'd in Que≈øtion, I examine fir≈øt the Grounds upon which the≈øe People them≈øelves re≈øt their Opinion, or upon what they ought to e≈øtabli≈øh it, according to the Idea they have of Spirits; I ≈øay, according to the Idea they have of Spirits; for, whether according to the Principles of De≈øcartes, they di≈øtingui≈øh them from Bodies the more neatly then other Philo≈øophers do, or that they gro≈øly attribute ≈øomething corporeal to them. The≈øe two Idea's neverthele≈øs proceed as yet equally, from that they conceive the Operations of Spirits upon external Objects, whether Bodies, or other Spirits, as a property of the Spiritual Nature; and from that they include them in the notion they have of that Nature: and it is by this means, that in≈øtead of con≈øidering the Body as an in≈øtrument which is nece≈ø≈øary to the Operation of Spirits, or at lea≈øt proper to them, they look upon it as an ob≈øtacle to the liberty and virtue of the Operations of a Spiritual Nature, Thence comes that every Body crys ‚Ä¢ ut ≈øo differrently again≈øt me, ≈øome ≈øaying, that De≈øcartes's Philo≈øophy has ≈øpoiled me, and that is the fruit which is reaped by his Followers, de≈øiring to ca≈øt upon it the Errors that they accu≈øe me of: Others, who being in the ≈øame prejudice, yet are Carte≈øians at bottom, give out, that I under≈øtand not the Philo≈øophy of De≈øcartes: But whatever my Learning and Experience be, I intend to have to do but with ≈øen≈øible People, and leave the others at full liberty to pa≈øs upon the Doctrine I teach, ≈øuch Judgments as they plea≈øe.

div.head: An Abridgment of the Second Book.
div.p: As to what concerns my Second Book ≈øee the method I have taken. I begin with the di≈øtinction of names, in fixing at fir≈øt, what mu≈øt be under≈øtood by a Body, and a Spirit, to avoid all equivocations: which I have done in the fir≈øt Chapter. I ≈øpeak of God in the Second, proveing not only, that the ≈øupream Being which I denote by that word, is only one, but al≈øo that there is not the lea≈øt communion between it and created things; directly confuting the Opinion of Spino≈øa, upon this ≈øubject; which I pretend to do with more force and evidence than any hitherto, becau≈øe ordinarily they undertake to demon≈øtrate by the mo≈øt perfect and incomprehen≈øible E≈ø≈øence of God, the manner and virtue of the Operations of created Spirits, which I ab≈øolutely reject, as a way which is u≈øed to lead us into error. By con≈øequence I cannot admit the arguments which are taken from the nature of God, to demon≈øtrate in what manner acts a Spirit which is his creature, and has nothing common with him, but the name. After, in the Third Chapter, I prove by arguments drawn from the ≈øovereign perfection of God, that there are none of tho≈øe ≈øorts of Spirits, that the Pagans e≈øteem to be Gods and ediators of Men towards the ≈øupream Divinity; becau≈øe the Rea≈øons of tho≈øe that ground that belief upon the perfection of God, are directly oppo≈øite to this perfection.

We then having taken off the imaginary Spirits, I come to tho≈øe which we certainly know to exi≈øt; that is, our Souls that are a part of our ≈øelves, and which by con≈øequence, are better known to us by
our own experience; this is treated of in the fourth Chapter, where I prove as much as is po≈ø≈øible their immortality, and that they ≈øub≈øi≈øt even out of the body: I employ for this purpo≈øe, Rea≈øon and Scripture, becau≈øe they are two ways, that equally conduct us to the knowledge of the Soul; the fir≈øt by experience and by our own Con≈øciou≈øne≈øs; and the ≈øecond by the particular in≈øtructions God gives us of the e≈øtate of the Soul, after this life: but I quote not the Scripture in this part of my Treati≈øe, where I examine but what concerns nature only. Neither do I judge it nece≈ø≈øary to do it afterwards, becau≈øe it is a point that a Chri≈øtian looks upon, as already ≈øufficiently e≈øtabli≈øhed; and ≈øuppo≈øes it when he will engage in a di≈øpute upon this ≈øubject. Be≈øides, I reject as ≈øuper≈øtitions and fables, whatever, proceeds from the invention of Men, e≈øpecially of the Heathens, which is the matter of the fifth Chapter. So we come to know with certainty, that ≈øuch a Spirit, that is the Soul which truly exi≈øts, has a body with which it lives, and without which it may ≈øtill live, and to reject all the other Spirits, of whom the greate≈øt part of the World fal≈øly believe the exi≈øtence. But be≈øides tho≈øe Pagan Opinions, we hear every day mention made of Angels, not only by Chri≈øtians, but al≈øo by Jews and Mahometans. The Que≈øtion is, Whether Rea≈øon alone is capable to di≈øcover to us, that there are ≈øuch Spirits, de≈øtitute of a proper and peculiar body? Upon this point I ≈øhew in the ≈øixth Chapter, that our under≈øtanding without the help of Scripture, cannot penetrate farther, than to comprehend, that it is po≈ø≈øible, but not certain, that there are Spirits. For this Rea≈øon, I have not judg'd it nece≈ø≈øary, to examine the Operations of the≈øe Spirits upon bodies, or upon the other Spirits; becau≈øe it ≈øeems to me ridiculous to trouble ones ≈øelf with the examination of the
Operations of Creatures, the exi≈øtence of which is not e≈øtabli≈øhed as certain. And therefore I have ≈øpoken in the fir≈øt Edition, but by the way in ver≈øe, which is at pre≈øent, the ≈øeventh Sect. of the ≈øixth Chapter. And therefore it is manife≈øt how wrongfully many People would per≈øwade them≈øelves, that I have compo≈øed my work only, To deny the Operations of Spirits upon bodies, and upon other Spirits. And be≈øides, that I ground upon this negative, all my explications of the pa≈ø≈øages of Scripture; but that I may avoid this per≈øecution for the future, I thought fit to in≈øert in the new Edition that is made of my Book, a whole Chapter between the ≈øixth and ≈øeventh, ≈øo that this new Chapter is at pre≈øent the ≈øeventh, and the ≈øeventh is the eight, and ≈øo of the others following. There I pretend clearly to ≈øhew, that the proofs related upon that ≈øubject, ≈øtrike not at all to the end, and cannot be con≈øidered as true proofs; which I mean as to what concerns nature, and as to what Human Rea≈øon may conceive of it ≈øelf, as de≈øtitute of help from the word of God.

After that I come to the word of God, and then I employ Rea≈øon no more, but keep to the Scripture only and I ≈øearch in it, what it will teach me, touching Spirits, which is now the que≈øtion; there I find that under the name of Angels, it gives us to under≈øtand, ≈øuch Spirits as are the Mini≈øters of God, toward other Creatures. But there is nothing di≈øcovered to us, touching their E≈ø≈øence; neither is their any thing in the Hi≈øtory of the Creation, as to their Original, or the manner of their fall; for which Rea≈øon, part of them was from the beginning rejected from God; notwith≈øtanding, the Scripture puts the≈øe two things for certain, which is the ≈øubject of the eight and ninth Chapters.

I con≈øider afterwards the properties and Operations that the Scripture attributes to them, and I endeavour
to know, what is their proper nature, their power upon other Creatures, either ≈øpiritual or corporeal. But the pa≈ø≈øages that ≈øpeak of the≈øe things do not appear to me to have been under≈øtood otherwi≈øe, than tho≈øe that attribute al≈øo to certain Men, that is, to Prophets and Apo≈øtles, the works that they have done in di≈øpen≈øing the miracles of God. That which gives me occa≈øion to ≈øay, that as this di≈øpen≈øation ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes the force of tho≈øe to whom it was entru≈øted, it cannot make us know what was their proper nature, whence I take occa≈øion to infer the ≈øame things touching Angels; this is in the tenth and eleventh Chapters.

That which could not be di≈øcovered by the means of the name, Original, or Operation of tho≈øe Spirits, I endeavour to learn by the means of their orders, of which is made an ample mention, in the twelfth, fifteenth, and nineteenth Chapters of my fir≈øt Book. But I draw not any light from thence, ≈øave that Angels, as well good as bad, have each their head; that the Prince of good Angels is called Michael, and that of the bad, named Diabolus, the Devil; that is in the two and twentieth Chapter.

Yet I leave it not here; I con≈øider again, that the Scripture attributes in many places, ≈øome particular admini≈øtration to Angels, I examined to know what it is, fir≈øt as to the good Angels in general, in the thirteenth Chapter, whom the Scripture often makes appear, and always for particular revelations to the faithful, either to work extraordinary miracles, or execute God's Judgments upon Men by puni≈øhments, or by deliverances. But I conceive not that what is ≈øaid of this Mini≈øtry, is different from what is related of that of tho≈øe holy Men, who have been employed in the works of God and his miracles, that they in no wi≈øe operated by their own virtue;
by con≈øequence I find nothing as yet which may give me a certain knowledge of the proper Angels, their power, or their Operations.

Afterwards I come to a more particular examination of the principle pa≈ø≈øages, e≈øpecially of the manner of ≈øpeaking of the≈øe three per≈øons, which appeared to Abraham, of the two others that appeared to Lot, Gene≈øis, Chapter the eighteenth and nineteenth: and in making reflection upon this Hi≈øtory, and comparing it with other in≈øtructions of the Holy Scriptures; It ≈øeems to me, that I am in the right to conclude, that tho≈øe Angels, that is to ≈øay, tho≈øe Me≈ø≈øengers, were Men as they named them≈øelves; not being able in the mean while, to determine what mu≈øt be under≈øtood by the Angel of the Face of God, which conducted I≈ørael in the de≈øert, Exod. 23 Chap. and by the Angels, by whom God gave his Law upon Mount Sinai. I propo≈øe only my thoughts, and what ≈øeems to me may be under≈øtood by it, by a Collation of the pa≈ø≈øages of the Holy writ, which make mention of the manner of that Divine conduct of the I≈øraelites, in the de≈øert, Chap. 15.

I pa≈øs farther and examine what is ≈øaid in the Scripture concerning the Angels, with relation to ≈øome certain Per≈øons, Nations, and Countries: And I conclude from thence, that what has ever been variou≈øly written upon this ≈øubject by particular Authors, is not founded upon Scripture, becau≈øe all the pa≈ø≈øages made u≈øe of to ground tho≈øe Opinions, ≈øpeak but figuratively.

At la≈øt coming to the Devil, and to the re≈øt of evil Angels, I ≈øee that this name has been given as well to ill Men, as to evil Spirits, and even fir≈øt to wicked Men. So I examine in the 17, 18 and 19 Chapters, what may mo≈øt conveniently be under≈øtood by the Chief of evil Spirits; but in making
the examination of all the particular pa≈ø≈øages which are u≈øually applied to the Devil, I find that the name of Satan or Devil, is u≈øed in ≈øome of the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages, and that of Daemon and of Daemonium in ≈øome others. And that there are ≈øeveral denominations ordinarily applied to the Devil, which obliges me to double my cares, that I may di≈øcover what ought to be under≈øtood by Devil, e≈øpecially in the Hi≈øtory of the fall of the fir≈øt Adam, and in that of the temptation of the ≈øecond. This is the matter of the 20 and the 21≈øt, Chapters. The other pa≈ø≈øages which contain the name of Satan, appear to me to be different from the≈øe, of which I treat in the 23, 24 and 25 Chapters. I examine afterwards in the 26 to the 30, what are the Daemonia, and tho≈øe that are called Po≈ø≈øe≈øt. And la≈øtly, in the 31≈øt, Chapter, what mu≈øt be under≈øtood in all the other pa≈ø≈øages, where in≈øtead of the name of Devil, and of Demons, others quite different are u≈øed.

And therefore as the principal operations attributed to the Devil in Scripture, con≈øi≈øt in the fall of the Fir≈øt Man, and the a≈ø≈øaults he made upon our Saviour in the De≈øart; Thence I take occa≈øion to examine, Whether tho≈øe Accounts may ≈øerve to the Opinion of the power of this evil Spirit, and of the power of his operation upon Men? But it ≈øeems to me, that in the narration of Mo≈øes, touching the fall of Man, that happen'd by the di≈øcour≈øe of a Serpent, nothing is ≈øaid that ought to carry me to conclude, that the Devil him≈øelf can act immediately upon the Soul and Body of Man. Here I keep to that di≈øcovery, without going any further. Tho≈øe that are of another Opinion, find that this conclu≈øion is drawn from that Relation, with a full evidence, and aske how the fall of Man could happen otherwi≈øe; rendring them≈øelves guilty of the ≈øame fault they reproach me with, by pretending
to know them≈øelves, how the thing came to pa≈øs, and to be able to render the rea≈øon of it. But he that judges, ought not to ≈øpeak of it ≈øo po≈øitively, declaring he knows nothing of it, and finds nothing revealed upon that point, he is pre≈øently accu≈øed of denying the ≈øame thing it ≈øelf, and of not believing the matter of Fact, becau≈øe he grants he is not acquainted with the manner of it. The celebrated Voetius has however, explained him≈øelf upon this ≈øubject very near, as I do, for in the fir≈øt part of his Di≈øputes, pag. 915. ≈øpeaking of the fall of Man, he ≈øays, upon the Que≈øtion, to know how, and in what manner? it is not po≈ø≈øible to give ≈øo ≈øatisfactory an an≈øwer; but it may be ≈øeen that there remains ≈øtill ≈øomething, which the weakne≈øs of our under≈øtanding cannot comprehend, nor likewi≈øe how the Devil ≈øeduced Eve.

Examining the temptation of our Lord by the Devil, I agree that the Tempter is the evil Spirit; and I believe that the literal Sen≈øe may very well pa≈øs, ≈øuppo≈øing that it was a wicked Man ≈øo called. But I ≈øhew, that under≈øtanding the≈øe words of the evil Spirit, literally; the quite contrary may be inferr'd from what is ordinarily gather'd from thence. Thereupon, if I be ask'd how I under≈øtand and explain that narration? I an≈øwer, That I believe that the thing was done in a Vi≈øion. See how Schultetus ≈øpeaks, who as well as Voetius, has been a member of the national Synod of Dordrecht: in his Exercit. Evang. Lib. 11. Chap. 3. the que≈øtion is to know, whether the thing really happend, or in a vi≈øion? he an≈øwers, it was in a vi≈øion, and after gives ≈øome rea≈øons, which however I do not judge ≈øo ≈øtrong as mine. None has right to require from me, that I ≈øhould preci≈øely explain my ≈øelf upon the pa≈ø≈øages of Scripture, and upon others: from which they ≈øuppo≈øe to draw ≈øtrong proofs in favour
of that Opinion, the truth of which I here call in que≈øtion; nor that I ≈øhould declare what ≈øen≈øe I give them, e≈øpecially to tho≈øe who mention the fall of the fir≈øt Man in Paradi≈øe, and the temptation of our Lord in the De≈øart. For I have had no other de≈øign on this occa≈øion, but to examine whether the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages, under≈øtood according to the Letter, afford ≈øufficient proof to make us admit the con≈øequences that are u≈øually drawn from thence, and to e≈øtabli≈øh the common Opinion which is had of the craft and power of the Devil to act upon Men. If it were nece≈ø≈øary to proceed farther, and to examine all the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages to the bottom, in order to penetrate their true ≈øen≈øe, a whole Book ≈øcarce ≈øuffices. I refu≈øe not however to do it, and hope to undertake it, as ≈øoon as the Divine Providence will furni≈øh me with occa≈øion and lei≈øure.

I ≈øhew, as to other pa≈ø≈øages of the Holy Writ, that they cannot be under≈øtood of evil Spirits, but only of ill Men; and of the works of God, not of tho≈øe of the Devil; th√¥ without he≈øitating, the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages are ordinarily applyed to the Devil. I maintain in the 22 Chapter, that it was a Man which brought David to number the People, Chap. 23. that the pa≈ø≈øage, wherein the fight of Michael again≈øt the Devil, is mention'd, is very ob≈øcure, and that there is a great uncertainty in the pre≈øent Opinions upon that point, as all Divines grant; and that by con≈øequence, nothing can be concluded from them, e≈øpecially if it be ≈øuppo≈øed, as ≈øome learned do, that the Devil was but a meer Man. I ≈øhew in Chap. 24. That the Spirit of Python that is ≈øpoken of in the 16th Chapter of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, can no ways be applied to the Devil. Neither does the famous Hi≈øtory of Job, always alledged one of the fir≈øt, as a proof of his power, being well examined in its whole extent, attribute
to him the lea≈øt part in the evils, which by the Providence of God, happen'd to that Holy Man. As to the Angel of Satan which tormented St. Paul, I place him in the ≈øame rank with the fight again≈øt Michael, that is in uncertainty, there being no ground to pretend to a perfect under≈øtanding of this pa≈ø≈øage; and therefore I look upon it as in≈øufficient to prove any thing which is the matter of the 25th Chapter.

But as the Po≈ø≈øe≈øt are univer≈øally alledg'd for a certain proof of the great power of the Devil, and that we read ≈øo many times in Scripture, that the evil Spirits have been ca≈øt out by our Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt, I be≈ølow five Chapters upon examining what is in it. I ≈øee that the term of Diabolus, which we Tran≈ølate Devil, is not found in any of the pa≈ø≈øages in which tho≈øe Relations are contained; but only that of Daemon, which I illu≈øtrate in the 26th Chapter. In the 27th I ≈øhew, that the mo≈øt dangerous di≈øea≈øes, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of the Head, were u≈øually a≈øcribed to Demons, or even call'd by the name of Demons; and in the 28th, that our Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt, has not changed the u≈øual way of ≈øpeaking, but made u≈øe of them according to the cu≈øtom of that time; neither did he always immediately confute all the errors, in the 29th and 30th Chapters; ≈øo that the cure of Daemonia, was not properly an expul≈øion of Devils, but a miraculous cure of incurable Di≈øea≈øes.

I come after to other pa≈ø≈øages of Scripture, where neither the names of Devil, Satan, or Demon are made u≈øe of, but tho≈øe of the Prince of the World, Prince of the power of the air; Prince of this Age, of Lord≈øhips, Powers, Dominions, and the like; And I ≈øhew that there is not the lea≈øt cau≈øe to apply them to the Devil; but that the Stile of Scripture leads us of it ≈øelf to under≈øtand by all the≈øe names a certain order of per≈øons.

Having then examined all, I could not conclude, that the Scripture, con≈øidered truely and without prejudice, attributes to the Devil this power and the≈øe operations, which the prevention of Commentators and Tran≈ølators di≈øcovers in it: I grant it has been very trouble≈øom to me to be obliged to take this party, and to confute and cen≈øure very famous Men and mo≈øt approved interpreters: It even ≈øeemed to me, that I expo≈øed my ≈øelf very much becau≈øe I know that a more advantageous opinion is had of tho≈øe that are not known, and that a Prophet is neither e≈øteemed in his own time nor in his own Country. For this Rea≈øon I did fir≈øt re≈øolve not to meddle with tho≈øe of Scripture, where I found my ≈øelf con≈øtrain'd to go from the expo≈øitions ordinarily received. But at la≈øt, con≈øidering that my work would appear but imperfect, and that they would not fail to object tho≈øe famous pa≈ø≈øages, to which I ≈øhould be then obliged to an≈øwer; I at la≈øt prevailed with my ≈øelf to venture in the main Sea, and to fly before none that came to attack me; further I do not believe that any one can ≈øhew me, that the interpretations that I make, are founded upon the light of rea≈øon and humane under≈øtanding, or upon any other particular propo≈øition I ≈øhould have a≈ø≈øerted; ≈øuch as this is ≈øaid to be, that a Spirit cannot act upon a body, nor upon other Spirits I have made u≈øe of for this effect, but of the ordinary means that the knowledge of Languages afford us; ≈øo there is no more unju≈øt accu≈øation then that which is rai≈øed again≈øt me upon this ≈øubject.

And therefore when I compare with the analogy of the whole Scripture, with the grounds of our Divinity, and with the rules of true Piety; whatever is ordinarily publi≈øhed concerning the under≈øtanding of the Devil, his power, his operations, his apparitions in divers places in the World, his Dominion,
and the Kingdom which he rai≈øes again≈øt that of Je≈øus Chri≈øt; I conclude not only that they are not grounded upon the≈øe three principles, but al≈øo being con≈øidered with all the nece≈ø≈øary attention, they appear contrary to them. In this place I begin to enter into di≈øpute, and to draw my conclu≈øion from arguments which the Scripture and rea≈øon furni≈øhes me with; having by the means heretofore e≈øtabli≈øhed upon tho≈øe two principles, ≈øearched after the ways how plainly and without equivocation to under≈øtand the ≈øtate of the que≈øtions which properly and particularly cocern the Devil. This is not then the point in que≈øtion, to di≈øpute of the meaning of tho≈øe pa≈ø≈øages which mention the fall of Man, or ≈øpeak of Angels, ≈øome of whom appeared to Abraham, and others wre≈øtled with Jacob; or of the tentation of Our Lord Chri≈øt in the de≈øert; nor of the ≈øen≈øe of tho≈øe that ≈øay David was tempted by Satan, and that Job was tormented by him, and the like places; but the Chief point, the ≈øcope of all this ≈øearch, is to know what to believe concerning the Devil.

Upon this I be≈øtow the five la≈øt Chapters, and in the three fir≈øt of the≈øe five, which are the 32th, 33th, and 34th, I am not afraid of calling Rea≈øon to my a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; after having ≈øhewn that the Scripture is ≈øilent upon this ≈øubject, for I pre≈øume to have made appear in the 32th Chapter, that the apparitions of Evil Spirits are contrary to true Rea≈øon, and that the Holy Scripture affords no proofs of it. Afterwards, in the 33th Chapter, I ≈øhow, that the knowledge that the Devil may have, as well of things Natural as Civil, and above all of things Spiritual, which concern our Salvation, is nothing of what is believed. I re≈øt as yet upon the ≈øame foundation of Scripture and Rea≈øon, to prove the Empire of the Devil is but a Chimera, and that he
has neither ≈øuch a Power, nor ≈øuch an Admini≈øtration as is ordinarily a≈øcribed to him, which is contained in the 34th Chapter. At la≈øt, after having treated of all tho≈øe things with all po≈ø≈øible exactne≈øs, I come to the conclu≈øion of my ≈øecond Book, where I ≈øhew the importance of this examination by rea≈øon of the great value the vulgar put upon the Devil, and his Operations in the World. My Opinion is, that the≈øe ≈øorts of Di≈øcour≈øes ≈øhake the Grounds of the Doctrine of our Salvation, and cau≈øe a great damage to Piety in divers occa≈øions. I demon≈øtrate the fir≈øt. of the≈øe things in the 35th Chapter, and the ≈øecond in the 36th.

As to the Doctrine, I prove in this place what I have a≈ø≈øerted in the fir≈øt Chapter of my Book, viz. that the common Opinion concerning the Devil is oppo≈øite to the proofs that Jehova is God, and that Je≈øus is the Me≈ø≈øiah, and that the Books of the Prophets and Apo≈øtles are the Word of God. In what concerns Piety, I ≈øhew, that the Service of God is thereby greatly weakened; that the Filial fear is very much dimini≈øhed by that they have of the Devil; that the e≈øteem that the holy Angels de≈øerve, is almo≈øt de≈øtroyed, that the glory and virtue of the miracles of our Saviour Je≈øus, are very much le≈ø≈øened, that the vanity of Man is maintained and increa≈øed; and that the comfort of the humble is cut off, or at lea≈øt, ≈øuffers a great diminution. That is whatever is contained in my ≈øecond Book.

div.head: An Abridgment of the Third Book.
div.p:
After having thus ≈øimply treated of what concerns Spirits, and particularly the Devil, according to the knowledge that ≈øound Rea≈øon can furni≈øh us
with, according to that which may be drawn from the word of God, where Rea≈øon cea≈øes; I pa≈øs ≈øtill following the order and divi≈øion e≈øtabli≈øhed in my fir≈øt Book,) to tho≈øe Men, who, according to the common ≈øentiment, have communication with Spirits, e≈øpecially with the Devil. The ≈øame order to which I have kept in my ≈øecond Book, is al≈øo ob≈øerved in this; for in the eight fir≈øt Chapters, I make an exact ≈øcrutiny of all which may contribute to clear the ≈øubject I treat of, and afterwards in the ≈øeven la≈øt, I ≈øhew what light the inquiry has afforded me, and how far one can rely upon what I have di≈øcovered.

The ≈øecond Order of the pa≈ø≈øages of the Holy Writ upon this ≈øubject, con≈øi≈øts of tho≈øe that contain the expre≈øs Laws, which condemn that ≈øort of People, and forbid them the exerci≈øe of their Function; which I examine in the 8th and 9th Chapters. Now as in the third Chapter, I have examined by the light of Rea≈øon, whether there is cau≈øe to believe the po≈ø≈øibility of the communication of Men with the Devil by expre≈øs Covenants, I do here the ≈øame by that of the Holy Writ. Afterwards we mu≈øt con≈øider what the Scripture ≈øays concerning tho≈øe that practi≈øe that Art, and what Te≈øtimony it gives of their Actions. This I do two ways, in the five following Chapters. But expounding to the Reader the force of tho≈øe things, I make yet this di≈øtinction: That I fir≈øt offer the Per≈øons to his view, that he may know what might be expected from them; what their aim may be; why they were interrogated; and on what the great Men and the vulgar be≈øtow their time. a great vertue to Conjurations and Enchantments; I examine in the 16th Chapter, what is the Sen≈øe of tho≈øe places, and I conclude that after an attentive Meditation it will not be found that it ≈øays upon that ≈øubject what it appears at fir≈øt to ≈øay.

All the≈øe things being thus enquired into, it remains to ≈øhow wherein properly con≈øi≈øts all the Evil; why tho≈øe Men with their Arts, e≈øpecially the I≈øraelites, that had a hand in their Crafts, are ≈øo defamed in the Bible; why, ≈øince that time they have been in as great hatred among≈øt Chri≈øtians, who have mortally dete≈øted them, and puni≈øhed them with the utmo≈øt rigour; And la≈øtly, for what Rea≈øon the Laws have been ≈øo ≈øevere again≈øt them, and prohited all their Arts, as well under the Old Te≈øtament as under the New. I have hitherto ≈øpoken only of tho≈øe who pretend to a Conver≈øe with the Devil, and to be in a Covenant with him; I add in this place a Chapter, which is the 18th, where I mention tho≈øe to whom he is an Enemy, who≈øe Mind is ≈øuppo≈øed to be troubled, or their Body to be tormented by him; tho≈øe are the po≈ø≈øe≈øt, as they are ordinarily call'd, but I enlarge not much upon that ≈øubject, having already fully clear'd it in my ≈øecond Book, from the 26th Chapter to the 30th, where it came to pa≈øs.

Concerning that fir≈øt and common Opinion; As in the Writings made again≈øt my ≈øecond Book, ≈øome expre≈ø≈øions of our Liturgy have been objected, I ≈øhow in the 19th Chapter, how weak are the Grounds upon which are founded the principal Doctors, who≈øe Doctrines are in ≈øhort in Voetius; and that the Proofs they alledge are not taken from the Sen≈øe of the Holy Writ, well examined and ≈øearcht into; but only from the external ≈øound of Words, if I may ≈øo ≈øpeak, upon which we are wont to in≈øi≈øt, as well as upon the Idea's that fir≈øt offer them≈øelves to us, when we con≈øider them but ≈øuperficially. div.head: An Abridgment of the 4th Book.
div.p: There would be rea≈øon to believe that this ≈øubject is exhau≈øted; but it ≈øeems experience carrys it above Rea≈øon; and being grounded upon matters of fact and in≈øtances, it ≈øeems that it will not favour us: Our Adver≈øaries appeal to its Tribunal, and plead their cau≈øe with ≈øo many ≈øtrong and aggravating rea≈øons, that it ≈øeems they de≈øign to overwhelm us by their multitude. This con≈øideration obliges me to add this 4th Book to the 3 preceding, and to examine what experience actually teaches, that it may be no more objected, that by my new Doctrine, I undertake to contradict opinions received and e≈øtabli≈øhed through all the World; where almo≈øt no place is to be found, but it affords plain in≈øtance of the operations of the Devil; of which I dare even deny the po≈ø≈øibility. I di≈øtingui≈øh therefore tho≈øe In≈øtances into tho≈øe, that any one may gather from his own experience, and into tho≈øe that are grounded upon the relation of others; there's no doubt but what one has experienc'd him≈øelf, mu≈øt prevail over all the re≈øt. I di≈ømi≈øs the fir≈øt of the≈øe que≈øtions, in the fir≈øt eleven Chapters; and he Second in the 21 following, adding two others at the end as a conclu≈øion of the whole.

from the beginning of the 5th Chapter, and the examples are the matter of the following Chapter to the 11th: But I could not ≈øo exactly follow the ≈øame method in the 2d part, having thought nece≈ø≈øary, or at lea≈øt u≈øeful, in ≈øome places, to mix with examples the illu≈øtrations I give at fir≈øt, and with the illu≈øtrations, the in≈øtances I produce afterwards.

I therefore ≈øhow in the fir≈øt part, that there are few Men among≈øt us, that are capable of pa≈ø≈øing a ≈øolid Judgment upon that ≈øort of things, and that be≈øides that our occa≈øions will not allow either to examine, or to ≈øearch into whatever could be nece≈ø≈øary, to attain to a naked and full knowledge of all the matters of Fact. ‚Ä¢ acidents as effects of Magick. Of the≈øe I have alledged many proofs in the fir≈øt Chapter; ≈øhewing afterwards in the 5th, that often we want only the occa≈øion to di≈øcover the My≈øteries of the Artifices of Men, and the ≈øecrets of the operations of Nature.

I begin in the ≈øame 5th Chapter, to produce ≈øome in≈øtances of Apparitions. In the 6th, I ≈øpeak of the Po≈ø≈øe≈øt and Bewitched, as far as I am acquainted with them, and thereupon I declare in the 7th, what judgment I make of that famous Parot, which was thought to be bewitched, comparing that ca≈øe with another known to me from my own experience. To admit as Truth, no Advices, Narrations, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Te≈øtimonies, how confidently ≈øoever they may

That I may, if po≈ø≈øible, leave no perplexity, on darkne≈øs in my work; I make yet a di≈øtinction upon this la≈øt point. I come afterwards to ≈øuch Ca≈øes as have a particular Reference to Apparitions and Witchcraft, or enchantments, if there be any ≈øuch. But as to Divination, there occurs the mo≈øt ≈øingular and ingenious Story which I ever heard of, that happen'd whil≈øt I was writing this Treati≈øe; and having begun at Lyons a Year ago, is ≈øtill in
