But before I ≈øpeak of Magick, I examine in the 23 Chapter, ≈øuch proofs as are drawn from the very confe≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe that are detained Pri≈øoners, as guilty of that crime; and I demon≈øtrate, that nothing in the World is le≈øs worthy of credit, than ≈øuch confe≈ø≈øions. Thence I take occa≈øion to examine the proceedings and enquiries of the Judges that take notice of it, and ≈øhow their nullity and inju≈øtice.

Afterwards I come to the chief proofs, that have been alledged for Magick, either far or near, long ago or lately; and begin with a ca≈øe which happened within the walls of our City of Am≈øterdam, in the hou≈øe of the Orphans about the Year 1570, whil≈øt the Inhabitants profe≈øt as yet, the Popi≈øh Religion, to which I add another ≈øtory, which happened at Hoorn, in 1670, with that of Antoinette Bourignon, which ≈øhe has related her ≈øelf; all the circum≈øtances of it having happened in her ≈øight at the Ho≈øpital of l'I≈øle. In the 24th Chapter, I ≈øhow what judgment mu≈øt be made of ≈øuch ≈øtories. In the 25th I ≈øpeak of that Woman of Abbekerk, that thrice publi≈øht, ≈øhe was become miraculou≈øly with Child; and has been held not long ago every where for a famous Magician, in the Years 1658 and 1659.

From that ≈øort of People that are only look't upon as Magicians by the Vulgar, I come to tho≈øe that have been condemn'd for ≈øuch, by the ≈øentence of Judges, and by con≈øequence put to Death. I mention
not ≈øuch as have been ≈øet down by Schottus, and ≈øome other Authors, becau≈øe it would be to no purpo≈øe, ≈øince they may be ≈øeen in their writings. I only relate ≈øuch new in≈øtances as are come into my knowledge, that I may leave no room to objection, nor be charged of having pa≈øt by ≈øuch matters of fact as might have perplex'd me, and to which I had nothing to reply. For that Rea≈øon, I fir≈øt examine what happened in our own Country, from the very time of the Reformation, and mention in the 26th Chap. the Hi≈øtory of tho≈øe that have been burnt here for Magick, as one at Schoonhove, and 4 at ∆≤tretch; as al≈øo another ≈øtory, of one that being accu≈øed of the ≈øame crime, had been condemn'd to the Rack, by the Court of Holland, and was acquitted by the ≈øupream Council. This happened in the Years, 1591, 1592, and 1593. Thence I go over to Denmark, and in the 27th Chapter, I make an examination of that black Art that was ≈øaid to be practi≈øed 80 Years ago, at Kogen in Zealand, a Province of that Kingdom. I likewi≈øe examine all the other particular events, worthy to be taken notice of, that happened in that Country, and were publi≈øhed ≈øeveral times in the Dani≈øh Tongue, and from that tran≈ølated into Latin and Dutch. To which I add a ≈øtory of another unhappy wretch, executed this very Year. From thence I go over to Sweden, and in the 29th Chapter, I relate what is in≈øerted in the Royal Records, concerning that famous Magick that began to appear in 1669, and again in 1670; and a third time in 1674, to which I add another ≈øentence delivered to me by a per≈øon that ≈øaw the execution of it, at Golnaw in Pomerania.

I afterwards mention the Magick practi≈øed in the We≈øt of England, the fal≈øehood of which I di≈øcovered
my ≈øelf, and gave the Hi≈øtory of it to the publick. This is the matter of the 30th Chapter. The 31th contains a judicial information made at Harlingen, with a letter written to me upon that ≈øubject from Leuwarden, which contains ≈øeveral other matters of fact concerning Magick, happen'd about the Years 1667, and 1668. I conclude this Chapter with the relation of a ca≈øe that happened in the City of Am≈øterdam 7 Months ago, which has been lately communicated to me, the particulars of it having been di≈øcovered whil≈øt I was writing this 4th part.

Some People may ≈øuppo≈øe it u≈øele≈øs to add narrations of a le≈øs con≈øequence, after having ≈øhown the groundl≈øene≈øs and delu≈øions of more con≈øiderable facts, But I thought, that in reference to the Vulgar, it was convenient to add here another Chapter, that is the 32th, where I relate the Story of a Child in Friezeland, it was ≈øuppo≈øed to be bewitch'd, of which I have had a full account by the letters of his friends and relations; that by this ≈øpecimen any one may judge of all the narrations of that nature, that are ≈øo much credited by the common People; who take ≈øuch matters of fact for undeniable effects of Magick. As for the re≈øt, ≈øhould I make an enquiry after all the examples that are reported to prove the Operations of the Devil, I ≈øhould never compa≈øs my end. And therefore I per≈øwade my ≈øelf, that I have alledged a ≈øufficient number of them to ≈øatisfy the Reader, who ≈øhall not be able to doubt of their truth; becau≈øe I have produced ≈øuch as are mo≈øt known, lately happened, and in neighbouring places; or at lea≈øt attended with one of tho≈øe 3 circum≈øtances, and con≈øequently may be examined with great conveniency and certainty, and te≈øtified for the mo≈øt part, by living per≈øons.

Thus I put an end to this Treati≈øe, and make my conclu≈øion, briefly rehear≈øing all the proofs related in the 4 Books, each in it's place. The≈øe proofs ≈øhow that there are no natural Rea≈øons, nor Revelations in the Holy Writ, no certain experiments, that give us cau≈øe to a≈øcribe to wicked Spirits, all the Operations and effects that are generally ≈øuppo≈øed to proceed from the Devil or from Men, his Confederates. This is contained in the 33th Chapter, whereupon it mu≈øt be remembred, that what I ≈øay concerns only the common Doctrine and Opinion. Afterwards 'tis not difficult to ≈øhow, how wrongfully ≈øuch a ≈øuper≈øtition is cheri≈øhed and increa≈øed, in≈øtead of moderating it, or even rooting it out, if po≈ø≈øible. In the 34th Chapter, I charge with that fault, Clergy Men and Divines, more than Princes and Magi≈øtrates; becau≈øe the former are more particularly obliged to meditate upon tho≈øe matters, to watch over the pre≈øervation of the Souls committed to their care, and to attempt the cure of a Di≈øea≈øe that is ≈øo contagious, and feeds upon the very Bowels.

But becau≈øe 'tis probable, that this undertaking will but ≈ølowly proceed, I will in the mean while propo≈øe to the Reader and my ≈øelf, the le≈ø≈øon of the Apo≈øtle in his fir≈øt Epi≈øtle to Timoth. 4.7. Reject prophane, and Old Wives Fables, and exerci≈øe they ≈øelf to Godline≈øs. I ≈øhow, in the 35th and la≈øt Chapter, that this is what I chiefly intend in this work, and that I obtain my end in mo≈øt of tho≈øe that undertake the Rending of it, with ≈øuitable di≈øpo≈øitions. Be≈øides I hold it for certain, that tho≈øe who take occa≈øion or pretence from thence, to accu≈øe me with error and libertini≈øm, are Men them≈øelves that have not for the word of God, all the deference that could be wi≈øht. This I demon≈øtrate in particular,
with ≈øo great evidence, that I have already had the ≈øatisfaction to ≈øee that my work produeed a great fruit, when but one half of it appeared. So that I hope by the ble≈ø≈øing of God, it being now fini≈øhed, I ≈øhall gather as plentiful a Harve≈øt, as the ≈øorrows which it cau≈øed to my Enemies, whil≈øt I was publi≈øhing it, were unea≈øy and ≈ømarting.

div.head: THE World Bewitch'd.
VOL. I. Containing the Opinions of all Nations, from the fir≈øt Ages till the pre≈øent time; concerning God, Spirits, and their Cu≈øtoms.
CHAP. I. Of the Importance, Nece≈ø≈øity, and ∆≤≈øefulne≈øs of this Matter, and in what Order it ought to be treated of.
div.p:
I Promi≈øed to undertake this Work a long time ago, and 'tis yet longer ≈øince I projected it: 'Tis now at la≈øt come to its perfection; but I am afraid to venture too much by the publi≈øhing of it, my own Experience in ≈øeveral Occa≈øions, and my frequent Conver≈øing with very Rational Men, together with my particular Study, have a thou≈øand times afforded me the occa≈øion to
con≈øider, Whether it was po≈ø≈øible, that whatever the Vulgar, and the Learned ≈øay of Devils, and whatever they a≈øcribe to them, were true? I would not have ≈øpar'd ≈øo much time as to ≈øearch into this matter, had not I perceiv'd that the Opinions of mo≈øt Men, and perhaps of all the World, are only grounded upon an un≈øure and wavering Foundation. This has moved me impartially to examine ≈øeveral things, which my Calling, and common Conver≈øation offered to me. This examination forced my Mind to reject many Opinions which I had admitted at fir≈øt, only becau≈øe they were common; though grounded upon in≈øufficient Rea≈øons, as I came by degrees to be ≈øen≈øible of; ≈øo that I find that at pre≈øent I know much le≈øs than I formerly imagined to do, e≈øpecially as to the ≈øubject in hand. This, however, I do not ≈øay with a de≈øign to Cen≈øure, or De≈øtroy, what others have Written: I only intend to joyn my Thoughts to theirs for a fuller In≈øtruction of ≈øuch Readers as love Truth, and are enquiring after it.

Sect. 2. I am not afraid to mi≈øtake, if I ≈øay, that whatever belongs to this matter has not been exhau≈øted. Tho≈øe that have written upon it before having been ≈øomewhat retarded by Prejudices, that ≈øtick to their Mind, though they had freed them≈øelves of many others; for I own they have proceeded ≈øo far as to de≈øtroy mo≈øt of the works of the Devil; at lea≈øt ≈øo far as 'twas nece≈ø≈øary to free Men from Super≈øtition and frivolous Fears: But, as for me, I would, if it were po≈ø≈øible, altogether overthrow them, and not leave one Stone upon another, that ≈øhould not be demoli≈øhed. And therefore I'll try whether I can bring my Countrymen to my Opinion, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of my Profe≈ø≈øion, de≈øiring them to read this Treati≈øe with as little prejudice as I have written; and not to ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be per≈øuaded
by other Rea≈øons, but such as proceed from Natural Light, from a clear Interpretation of the Holy Scripture, and from certain Experiments. I have right to require the≈øe Conditions from the Reader, ≈øince they cannot be rejected by any Rational Per≈øon, that they are a Law to which I ≈øubmit my ≈øelf, and that the great con≈øequence of the matter requires them.

Sect. 3. I am Confident, and I hope, that the Reader will more plainly perceive it hereafter, that no point of the Chri≈øtian Religion is more important than this; and that no certain and ≈øufficient proofs may be had of all the others, than by rejecting the Opinion commonly receiv'd among≈øt the Vulgar, concerning the Craft and Power of the Devil. Can it be imagin'd a ≈ømall Matter to know whether the Devil has a Kingdom upon Earth; and what are the Limits that ≈øeparate his Dominions from that of God Almighty? Or is „Äà‚óä„Äâ un≈øerviceable to examine, whether ≈øuch a cur≈øed and dete≈øtable Creature can do more wonderful things than God ever did; and con≈øequently, whether the tru≈øt we repo≈øe in God, and the fear we have of the Devil, ought to be equal? Such Thoughts ought never to enter into a Chri≈øtian Heart; yet they creep into it unawares; at lea≈øt I think ≈øo, and can ≈øcarce doubt of it: for the more I ≈øearch into this matter the more it ≈øeems evident to me; that whoever entirely believes all that it u≈øed to be a≈øcrib'd to the Devils and his Angels, and all that is commonly ≈øaid of them, both by the Learned and the Vulgar, ≈øaving the bottom of the Doctrine publickly receiv'd and taught in our Church; he can have no convincing proof that JES∆≤S is the Me≈ø≈øiah, or that there is but one God: And if in this Writing I do not make the Reader very ≈øen≈øible of it, I grant that I have compo≈øed it to no purpo≈øe.

Sect. 4. But if I ≈øucceed, it will at the ≈øame time plainly appear, that it was altogether nece≈ø≈øary to publi≈øh this Treati≈øe, becau≈øe the Vulgar are ≈øtill confirm'd in their Errors by Men of Letters, and of great Name; who, being full them≈øelves of tho≈øe prejudices, make u≈øe of their Tongue and Learning to lead others into the ≈øame Labyrinth. To that end they wre≈øt ≈øeveral Expre≈ø≈øions and Hi≈øtories of the Holy Scripture; which being not accurately examined, nor conferr'd with others, give a great probability to the common Opinion concerning the Devil; but if taken in the ordinary Sen≈øe, they prove evidently oppos'd to other clear Expre≈ø≈øions concerning the Fundamental Articles of our Faith: It follows, that ≈øuch a Sen≈øe cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt without overthrowing the grounds of our Salvation; that I can hardly bear, ≈øince a long time the nicety with which Points of ≈ømall con≈øequence, or at lea≈øt of little certainty, u≈øe to be treated of; ≈øince one cannot di≈øcu≈øs them without getting into a ≈øu≈øpicion of entertaining Erroneous Opinions; whil≈øt, in the mean time, we are not yet agreed upon Matters of the utmo≈øt con≈øequence; or if we are agreed upon them, it 'tis without any foundation: And therefore, ≈øince none was ever found fault with for defending an Article of Faith, or giving out a new Explication of it; ≈øo I per≈øuade my ≈øelf, that I do well by publi≈øhing the Illu≈øtrations upon a matter, on which the whole Edifice of our Salvation is grounded; in order that whoever will carefully and impartially examine it, may become Wi≈øer and Learneder.

Sect. 5. As to what concerns this Book, I will at fir≈øt ≈øet down the ≈øubject matter of it before the Reader. The de≈øign is to examine to the bottom what the Devil can do, and what he really doth; that is, How far his Knowledge extends; either in Natural or Supernatural Things. Either as to the Pre≈øence,
as it is conceal'd from Men; or as to the Future, as it is contingent, or po≈ø≈øible, and not nece≈ø≈øary. Moreover, what Direction or Power he has to operate in Nature, what Communication he has with Men, with the Human Soul, and with all ≈øorts of Bodies? That he ≈øhould tran≈ømute him≈øelf into them, or put on their various Forms: That he ≈øhould act upon the Soul, or upon the Body: That he ≈øhould direct Thoughts, Words, Actions, and Ge≈øtures: What is his Power over the Bea≈øts and Fruits of the Earth; Over the Air and Winds: What his help may contribute to the Knowledge of Man and his Actions. Herein con≈øi≈øt Auguries, or Sooth≈øaying, Witchcraft, the Art of Conjuring up Gho≈øts, and of Divining Dreams. All which things are methodically (and in the ≈øame order that is mentioned here) treated of in this Book.

Sect. 6. But becau≈øe the perfect Knowledge of them depends upon another, viz. which is the Nature of a Spirit, wherein it con≈øi≈øts, and how it's di≈øtingui≈øhed from that of the Body: (for Devils are undeniably Spirits, and Man is compo≈øed of a Body and a Spirit) ≈øo it will be nece≈ø≈øary in this Treati≈øe to proceed farther, and to examine fir≈øt the Nature of Spirits, Good and Bad, and then that of Man. Be≈øides, God him≈øelf being a Spirit, but infinite and independent, we ought not to pay our ≈øelves with the conformity of the Name; but by rea≈øon of the manife≈øt difference betwixt the Creator and the Creature, we are obliged more particularly to examine, how much the increated Spirit differs from tho≈øe that are created; and among≈øt the≈øe la≈øt, how much tho≈øe that are immaterial, and tho≈øe that are united with a Body, differ from each other.

Sect. 7. However, ≈øuch a difficult piece of work cannot be undertaken, without knowing the different Opinions and Practices upon this Subject; and without ≈øpecial Con≈øiderations upon them: Now, whoever ≈øhall reflect upon what is ≈øaid and practic'd, as to this matter, through all the World, and withall upon the conver≈øe, which Men may have with the Spirits, and the Operations that may attend them, he will undoubtedly de≈øire to be well informed of all the≈øe things, that he may di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt the Truth and Fal≈øhood of tho≈øe Opinions, and what is lawful and unlawful in tho≈øe Practices. For the≈øe Rea≈øons I de≈øcribe all the Sentiments that have been receiv'd among≈øt Men, in all Ages and Places what≈øoever, concerning God and the Spirits; what means Men have made u≈øe of to conjure them up and down; and what they may be able to operate by the help of tho≈øe Spirits: whence proceeds a ≈øufficient matter for a more particular examination of what ≈øound Rea≈øon, and the Holy Scripture teach us, as to this Point, and what experience te≈øtifies of it.

Sect. 8. To treat of the≈øe things methodically, I have divided this Treati≈øe into four Books. In the fir≈øt I propo≈øe the Opinions and Cu≈øtoms of all Nations, in all Ages, Countries, and Religions, concerning the Deity, and the good and bad Spirits. I ≈øay the Opinions and Cu≈øtoms; for in the matter we undertake to treat of, we mu≈øt take a ≈øpecial notice of the≈øe two things; the Knowledge, and the Action; Since no Fruit can be perceived from the Knowledge, but by putting it into Practice. Be≈øides, we fee every where that the Behaviour of Men, either in the Words or Actions, has a relation to the Doctrines they have been taught. For this Rea≈øon I have again divided in two parts, the examination of what is contained in the fir≈øt Book. In
the fir≈øt part I enquire what Knowledge may be had or Spirits, of their Power and Operations, according to Rea≈øon and the Holy Scripture; which Enquiry is the matter of the Second Book. In the other part, which is the ≈øubject of the Third Book, I examine tho≈øe Sciences that are ≈øaid to be grounded thereupon; as Witchcraft, Divination, Conjuring, and the like. Moreover, as Men u≈øe to have recour≈øe to experience, not only in things which are not di≈øcover'd by Rea≈øon, and of which the Holy Scripture is ≈øilent; but al≈øo e≈øpecially in this Ca≈øe, in which Rea≈øon, and the Holy Writ, are made to ≈øpeak, according to the certainty which we ≈øuppo≈øe to have acquired by Experience: This Con≈øideration has furni≈øhed me with the matter of the Fourth Book, in which I examine all that Men te≈øtifie ever to have experienced in them≈øelves, or profe≈øs to have done.

div.head: CHAP. II. That the opinions of the Heathens, concerning God, and Spirits, are to be found in Greek and Latin Authors.
div.p: Sect. 1. THat we may the better ≈øearch into the bottom of this matter, it will not methinks, prove un≈øerviceable. Fir≈øt, to examine the various Opinions of other Nations, and then tho≈øe that are receiv'd among≈øt us. As to Foreign Nations, we have to con≈øider tho≈øe that are not Chri≈øtians, and ≈øuch Chri≈øtians, as may be called Spurious. The Fir≈øt are the Heathens, who never wor≈øhiped one true God, or the Mahometans, who keep as the mean betwixt them and us; or the Jews, who Wor≈øhip one God only. The others are Chri≈øtians, who are extreamly corrupted, and plung'd into ≈øtrange Errors, both as to the belief, and to their Wor≈øhip, ≈øuch as tho≈øe of the Roman Communion. After we have ob≈øerv'd the di≈øpo≈øition of all the≈øe Nations, ≈øhe ≈øhall more ea≈øily examine what is believed and practi≈øed among≈øt us. As to the Heathens, we mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt the Cu≈øtoms that were formerly in u≈øe in tho≈øe Countries, in which Chri≈øtianity is at pre≈øent e≈øtabli≈øh'd; and betwixt tho≈øe that are ≈øtill practi≈øed among≈øt tho≈øe Nations, that have not yet been illuminated with the light of the Go≈øpel. We ≈øhall now proceed in that order.

Sect. 2. Europe, which is now mo≈øt or all Chri≈øtians, and tho≈øe parts of A≈øia and Africa, which are in the Turks po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and of which very near one half profe≈ø≈øes the Chri≈øtian Faith, were formerly buryed under the frightful Darkne≈øs of Pagani≈øm,
as are ≈øtill mo≈øt or all the re≈øt of the World. Formerly the Greeks, who inhabited tho≈øe Countries, that are in the Grand Seignior's Dominions, were the mo≈øt famous People in the World, by rea≈øon of their Learning and Religious Wor≈øhip. Next to them came the Romans, and mo≈øt of the Nations, who ≈øtill keep Communion with the Pope of Rome. For proportionably as the Romans extended the limits of their Empire, ≈øo they ≈øubjected the conquer'd Nations, to the Wor≈øhip of their Gods, and to their Religion, ≈øo that their Doctrine and Wor≈øhip ≈øpread every where, and drew to them≈øelves an Univer≈øal Awe and Veneration. From them therefore we mu≈øt know the Cu≈øtoms of our Forefathers in the time of Heatheni≈øm; but we cannot accurately di≈øcover what was their Belief concerning Spirits, unle≈øs we know, at lea≈øt in general, their Opinions and Practices, concerning God and inferiour Deities,

Sect. 3. But the great difference and Divi≈øions, that were among≈øt the Heathens them≈øelves upon this Account, leave us extreamly in the Dark, as to the Opinions that are to be a≈øcribed to them. However, we may agree upon this, viz. to take that ≈øtupendous number of differencies for an Uniformity; ≈øo that it may he affirmed, that in all Ages, the Pagans have Unanimou≈øly believed, that there is but one Sovereign God, the Fir≈øt Univer≈øal cau≈øe of all things; ≈øince the Fir≈øt Doctors of their mo≈øt famous Schools, and the heads of their principal Sects, have generally taught this Doctrine to their Di≈øciples. The Opinion of Pythagoras, that Old Father of the Pagan Religion, may be ≈øeen in Lactantius, who writing again≈øt the Heathens, did doubtle≈øs not intend to ≈øpare them; however he ≈øays, that Pythagoras owned one God, an immaterial Spirit diffu≈øed and extended through all Nature, who gives Life
and Sen≈øe to all beings. Plato, who has de≈øerved the name of Wi≈øe, by all the ≈øucceeding Ages, agrees with him, as to this point, as appears by his di≈øcour≈øe to the Athenians, in his four Books of the Laws. Gentlemen, ≈øays he, God in whom, according to the Ancient Te≈øtimonies, is the beginning, the middle, and the end of all things, penetrates every where, &c. And Ari≈øtotle, his great Di≈øciple, who for Two Thou≈øand Years, has been e≈øteemed the Prince of Philo≈øophers, plainly ≈øayes in his Fir≈øt Book of Metaphy≈øicks, Chap. the 7th. that God is Eternal and perfectly good, ≈øo that the Eternal and Infinite Life con≈øi≈øts in him. From this capital point they infer this other Belief, that the good and evil, which befal Men, proceed from the Fir≈øt and Univer≈øal Deity, as Plato more largely explains in the forementioned place. Equity, ≈øays he, Eternally attends him, which is the Avenger of tho≈øe that for≈øake the Law of God, but happy is he, who ≈øticks to it, and follows it con≈øtantly.

Sect. 4. But how advantageou≈øly ≈øoever they may ≈øpeak of the ≈øupream Deity, it neverthele≈øs appears, that they do not a≈øcribe to him Independency, nor the immediate direction of all things; ≈øince they divided the Government of the World betwixt ≈øeveral Gods, to each of whom they a≈ø≈øigned his particular ≈øhare. 'Tis very probable that the Caldees and Per≈øians, ob≈øerving how Human affairs were often here below obnoxious to con≈øiderable changes, which proceeded from Heaven, took occa≈øion from thence, to contrive two ≈øupream Deities, proceeding from that Fir≈øt being; one of whom they called Oromasdes, and gave him the direction of Heaven; to the other, named Arimanius, they a≈øcribed that of the Earth. The Romans afterwards gave them the Greek names, viz. to the former that of Jupiter, and to the latter, that of Pluto, whom they at Fir≈øt look't upon as the God of the Earth.
And becau≈øe all the wi≈øe held for a certain Truth, that the Heavens ≈øurpa≈øs the Earth in perfection, they placed the ≈øupream Deity in Heaven, and the other Gods under it, each according to his Dignity: And as they conceived that the Soveraign God could never cea≈øe from being good, ≈øo Jupiter, who had the Empire of the Heavens, was in great credit among≈øt them; but Pluto, the God of Hell, obtain'd but an ill name.

Sect. 5. It is here, methinks, the proper place to di≈øtingui≈øh the Doctrines of the Pagans into ≈øuch as had either Religion, or Nature, for their object. In the latter, they enquired after the Fir≈øt and Second Cau≈øes of all things, of their Motion and Changes, without any reference to Religion. Thus came upon the Stage Plato, with his Idea's, and Ari≈øtotle with his Intelligencies, Plato called Idea's the principles that flow from the Divine Nature, that ≈øub≈øi≈øts with him, and by which all things ≈øub≈øi≈øt; each of them being as an Engraven Image of him, from whom they all proceed; ≈øo that they all partake of the Nature of their Original, and are ≈øuch as the principal, from whence they flow. When I confer the ≈øentiment of Pythagoras contained in the words of Socrates, related in the Parmenis, with what Plutarch ≈øayes in his Fir≈øt Book, Chap. the 10th, of the Opinions of Philo≈øophers; and Laertius in the Life of the ≈øame Pythagoras, as al≈øo Cicero, in the Fir≈øt Book of the Tu≈øculan Que≈øtions. Fifty Eight, wherein he explains the meaning of that Philo≈øopher, it ≈øeems to me, that nothing can be better nor more plainly expre≈ø≈øed, concerning this ≈øubject. As for Ari≈øtotle his Opinion was that there are ≈øub≈øtances di≈øtinct and ≈øeparate from matter, who put the Heavens into Motions, ≈øuppo≈øing Heaven it ≈øelf „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a Body in a continual and re≈øtle≈øs motion; that the Stars are of an Eternal Nature,
and that wh ‚Ä¢ t moveth, mu≈øt be more durable and precede that which is moved. Thence he inferr'd, that there are as many permanent and immoveable ≈øub≈øtances. This is what he teaches in his Metaphy≈øicks Book the 14th. cap. 18. And what is called by his Latin Interpreters, Intelligencies.

Sect. 6. But when they proceed to Religion, there ari≈øe ≈øtill among them more con≈øiderable differencies, which may be plainly perceived in the Book of Plutarch, Entituled, The Opinions of Philo≈øophers, and el≈øewhere in the ≈øame Author, as al≈øo in the Book; which Apuleius, a Platoni≈øt, more Ancient than Plutarch, has written of the Life of Socrates. The ≈øum of what he ≈øays, comes to this; that the Deitie is divided into Four, as into ≈øome Degrees that de≈øcend from high to low, and that the three la≈øt Degrees are again ≈øubdivided into ≈øeveral others, which they call „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Gods, Demons and Heroes. Plato, ≈øayes Apuleius, has divided the whole Nature into three, with relation to Spirits in particular, believing that there are Gods, Superior, Middle, and Inferior. Of which Three ≈øorts of Gods, it is convenient to ≈øay ≈øomthing.

Sect. 7. As to the Superior or Cele≈øtial Gods, he ≈øayes, that their habitation is in Heaven, that they are Immaterial and Eternal of their own Nature; but that there are ≈øome, which are in ≈øome ≈øort vi≈øible in the Stars, though others cannot be perceived by corporal Eyes, but only by tho≈øe of the Under≈øtanding. After he has di≈øtingui≈øhed tho≈øe Deities into Sexes. like Mankind, that is, into Gods and Godde≈ø≈øes; he mentions the≈øe 12, viz. Jupiter, Apollo, Vulcan, Mars, Neptune, Mercury, who are Six Gods, Juno, Diana, Venus, Ceres, Ve≈øta, Minerva, who are as many Godde≈ø≈øes. The dignity of the≈øe Cele≈øtial Gods, notwith≈øtanding the liberty which the Poets often took to contrive other Accounts of
them, 'twas e≈øteem'd too high, that it ≈øhould allow them to de≈øcend and conver≈øe with Men, though they govern'd their affairs, each in his Jurisdiction. But the ≈øame Plato believes, the Stars are but improperly called Gods, and only in reference to the Divine and Immutable conduct, that is ob≈øervable in them. The names of the fixed Stars, which are reckon'd among≈øt the vi≈øible Gods, are contain'd in this Ver≈øe.

But leaving tho≈øe Gods to Plato, of who≈øe making they were, the Stars, which are called by Ignorance Planets, or erring Stars, were al≈øo accounted among≈øt the Gods; the Sun was called Apollo, and the Moon Diana, to which the≈øe Five were joyned, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, called al≈øo the Morning and Evening Star, and Mercury, though they appear but ordinary Stars. Another ≈øource of the Pagan Errors in their Divinity, is the Conformity, betwixt the name of ≈øome Stars, and tho≈øe of their invi≈øible Gods, they believed, that there were Deities in the Stars, who acted by them, or that the Stars were Gods; who having life in them≈øelves, communicated it to other Creatures, as it was believed by Alomen, who≈øe Opinion is related in Clemens Alexandrinus.

Sect. 8. We may ≈øtill perceive ≈øome Remains of that Opinion in the names of the Days of the Week, in the Engli≈øh, French, and Dutch Tongues, as well as in Latin, for they ≈øtill name by one of the Seven Planets that Day, on which they believe them to have a particular Influence. As Lunae Dies, Lundi, Munday, Maanday; Martis Dies, Mardi, Duigsday, an Abbreviation of Dy≈ø≈øenday, which is ≈øtill in u≈øe in Zealand, and Brabant. Mercury Dies, Mecred, Wedne≈øday,
Woon≈ødag, from Woden≈øday, the Day of Woden, the name of Mercury among≈øt the Ancient Germans and Dutch, becau≈øe he was the God of Merchants, and the Me≈ø≈øenger of the Gods; Jovis Dies, Jeudi, Thur≈øday, Donderdag, becau≈øe Jupiter was e≈øteem'd the God of Thunder; Veneris Dies, Vandredi, Friday, Vrydag, from Freda, the Ancient name of Venus in the Dutch and Saxon Tongue; whence it comes, that the Fri≈øons called that Day Freed, and whence undoubtedly comes the Dutch word Vryen, to Court a Woman. Saturni Dies, Samedi, Saturday, Saterdag. Solis Dies, Sunday, Sondag, but in the French Tongue, it has lo≈øt it's Ancient name, in remembrance of the Re≈øurrection of our Lord, and is called Dimanche from Dies Dominica.

Sect. 9. Let us proceed from the Gods to the Demons, or Spirits of a meaner Order. Thales of Milet taught, if we believe Plutarch,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that the World is full of Spirits, namely, the Air, which they inhabit, and the Earth in which they conver≈øe among≈øt Men; the Greek word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , comes from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , I know, as ≈øignifying one that is very Learned, becau≈øe they believed that tho≈øe Demons knew whatever is important to Men, either for their Happine≈øs or Mi≈øery, and that they were as the Mediators of Men towards the Gods. And 'tis ob≈øervable, that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ likewi≈øe ≈øignifies to Mediate, ≈øo that the Demons import ≈øo much as Mediators. And therefore they have al≈øo been called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the Mediators and Directors of Men, and have been placed according to the Opinions of the Heathens, betwixt the Heavens and the Earth, viz. in the Air, and con≈øequently betwixt the Gods and Men.

Sect. 10. Though the Opinions were divided, as to their Nature, yet they agreed in the≈øe principal points, that they were Spirits, that they were Mortal,
and however, that they were no Gods, as Plato writes in his Timoeus, which explaining more at large in his Convivium, he ≈øays, that the Demons have a Nature which is the Mene betwixt God and Men, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . But what virtue have they? That of explaining and declaring to Men, what things belong to the Gods, which are their Commands, and how Sacrifices mu≈øt be performed; As al≈øo, that of offering to the Gods, what comes from Men, viz. their Prayers and Sacrifices, ≈øo that they being in the middle, comprehend the Nature of both, as binding and uniting the whole together.

Sect. 12. As to their Admini≈øtration, Plato explains it thus. From them come to us Predictions, Auguries, the wor≈øhip of Sacrifices, Conjurations, Orations, and the whole Art of Magick. The Deitie meddles not with Men, but tho≈øe Spirits are the Directors of all the communication and conver≈øe of the Gods with us, either wakeing or ≈øleeping. The Demons therefore being by their Nature Mediators, betwixt the Gods and Men, and being be≈øides, Spirits, and almo≈øt Gods, could not be better called, then Spirits of a middle Order, in relation to their Nature; or Mediating Gods, in reference to their Functions, in how great con≈øideration tho≈øe Spirits were, and what was the Sentiment of the Antients concerning them, may be learned from St. Chry≈øo≈øtome, Tom. 6. Le≈ø≈ø. 66. Entituled, Again≈øt tho≈øe that ≈øay, that the Demons direct the Affairs of Men.

Sect. 12. But, what will be mo≈øt u≈øeful to ob≈øerve, was, that there were Demons of a Superiour, and others of an Inferior Order; and that ≈øome were e≈øteemed Good, and others Wicked „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Good and favourable; whereas the other were „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Evil Spirits, or by a
more particular explication of their Qualities, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Wicked, dangerous, Enemies, Cruel. However, the≈øe Demons, either good or bad, were not believed of all Nations, to be of the ≈øame Dignity. There were ≈øome, among≈øt whom, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , imported as much as Deity, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Divine, even in Plato, the Soveraign God is called, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the greate≈øt Demon. However the general u≈øe was to di≈øtingui≈øh the Gods from the Demons, as has been already ob≈øerved, and as Ae≈øchines expre≈ø≈øes it in his Cle≈øias, O Earth, Gods, Demons, and Men, whoever ye be, that de≈øire to know the Truth! and therefore Plato, in the place already quoted, may rightly ≈øay, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that tho≈øe learned and middle Spirits, are in great numbers and ≈øeveral kinds. But 'tis not nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øpeak more of it, for perhaps it would only induce us into ≈øeveral errors; there is ≈øo much uncertainty in Plato, and others that have written upon it, they are ≈øo much oppo≈øed again≈øt one another, and even to them≈øelves.

Sect. 13. As to the Heroes, they were extraordinary Men, and ≈øo far above the vulgar, that every where, e≈øpecially among≈øt the Romans, they u≈øed to con≈øecrate and deifie them, after their Death, which was called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a Canonization. Herodian in his Fourth Book, Chap 2. makes a particular De≈øcription of that Ceremony, with all the Circum≈øtances of it, on occa≈øion of the Death of the Emperor Severus. Be≈øides we generally find in the writing of the Ancients, that they paraell'd them with the Demons; Plutarch, relates in his Opinions of the Philo≈øophers, Chap. 8. Book Fir≈øt, That Thales, Plato, and the Stoicks believ'd, that the Demons were Spiritual ≈øub≈øtances, and that the Heroes were Souls ≈øeparated from the Body, which were good or bad, as Men had been Virtuous or Vitious, this was e≈øpecially the Doctrine
of Pythagoras who in all things that relate to Religion has had more Di≈øciples then any of the Ancient Heathens, and is yet the mo≈øt followed by tho≈øe that are not Chri≈øtians. He teaches that tho≈øe Demons and Heroes brought in Dreams, Di≈øea≈øes, and Cure to Men, and even to Cattle, and labouring Bea≈øts; according to the Te≈øtimony of Diogenes Laertius, confirm'd by Plato, and not contradicted by Ari≈øtotle.

Sect 14. Apuleius, in the Book formerly quoted, more particularly demon≈øtrates, that the powers, which put the natural pa≈ø≈øions of Men into motion, which govern them, and Lord it over them, as al≈øo the Souls ≈øeparated from the Body, are called Gods, and Demons, or Spirits; that the Soul born with the Body, dies not however with it; and that ≈øhe bears the name of Genius, when they are ≈øeparated from each other. This meaning cannot, methinks, be better expre≈øs'd, than by naming tho≈øe Souls, A≈ø≈øociated Spirits, or Spirits peculiar to one ≈øubject, ≈øince every Man has one within him≈øelf. The others, that is tho≈øe that are ≈øeparated from the Body, or the Souls of the Decea≈øed, are commonly called Manes, as though remaining, becau≈øe they remain of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt after the Body; for Which rea≈øon, I ≈øhall name them, Surviving Spirits. However, as to the Latin word, it ≈øeems rather to be derived from Manis, an Ancient ob≈øolete Term, which ≈øignifies fine and good; as immanis imports, as much as ∆≤gly and Cruel; becau≈øe the Manes were ordinarily taken for Benevolent Spirits.

Sect. 15. Some of this la≈øt ≈øort remained in the Hou≈øe of the decea≈øed, to watch over his Succe≈ø≈øors, and were called Lares, or Dome≈øtick Gods; but the others err'd at random, and as Exiles, according as they had de≈øerved by their wicked Life: They could cau≈øe but vain Fears to virtuous Per≈øons,
but to the vitious a ju≈øt Terrour, and all ≈øorts of Pains. They were called Lares, Night Phanta≈øms, and Spectra. Diogenes writes, that mo≈øt of tho≈øe things were taught in the School, of Plato, as it ≈øtill appears by his Book, Entituled, Phoedo. They had al≈øo the name of Lemures, which is ≈øuppo≈øed to come from Remures, and this from Remus, Brother to Romulus, who frightfully imagined to ≈øee the Gho≈øt of his Brother Remus, after he had killed him. If tho≈øe Narrations were true, ≈øuch Spirits might be called terrifying Spirits. Ovid in the Fifth Book of the Fa≈øti plainly ≈øays what mu≈øt be under≈øtood by that Name.
div.q: The Soul of the Dead had the Name of Lemures.
div.p:
Sect. 16. The Lares, or perhaps the Geniues are called by Macrobius in his Third Book of the Saturnalia, Chap. 4. Penates, that is, Born together, Qua≈øi penes nos natos: For, as that Author pur≈øues, 'tis by them that we breath, by them that we have our Body, and by them that our Soul ≈øub≈øi≈øts: But 'tis, better to call them Gods, and Governors of Countries, to di≈øtingui≈øh them from the Lares, who were particular to each Family, as they were both di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Geniu≈øes, and look'd upon as taking care of the exteriour of Man, as the Geniu≈øes did of the interior. However it mu≈øt be confe≈øs'd, that there is but Confu≈øion and Darkne≈øs to be met with in the Books of the Heathens, concerning tho≈øe Names, and their pretended Signification, they having not well known them≈øelves what they Wor≈øhipped, as Gods, or as Spirits; neither need we take much trouble in unravelling what they them≈øelves knew not; ≈øince the memory, both of them, and of their Daemons, is long ≈øince extingui≈øhed upon Earth; This being
the Lot of the Heathens, and of their Gods, Jeremiah, cap. 10.

Sect. 17. Whether this la≈øt ≈øort of Gods, or Spirits, were called Genii, Manes, Penates, or Lemures, it plainly appears that they believed the Immortality of the Soul; which Opinion being confounded with that of Daemons, gave occa≈øion to contrive tho≈øe ≈øorts of Spirits. Plato in his Book Of the Soul, Entituled Phaedo, induces Socrates, ≈øpeaking near his Death in the≈øe Words. Above all, the Soul mu≈øt be immortal, and unperi≈øhable, and con≈øequently it mu≈øt go to live,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in invi≈øible places; or, as others pretend to infer from the Etymology of the Word, in agreeable Places. Marcilius Ficinus has Tran≈ølated it in Latin, apud Manes, by the ≈øurviving Spirits, as I have named them above; but a little after he Translates, apud Inferos, in the Subterraneous Places: which proceed from that they placed the Soul of the Decea≈øed under the Earth. Cicero, in the fir≈øt Book of the Tu≈øculan Que≈øtions, Sect. 26. ≈øhows both in the≈øe Words. We believe, that the Souls ≈øurvive becau≈øe all our Rea≈øonings lead us to that Opinion. Rea≈øon ought al≈øo to teach us where they are; whence Ignorance has taken occa≈øion to invent ≈øubterraneous places, becau≈øe Bodies being put into the Earth, and cover'd, with Earth, (humo, whence comes humari to be Buried) thereof it has been believed, that the Dead ≈øtill live under the Earth. Now „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ is the ≈øame word which the Interpreters of the New Te≈øtament ≈øometimes Tran≈ølate by that of Hell, ≈øometimes by that of Grave; none of which agrees with the Sen≈øe of Socrates, or that of Plato: For at the end of the forementioned Book, Socrates derides Crito, who asked him how he would be buried. He believes, ≈øays he, That I am that dead Body which he ≈øhall ≈øee anon; ≈øignifying, that they might indeed Bury his Dead Body, but as to him, that is, his Soul, he
≈øhould pa≈øs, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , to the a≈ø≈øur'd Felicity of the Ble≈ø≈øed: which very much differs from the Grave or Hell. And therefore 'tis certain, that Socrates, who ≈øpake ≈øo, believed the Soul to be Immortal, and that Plato, who writ his Words, was of the ≈øame per≈øua≈øion.

Sect. 18. But there were others, who tho' they were of the ≈øame opinion, yet having not acquired ≈øo much in≈øight into the State of Souls ≈øeparated from their Bodies, invented Tran≈ømigrations and Purifications. The Druids, ≈øo famous among≈øt the Ancient Gauls, held together the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or Tran≈ømigration of Souls, with their Immortality; For they unanimou≈øly taught, according to the Te≈øtimony of Cae≈øar, Book 8. Chap. 18. Non interire animas ≈øed ab aliis po≈øt mortem tran≈øire ad alios: Souls die not, but that after Death they pa≈øs from one to another. The antient Egyptians were of the ≈øame Opinion, and Herodotus writes, that they were the fir≈øt who taught the Immortality of the Soul: For, ≈øays he, their ≈øentiment is, that the Soul being deprived of the Body, pa≈ø≈øes into another Body, which is then born; and after ≈øhe has thus walked through all ≈øorts of Bodies upon Earth, in the Sea, and in the Air, ≈øhe at la≈øt returns into a human Body. Thence it was that Pythagoras had his Doctrine, which he brought over into Greece, whence it pa≈ø≈øed into Italy. Lactantius explains the Opinions of that Phili≈øopher in his Seventh Book de Proemio, Chap. 8. In the≈øe words; Pythagoras as fooli≈øhly a≈ø≈øerted, that the Souls pa≈ø≈øed into other Bodies, from the Bodies of Men into tho≈øe of Bea≈øts, and from tho≈øe of Bea≈øts into tho≈øe of Men again, and that his own had formerly been that of Euphorbius. Plato and ≈øeveral others have partly followed him, which we ≈øhall be obliged frequently to mention hereafter.

Sect. 19. But Socrates, as Plato relates in the forementioned Treati≈øe, which contains his la≈øt Words, leads the Souls to ≈øome places, where they ≈øhall be Ble≈ø≈øed or Tormented, without Bodies: He ≈øends tho≈øe who ≈øhall have done Good into the Upper and Aetherial Regions, where he believes the mo≈øt pure part of this Orb to be, and where the Soul ≈øhall Eternally live without the Body, in an unexpre≈ø≈øible Felicity. Whereas he condemns tho≈øe of the Wicked to the Tartarus, which is a deep and frightful Aby≈øs, where they ≈øhall be puni≈øh'd according to their De≈øerts. From that Gulf of Torments he draws four Rivers, to which he gives as many Names, very fit to expre≈øs his Notion, viz. Oceanus, a precipitate Torrent; Acheron, a Torrent of Torments; Pyriphlegeton, Conflagration; and Cocytus, Bemoaning. Here Sinners, who have not been altogether incorrigible, are to be purged with many Pains and Vexations, more or le≈øs, longer or ≈øhorter, according to their De≈øerts. There you have the original of Purgatory, or of that purging Fire, ≈øtill believed by the Roman Church. However, Socrates gives out that Narration but for a Chimaera: For before he begins it he calls it, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a pretty Fable worth hearing; and at the end he ≈øays: But no Man of Sen≈øe ought to maintain that Opinion ≈øo, as I have related, though I e≈øteem it rational and ju≈øt, to ≈øhow that it goes very near ≈øo, in reference to our Souls, and their Habitations; ≈øince it plainly appears that the Soul is immortal. The≈øe Words of a Dying Man, who exhorts, tho≈øe that were pre≈øent to be at all times ready for Death, per≈øuade me more and more of what I have already ≈øaid, that the Heathens expre≈øs'd them≈øelves variou≈øly upon the≈øe Matters; and that they ≈øpeak otherwi≈øe, when they con≈øider them in reference to Religion; than when they conceive them in relation to the enquiry
after Natural things; but at the ≈øame time they ≈øhow, that they were not very certain of what they ≈øaid, nor of What they believed.

div.head: CHAP. IV. That tho≈øe Opinions, are the Source and Ba≈øis of the Art of Divination.
div.p: THE Opinions of the Heathens concerning Spirits, being thus explained in ≈øhort, will give us an ea≈øie under≈øtanding of whatever is read in their Books, concerning their Cu≈øtoms and Practi≈øes upon this Subject, and the Arts that aro≈øe from them; The≈øe Arts were directed to two ends, to which Man is always inclined of him≈øelf; that is, to know much, and to do much. Divination was u≈øed to acquire an unlimited Knowledge, and Magick, to produce wonderful effects. Our pre≈øent de≈øign nece≈ø≈øarily requires to ≈øpeak clearly and di≈øtinctly of both.

Sect. 2. As to the Fir≈øt, we find in the Authors, and in ≈øeveral others, that every one was eager to obtain the favour of the Gods, whether great or little, and that they earne≈øtly ≈øought to plea≈øe the good Spirits, and to turn off the evil. To this end they built Temples, e≈øtabli≈øh'd Forms of Prayer, con≈øecrated Prie≈øts, offer'd Sacrifices, in≈øtituted Fe≈øtivals and Games of all ≈øorts. Be≈øides that, they u≈øed ≈øeveral means to di≈øcover the de≈øigns and inclinations of the Gods, together with the happine≈øs and misfortune of Men; to which they ≈øuppo≈øed to attain, either by the Knowledge they might receive from the help of the Demons, the communication of the Penates, of the Remures, by the means of Oracles,
Conjurations and Witchcraft, or by the ob≈øervation of the influence of the Stars, the motions of the Air, the dreams of ≈øleeping Per≈øons, by conjuring up Gho≈øts, by inchantments, for which they made u≈øe of Carca≈ø≈øes, by Progno≈øticks drawn from the days of the year, the hours of the day, or the meeting of Men and Bea≈øts. Whatever was practi≈øed as to this point among≈øt the Romans, was called Divination, that properly ≈øignifies an exerci≈øe of things concerning God, of which, Cicero has written a particular Book. Polydore Virgil in his fir≈øt Book, Chap. 24. relates, in what con≈øi≈øted all tho≈øe Arts. Wherefore I ≈øhall extract out of that Author, and ≈øeveral others, what is nece≈ø≈øary for the under≈øtanding of this matter.

Sect. 3. There, were two, ≈øorts of Divinations Anciently in u≈øe among≈øt the Greeks and the Romans, the one was rightly called Natural, but the other Artificial, they held for a Natural Divination, what ever a particular, free, and voluntary Action of the Mind of Man, without the help of Rea≈øon, or any Conjecture, or Progno≈øtick, portended as future, as it often happens in a Dream, and even without Sleeping in the Fits of a raving Fever, thence the Godde≈ø≈øes called Furies, had their Name and 'twas believ'd, that ≈øome Prie≈øts, and even the Sybil, Erythrea had begun to utter their Oracles in ≈øuch Paroxy≈øins. Jupiter Hammon, and Apollo of Delphos, gave their An≈øwers in ≈øuch a way, and by ≈øuch ≈øort of People of which their Prie≈øts them≈øelves boa≈øted. And as tho≈øe Per≈øons were e≈øteem'd ≈øincere, and to act in the cour≈øe of Nature, the vulgar a≈øcribed to their affected furor; what a long Ob≈øervation and a frequent experience cau≈øed them to di≈øcover, or to foretell upon concealed or future things. The chief and mo≈øt famous of tho≈øe divining Arts were A≈øtrology, the Art of Haru≈øpices, or foreteling, by
the in≈øpection of the Bowels of ≈øanctified Bea≈øts, be≈øides Auguries, and ca≈øting of Lots.

Sect. 4. A≈øtrology was called by the Greeks, a Conjecture drawn from the Stars; ≈øo that A≈øtrologers may be named Divines by the Stars, the communication of the Gods with the Stars, of which mention has been made before, the operations of tho≈øe Cele≈øtial Bodies, and the influences upon the inferior part of the World, and upon Men, and even upon one another, gave occa≈øion to believe, that from thence may be drawn conjectures u≈øeful for Mankind; but I ≈øhall not inlarge upon this point further; becau≈øe I treat of it as far as 'tis nece≈ø≈øary in my Examination of Councils, Chap. 8. where is to be ≈øeen, what rank is to be given to tho≈øe that are called Genethliaci, or Planetarii, which we u≈øually call Fortune-tellers; who by the in≈øpection of the Stars, e≈øpecially of the Planets, in the in≈øtant that a per≈øon was born, foretell what inclinations, what fortune he ≈øhall have, and of what ≈øort of death he ≈øhall dye; which Art is not yet aboli≈øh'd in the World: but becau≈øe there will be occa≈øion to ≈øpeak of it afterwards, I ≈øhall pre≈øent the Reader only, with a ≈øhort account of the three others.

Sect. 5. Donatus derives the Word Haru≈øpices, and Haru≈øpicina, from Haruga a Sacrifice; and Exta Entrailes, it being the Art of foretelling future things, by the in≈øpection of the Entrails of Bea≈øts, that were ≈øacrificed to the fal≈øe Gods, as th√¥ tho≈øe Gods had imprinted ≈øome ≈øigns on the Bowels of the Victims that were offer'd to them. To this ≈øort belong the Ca≈øe recited by Apian in his ≈øecond Book of the Wars of Alexandria, and by Cicero, namely, that no Heart was found in an Ox, which Julius Cae≈øar ≈øacrificed, the fir≈øt day that he ≈øate on the Golden Seat; wherefore the Diviners told him, that ≈øuch a ≈øitting could not prove happy to him.

Sect. 6. To tho≈øe Arts M. Tullius adds two others, viz. that of Prodigies, and that of Lightning. Prodigies, O≈øtenta, comes from O≈øtendendo, to ≈øhew, to ≈øignifie, becau≈øe when ≈øomething extraordinay in Nature offer'd it ≈øelf to the ≈øight, they drew pre≈øages from it; as it was done, if we believe Herodotus, in his 7th Book, when a Mare was big with a Hare, at the time of the inva≈øion of Greece by Xerxes, for from thence the Divines conjectured, that his powerful Army ≈øhould flye before the Grecians, as a Hare before the Hunter. Such accidents were al≈øo called Portenta, Mon≈øtra, Prodigia, Signs and Mon≈øters. Such al≈øo were Thunders and Lightnings, Fulmina and Fulgura, as Virgil ≈øays, De caelo tactas memini praedicere quercus. The thunder'd Oaks foretold me that event.

Au≈øpicium, Au≈øpice, and Augurium, Augury; the former ≈øo call'd, from viewing the flight of the Birds, and the latter from ob≈øerving their Song and Cry, made the whole imployment of tho≈øe that were called Au≈øpices and Augures: they were very famous among≈øt the Antient; for at Rome, that ≈øort of Divination was preferr'd before all the others; and the College of Augures was extreamly reverenced. No Affair of importance was undertaken without con≈øulting them, to know whether it ≈øhould ≈øucceed, or not. That ≈øo much exalted Art ob≈øerved the Birds three ways, in their Flight, in their Singing, and their Eating: As to their Flight, they made their ob≈øervations upon the Praepetes, that is, on ≈øwift flying Birds; as to the Singing, they drew their conjectures from O≈øcines, or Singing Birds; and as to Eating, they ob≈øerved the young Chickens Among≈øt the 4th ≈øort is ranked the ca≈øe of the Emperor Augu≈øtus, from who≈øe hands an Eagle took a
piece of Bread, whil≈øt he was yet a Child, carried it into the Air, whence ≈øoftly coming down, ≈øhe let it fall; which gave occa≈øion to the Diviners, to foretell the happine≈øs of Augu≈øtin's life, if we may believe Suetonius. To the 2d, way or the Divination by Singing, this Ver≈øe of Virgil may be applyed, Saepe ≈øini≈øtra cava praedixit ab ilice Cornix. Th' ominous Crow foretold it on an Oak.

For the 3d, ≈øort, they u≈øed the Tripudia ≈øol≈øtima, which were a ≈øort of Skipping and Dancing, during which, if the Chicken fell upon the Meat, that was fall'n from his Bill on the ground, called Solum, and ≈øwallow'd it greedily, it was a happy Omen; whereas, if he let it ≈øtand, an ill ≈øucce≈øs was to be feared. Thus was fore≈øeen the defeat of Ho≈øtilius Mancinus by the Numantines; becau≈øe the Chickens had refu≈øed to eat, and were fled from their Coops.

Sect. 8. Sortilegium, or Ca≈øting of lots, was a di≈øpo≈øition of ≈øome Letters mixed together, and drawn at adventure, by the fir≈øt Child to be met with; tho≈øe Letters were engraven on the Bark of an Oak, according to the antient Cu≈øtom, and di≈øpo≈øed as many different ways as was po≈ø≈øible, to ≈øee whether they ≈øhould render ≈øome Sen≈øe or none. Whence the good or bad fortune of the Inquirer was inferr'd. When Tiberius, ≈øays Suetonius in his Life, undertook a journey into Dalmatia, and at Pavia con≈øulted the Oracle of Geryon by Lots, he was obliged to make u≈øe of another way; for he was an≈øwered that he ≈øhould ca≈øt Golden Dice in the Spring of the Fountain Apona; which having done, it was the greate≈øt point that appeared to his Eye, which is ≈øtill to be ≈øeen under water at this day.

Sect. 9. There is yet another way of Divination, famous, even in the Holy Scripture, viz. by expounding of Dreams. I ≈øhall be obliged to ≈øpeak of it more at large another time, becau≈øe the Omirocritici, or expounders of Dreams, are nor yet bani≈øh'd out of the World, and that ≈øome, e≈øpecially of the French Court, begin to revive that Art. As to the Heathens, as often as the Demons, Geniu≈øes and Larvae, medled with their Dreams, it was to offer them ≈øomething particular, by which, according to the u≈øual Rules of their Art, they might know the good or bad ≈øucce≈øs of future things.

Sect. 10. Our Ance≈øtors in the time of Pagani≈øm, had among≈øt them a Cu≈øtom of that nature, as Tacitus relates. Divinations, and ca≈øting of Lots ≈øays he, are as much in fa≈øhion among≈øt them, as any where el≈øe. They ca≈øt their Lots in a very ≈øimple way, for they cut the branch of a Fruit-tree in ≈øeveral little Lots, on each of which they make a particular mark, and then Confu≈øedly throw them on a piece of white Cloth. There the Prie≈øt, if matters of State are treated of, or the Father of the Family, when it concerns him, or his hou≈øe looking to he Heavens, lifts up thrice each little Lot, and gives the explication of the marks printed on them; if they di≈ø≈øwade, no farther con≈øultation is made that day; but if they allow to proceed, they go to the Diviners for an An≈øwer. There is yet another particular way of predicting among≈øt that people, by the means of white Hor≈øes, that were never back'd, and are kept together in a Fore≈øt at the Publick Co≈øt. They hunt them, and the Prie≈øt, King or Governor ≈øitting on a con≈øecrated Chariot, ob≈øerves their Neighing and Foam. There is no Divination more e≈øteemd than this, not only by the People, but even by the Great Men and the Prie≈øts; the
latter are look'd upon as the Mini≈øters of the Gods, and the Great Men as tho≈øe that are nearer and better known to them.

Sect. 11. But 'tis not ≈øufficient to have explained 'the names of tho≈øe 3 or 4 ways of making the Heathen Gods ≈øpeak; for tho' they be the chief, yet I find that ≈øeveral others have been in u≈øe, called by the Greeks, ‚Ä¢ egromancy, Pyromancy, Aeromancy, Hydr ‚Ä¢ mancy, Geoma ‚Ä¢ cy and Chiromancy: the 1≈øt. relates to the dead, the 2d. to the Fire, the 3d. to the Air, the 4th to the Water, the 5th to the Earth, the 6th to the Hands. Polydore Virgil gives us a de≈øcription of each of the≈øe Arts, in the 23 Chapter of his 1≈øt. Book.

Sect. 12. Necromancy, or the Divination by dead Bodies, is made by ≈øomething perceived on a Corps, which gives occa≈øion to the foretelling. The ignorance of the Greek Tongue has made ≈øome believe, that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , which ≈øignifies dead, was derived from the Latine, as tho' it had been Negros, from Niger Black, which mi≈øtake cau≈øed Necromancy to be called the Black Art; which name is u≈øed at pre≈øent to ≈øignifie all ≈øorts of Witchcraft, Inchantments, and Diabolical Illu≈øions. Under this ≈øort is comprehended Sciomancy, or Divination by the ≈øhadows in which they conjured up the Gho≈øts or Shadows of the dead, to foretell future things. It would be a great proof of the power of this Art, if what Lucan relate in his 6th Book, were true, that a Gho≈øt conjured up, foretold the whole ≈øucce≈øs of the Battle of Phar≈øalia. Sciomancy differed from Necromancy herein, that the latter requires Blood, and made the dead Bodies appear, whereas the other conjured up only Gho≈øts.

Sect. 13. Pyromancy was, according to Polydor? a Divination by Fire, when they ≈øuppo≈øed to know ≈øomething by the means of Fire, for which purpo≈øe Ob≈øervations were made upon Lightning, or
≈øome other extraordinary Fire. In≈øtances of it are to be read in Livy, and in the Fir≈øt Book of Diony≈øius Halicarna≈øs. where 'tis related, that the Wi≈øe of Tarquinius the Ancient, ≈øeeing a Flame ≈øurround the Head of Seruivs Tullius, foretold, that he ≈øhould become King of Rome.

Sect. 14. Acromancy, or the Divination by the Air, con≈øi≈øted ob≈øerving Tempe≈øts, and extraordinary Clouds; as when Pliny relates in his Second Book, that there Rain'd Iron in Lucania, which in his Opinion ≈øignified, the Defeat of Cea≈ø≈øus, by the Parthians. He likewi≈øe relates in his Fir≈øt Book of the Second Punick War, that their Rained Stones in Picenium, which he takes for a forerunner of the Evils, that Hanibal was bringing to Italy. Tho≈øe Divines are called in the Hebrew Bible „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Jidnoni, Diviners by the Clouds; among≈øt this ≈øort may be ranck'd the Capnomancy, which con≈øi≈øted in ob≈øerving the motions of the Smoke of Sacrifices

Sect. 15. Hydromancy, or the Divination by Water, aro≈øe from ≈øomthing particular, which they fancyed to ≈øee in the Water. Varro relates upon this occa≈øion, that a Youth ≈øaw in the Water, the Image of Mercury, who declared to him, in 150 Ver≈øes, the whole cour≈øe, and all the events of the War again≈øt Mithridates; St. Au≈øtin, in the 9th Book of the City of God, ≈øays that Numa Pompilius, the Second King of the Romans, was the Inventer of that Art, and that by the illu≈øion of the Demons, he made appear upon the Water, the Images of the Gods, who gave him Laws, for governing his People, with goodne≈øs and Ju≈øtice.

Sect. 16. Geomancy, or the Divination by the Earth, was made by the Ob≈øervation of the Clefts and Cha≈øms, of an Earth quake, I could not find any particular De≈øcription of it, th√¥ I was never ≈øo inqui≈øitive after it; but I ≈øuppo≈øe, that to this may be
referr'd, what is related by Livy, Decad. 1 Book 7. Sect. 6. concerning Marius Curtius. In the ≈øame Year (which was according to the Calculation of Calvi≈øius 357 before Chri≈øt;) either by an Earthquake, or ≈øome other ≈øtrange commotion, almo≈øt one half of the Market of Rome, was ≈øwallowed up. There was a great Depth, and mo≈øt frightful Cha≈øm, which could not be fill'd, what trouble ≈øoever was taken for it, th√¥ People carried Cattle thither continually. The Oracles of the Gods were con≈øulted, and the Diviners an≈øwer'd, that the things in which the principal Strength of the Roman People con≈øi≈øted, mu≈øt be Con≈øecrated to them in that very place, if they de≈øired to e≈øtabli≈øh for ever, the Republick of Rome. And as they were troubled to know, what was the thing to be Con≈øecrated; a warlike Young Man called Martius Curtius derided it, a≈ø≈øerting, that the chief Strengh of the Roman People, con≈øi≈øted in Valour, and an undaunted Courage, to confirm which, he got on Hor≈øeback, and precipitated him≈øelf into the Aby≈øs.
Sect. 17. Chiromancy, or Palmi≈øtry, con≈øiders the Lines of the Hands, to know the Fortune of Men, whereupon Juvenal ≈øays in his 6th Satyr.
div.q: His Hand and Head, he'd ≈øhow to the Divine.
div.p:
Whence appears, that Phy≈øiognomy, that is, accordeing to the Etymology of the word, the Knowledgs of Nature; but by u≈øe, the Ob≈øervation of a Man Shape, mu≈øt be comprehended under this ≈øort, for this Art foretells things by the Looks, the Features
and Lineaments of the Face, by which the Genius and Humour of Men are to be di≈øcovered.

Sect. 18. Now all the≈øe things are natural, th√¥ they were abu≈øed to attain to a ≈øupernatural knowledge. But Art was made u≈øe of in other means, which were the works of Mens Hands, that might well be called a Bewitching Pomp; in that ranck was contain'd the Axinomancy, a Witchcraft made with an Axe, Hatchet, or the like Tool. The Lecanomancy another Witchcraft, in which they u≈øed a Caldr ‚Ä¢ u full of Water, on the bottom of which, they fancyed, that the Demons came to walk. The Catoptromancy, a Witchcraft made with Looking-gla≈ø≈øes, in which they ≈øuppo≈øed that blindfolded Children ≈øaw what 'twas de≈øired to be known. The Keskinomancy, in which they u≈øed a Seive, and a Thou≈øand other Impertinencies.

div.head: CHAP. IV. That all the different ≈øorts of Witchcraft, that have been in u≈øe, proceeded from the ≈øame Original.
div.p:
Sect. 1. I have hitherto treated of tho≈øe Arts, that to ≈øay properly, are Sciencies, ≈øuppo≈øed to be acquired ≈øeveral ways, by the Communication with the Gods, or with the Spirits. Now I ≈øhall Treat of Magick, which refers to Action. That name is now determin'd to that particular practice, th√¥ it has been given in general to all the other Sciencies, of which I have ≈øpoken in the foregoing Chapter. If comes from the Grecians, th√¥ it be not a Greek word. 'Tis univer≈øally believ'd, that it is a Per≈øian word; now that Tongue had Anciently many things common with the Hebrew, as well in the Stile as in the Etymologie; But in Hebrew
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Hagah, ≈øignifies to cen≈øider, to reflect and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Mahgeh, thinking Per≈øon, one who tells Secrets and My≈øteries. I have explain'd what the Magi were in my Commentary upon Daniel, Sect 62, where the matter required it; they, were at fir≈øt hone≈øt Men, who endeavoured to penetrate into the ≈øecrets of Nature, by lawfull means, and attained to the performance of things above the common Belief, Nam quod ego apud plurimos lego, Per≈øarum lingua, magus e≈øt, qui no≈øtra ≈øacerdoss. for as I read, in ≈øeveral Authors, a Magus in the Per≈øian Tongue ≈øignifies a Prie≈øt in ours. The≈øe are the words of Apuleius in his Apology, and Plato calls Magick,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the Cure of the Gods,
'and Porphyrie
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øays, that Divines and Phy≈øicians were called by the Per≈øians, Magi; which title was given to both in the Countrey. He≈øychius likewi≈øe ≈øays, that a pious Man and well inform'd in the knowledge of Divine things, or a Prie≈øt is called Magus,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ; and Cicero de Divinatione, ≈øapientum & doctorum genus magorum habebatur in Per≈øis; among≈øt the Per≈øians, the Magi were look'd upon as Wi≈øe and learned Men.

Sect. 2. 'Tis very probable, that when tho≈øe Men were got at Court and in great e≈øteem among≈øt the Vulgar, their Art was not ≈øufficient to keep up their Reputation; then they begun to u≈øe Craft and Cheats, and even ≈øome of them, abu≈øed that Art ≈øo far, as to joyn Malice to Deception, and not to ≈øpare either the Goods, or the Blood or ≈øeveral Per≈øons; ≈øo that as on the one ≈øide, the Pagans extreamly honoured that ≈øort of People, becau≈øe of their Wit and parts; ≈øo they de≈øpi≈øed them upon another Account, and had a great hatred for them. Thence proceeded that ≈øome have Anciently been famous in the Magick Art, as well for the good, as the bad u≈øe they made of it, as Apollonius of Tyanis, who≈øe Life has been written by Philo≈øtrates, and Elymas, who re≈øi≈øted St. Paul, Acts, 13. Ver≈øe 8. And the Wi≈øemen of Egypt and Babylon, who were called to expound the Dreams of their Kings. Gen. Chap. 4. Ver≈øe 8. And Daniel, Chap. 2. Ver≈øe 4. Even Mo≈øes, Daniel, the Wi≈øemen of the Ea≈øt, who ≈øought the King of the Jews newly born; all tho≈øe Men were famous for Magick, th√¥ Authors ≈øpeak variou≈øly of them, either with or again≈øt them, there is ≈øo much difference betwixt the ≈øame Sciences and the ≈øame Actions, by the good or bad u≈øe that is made of them. Neverthele≈øs, it was properly that Art, to
which we now give the name of Magick. Agrippa of Nettinheim, di≈øtingui≈øhes it in Two ≈øorts, one of which may be called Natural Magick and the other Artificial; becau≈øe the fir≈øt having Natural cau≈øes, produces Natural Effects, but the Second being an invention of Art, Nature has no ≈øhare in it's Operations. I mean that as it is nece≈ø≈øary in all Arts and Handicrafts, that Nature ≈øhould ≈øupply the matter and power of Action, th√¥ the Workman imploys them this or that way, only by the rules of his Art. It goes even ≈øo with the Arti≈øts of whom I ≈øpeak, and not as which a Husbandman, who can only prepare the Ground, ca≈øt his Seed upon, or plant a Tree upon it, but mu≈øt expect the Harve≈øt and Fruit from Nature it ≈øelf, holpen with his Art.

Sect. 3. They believe, ≈øays Agrippa, that Natural Magick is but the highe≈øt Degree of power, in Natural Sciences; for which Rea≈øon they call it the extream and la≈øt perfection of the knowledge of Nature; ≈øaying, that it is the active part of Natural Wi≈ødom, which, by the help of Natural power u≈øed in proper time, operates wonderful effects, and rai≈øes Admiration. The Moors and Indians made a ≈øpecial u≈øe of that Magick, that is, as much as it was able to produce effects, by the power of Herbs, Stones, and other things of the ≈øame kind. Moreover, ≈øays again Agrippa, for that Rea≈øon, Natural Magick is that, which penetrates the Virtues of all Natural things, and which with a ≈øubtle di≈øcerning, having exactly ≈øearched into their Indurations, and Sympathies, di≈øcovers ≈øo far their ≈øecret powers, that by them it produces wonders, which amaze Humane under≈øtanding; not ≈øo much by Art, as Nature, to which, as to its Soveraign Art ≈øubmits it ≈øelf, and only lends her the helping Hand. Thus we can by Natural ways produce ripe Fruits before their Sea≈øon, and even infects,
only by ≈øupplying the want of time, by Natural means unknown to other Men; as it is done, th√¥ in a le≈øs Degree of perfection, by Gardners, each of whom, ≈øtrives to be the fir≈øt in getting early Fruits, helping Nature by Art, and ≈øtill however by the means of Nature her ≈øelf. The difference only con≈øi≈øts in this, that a Magus, who wholly gives up him≈øelf to his ≈øtudy, penetrates much farther into the knowledge of the power of Nature, than the Vulgar, and even tho≈øe learned, who care not to take that trouble upon them. But as all the≈øe things are done without the particular a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and concour≈øe of God and the Spirits, they concern not the pre≈øent que≈øtion; however we mention them, that we may learn to di≈øtingui≈øh them from the ≈øubject in Hand, and all it's dependencies, of which we intend to give a clear and undeniable notion.

Sect. 4. We have hitherto ≈øeen the Magick of the Pagans, included within the bounds of Nature. Now I de≈øire the Reader to remember what I have ≈øaid in my Commentary upon Daniel, Sect. 26. viz. That to the Magick antiently in u≈øe Mathematicks, Phy≈øick, and Divinity were ordinarily conjoyned; ≈øome giving up them≈øelves to one of tho≈øe Sciences, and others to another, whence proceeded a difference of Names, betwixt the Students of Magick; ≈øome of whom were called Mathematicians, and others Phy≈øicians, or by a more odious name, Poi≈øoners. The former applyed them≈øelve chiefly to perform wonderful things; and the others to perpetrate Wickedne≈øs. Among≈øt their Wonders may be counted the Wooden Dove of Architas, that fly'd, and the Statues of Mercury that ≈øpake; but the imployment of Poi≈øoners was to annoy Men, their Goods and their Bea≈øts, by many things commonly unknown. And having learned the Virtues and Properties of them by their Study, they put them, in
u≈øe in ≈øuch a concealed and imperceptible way, that one could ≈øcatce belieye what he ≈øaw effected; and this is, what they really operated. But as to what they boa≈øted of be≈øides, or perhaps, imagin'd them≈øelves capable of; it was, that by the virtues of Simples, and ≈øome other Drugs mixed together, they could transform Men into Bea≈øts, Bea≈øts into Men, Bea≈øts and Men into other Bea≈øts and Men, conjure up Gho≈øts, or rai≈øe the Dead out of their Graves, &c.

Sect. 5. Now we mu≈øt ≈øpeak of Magick meerly Artificial, which may rightly be ≈øo called, becau≈øe Nature has no ≈øhare in it; but that is a work of Art alone, which however pre≈øuppo≈øes Nature; one may al≈øo very fitly give the names of Witchcraft, Conjuration, and Inchanting in general, to all the various practi≈øes that are made of it; for we call Witchcraft whatever is operated by the power of the Devil, with the communication of Men, which is never done, without u≈øing ≈øome ≈øort of Conjuration , and Inchanting. That Art which required of its Profe≈ø≈øors a particular way of living, always con≈øi≈øted in the u≈øe of ≈øome certain Signs and Words, that they utter'd or wrote, and in extraordinary Ge≈øtures, in con≈øideration of which, the Demons were ready at all times to di≈øcover to them hidden things; and to operate in their behalf, ≈øupernatural Wonders. This was therefore the opinion of the Heathens, that be≈øides natural Magick, they believed them≈øelves capable of producing the mo≈øt wonderful effects by the power of Demons, whom they knew how to make comply, by their Conjurations, to whatever they de≈øired.

Sect. 6. We mu≈øt carefully ob≈øerve this, becau≈øe, natural Magick is not commonly accurately di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Artificial, either by the Antients or by the Moderns; and that which belongs to one,
is frequently attributed to the other: even tho≈øe that meddle with it, having committed as many mi≈øtakes as the others. For ≈øome of them, ≈øays Agrippa, are come to that heighth of Folly, as to believe, that by the different Concour≈øe and A≈øpects of the Stars, with the interpo≈øition of time and proportions duely ob≈øerved, they may, in a certain in≈øtant, acquire a ≈øen≈øible Idaea of Cele≈øtial things, and a Spirit of Life and Under≈øtanding; which being Interrogated by them, will give them An≈øwers, and di≈øcover 'em hidden things. On the other ≈øide, they a≈øcribe to Nature what is above her power, which I cannot better expre≈øs, than by the very words of Agrippa, who proceeds thus. I de≈øire you to take notice, that tho≈øe Magicians, not only rake up into natural things, but even in a manner remove Nature out of her place; which they endeavour to do by Motions, by Numbers, by Ge≈øtures, by Sounds, by Voices, by Congregations, by Lights, by the Inclinations of the Mind, and by Words. Thus it was that the Inhabitants of P≈øilli and Mar≈øi conjured Serpents, and put them to flight; thus Orpheus by his ≈øinging allay'd the Tempe≈øts, for the ≈øake of the Argonauts; Thus, as Homer relates, by ≈øome certain words, the blood of ∆≤ly≈ø≈øes was ≈øtopp'd. There was a puni≈øhment ordained by the Law of the 12 Tables, to tho≈øe that ≈øhould u≈øe ≈øuch ≈øort of Inchantments again≈øt Corn.

Sect. 7. It mu≈øt not ≈øeem ≈øtrange to us that things ≈øhould be ≈øo, in the Pagans time, for Magick con≈øider'd in general, and in it ≈øelf, was e≈øteemed, becau≈øe of its depth, and honoured as Divine, taking the word in the ≈øen≈øe of the Heathens, and as it may be attributed to their Deities, which have been de≈ø ‚Ä¢ ribed before. Be≈øides, Magick was reverenced, becau≈øe of Efficacy and Power, beloved for
its ≈øerviceablene≈øs in the good u≈øe of it, but hated and dete≈øted, by rea≈øon of its malignity, and the di≈øturbance it cau≈øed, when it was abu≈øed. The ≈øame Agrippa will tell us, in the words of Porphyry, which was the opinion of the mo≈øt ingenious Heathens upon that ≈øubject. Porphyry ≈øays he, treating of Witchcraft, and of the Magick of Divine things, concludes at la≈øt, that it may render the Souls of Men capable of receiving Spirits and Angels, but he ab≈øolutely denies, that one may approach God by that Art.

div.head: CHAP. V. That we ≈øee ≈øtill among≈øt the pre≈øent Pagans, the ≈øame Doctrines and Practices.
div.p:
WE have ≈øpoken as much as it was nece≈ø≈øary for our ≈øubject, of the Doctrines of the Antient Pagani≈øm, which reigned in the Countries we, inhabit. We have al≈øo ≈øpoken of the Nations, who introduced mo≈øt of tho≈øe Arts and Sciences, of which we treat, It is now fit to con≈øider the Modern Heathens, to know how far their Sentiments and Practi≈øes concerning Spirits can reach, without the Light of the Holy Scripture, which never ≈øhined upon them. It is the more nece≈ø≈øary to enter into that examination, that we ≈øhall ≈øee, withal, the Cu≈øtoms of very many Nations, arid that the proofs they ≈øhall furni≈øh us with, of the uniformity of Opinion, (that which we contend to be among≈øt the Heathens) will then be more general and extended, then ≈øuch as are drawn from the Writings of tho≈øe we have already ≈øpoken of, of which Chri≈øtianity has taken place; ≈øince they inhabited only a ≈ømall part of life World, and have given us in their Writings
but a ≈ølender account of the other Heathens. So that all the≈øe others, the number of which is far more con≈øiderable, are ab≈øolutely unknown to us.

Sect. 2. Experience teaches us, that we cannot better divide the World, then as into three great I≈ølands; one part of which was known to the antient Greeks and Romans, though not perfectly: The ≈øecond part is come to our knowledge, ≈øince about two hundred years: The third is yet for the mo≈øt part unknown. The fir≈øt is called for that Rea≈øon the Antient World, divided into Europe, A≈øia, and Africa. But in the North of Europe, which continent is not much greater than one half of the other, there are ≈øtill many Heathen Inhabitants. In A≈øia the Chri≈øtians are hardly the tenth part of the People, and about the third part of the re≈øt follow Mahomet; ≈øo that the greate≈øt number is ≈øtill Pagans. The Mahometans take up the North of Africa, and the Heathens po≈ø≈øe≈øs the two third parts Ea≈øtward: The half of the third part is filled with Mahometans, and the other half by imperfect Chri≈øtians. In the new World, called America, or the We≈øt Indies, the Southern part is almo≈øt as big as Africa; and the Northern, which is not yet fully known, is perhaps as big as A≈øia. All that Country is Heathen, ≈øave a ≈ømall number of Chri≈øtians, gone thither from Europe, viz. ≈øome Spaniards, Portugue≈øe, Engli≈øh, French and Dutch, who bring over from time to time ≈øome Heathens, though very few, to Chri≈øtianity; at lea≈øt, the Engli≈øh are now very earne≈øt in it. In the mean while; tho≈øe Europeans may inform us of the State of tho≈øe Nations, as to what concerns their Belief and Religion, of which they have gotten a great knowledge, by the Commerce they have with them. But as to the Au≈øtral Country, (which is known only by the Conjectures that we can
make upon its Circuit (their being no Inland Sea) 'tis perhaps as big as Europe and A≈øia together. Now that great part, having never been enlightned by the Doctrine of our Saviour, mu≈øt be pre≈øumed to be ≈øtill altogether Heathen.

Sect. 3. But it will perhaps be ≈øaid, to what purpo≈øe is all that Narration? I an≈øwer, that having ≈øhown the Reader that three parts of the known World, con≈øider'd as divided into five, are ≈øtill Pagan, he cannot but infer, that we are not ≈øufficiently informed of the Cu≈øtoms and Sentiments of the Heathens concerning Spirits, by the Books of tho≈øe Nations that ≈øub≈øi≈øt no more, and who never made up the tenth part of the Inhabited World: and therefore we mu≈øt not keep there; but 'tis likewi≈øe fit to examine the Opinions of tho≈øe many Nations, who are not yet Chri≈øtians, who≈øe uniformity upon this que≈øtion, notwith≈øtanding ≈øo many other things, in which they differ, and with all the great di≈øtance of the places they Inhabit, which cuts of all manner of Communication betwixt them; ≈øo that the greate≈øt part of the one never heard ≈øo much as one word of the other: That Uniformity, I ≈øay, is an evident proof of the good, which the common light of the Under≈øtanding remained in Man after his Fall, has pre≈øerved in him; and of the evil which the general corruption has brought to the fame. And when we come to the examination of the Sentiments of the Chri≈øtians, that will help us to di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt tho≈øe general Truths, and tho≈øe impure mixtures of Corruption. For the≈øe Rea≈øons, I ≈øhall now ≈øpeak of the Belief and Practices of the pre≈øent Heathens.

Sect. 4. But I need not to treat largely of it, for an entire Volume would not ≈øuffice. Neither do I intend to write a Hi≈øtory, but only to give In≈øtances, in order to ≈øhow what the mo≈øt pare of the Nations
known to us, think in this matter. 'Tis not convenient to proceed in this enquiry farther, then it's requi≈øite to ≈øhow that all tho≈øe People agree together, as al≈øo with the Ancient Nations, th√¥ there is never ≈øo great a difference in their Language, Country and time. The way is already more than half traced out, by the diligence of Carolinus; who, in his Modern Pagani≈ø ‚Ä¢ , has extracted, out of more than 50 Authors, whatever the Heathens of our time Believe and Practi≈øe as to Religion, in all A≈øia, Africa, and part of Europe. 'Tis pity he has not lived long enough, to inform us of the Opinions of the new World. It would have proved very ≈øerviceable to me, for it would have ≈øpared me the trouble of con≈øulting a great many Writers, whence I have extracted them.

Sect. 5. In the mean while it will not be u≈øele≈øs to ob≈øerve, that all the Authors which Carolinus has follow'd, and which I am likewi≈øe oblig'd to follow, are Chri≈øtians; and therefore they have ≈øet down the Belief and Wor≈øhip of tho≈øe Heathens, only upon the particular Information they received from the Heathens them≈øelves, or the things that they ≈øaw them practi≈øe, ≈øo that they cannot afford us ≈øuch a clear and neat knowledge of what they relate, as is that which may be gathered from the Writings of the Ancient Heathens, who have them≈øelves, in their own Tongue, treated of their own Affairs. And therefore we cannot relie ≈øo much upon the de≈øcriptions of the pre≈øent Heatheni≈øm, which are made by Chri≈øtians who undoubtedly have but ≈øeen or learned part of the Sentiments and Cu≈øtoms of the People they ≈øpeak of, and who perhaps, are not di≈øpo≈øed to make ≈øuch a ≈øimple and natural relation of them, as could be de≈øired. Now I find that all tho≈øe Writers are in the fame prejudice, when they tell us, that there are many Nations who
adore the Devil him≈øelf, vexing them≈øelves with grievous pains, and cruel torments, to be his Martyrs: But the mi≈øtake of tho≈øe Authors, ≈øeems to me to di≈øcover it ≈øelf, for he that has been quoted before, ≈øays in the 7th Chap. of his 1≈øt. Part, pa. 56. That Trigaltius te≈øtifies, that mo≈øt of the Chine≈øe interrogated the Devil, or Familiar Spirits, as they call'd a them, of which there are many among≈øt them, and that they e≈øteem it rather a Divine, than a Diabolical operation. I believe that 'tis the ≈øame with all the other Nations, woh are accu≈øed directly to adore the Devil, and am per≈øwaded, that if the thing were ≈øtrictly examined, it would be found, that they have not ≈øo much as a Notion of what we under≈øtand by the word Devil.

Sect. 6. For 'tis ea≈øie to conceive that tho≈øe that have not the ≈øame knowledge and ≈øentiments of God with us, cannot al≈øo have the ≈øame Ideas of the Devil, that the Chri≈øtians have, ≈øince he, that knows not God after the manner of the Chri≈øtians, cannot al≈øo know the Devil; and that is impo≈ø≈øible that any rational Creature ≈øhould know the Devil as he is, and adore him. For as to what is ≈øaid by the Apo≈øtle, concerning the Heathens, that they offer their ≈øacrifices to the Devils, 1 Cor. 10.20. 'Tis not expre≈øly ≈øaid to the Devil, as to the Chief of the wicked Angels, no more then in St. Matth. 25.41. But to him, as the Chief of the Demons, of which we have formerly ≈øpoken. And 'tis ob≈øervable, that the Greek word u≈øed by St. Paul, is not that of Devils but Demons, which is the name the Heathens gave to a ≈øort of inferior Gods, as has been already ≈øaid.
