After that Ob≈øervation, let us ≈øee what conformity may be found, betwixt the ≈øentiments of the Ancient Pagans, and that of the Modern Heathen, as to Spirits; we ≈øhall begin with Europe, thence proceed to A≈øia, and Africa, and at la≈øt, go over into America.

div.head: CHAP. VI. That this Conformity mu≈øt be ≈øought, 1≈øt, in the remains of Pagani≈øm in Europe.
div.p:
Sect. 1. IT has been already ≈øaid, that there are ≈øome Pagans in the extremity of Europe, e≈øpecially in the Northern parts, but they are ≈øo bruti≈øh and wild, that it is ea≈øier to ≈øee what they do, than to conceive or gue≈øs what they believe. They are Laplanders and Finlanders, e≈øpecially tho≈øe Swedi≈øh Dominion, with whom we are be≈øt acquainted, by a description drawn from the be≈øt Authors, which Scheffer has made in his Swedi≈øh Lapland; and therefore I ≈øhall declare as much as I judge convenient for my de≈øign; Fir≈øt, what he ≈øays of the≈øe, and afterwards what is added of the others; yet without giving credit to whatever is written, of which I ≈øcarce believe one halfe to be true. This however, is certain, that tho≈øe People, tho' under the Dominion of Chri≈øtian Princes, viz. tho≈øe of Swedeland, Denmark, and Mu≈øcovy, are as fond of their Pagan Super≈øtition, and continue as zealou≈øly, tho' ≈øecretly, their antient practi≈øes, as they have little knowledge of Chri≈øtianity, and inclination to embrace our Faith. In the mean while, Scheffer has made of late ≈øuch an accurate de≈øcription of Lapland, and upon ≈øuch certain information, that one may, methinks, ≈øurely relye upon what he ≈øays; and as he frequently intermixes in his Narrations, other Laplanders and Finlanders, it may be probably inferr'd that he e≈øteems them all very near alike in Belief and Wor≈øhip: which may be confirm'd by this rea≈øon, that what other Writers ≈øay
of tho≈øe other Nations, is pretty agreeable with what Scheffer relates of Swedi≈øh Lapland. And therefore I ≈øhall follow him only, tho' I ought not to ≈øay him only, ≈øince his Book contains whatever the others had written before him. Let us then Fir≈øt ‚Ä¢ ee, which are the ≈øentiments of tho≈øe Pagans, and afterwards we ≈øhall ≈øpeak of their Magick.

Sect. 2. The objects of their Wor≈øhip are divided into three ≈øorts, as into ≈øo many degrees: the mo≈øt ≈øublime are Thor, or Thordoen, which is properly the Thunder; Storjunkare or Stourra-pa≈ø≈øe, which ≈øignifie Holy and Great; and Baiwe, that is the Sun. The fir≈øt has al≈øo the name of Tiermes, which in the Laplandi≈øh Language, is as much as the noi≈øe of the Thunder, becau≈øe that God is believed to be the Ma≈øter of Thunder, and ≈øeems therefore to be their Jupiter. He is al≈øo named Aijeke, that is, Great Father. The Laplanders a≈øcribe co him an ab≈øolute Power over the Life and Death of Men, over their Health and Di≈øea≈øes, and over the wicked Demons, who live on the top of the Rocks, Mountains and Lakes. They believe that he re≈øtrains tho≈øe Demons, when they vex Men too much; that he cha≈øti≈øes them, that he ≈øometimes Thunder-≈øtrikes 'em, and puts 'em to death, e≈øteeming it to be the chief employment of the Thunder, as the eminent Latins imagin'd that Jupiter ca≈øt his Thunderbolt upon the wicked, and all other Criminals; for that purpo≈øe they give him a Bow, which they imagin'd to be the Iris or Rainbow, that he might dart his Arrows, wound and kill all the wicked Demons. They call in their Tongue the Iris, Aijeke dauge, the great Fathers Bow, that is, the Bow of the Good and Beneficent God, who pre≈øerves them as his Children, and defends them again≈øt the In≈øults of tho≈øe wicked Demons. They imagine that God has likewi≈øe a Hammer, which
they call Aijewetchera, with which he ≈øtrikes on the Neck of the Demons, and breaks their Head. Storjunkare, or Stourra-pa≈ø≈øe, which ≈øignifies the Governor of the Country, is among≈øt them as the Great Pan or as Diana, having the Country and Woods under his directions; Fi≈øhes and Birds are al≈øo at his di≈øpo≈øal, and all Anima ‚Ä¢ s and w ‚Ä¢ ld Bea≈øts, acknowledge his Empire, 'tis by him „Äà‚óä„Äâ they are happy in hunting, and without his leave they cannot catch any thing. True it is, that Aijeke or Tiermes governs Gods, Demons, and Men; but Storjunkare, in quality of Vicar of that God has the conduct of all tho≈øe other things. Barwe that ≈øignifies the Sun, as Paiwe does the Day, is adored by them for the good he does to the Earth, but they particularly venetrate him in Summer time, becau≈øe they always ≈øee him, that he has re≈øtored them his Light, di≈ø≈øipated their Darkne≈øs, brought Heat and expel'd Cold.

Sect. 3. The Manes of the Romans, mentioned before Chap. 2. Sect. 15. Are among the Laplanders Inferior Gods, which they call Sitte. They erect no Figures to their Honour, and content them≈øelves with offering Sarcifices to them; we find in no writing, what ≈øentiments they have of the power of tho≈øe Sitte, nor for what rea≈øon, they make them Offerings. The la≈øt ≈øort of tho≈øe Inferiour Gods, are the Juhles, or Inhlaforket, that are a Vagabond Crowd, whom they believe to wander in the Air, and through Fore≈øts and Mountains. But I find al≈øo, no where what good or hurt tho≈øe Spirits, may, in their Opinion procure to Men, only they believe them Inferior to the Sitte; however, they pay them al≈øo ≈øome Wor≈øhip, behind their Cottage, at a Bow ≈øhot di≈øtance, which Wor≈øhip ends in a ≈øuper≈øtitious Sacrifice. They con≈øecrate to them neither Images nor Statues, no more then to the Manes; they have likewi≈øe no Image of Bawe, or
the Sun, either becau≈øe he is vi≈øible him≈øelf, or becau≈øe the mo≈øt ≈øecret Science of their My≈øteries accounts him but one God, with Tiermes. There is but Ayeke and Storjunkar, who have Statues erected to their Honour, tho≈øe of Aijeke are of Wood, and tho≈øe of Storjunkare of Stone.

Sect. 4. 'Tis upon tho≈øe Opinions that their Divinations and Witchcraft are grounded, and hereupon I can't but make this ob≈øervation, that by reading Scheffer, and comparing what he fays of his own, with what he has collected from other Authors, it may ea≈øily be perceived, that the Witchcraft of the Northern Nations extends not ≈øo far as is commonly reported. But then we mu≈øt credit what Scheffer a≈ø≈øures us from his own experience, in the following words, Chap. 12. Tho the pre≈øent Laplanders do not frequently nor publickly exerci≈øe Magick, their Ance≈øtors having been more addicted to tho≈øe ≈øuper≈øtitions, of which mo≈øt of the modern Laplanders are free, and th√¥ the Country be purified of that ≈øort of Witchcraft, ever ≈øince the King of Sweden has forbidden, under grievous pains, to u≈øe Inchantments: yet there are ≈øtill a great number among≈øt them, who make it their whole ≈øtudy and employment. The cau≈øe of it is, that every one of the Laplanders is per≈øwaded, that Magick is indi≈øpen≈øably nece≈ø≈øary to him, that he may avoid the ≈ønares and in≈øults of his Enemies. To this he adds, That they kept Schools, in which Children are taught that Art, and that Parents are often their Tutors in it. That they exerci≈øe them in it, required their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and are pre≈øent at the performance of tho≈øe dete≈øtable practices. But what is yet more ≈øtrange, is, what this Author farther relates, That the Fathers bequeath, as an Inheritance to their Children, the, wicked Spirits that were in their Service, that by their help they may overcome the Demons of other Families, their Enemies.

Sect. 5. What they pretend to effect, by means of their Gods and Spirits, is to di≈øcover ≈øome things by Divination, and to operate ≈øome others by Witchcraft; for Divination, they make u≈øe of a Kannus, which is like a Drum, and mu≈øt be made of a particular Wood, and rather of Birch-tree than any other. There is a Skin, or Membrane, extended upon the Body of that Drum, wherein the Laplanders draw ≈øeveral Figures with a red colour made of the Bark of Alder-tree, brui≈øed and boyl'd; they beat it with an In≈øtrument like a Hammer, 6 Inches long but not bigger then the little Finger, not ≈øo much to make a noi≈øe, as to cau≈øe a bundel of Bra≈øs Rings, that lies upon it, to move, when that bundle begins to leap up they ob≈øerve the parts and Figures towards which it moves, and Divine by the Scituation, Motion, and re≈øt of the bundle, on the place which ≈øignifies the de≈øign they have form'd. The manner of this enquiry is not always the ≈øame, for they make u≈øe of ≈øeveral, different from one another, by tho≈øe means they di≈øcover, what pa≈ø≈øes in Foreign Countryes, how di≈øtant ≈øoever they may be; they know the good or bad ≈øucce≈øs of the Affairs they have undertaken, they cure Di≈øea≈øes, they find out what Sacrifices and Victims are mo≈øt plea≈øant to the Gods of the Land. The≈øe that de≈øire to know the State of their Friends or Enemies, living a Thou≈øand Miles from that place, have but to go to a Laplander, who di≈øcovers it this way. He ca≈øts him≈øelf upon the Ground, and becomes tike a Dead Man, and his Face altogether livid. He remains in that ≈øtate an hour or two, according as the Country, whence he will get News, is more or le≈øs di≈øtant, and when he awakes, he tells whatever pa≈ø≈øes in that Country, e≈øpecially as to what is enquired after. There are yet ≈øome other particulars, as to that way of Divining, gather'd from ≈øeveral Authors, but it would be too long, and even un≈øerviceable, to relate them.

Sect. 6. They have yet other ≈øorts of Witchcraft The Fir≈øt is, a Twi≈øted Cord with ≈øeveral knots, which they u≈øe to rai≈øe Winds on the Sea, ≈øo they do, as it were, ≈øell the Winds, and profer them to Merchants, that are detain'd on their Coa≈øts, by Tempe≈øts and contrary Winds, having agreed upon the price, and receiv'd it, they give him a ≈øtring with three Magical Knots, on which lies this Condition, that as ≈øoon as they have untyed the Fir≈øt, there ri≈øes a fre≈øh and plea≈øant Gale; when they have loo≈øed the Second, the Wind grows ≈øtronger, but when they have unty'd the Third, there ari≈øes ≈øuch a Tempe≈øtuous Storm, that they are no longer able to govern their Ship. This ≈øort of Trade is u≈øed, e≈øpecially in Finmarke, among≈øt the Dani≈øh Laplanders, becau≈øe the Neighborhood of the Sea afford them more occa≈øions of it, then any where el≈øe, But the account that Scheffer gives of their other ≈øorts of Witchcraft, ≈øhows that he him≈øelf gives little credit to it, They have little Magical Darts made of Lead, very ≈øhort, being no longer than ones Finger, they dart them to the remote≈øt place again≈øt their Enemies, of whom they de≈øire to avenge them≈øelves; and by that Witchcraft, they ≈øend upon them ≈øuch dangerous Di≈øea≈øes, with ≈øuch ≈øharp pains, that for the violence of them, they often Die within three Days. Thy have al≈øo a kind of Flyes call'd Gans, which they let out of their Ganeske, that is a Leaden Pur≈øe: And Daily ≈øend ≈øome of them to annoy and vex their Enemies. But we have not a perfect knowledge of whatever they practi≈øe on the≈øe occa≈øions. There are al≈øo ≈øome Laplanders, who for this purpo≈øe, make u≈øe of a Tyre, which is a round Ball, as big as a Walnut; it has a particular ≈øhape, as is de≈øcribed in Scheffer's relation, and it has al≈øo ≈øome motion. They ≈øell this Tyre, and the buyer may ≈øend it upon whom≈øoever he plea≈øes, he ≈øhall be mo≈øt cruelly tormented with it.

Sect 7, But enough of the Laplanders, let's now ≈øpeak of other Nations. Litgau ≈øays, that the Wild-Iri≈øh adore the Moon, as well for their own pre≈øervation, as for that of their Flocks, and that they direct to her this Prayer among≈øt others, Leave us as Healthfull, as thou finds us. Whence I infer, that they hold ≈øomething of the Ancient Pagani≈øm, that a≈øcribes a Divine Virtue to the Influence of the Stars, th√¥ it ≈øeems by this form of Prayer, that they attribute not to them, a full and Sovereign power, in the Admini≈øtration of the World.

Sect. 8. As for the remains of Pagani≈øm among≈øt the Samagites, a People ≈øcituated betwixt Lithuania and Livonia, we are taught, that they much Worship the Sun and Moon, the Fire, the Thunder, the Groves, and Trees exceedingly high; which ≈øhows that they go farther than the wild Iri≈øh, and believe that there are Demons in the Air, and upon Earth, that re≈øide in all tho≈øe objects. But it may be ≈øeen in Olaus Magnus, what account they them≈øelves make of the Gods of Thunder, and of the Spirits in the Air. For ≈øays he, they not only pretend to give ≈øuccors to their Gods in their quarrels they have with their Enemies, endeavouring to imitate the Thunder with the beating of Hammers, but are not afraid even of Fighting again≈øt them with Arrows and other Arms, they, ≈øhoot in the Air. There are al≈øo places in Lithuania, where the Inhabitants adore a, Dome≈øtick God, called Dinstipan, that is, The Director of the ≈ømoke or Chimneys.

Sect. 2. The Tartars Keremi≈ø≈øes, a People of Ea≈øtern Mo≈øcovy, believe according to Olearius, that there are malitious Spirits, who may at plea≈øure, cau≈øe ≈øeveral di≈øturbances and vexations to Men in this Life; for as to the future, they have no notion of it. To prevent tho≈øe pains, or turn off tho≈øe Spirits, they offer Sacrifices to them, near Rivers,
they likewi≈øe adore the Sun and Moon, becau≈øe they perceive much good is done to the Earth, by their Operations. But we find nothing con≈øiderable left in writing, as to their way of exerci≈øing Magick.

Sect. 10. The I≈ølanders have more relation to the Laplanders and Fuilanders, the greate≈øt knowledge we have of them, comes to us from the writings of Blefkenius, they al≈øo believe Dome≈øtick Spirits, who wake them in the Night, to go a Fi≈øhing, being per≈øwaded, that if one ≈øhould go thither without the Adverti≈øement of the≈øe Spirits, he could not make a happy Fi≈øhing. The ≈øame Ditmarus Blefkenius, ≈øailing from that Countrey to Portugal in 1633, received from one Jonas a Handkerchief, with three Knots, to be loo≈øed at Sea, in ca≈øe he wanted Wind. They u≈øe to make the≈øe Knots, ≈øoftly muttering ≈øome words, Be≈øides that they boa≈øt, that from the place where they ≈øtand upon the ground, they may cau≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels at Sea, to ≈øtop or to Sail on. But I ≈øhall yet keep by me for ≈øome time that Handkerchief and it's Knots, to try hereafter, how they may be unty'd; I ≈øhall al≈øo leave tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels at Sea, untill I examine what may ≈øtop or promote their Voyage. So that having nothing more to do with Europe, we ≈øhall go over to A≈øia.

div.head: CHAP. VII. That the ≈øame Sentiments are to be found among≈øt mo≈øt of the Nations of A≈øia.
div.p: Sect. 1. THE Inhabitants of A≈øia, as far as that Continent is known to us, are not ≈øo dull as the Northern Europeans. The Chine≈øe, Japanders, Siane≈øe, Peguans, tho≈øe Indians that are known from ancient times, and tho≈øe from the We≈øt of Bengala, ≈øurpa≈øs all the re≈øt in civility and ingenuity; but the Chine≈øe carry it before all other Nations. Let us allow them to explain their own Sentiments, and give us an account of their practi≈øes. We ≈øhall hear them unanimou≈øly grant, that to ≈øpeak properly, there is but one Divine Being, who≈øe virtue extends every where. However, when they came to con≈øider the various objects of the Divine Admini≈øtration, and his different effects. they divided the Government of the World, betwixt two Principal, and many Inferior Gods, as the Ancient Heathens, of whom we have ≈øpoken.

Sect. 2. Thus the Japanders have intru≈øted Chaca and Amida with the ≈øupream admini≈øtration of all things, and Tanconida, Benjamonda, Homocanda Zoiola, Pipi and Ji≈øus, with the particular directions of the Heavens, whither the la≈øt leads the Souls of the decea≈øed. The principle Sect among≈øt the Chine≈øe, is that which follows the Sentiments of Conr futius, who is e≈øteemed a great Saint among≈øt them. That Sect, ≈øays Carobius, in the words of Trigaltius, acknowledges and adores one only God, believing that he governs and keeps all things here below. They
al≈øo venerate the Spirits, but much le≈øs than that Deity; neither do they a≈øcribe to them ≈øo great a Power. All the≈øe People imagine a graduation from the Great Gods to the Inferior Gods, and from them to the Spirits; for the≈øe pretend that the Soveraign God, has ≈øet over the Heavens Laocon, that is, the Mini≈øter of the Great God, and upon the Inferior World Can≈øai, who has under him three Spirits, Tanduam, Teiquam, and T≈øuiquam: the fir≈øt of whom has the direction of the Air; the ≈øecond of the Earth, and the third of the Sea. Among≈øt the inferior Gods, who are very numerous, they reckon the Inventors of Arts, e≈øpecially Sichia, Quanina, and Neoma, a God and two Godde≈ø≈øes. Among≈øt the Tartars, tho≈øe of Sarmacande, who border on the Empire of the Great Mogul, are Mahometans. But among≈øt the others, particularly tho≈øe of Niuche, on whom the Empire of Chinais now depending. The Deity is likewi≈øe divided into two; the one is the God of Heaven, and the other of the Earth; but they make the condition of the fir≈øt, ≈øo high and ≈øublime, that it may be ea≈øily perceived, they acknowledge but one God indeed.

Sect. 3. The Peguans believe a Supream Deity, called Duma, who is Good, but admit al≈øo of a 2d, who is Bad, and for that rea≈øon is accounted to be the Devil by the Chri≈øtians. They e≈øteem be≈øides, that there are a great number of Gods, each of whom has his particular Office; the Chief are Carco vitas, the mo≈øt ancient of all, on whom the other depend, Oi≈ønna, the mover of all things, Apalita, the Leader of the Pilgrims, Fotoco their Interce≈ø≈øor by Duma, who e≈øpecially prays for the Souls of the decea≈øed, that are condemn'd to the darkne≈øs or the Gulf, in the Hou≈øe of Smoak. The Siamois acknowledge one God, who inhabits the Heavens, with
many other Gods inferior to him, among≈øt whom they place the decea≈øed, who have been their Lawgivers.

Sect. 4. Among≈øt the Inhabitants of Java, in which I≈øland is ≈øituated the City of Batavia, belonging to the Dutch Ea≈øt-India Company; ≈øome believe the Tran≈ømigration of Souls. The Cingalois in the I≈øle of Ceilon wor≈øhip four Gods, betwixt whom they believe the Goverment of the World to be divided; and withal, venerate the Souls of the decea≈øed, who≈øe Lives have been virtuous; ≈øo that both the one and the other, believe the exi≈øtence of Demons. But tho≈øe of the Javanois may be good or bad, whereas tho≈øe of the Cingalois can be but good.

Sect. 5. Tho≈øe that inhabit the North of the Cape Comorin, and reach to the Dominions of the Great Mogul, tho' they be much divided in their Sentiments; yet agree in this point, that there is a Supream Deity, called either Vi≈øtenau or E≈øuara, who, however Governs the world only by the Mini≈øtry of inferior Gods, of whom Brama, who is the Creator and Director of all things, is the Chief. Some ≈øay, that all the≈øe three depend upon T≈øechti, as upon the only Sovereign God. But after all, the difference is not ≈øo much in the thing as in the name. They all believe that Brama gives to Indre or Deuendre a Supream Authority, over 8 principal Directors of the Superior World, who they place higher than the Earth, and neverthele≈øs under Bramalocon, which is the abode of Brama. Of the≈øe eight, ≈øeven receive the Souls of the dying, who have led a good Life, and the eighth receives that of the Damned. They likewi≈øe believe that tho≈øe Gods have been begotten and married after the manner of Men; that they have ≈øometimes appeared upon Earthy, in a bodily ≈øhape, and that Vi≈øtenau
him≈øelf has been ≈øeen under more than ten Forms as Rogerius relates to have learned it from the mouth of a Bramine.

Sect. 6. Going farther Northward into the Kingdoms of Gu≈øuratte or Cambaie, Decan and Bengale, ≈øubject to the Great Mogul, you will find above four≈øcore Sects, among≈øt which there are four Principal, whereof one called Chevravac, hardly believes the exi≈øtence of one God: However taken together, they all confe≈øs that there is one, who pre≈øides over all the re≈øt, and on whom they all depend. Even that Sect, that will ≈øcarce believe the Exi≈øtence of Gods wor≈øhip. Tiel Tenquer, who is e≈øteemed a general Saint, ≈øhewing thereby that it is ea≈øier to for≈øake God with the Mouth, than with the Heart. The Sect named Samaraet con≈øtituted, under Permiseer their Soveraign‚ñ™ God, three other Gods, each of whom has a ≈øhare in the Government of the World. They ≈øay that Brama has power over all the Souls, and di≈øtributes them to Men and Bea≈øts, as he plea≈øes; that Baffiuna teaches Men the Commandments of Permi≈øeer, and provides with all things in this life, tho≈øe that are obedient to him; and that Mais calls to Judgment before Permi≈øeer, the Souls ≈øeparated from the Bodies, who ≈øends them according to their de≈øerts, into the Bodies of Men or Bea≈øts, to be afterwards with them purified of their Fits in a certain purging Fire. The Gentives in the Kingdom of Goleonda, believe al≈øo one only God, who has been from all Eternity; but in proce≈øs of time, has a≈ø≈øociated him≈øelf to ≈øome inferior Gods, cho≈øen from among≈øt Men; which notion is agreeable with the Semidii Indigetes, or Heros of the Ancient Romans.

Sect. 7. Tho≈øe Ancient Per≈øians who have remained in their Religion, ≈øince Mahometi≈øm has ≈øetled in their Country, de≈øerve to be taken notice of.
Some remained in Per≈øia, and live for the mo≈øt part at I≈øpuhum, the Capital of that Empire. Others have retired into the Indies, e≈øpecially into the Kingdom of Gu≈øuratte, where they are in great numbers. Here you have the belief of the people in the very words of Carolinus, extracted from de Laat, Varenius, and Tui≈øt, They believe that there is one God pre≈øent every where, who Governs all things a ‚Ä¢ plea≈øure, without needing the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of any one; tho' in the mean time he has ≈øeven Mini≈øters by him, almo≈øt of the ≈øame Dignity with him≈øelf, who have each their particular Office, of which they are accountable to him. The 1≈øt. is Hamalda, the Governour of Men. The 2d. is Baman, who has in≈øpection over the Bea≈øts, and the Creatures of the Sea. The 3d. is Ardi Be≈øt, who pre≈øerves Fire, and hinders it from going out. The 4th. is Sariuard, on whom Metals and Minerals depend. The 5th, is E≈øpendaar, who takes care le≈øt the Earth ≈øhould be fill'd with filthine≈øs, and grow wild; The 6th. is Arendaar, who has the direction of the Waters, and who takes care that they be not ≈øoiled with na≈øtine≈øs: The la≈øt is Amadaat, who has the in≈øpection of the Trees and Fruits of the Earth, and of Herbs. All the≈øe Gods are only In≈øpectors and Directors; it being not in their power to inflict death upon any thing, or to give it a new Life, for they are ≈øolely e≈øtabli≈øhed to give an account to the Sovereign God, and to inform again≈øt tho≈øe that have ill u≈øed, corrupted, or violated the things, that are under their keeping:

Sect. 8. Be≈øides tho≈øe 7 Mini≈øters, there are yet 26, of an inferior Order, each of which has his particular di≈øtrict. Sorach is the fir≈øt, who≈øe Office it quickly to bring the Souls ≈øeparated from the Bodies before their Judges, viz. Mees, Re≈øna and Saros. The 4th. is Beram Carra≈øedaats, who directs War at his plea≈øure. The 5th is the Sun. The 6th, is Anoa, who has dominion over the Waters. The 7th. is Ader, who is e≈øtabli≈øhed
over Fire. The 8th is Maho, who governs the Moon. The 9th. is Tiera, that is the Rains, 10th. Gos governs and pre≈øerves Cattle. 11. Tavardi takes care of the S ‚Ä¢ uls who are in Heaven. 12th. Aram brings Joy to t ‚Ä¢ e World, and bani≈øhes Pains and Sorrows from thence. 13th. Goada rules the Winds, tho' he be not the Wind him≈øelf. 14th. Dien gives to Nations information and under≈øtanding of the Laws, and inclination to keep them. 15. Apper≈øone affords Riches. 16th. A≈øtaat gives ∆≤nder≈øtanding and Memory. 17 th. A≈ø≈øamaan has the in≈øpection of Wares. 10. Gimninaat, has the conduct of the Earth. 19. Mari≈øipant is the God of Goodne≈øs, which he communicates to tho≈øe that have recour≈øe to him. 20. Armira is the director of Money. 21. Hoem is the Author of the conception of Women, and gives life to their Fruit. 22, 23. Dimnia and Ba≈øe are e≈øtabli≈øhed to ≈øuccor tho≈øe that ≈øtand in need of them. The three la≈øt, Befadeer, Defemeer and Defyn, ≈øtand by God to ≈øerve him, and are always ready to perform his Orders. The≈øe are the Names of tho≈øe 26 Mini≈øters, whom the Country men of Per≈øia honour with the Title of Ge≈øtio, or Saint, and whom they believe to have Authority and Power all the things that are under their direction: For which reason they al≈øo adore them, tru≈øting that they will be their Interce≈ø≈øors to God, and obtain from him whatever ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary for their good.

Sect. 9. Having thus ≈øufficiently ≈øpoken, as to the Gods, we'll now treat of the Spirits, tho' we find but little information upon this point in Authors, ≈øaving in what concerns China, and the Ea≈øt-Indies, on this ≈øide the River Ganges. I only find mention made, that the Japanders, in a place not farr from O≈øacca, venerate a God or Spirit, named Tiedebaie, le≈øt he ≈øhould hurt them, and that another God called Goquis, frequently appears to them in a humane Shape. In the Town of Micao. They
wor≈øhip in a Statue of a frightful Figure, another Spirit, to whom the Chri≈øtians give the name of King of the Devils. There is no Pagod in all Japan, ≈øaith Carolinus, which is ≈øo frequented, nor enriched with ≈øo great Pre≈øence, becau≈øe thereby they think to redeem their ≈øins.

Sect. 10. Martinius, Kircher, and Trigaltius, three Je≈øuits, have written large Hi≈øtories of China, but very little in≈øi≈øted upon this matter: However, con≈øidering what they ob≈øerve of the Wor≈øhip of that People, it may be concluded that they believe the exi≈øtence of Spirits, as we ≈øhall ≈øhow hereafter. The Siame≈øe likewi≈øe venerate ≈øome wicked Gods, though again≈øt the ≈øentiment of many of their Doctors, under pretence of charging tho≈øe bad Spirits of ≈øuch evils, of which they will not make God the Author. It is ≈øaid of the ≈øame Nation, that they give two Spirits to every Man, one of which makes them to be good, and the other evil.

Sect. 11. But the greate≈øt knowledge we have of the Opinions of tho≈øe Countries comes from the Coa≈øt of Choromandel. Carolinus, who has gatherd what Rogerius ≈øays of it in many places, ≈øays, That they believe good and bad Spirits, that is, Angels and Devels; They name the Angels Deuetas, and the Devils Rat≈øia≈øias: They hold that both were begotten by Men; and that their common Father was Ca≈ø≈øiopa, the fir≈øt Bramaine, or Prie≈øt and Legi≈ølator; The Mother of the Deuetas was Diti, and that of the Rat≈øia≈øias was Aditi; both Wives of Ca≈ø≈øiopa.

Sect. 12. There are two ≈øorts of Deuetas; For ≈øuch Men as go after their Decea≈øe into the Happine≈øs of the Worlds under the Sun, and above the Earth, are al≈øo called Deuetas, but tho≈øe places are not for them an eternal abode, ≈øince after the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of ≈øome Ages, they mu≈øt come back into the World, and be Born again. As to the other Deuetas, who are in great numbers,
they never depart from their Abode. The Sun, Moon and Stars are in that number, they a≈øcribe unto them both Soul and Life.

Sect. 13. The Rat≈øia≈øias are al≈øo of two ≈øorts, ≈øome of them are Wicked Men, who are condemn'd for their Sins to wander in the World, and to ≈øuffer Hunger and Thir≈øt, which they cannot ≈øatisfie but by the Alms that Men hand them: Wherefore they often appear in a human ≈øhape, to beg ≈øomething from them, but they have no power to hurt them. Be≈øides the≈øe, there is another ≈øort of Devils, or Rat≈øia≈øias, properly ≈øo called, becau≈øe they are the Children of Aditi, and are very Malitious. They have power to mole≈øt Men, and even to cau≈øe much trouble and vexation to the Angels, or Deuetas. They may walk every where, except ≈øave in the abode of Brama, and in the Heavens. They are de≈øcribed with huge, frightful, and ≈øtinking Bodies, they are ≈øaid to be Male and Female, to procreate Children, and to be ≈øubject to Death.

Sect. 14. There's enough concerning the Demons of the Pagans of A≈øia; but as mo≈øt of tho≈øe Nations are Pythagoreans, and believe the Metemp≈øycho≈øis, they al≈øo ≈øupply us with Heroes: For, (≈øays Baldaeius, in his Book of the Idolatry of the Ea≈øt Indies) the Modern Heathens believe that Man is happier in this Life than the Bea≈øts, by rea≈øon that he has a Body, by which the Soul may exert her Operation; but they agree not that a Man is more noble than a Beast; nor that he has a Soul more excellent than it has. And when they are ask'd, why Bea≈øts rea≈øon not, they an≈øwer, becau≈øe they have not Bodies capable of exerting the qualities of a Soul, as a Dumb Man who wants a proper Organ to utter Words, and may be neverthele≈øs very Wi≈øe; or as ≈øome People, who have a great deal of Knowledge and Learning, but have no more readine≈ø ‚Ä¢ to expre≈øs them≈øelves than Children who cannot do it.
He that ≈øhall Read this will be le≈øs surprised at what follows.

Sect. 15. Nothing certain can be ≈øaid of the Japanders, becau≈øe the Je≈øuits, who relate their Opinions, agree not together. It appears however, that there are among≈øt that People three ≈øorts of Opinions concerning human Souls, and their E≈ø≈øence. The fir≈øt is, That the Soul of Man differs not from that of Bea≈øts. The ≈øecond, That Men have a Soul of another Nature than that of Bea≈øts, but ≈øtill Mortal. The third, That the Soul is Immortal. They likewi≈øe believe the Metemp≈øycho≈øis, and that the Soul going out of the Body is determined to enter into another Body, either of Man or Bea≈øt, by the conjunction that is then made of the Sun and Moon with other Stars.

Sect. 16. The Chine≈øe are likewi≈øe Pythagoreans, Martinius te≈øtifies it very plainly, as to one of their Sects, in the≈øe Words. Chiquiao is a Sect, which our People e≈øteem to be the fir≈øt introduced in China, after the Birth of our Saviour. They believe the exchanges of Souls inwardly and outwardly. They Honour Images, and imagine that the Soul after Death pa≈ø≈øes in puni≈øhment of her Sins from one body into another; for which rea≈øon they ab≈øtain from what ever has had life. That Narration is confirmed by Trigaltius, who ≈øays, That the Parents are not afraid of killing their Children to be di≈øcharged of them, when they are incumbred with too many, a≈ø≈øerting, that by that means they procure them a better Condition; ≈øince in≈øtead of Poverty, they afford them by Death the occa≈øion of going into other Bodies, and being Born again in the Hou≈øe of Richer People, where they will live more at ea≈øe. The Peguans ≈øeem to have the ≈øame Sentiment by the Relation Piuto, when by the Tomb of their Rolym, or High-Prie≈øt, they let loo≈øe a great many Birds and Fi≈øhes, which they
kept Pri≈øoners, believing them to be as many human Souls, who will keep company to their Rolym in his way to the other World.

Be≈øides we read in Corolinus, out of Artus, in his Speculum Mundi, That the Wi≈øe Men of China have invented three places for tho≈øe that depart this Life. Nachac is a place of Torment; Schuum one of Delights, ≈øuch as the Paradi≈øe of Mahomet; and Miba, or Nibam, ≈øignifies an entire, privation of being, or a full De≈øtruction of Body and Soul. All the Souls have their abode in the two fir≈øt places, or depart from thence, to go to and fro through the World, and often pa≈øs from one Body into another by new Birth, until they de≈øerve. to enter into the Nibam, that is, to be annihilated. Le Blanc ≈øpeaks of it ≈øomewhat differently, in a Relation extracted from a Franci≈øcan Monk. He ≈øays, That the Chine≈øe believe that Men become Gods at la≈øt, after they have pa≈ø≈øed through the Bodies of ≈øeveral Bea≈øts, Birds, and Fi≈øhes; and that they imagine that the Souls, after the cour≈øe of many Ages, having been well purified in ≈øome proper places, and returned ≈øeveral times into new Worlds, are at last introduced into Paradi≈øe, ca≈øt down to Hell, or reduced to nothing.

Sect. 18. As to the Opinion of the Siame≈øe in this point, we mu≈øt learn it from the Relation of the Je≈øuits in their Journey to Siam, in the years 1685. and 1686. becau≈øe that Book is the newe≈øt and much credited. Thus then writes Tachard, p, 297, 298. Edit. Am≈øteled. Metemp≈øycho≈øis is one of the Fundamental Points of their Religion, ≈øo that the Life of Man pa≈ø≈øes in continual Tran≈ømigrations, untill he be ≈øanctified, and de≈øerves to be God. They admit of Spirits, but ≈øuch as are nothing el≈øe than Souls, who always inform ≈øome Bodies, until they have attained to Holine≈øs or Deity: Angels are Corporeal, and of different Sexes, and con≈øequently may beget Sons and Daughters. Tho≈øe Angels are never Sanctified nor Deified:
but to them only belongs to watch over the Government of the World, and the pre≈øervation of Men. They di≈øtribute them into ≈øeven Orders, or Hierarchies; ≈øome of which are more perfect and noble than the others; all which they place in as many different Heavens. Each part of the World has one of tho≈øe Intelligences to pre≈øide over what is done there. They likewi≈øe impart them to Stars, to the Earth, to Cities, Mountains and Fore≈øts, and even to the Winds and Rain. And becau≈øe they are per≈øwaded, that tho≈øe Angels examine the conduct of Men, and are witne≈ø≈øes of all their actions, to reward tho≈øe that are commendable, by vertue of the merits of their God; It is therefore to tho≈øe Intelligences and not to their God, that they u≈øe to apply them≈øelves in their nece≈ø≈øities and mi≈øeries, and to thank them for the favours they ≈øuppo≈øe to have received from them.

Sect. 19. They acknowledge no other Demons but the Souls of the wicked, who making their e≈øcape out of the Hell, in which they were detained; wander through the World a certain time, and do as much hurt to Men as they can. Among≈øt tho≈øe unhappy Spirits, they rank untimely Births, Women dying in Childbed, tho≈øe that are killed in a Duel, or guilty of ≈øome crime of that nature.

Sect. 20. The Heathens of Java believe likewi≈øe Metemp≈øycho≈øis, as well as tho≈øe of Sumatra, the Malabars, and the Inhabitants of the Coa≈øt of Cormandel. All the Benjanes in the hither Ea≈øt-Indies, agree upon no Article of Religion, better than upon this. Mo≈øt of the Bramines, that are not engaged in any of the≈øe two Sects Schaaruakka and Pa≈øenda, admit the immortality of human Souls, and ≈øay that there are ≈øome, who being ≈øeparated from the Bodies become Devils, becau≈øe of their ≈øins; and that the time of their fir≈øt puni≈øhment being fini≈øhed, they mu≈øt wander in the Air, and there induce an intolerable Hunger, it being impo≈ø≈øible
for them to draw ≈øo much as the Leaf of an Herb, or to ≈øupply their wants with any other thing, be≈øides what Men be≈øtow upon them in Charity. I had mention'd that Opinion, ≈øpeaking of the Rat≈øia≈øias.

Sect. 21. In a word, when we gather all the Ob≈øervations made in this Chapter, and before it, to di≈øcover the Opinions of the Heathens; we find that, tho' all their Super≈øtitions be grounded upon very different Cau≈øes; yet they all tend in the main to the ≈øame ≈øcope, that is, to wor≈øhip one ≈øole Object, as the Supream Deity, and yet to a≈ø≈øociate Spirits to him. I cannot better expre≈øs that Thought, than by the very words of Carolinus, which, are as a re-capitulation of what has hitherto been ≈øaid. Some e≈øteem, ≈øays he, that the Souls are mortal, others e≈øteem them immortal; ≈øome e≈øtabli≈øh rhe tran≈ømigration of Souls, others are not of that Opinion: and how much differ tho≈øe that a≈ø≈øert the Metemp≈øycho≈øis between them≈øelves; ≈øome, as tho≈øe of Java believe, that the Soul goes into the fir≈øt Body ≈øhe meets with; others believe that ≈øhe is ≈øent into ≈øuch or ≈øuch Body, according as ≈øhe has merited by the good or evil ≈øhe has done, which is the Opinion of the Banjanes. Some affirm, that the Souls change their abode but once, others three times, and others teach a va≈øt number of Tran≈ømigrations; others make them pa≈øs only into Men, who mu≈øt al≈øo be ≈øtrangers; others again ≈øend them into Man and Bea≈øts; but others at la≈øt make them pa≈øs only in the Females of Men and Bea≈øts; which is the imagination of the Thearauachs; others have yet quite different Opinions. In a word, it may be rightly ≈øaid upon this ≈øubject, Many Men many Minds; for there are almo≈øt as many Opinions as Per≈øons.

div.head: CHAP, VIII. That the Witchcraft practi≈øed amongst the People, proceeds from the ≈øame ≈øource.
div.p: Sect. 8. AS the name of Withcraft is given to whatever is ≈øuppo≈øed to be done by the help of the Devil; I cannot but judge that many per≈øons are called Sorcerers and Witches, who perhaps are not ≈øo, and that this mu≈øt be a≈øcribed to the ≈øame prejudice, which I have mentioned before, ≈øpeaking of the wor≈øhip of Demons. And therefore I intend to examine hereafter, what the≈øe People really are. It is ≈øufficient to adverti≈øe here before hand, that all the Heathens mu≈øt not be taken for Magicians, Sorcerers, and Inchanters; becau≈øe many Writers have called them by ≈øuch names, giving them indifferently in their Writings to all the He and She Prie≈øts, and to all tho≈øe who di≈øcharge any Office, Mini≈øtry, or employment in their Religious Wor≈øhip, and in their Sacrifices. But I de≈øign to in≈øert in this pre≈øent Chapter, whatever is known to us of their practices, or of their communications with any of the inferior Gods or Spirits, good or bad.

Sect. 2. The veneration which that People have for the Sun, Moon and Stars, is ≈øufficient to e≈øtabli≈øh the choice of Days among≈øt them: whence proceeds wha ‚Ä¢
Pete ‚Ä¢ Vaudenbrook has ob≈øerved, ≈øpeaking of the Benjanes of Nar≈øinga. That as to happy and unhappy ‚Ä¢ ours they judge of them by the cour≈øe of the Stars, w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ he ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e with great nicety. Trigaltius in „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Chap. ‚Ä¢ 9, ≈øays, that there is no Su ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ in China, as that of ob≈øerving
the Fea≈øt and Working days, and that they rule the whole conduct of their Lives, upon the di≈øpo≈øition of Time. To that end there are Printed every year two ≈øorts of Almanacks made in the Emperor's name by his own A≈øtrologers, which contributes to ≈øet off this delu≈øion for a Truth: there is marked every day what is good to be done, or not to be done, and to what hour mu≈øt be deferr'd, what offers it ≈øelf in the intervals of the fortunate, or unlucky moments.

Sect. 2. Carolinus has, methinks, made a good Abridgment of what follows in Trigaltius, which therefore I intend to make u≈øe of. There are other Books, ≈øays he, be≈øides tho≈øe that more particularly treat of this matter, and even, there's a ≈øort of Teachers, which only ≈øub≈øi≈øt from what they get in pre≈øcribing happy Days and Hours to the Queri≈øts, th√¥ they have but a ≈ømall reward for it. They are ≈øo much bewitcht with tho≈øe predictions, that they often deferr an importunate Affair, or a long and dangerous Journey, till they have found out a Day or Hour of good Omen. And th√¥ it ≈øometimes happens, that at that Day or Hour, there falls a great Rain, or a contrary Wind blows, yet for all that, they begin the undertaking or journey in their perfixed time, ≈øhould they only proceed 4 ≈øteps, or dig out but a Basket full of Earth from the place where they intend to lay the Foundation of a Hou≈øe. That was al≈øo the employment of tho≈øe that were Anciently called A≈øtrologers and Mathematicians, of whom we have ≈øpoken before.

Sect. 4. They are no le≈øs ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly curious, in ob≈øerving the time of the Birth, to foretel the condition of the whole cour≈øe of ones Life. Tho≈øe calculators of ones Nativity, are the ≈øame with the Ancient Genethliaci before mentioned, Chap. 3. Sect. 4. There are many other Diviners, who boa≈øt of foreteling future things by the Ob≈øervation of the Stars, by the in≈øpection of the Face, by the Dreams, by the po≈øture of the enquirer, by
his manner of ≈øitting or ≈øtanding, and this ≈øort of Men are in great e≈øteem among≈øt the vulgar.

Sect 5. Rogerius gives a larger account of what has been ≈øaid, concerning the choice of Days, among≈øt the Chine≈øe, which is likewi≈øe practi≈øed among≈øt other Nations, as e≈øpecially the Inhabitants of the Coa≈øt of Coromandel, where they u≈øe Almanacks, like tho≈øe of China; and call them Paniangam. That Author ≈øays, That they are two ≈øorts; one, that ≈øhows what mu≈øt be done, and the other, what mu≈øt be laid a≈øide at every Hour of the Day of the Week, and what ≈øhall ≈øucceed or not. For a Specimen of it, he relates the predictions of Sunday, from Hour to Hour. They reckon in that Country 30 Hours, betwixt the Ri≈øing and Setting of the Sun.

Sect. 6. That Super≈øtition has proceeded ≈øo far as to have ≈øtained an Art very commendable in it ≈øelf, and one of the liberal Arts. For, according to the Relation of Daviti, extracted from O≈øorius, the Malabars, who u≈øe to begin their Year with the Month of September, have recour≈øe to Super≈øtitious Ob≈øervations, in Order to mark the Fir≈øt Day and Hour of it. That Day all tho≈øe that are above the Age of 15, cover their Eyes and Face, that they may ≈øee nothing, and cau≈øe them≈øelves to be brought into the Pagodes of their Idols, where they pre≈øently uncover their Faces, and quickly ca≈øt their Eyes upon the Fir≈øt Object before them. If it happens to be the Statute of ≈øome Idol, for which they have a particular Veneration, they fancy they ≈øhall pa≈øs the Year mo≈øt happily.

Sect 7. Tho≈øe that ob≈øerve the cry of Birds, have a very great relation with the Malabars, and
agree with them almo≈øt in the ≈øame things; for Carolinus ≈øays after Rogerins, that they ob≈øerve what ≈øort of Birds flie near them, and to what part, whence they draw a favourable or ≈øini≈øter Augury. They ≈øay that when a A≈øh-coloured Crow, whereof there are great numbers upon the Coa≈øt, comes to touch ≈øome body in flying, it forebodes very ill. viz. that he that has been touched or ≈øome of his Friends, ≈øhall Die within 6 Weeks. Lin≈øchoten gives very near the ≈øame account of the Decanins, and the Inhabitants of Guru≈øatte, ≈øaying, that if the Fir≈øt Object they ≈øee in the Morning is an A≈øh-coloured Crow, they will not go out of their Hou≈øe for any thing.

Sect. 8. Daviti ≈øays after Mendoze, that the Heathens of the I≈ølands, called by the Spaniards Philippines, have ≈øome ≈øhe Diviners named Holaoi, whom they honour as Prie≈øts, Who conver≈øe daily with the Demons, (at lea≈øt in his Opinion,) and that they publickly before all the People, make ≈øtrange po≈øtures, and a horrid noi≈øe, during which, the Spirit of Divination ≈øeizes upon them, and gives by them an≈øwer to whatever is asked. The ≈øame Author adds, that they have a particular ≈øort of Divination, in which if they meet a Cayman in their way, they return home. Whence appears, that they e≈øteem that meeting unfortunate.

Sect. 9. Be≈øides that, all ≈øorts of pre≈øages are in credit among≈øt tho≈øe Nations, who draw them from whatever offers it ≈øelf to them. If any body ≈øneezes before them when they go out, of their Hou≈øe, they pre≈øently ≈øtep in again, for they e≈øteem it a very bad Omen. Peter Vandenbroek affirms the ≈øame of the Inhabitants of Nar≈øinga, and adds, that when they go out in the Morning, if they meet with ≈øome bad Augury, they return back, or ≈øtay till a more favourable offers it ≈øelf. We read in Carolinus, which are according to them, good or bad Signs, which he has tran≈øcribed out of Tuisk, and
Vandenbroek. Here they are. Be≈øides ≈øneezing and flight of Birds, there are ≈øeveral others ill pregages; as an empty Cart, a Dog who has nothing to Eat, a Buffle, an A≈øs, a Guilded-he-Goat, an Ape, a loosen'd Hart, a Gold≈ømith, a Carpenter, a Barber, a Taylor, a Cotton-Merchant, a Farrier, a Weaver, a She-Widow, a Dead body, all People coming from a Burying, before they be wa≈øhed, and having changed their Dre≈øs. 'Tis al≈øo an ill Augury to meet with one that carryes Butter, Milk, or brown Sugar, or ≈øour things, as Apples and Lemmons, or one that carries Fire, and any thing u≈øed in War. But 'tis a good Omen to meet with an Elephant a Cammel either Loaden or ∆≤nloaden, a Hor≈øe better ∆≤nloaden than Loaden, a Cow, an Ox, a Buff Loaden with Water, for ∆≤nloaden it forebodes nothing but Ill; a He-gcat, a Dog Eating, a Cat on the Right Hand; likewi≈øe to meet one carrying Meat, Curds or white-Sugar, a Cock, an ∆≤nicorn running ≈øtrait out in the way, and a Hundred things of that Nature are e≈øteemed ≈øo fortunate by them, that they boldly pur≈øue their way with hopes of a good Fortune. Tereira adds, that they believe it a very ill thing, and even a Sin to Eat before Sun-≈øet.

Sect 10. This is what I emended to relate as to Divination, upon which point, and e≈øpecially upon Witchcraft: I am ≈øurprized to find ≈øo little in the writings of ≈øo many Authors, whom I have con≈øulted with great exactne≈øs; neither do I remember to have learned any thing more particular in the Conver≈øations I have had with Gentlemen that have made long Journeys into the Ea≈øtern Countryes; but I wonder mo≈øt of all, that Baldaeus, who≈øe chief ≈øcope in his writings, is to treat of the Idolatry of the Ea≈øtern Countryes, makes almo≈øt no mention of it. The only thing I find in him, concerns the Conjuration of Serpents. The Inhabitants, ≈øays he, of the Coa≈øt of Coromandel, and ≈øome of the Cingale≈øe and
Malabars, know how to Enchant Serpents; ≈øo that by their Songs, they make them Dance, which is ≈øtrange and wonderful. When they require the Oath of any Per≈øon, they put his Hand in a Pot, where there is a Serpent; if he be not wounded, they hold his Oath to be true, but if he be bitten, they believe him Perjur'd. Peirard adds to this, that they Conjure the greate≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øubtle Snakes not to be hurt by them, and Baldaeus reports the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. IX. That the Opinions and Practices of the African Heathens, agree at bottom with the Sentiments and Cu≈øtoms of the other Pagans.
div.p: Sect. 1. THE Heathens of Africa being duller than the others, becau≈øe the Men of Letters, are mo≈øt or all Mahometans, we can have little knowledge of their Opinions, unle≈øs it be by their practices. From them only, we may infer their belief, as to die matter in hand: and th√¥ Travellers have left us but few Ob≈øervations, I ≈øhall neverthele≈øs examine them two ways, to know what ≈øort of Creatures are e≈øteem'd and wor≈øhiped as Divine, by tho≈øe Nations, and afterwards what ≈øorts of Divination and Witchcraft are in u≈øe among≈øt them. Among≈øt the be≈øt writers, none have given more Information than Carolinus, whom therefore I ≈øhall take for my leader; but add to his Narration, what I ≈øhall think convenient out of other Authors in proper places.

Sect. 2. Tho≈øe Africans, that without living under the Law of Chri≈øt, or that of Mahomet, having neverthele≈øs ≈øome knowledge of God di≈øtribute the
Deity among≈øt ≈øeveral Creatures, as do all other Heathens. They give the fir≈øt ≈øhare to the mo≈øt vi≈øible and ≈øhining, as the Cele≈øtial Lamps, which they look upon as Lights placed in Heaven, by the Sovereign Creator, for a proof of his Eternal Power and Deity. The Inhabitants of D ‚Ä¢ mute, a Country lying very near the Equinoctial L ‚Ä¢ ne, tho≈øe that live under the Dominion of the Great Negus, and tho≈øe of Ballagata in the Kingdom of Monopotapa, have time out of mind adored the Ri≈øing Sun. Tho≈øe of the Kingdom of M ‚Ä¢ ngibur, Subjects to the Great Negus, render him the ≈øame, wor≈øhip, and hold him for the Creator him≈øelf. Tho≈øe of Suarim, capital of the Kingdom of Morat under the ≈øame Empire, have the ≈øame Faith. But they ≈øay, according to the relation of le Blanc‚ñ™ that Heaven is only for the Gods, by which they ≈øhow, that they acknowledge other Gods, who are doubtle≈øs inferior to, and in le≈øs credit than the Sun. Tho≈øe of Songo, in the Kingdom of Congo, look on the Sun and Moon as Husband and Wife; and as the Fir≈øt and Second God. They adore the Earth, as the Mother of all things. They wor≈øhip likewi≈øe ≈øome Birds, particular to the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Country, and as it ≈øeems what ever comes into th ‚Ä¢ ir fancy.

Sect. 3. When tho≈øe of Jaloffe in Guinea di≈øcover the Moon, they adore her with great Cries. They have the ≈øame Cu≈øtom at Mandimanca in the ≈øame Country, where the Moon is named Bariomari, or the Godde≈øs of the Night. Daviti ≈øays, that the Berbe≈øeins, in the Kingdoms of Ale and Brocale, wor≈øhip her at the foot of certain Trees. But other People of Guinea, make even of certain Trees and Herbs, their Feti≈ø≈øos or Gods. They wor≈øhip the ≈øpeckled Starry-Hern, as a Divine Bird. Among≈øt the Fi≈øhes they venerate the Tunny as Feti≈ø≈øos, and put them
before the Emperadors or Emperor's Fi≈øhes, which they venture to Fi≈øh, but not to Eat, until they have cut off their Sword, which being dry, becomes then a Feti≈ø≈øo too. When it Lightens or Thunders upon very high Mountains, fear makes them believe, that tho≈øe Mountains are likewi≈øe Feti≈ø≈øos. The Lybians, divided into 4 Nations, do all agree, that there is a particular virtue and even Deity in Garlick. Some Inhabitants of Capo Verde wor≈øhip the Moon and others the God Conculi, becau≈øe of his Malice.

Sect. 4. Few among them believe the Mortality of the Soul, or if they do, their Faith is attended with many doubts, and mix'd with the Opinion of the Metemp≈øycho≈øis; ≈øo far the Sect of Pythagoras reaches. The Inhabitants of Mongibur in Ethiopia, make a favourable reception to ≈øtrangers, provided they be no Chri≈øtians, who they e≈øteem le≈øs than others. The cau≈øe of that kind reception is, that they imagine the Souls of their Relations or Friends may be pa≈ø≈øed into tho≈øe Per≈øons. They admit pains and puni≈øhment during this Life, but without any larger explication of it. In Guinea, the Hollanders were told in 1600, that the belief of the Country was‚ñ™ that the Souls of the Decea≈øed came again upon Earth, and that they took from Hou≈øes, what they ≈øtood in need of; ≈øo that when they have ≈øu≈øtained ≈øome lo≈øs, they ea≈øily ≈øu≈øpect, that tho≈øe Spirits have taken it away. The Inhabitants of Capo Verde imagine, that after their Death, they are transform'd into white Men, and in that State come to dwell upon Earth.

Sect. 5. I find no other particular Ob≈øervation on the ≈øentiments of tho≈øe Nations, and much le≈øs upon their practices. In the mean while, what may be learned of it, ≈øufficiently ≈øhows, that they proceed from the ≈øame Original with the others; they have very near the ≈øame Gods and the ≈øame Oracles,
which they get from their Gods by the ≈øame means, viz. Divination and Witchcraft. In The new Hi≈øtory of the Aby≈ø≈øines, by Ludolf, may be ≈øeen, how the Inhabitants of the Kingdom of Zendero, have them≈øelves in the Election of a King. He is cho≈øen from the greate≈øt Men of the Kingdom, who go together in a Wood, whither they expect the flight of a certain Bird, that nearks by his Cry, who is to be their new Prince; As they have a great Inclination to Witchcraft, the new Prince gives immediatly a proof of his Proficiency in that Art; for as ≈øoon as by his Conjurations, he has Notice of his choice, he draws by the ≈øame virtue, Lyons, Tygers, Vipers, and Dragons about him, and in the middle of that ≈øtately Pomp, he is received by all the great ones of his Kingdom, who go to meet him. This is what that Author relates, and the pure Truth in his Judgment; but we ≈øhall examine hereafter, what virtue ≈øuch a Witchcraft may have.

Sest. 6. The Inhabitants of the Kingdom of Baiafar, on the Ea≈øt of that Benin, are accu≈øed to be the greate≈øt Magicians in the World, becau≈øe they boa≈øt of obtaining Rain, and cau≈øing Thunder and Lighting, whenever they plea≈øe, and even of effecting all they de≈øire. The Brames in the Kingdom of Loango know how to hinder, by their Inchantments, the Fruits of the Earth from being taken away by Thieves, who are in great numbers among≈øt them, and yet not ≈øo bold as to touch any thing; where there is a Basket with a pair of Goats Horns, Parrots Feathers, and other trifles of Nature, becau≈øe they are con≈øecrated to their God Magu≈øchi, otherwi≈øe Moqui≈øche, or Mohilo, of whom however Daviti has no rea≈øon to believe, that he is the Devil.

Sect. 7. When tho≈øe of Guinea, meet not with a happy Fi≈øhing, they compel their Gods with their Conjurations, to drive Fi≈øh into their Nets, which is done by the frightful noi≈øe of the Feti≈ø≈øeres, who
are their Prie≈øts Wives, or by branches of Trees hanging about their Neck, ≈øuppo≈øing tho≈øe Trees to have a Divine virtue, as has been ob≈øerved; or by the beating of Drums, or by ≈øome words that the Feti≈ø≈øero, or Prie≈øt mutters, as grumbling again≈øt his Wife, or by ≈øome Corn, or other matters, variou≈øly Painted, and thrown into the Sea. If the King happen to have occa≈øion for Money, and impatiently de≈øires to know, whether there are Merchants in the way from whom he may hope to get an Advantage, the Feti≈ø≈øero goes with his Wives to interrogate a Tree thereupon, at fir≈øt he makes a great many po≈øtures, then offers Sacrifices, u≈øes A≈øhes, the branch of a Tree cut on purpo≈øe, Water drawn ≈øucking from a Bea≈øon into his Mouth, wherewith he be≈øprinkles the ≈øaid branch, then he ≈øays ≈øome words to his Wives, upon whom he likewi≈øe makes a≈øper≈øion; afterwards he pronounces the que≈øtions aloud; then there is heard, without ≈øeeing any thing, a Voice an≈øwering, which ≈øometimes manife≈øts it ≈øelf under the ≈øhape of a Dog, but that's only practi≈øed for things that concern this Life, e≈øpecially for the Kings pro≈øperity.

Sect. 8. But they u≈øe another ≈øort of Witchraft either for the King or the Subjects, to obtain a good condition in the future Life. When any body comes to Die, they chu≈øe a new Feti≈ø≈øo for that time, whom they intreat to conduct the Soul of the Decea≈øed into the other World. The neare≈øt Relations come together, kill a Hen, and dre≈øs her, then they di≈øpo≈øe all the Feti≈ø≈øos or Idols of the Decea≈øed upon a Line, hang about them ≈øeveral collars of Peas and Beans, adorn them with many Garlands of green Herbs, and be≈øprinkle them with the blood of the Hen. That's the Duty of the Men. That of the Women, con≈øi≈øts in bringing the dre≈øs'd Hen in a Di≈øh, and placing her in the, middle of the Feti≈ø≈øos, thnn one of the Men begins his Conjurations, by drinking
and throwing a mouthful of Water, or palm Wine upon the Feti≈ø≈øos. He takes 2 or 3 leaves of tho≈øe Garlands, which he rakes up, and makes a little round Ball of it, he puts it between his 2 Fingers, and many times betwixt his Feet or Toes, whence he draws it out, greeting the Feti≈ø≈øos as many times; when he has ≈øquezed all the moysture out of that green Ball upon his Gods, he makes another, and then another, till all the Garlands be ≈øpent, then out of all the≈øe little Balls, he makes one, with which he rubs his Face, which rai≈øes it to the dignity of a Feti≈ø≈øo, and cau≈øes it to be kept as an excellent pre≈øervative again≈øt all ≈øorts of Evils, and a certain ≈øuccour in the War. Thus they pretend to bring the Dead to a quiet State.

Sect. 9. They al≈øo u≈øe Birds in their Divinations, viz. The ≈øpeckled Hern, becau≈øe (≈øays Carolinus, who has ≈øupplyed us with the former Narration,) it lows as much as an Ox, when it ≈øticks it bill into the ground When they undertake to Travel, and hear it crying, they extreamly rejoyce, ≈øaying that the Feti≈ø≈øo comes to promi≈øe them a happy journey. They put Corn and a Ve≈ø≈øel full of Water, near the place where they have heard the cry, that the Feti≈ø≈øo may find Meat and Drink, thence proceed that many of tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels with Mays, Rice, and other grains, are to be found every where in the Woods and Fields. But enough of the Pagans of Africa, let us go over to tho≈øe of America.

div.head: CHAP. X. That very near the ≈øame Opinions and Practices, are to be found in America.
div.p: Sect. 1. THE Chri≈øtians keep under their Dominion the greate≈øt part of what has been di≈øcovered of the We≈øtern Continent, which is known only, ≈øince 200 Years, and commonly called America or We≈øt-Indies. They keep down the pulick Idolatry and Witchcraft of the Inhabitants, as far as their Authority will extend. But as tho≈øe Nations are Heathens at the bottom, and live to it, whenever they are at liberty, privatly continuing their Ancient practices. I ≈øhall therefore ≈øpeak of them, as they are in them≈øelves, to ≈øhow their true ≈øentiments, and Ancient Cu≈øtoms: for that end, I ≈øhall make u≈øe of the newe≈øt Authors, who have publi≈øhed Relations of the Southern parts of that Country, whom Montanus has compiled, and when I come to the Northern parts, I ≈øhall abound with In≈øtructions newer and very much credited.

Sect. 2. In Southern America, which is the neare≈øt to Africa, Brazile is the fir≈øt County to be met with in the North-Ea≈øt, and Peru over again≈øt it to the We≈øt.
