Sect. 26. The Inhabitants of Virginia hold al≈øo Okea for the ≈øupream God, th√¥ they confe≈øs the God of the Chri≈øtians to be above him; becau≈øe the Chri≈øtians can do more Execution with their Guns, than they with their Bows and Arrows; for their Religion, and that of the mo≈øt part of the Neighboring Nations is all turned to the War, and to obtain a happy ≈øucce≈øs of it. A Coun≈øellor of one of their Kings being in England in King James the Fir≈øt time, ≈øays, That Okea often appears in his Pagode, whereupon 4 Prie≈øts enter into it, uttering ≈øtrange Words, and making Ge≈øtures and Po≈øtures no le≈øs ≈øurprizing, The≈øe call others again, whom they cau≈øe to come in, after the ≈øame manner, and the God declares his Will to them, ∆≤pon this Declaration, they take their mea≈øures in all their Affairs, either journey or any thing el≈øe. If they de≈øire to go a Hunting, he preci≈øely teaches them, where the Bea≈øt will be found; they receive his Advices with great ≈øatisfaction, and never fail to follow them, which often ≈øucceeds, He appears to them in the ≈øhape of a comly Indian, and after he has ≈øhewed him≈øelf for ≈øome time to his 12 Confederates, he goes up into the Air whence he came.

Sect. 27. The ≈øame Author gives us the ≈øentiments of the Inhabitants of Carolina, which is part of Florida, bordering upon Virginia, as we have heard him before, relating tho≈øe of the Inhabitants of the I≈øland St. Vincent. They likewi≈øe hold Okea to be the Supream God. Good and bad Spirits are look'd upon to be inferior Gods, and they offer Sacrifices to the lea≈øt, as well as to the greate≈øt Gods. They al≈øo believe the Tran≈ømigration of Souls, and when any body dies, they bury with him ≈øufficient provi≈øion for his maintenance, and all ≈øorts of Cloaths for his u≈øe, when he ≈øhall be in the Ely≈øian Fields, which they fancy
to be beyond the Indian Sea. The Author gives the name of Ely≈øian Fields to the places he de≈øcribes, becau≈øe of the Relation he has found betwixt them and tho≈øe the Greeks have call'd by that name.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Where all the Sentiments and Practices of ≈øo many different Heathens, are u≈øefully compared together.
div.p:
Sect. 1 HItherto, we have but gather'd the various Opinions of the Antient and Modern Pagans, and related their Cu≈øtoms without pa≈ø≈øing any Judgment upon them, neither is it time to do it as yet; we mu≈øt fir≈øt ≈øee of what u≈øe it may prove to be informed of all the≈øe things: to which end we mu≈øt again con≈øider together, what has been hitherto related, to ≈øee what will be the re≈øult of it. On the one ≈øide, we find that Nations, that extreamly differ in the Opinions they have concerning the Gods and the Spirits; yet on the other ≈øide, they wonderfully agree upon the ≈øame ≈øubject. They differ in the Names they give them, which is not ≈øtrange, the Tongues being ≈øo different, and all the Nations not a≈øcribing the ≈øame properties to Spiritual Beings. Thence proceeds a ≈øecond difference, that they make not their number equal, nor di≈øtingui≈øh them in the ≈øame manner, as to their Dignity and Admini≈øtration, or as to their Operations, as it has particularly been ≈øhewn in the 2 Chap. Sect. 21. concerning the Inhabitants of A≈øia. But the difference to be found among≈øt them is not material, and mu≈øt be accounted as incon≈øiderable, comparatively to the conformity that
is betwixt them all, that looks as a work to which they ≈øhould unanimou≈øly have con≈øpired.

Sect. 2. Whatever has been hitherto quoted; is either collected from the Writings of the Pagans, or taken from what pa≈ø≈øes among≈øt them, and relates partly to their Sentiments, partly to their Practices. They agree in their Sentiments in two re≈øpects; as their under≈øtanding is yet in ≈øome manner illuminated by the natural Light, or as it is darkned by error. I ≈øhall mark both the≈øe conformities, and at the ≈øame time, the places in which they have been before related, where the in≈øtances are to be found: becau≈øe it would be too long and tedious to repeat them every time, and that I may hope the Reader will take the trouble to look them over, or being all fre≈øh in his memory, he will excu≈øe me from an unnece≈ø≈øary trouble.

Sect. 3. As to the fir≈øt conformity, if we attentively reflect upon ≈øo many in≈øtances and te≈øtimonies as are contained in the 2d, 5th, 6th, 8th, 9th and 10th. Chapt. We ≈øhall perceive, that tho≈øe, that are lea≈øt provided with human Light and Rea≈øon, agree neverthele≈øs upon the mo≈øt important points, referring the Reader to the places where the In≈øtances are ≈øet down. All the Heathens therefore, whether Ancient or Modern Europeans, A≈øiatick, Africans, North and South Americans agree in the≈øe five principal points, which are of an undeniable Truth.
1. That there is only a fir≈øt Being, or a Supream Divinity. Chap. 2. Sect. 3. Chap. 7, Sect. 1, 2, 3, 5, 7. Chap. 10. Sect. 6, 11, 16, 24, 27.
2. That there are Spirits, who have had a beginning, and that they are di≈øtingui≈øhed from humane Souls: Chap. 1. Sect. 2, 9, 10, 11. Chap. 7. Sect. 2, 9, 12, 18. Chap. 10. Sect. 3, 13.
3. That tho≈øe Spirits are either good or bad, ≈øome Friends and others Enemies to Mankind: Chap. 2. Sect. 11, 15. Chap. 7. Sect. 9, 10. Chap. 10. Sect. 5, 13, 14, 27.
14. That humane Souls dye not with their Bodies. Chap. 2. Sect. 15, 16, 17. Chap. 6. Sect. 3. Chap. 7. Sect. 2, 3, 5, 6, 12, 20. Chap. 9. Sect. 4. Chap. 10. Sect. 8, 12, 14, 22, 25, 27.

5. That the Good or evil we have done, will be rewarded or puni≈øhed after this Life. Chap. 2 Sect. 18. Chap. 7. Sect. 2, 5, 6, 8, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20. Chap. 10. Sect. 3, 12, 25. for if in the Sentiments of Epicure there appear ≈øomething contrary to this la≈øt propo≈øition; I ≈øhall ≈øpeak of it, and explain it in its proper place.

Sect. 4. But the proof of the ob≈øcurity, that is ≈øpread over their under≈øtanding, di≈øcovers it ≈øelf in their other Opinions: for 'tis ob≈øervable, that in all their Rea≈øonings, even tho≈øe in which they ≈øpeak the Truth, they mu≈øt take two ways; by compelling the Divine Maje≈øty to de≈øcend from Heaven upon Earth, and by rai≈øing the humblene≈øs of Man from the Earth to the Heavens. So that they have too high an Opinion of the Creature, and too de≈øpicable of the Creator. That mi≈øtake, which proceeds from a confu≈øed Notion of what belongs to the Divine Nature, and to that of Created Beings, leaves them to gro≈øs errors, and that are ≈øource of their Idolatry and Magick. For 'tis ea≈øie to perceive, that none of tho≈øe practices flow from tho≈øe 5 Truths ju≈øt now mention'd, but only from a fal≈øe and erroneous Idea, as we ≈øhall ≈øee, if we hear in few words, the re≈øult of the preceding ob≈øervations.

Sect. 5. Concerning the Divine E≈ø≈øence we ≈øee, Fir≈øt, that they conceive the Divine Greatne≈øs and Excellence, only with relation to their Ideas of the
Human Nature, ≈øince they a≈øcribe to the Gods, both Superior and Inferior; an Human Original, Marriages, begetting of Children, &c. Chap. 7. Sect. 5, 6, 17. Chap. 10. Sect. 16.

Second. That they have too vile and abject Thoughts of the perfections of God, fancying that he would tire him≈øelf, and impair his Glory and Felicity, if he ≈øhould take in his own hands the direction of all things. Chap. 2. Sect. 4. Chap. 10. Sect. 13. For which rea≈øon they have a≈ø≈øociated with him inferior Gods, as Governors under him, Chap. 2. Sect. 7.12. Chap. 7. Sect. 2, 8. Chap. 10. Sect. 6, 7, 12, 13.

Third. That they fix not Goodne≈øs as a ncce≈ø≈øary Idea to the Deity; ≈øince they have almo≈øt all a wicked God, as well as a good. Chap. 2. Sect. 4.12. Chap. 7. Sect. 3. Chap. 10. Sect. 5. However, with this difference, that they always place the good above the bad; th√¥ ≈øome honour them mo≈øt, who fright them mo≈øt, as the Tapaians, and the Inhabitants of New England. Chap. 10. Sect. 5.23.
Fourth. That they ea≈øily confound the Creator with the Creature. Chap. 4. Sect. 7. Chap. 6. Sect. 2, 3. Chap. 10. Sect. 6, 7, 17, 23, 24.
Sect. 6. Concerning Spirits, it may be ob≈øerved,

Fir≈øt, That they make not a ≈øuitable di≈øtinction betwixt Spiritual and Corporeal ≈øub≈øtances. Chap. 2. Sect, 1, 6. Whence proceeds, that they have attributed, not only to the Spirits, but al≈øo to the Deity it ≈øelf, bodily motions and properties, diver≈øions affixed above in the Heavens, in the Air, upon Earth, or under it. Chap. 2. Sect. 14, 16. Chap. 7. Sect. 6.14, 18. Chap. 10. Sect. 12, 25.

Second. That con≈øidering the Spirits or Demons as inferior Gods and Mini≈øters of the great God, they di≈øtingui≈øh them into ≈øeveral Orders, as into ≈øo many Degrees, according to the admini≈øtration
they have been been entru≈øted with. Chap. 2. Sect. 6, 14. Chap. 2. Sect. 7, 8, 11, 12 13, 18.

Third. That conceiving not what difference there is betwixt the Soul of Man and that of Bea≈øts; Some are fall'n into that gro≈øs error, as to a≈øcribe to Men and Bea≈øts, a Soul of the ≈øame Nature. Chap. 7. Sect. 14. Without which, it had been impo≈ø≈øible that the Opinion of Pythagoras, concerning the Tran≈ømigration of Souls, into the Bodies of other Men and Bea≈øts indifferently, ≈øhould have taken ≈øo deep roots, and have ≈øpread ≈øo far into the World. Chap. 2. Sect. 17. Chap. 7‚ñ™ Sect. 14, 15, 16, 17, 18.

Fourth. That from the ≈øame ≈øource this Sentiment has vi≈øibly proceeded, that the Spirits are wandring, as well as the Souls of Men after their death. Chap. 2. Sect. 15. Chap. 6. Sect. 2. Chap. 7. Sect. 19, 20. Chap. 10. Sect. 11.

Sect. 7. What contributes mo≈øt to the vilifying of the Deity, is, that they deify even Men, either during their Life, or after their Death. Witne≈øs the ancient Greeks and Romans, who transformed the Pa≈ø≈øions of Men, and the Motions of the Heart, into ≈øo many Gods and Godde≈ø≈øes; or as the modern Cannibals, who are very near of the ≈øame mind, as has been ≈øhewed, Chap. 2. Sect. 14. Chap. 7. Sect. 5, 6. Chap. 10. Sect. 14. which however is not commonly us'd, but after death, as appears by the Apotheo≈øis of the Ancients, Chap. 2. Sect. 13. and was no where brought to ≈øuch a light, as among≈øt the Cannibals, as has been ≈øaid, Chap. 10. Sect. 12, 16. That they believe the whole race of the Gods i≈ø≈øued from their Ance≈øtors, and that they them≈øelves are of Cele≈øtial Origin: from the ≈øame ≈øpring is derived the Sentiment of the Exi≈øtence of the Genii or Zemeans, that is of helpful Spirits, the
de≈øcription of whom may be ≈øeen in ≈øeveral Authors.

Sect. 8. It is now ea≈øy to conceive on what ground are founded the Divination and Magick of the Ancients, that are the ≈øame with the predictions and Witchcraft of the modern Heathens; for, as to their foretelling or Divination, it is grounded upon this.

Fir≈øt, Every God has his People, whom he favours and protects, or his own property; for which Rea≈øon, they put que≈øtions to him, concerning that which is to happen to his People, and what is to be done on that occa≈øion.

Second. That every God has his Enemy; for which Rea≈øon, every one looks for help again≈øt the Gods of whom he is to receive damage, and implores the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øuch Gods, as are e≈øteem'd to be their mo≈øt violent Enemies.

Third. That every Man has his God or particular Spirit, and therefore every one mi≈øtakes his own pa≈ø≈øions, and whatever comes into his fancy, for divine In≈øpirations and motions; e≈øpecially when Dreams ≈øupply him with the occa≈øion of it; not knowing that the employments or accidents that have preceeded the Dreams, are the Origin of them, or being hindered by his prejudices, to make an exact enquiry after their po≈ø≈øible cau≈øe.

Fourth. That it is by confounding the Deity with the Creature, that there have been introduced ≈øo many ≈øorts of Divinations and Progno≈øticks, drawn from the Stars, from the Thunder, from Birds, Mountains, Woods, Waters, and from all the things in which 'tis believed that ≈øome Deity is di≈øcoverable.
Fifth. That from the belief that the Souls of the Dead are wandering about their Corps; it was ea≈øy to take occa≈øion to conjure up Gho≈øts.
Sect. 9. Concerning the Witchcraft, we ≈øhall only make the following Con≈øiderations.

Fir≈øt, That it is not ≈øtrange, that di≈øtingui≈øhing not only created Spirits, but even the Gods, into good and bad; they ≈øhould endeavour to ≈øet them one again≈øt another, and to defend them≈øelves by the help of the good, or of ≈øome of the wicked, again≈øt another; or to avenge them≈øelves by the power of one God, of the wrong they ≈øuppo≈øe to have received from another.

Second. That having forged to them≈øelves ≈øo many ≈øorts of Gods and Spirits ≈øuperior and inferior, 'tis no wonder, they ≈øhould believe to de≈øtroy the power of the le≈øs, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the greater.

Third. That having ≈øo ba≈øe thoughts of the Gods, whom they ≈øubject to the ≈øame pa≈ø≈øions as Men, and thus Deify human pa≈ø≈øions them≈øelves, they act con≈øequently, by ≈øtirring them up again≈øt their Enemies, as it comes into their fancy.

Fourth. That putting ≈øome of their Gods ≈øo low, and in ≈øo great a familiarity with the Spirits, they ≈øeem to a≈ø≈øume to them≈øelves, the quality of their Directors, and to be able to make the Divine Operations, even in the mo≈øt hidden things, ≈øub≈øervient to what u≈øe they plea≈øe. Chap. 6. Sect. 4.

Sect 10. There is yet ≈øomthing to be ≈øaid upon Divination and Witchcraft together, which partly concerns the thing it ≈øelf, and partly the ge≈øtures of the body u≈øed in it. What concerns the thing it ≈øelf, comes to this.

Fir≈øt, That the Opinion of the Heathens, concerning the Genii or familiar Spirits, and the Spirits wandring about Graves, makes 'em believe, that ≈øomthing may be operated by the means of Graves, and Carca≈ø≈øes; for which Rea≈øon, they u≈øe the bones of the Dead in their Witchcraft, and con≈øult them in their Divinations, in hopes of getting an
an≈øwer from the Gods or Spirits, which operate in them, or abide near them, Chap. 10. Sect. 11, 15.

Second. That according to this, their belief of the exi≈øtence of ≈øo many ≈øorts of Spirits, whereof mo≈øt part are wicked Spirits, that walk and wander every where; they are always ready in any unfore≈øeen di≈øea≈øe, Mortality, or ≈øini≈øter Accident, to ca≈øt the ≈øu≈øpicion upon their Enemies or Envious, who have bewitchd them for believing that the inferior Gods or Spirits act according to the Will of the Men to whom they belong, they mu≈øt con≈øequently believe, that tho≈øe Men will not fail to effect reciprocally, the one again≈øt the other, whatever the help and power of the Spirits will allow. Now tho≈øe ≈øu≈øpitions, that will ≈øurely move Men to ≈øeek by whom they have been bewitch'd or the cau≈øe, matter, and foundation of Divination, Chap. 10. Sect. 8, 16.
Sect. 11. As to the po≈øtures u≈øed in Witchcraft.

Fir≈øt, The Corpereal Ideas, which they have of the Spirits and of the Gods them≈øelves, move them doubtle≈øs to u≈øe ≈øo many outward ge≈øtures in their Conjuration, Chap. 10. Sect 16. But there is ≈øtill another Rea≈øon of that Cu≈øtom, viz. That the Prie≈øts, who are Impo≈øtors, make u≈øe of them to impo≈øe ≈øo much the ea≈øier upon the ≈øimplicity of the Vulgar.

Second. Con≈øidering how the Opinion of Pythagoras, is become almo≈øt Univer≈øal, it may be, methinks, conceived at the ≈øame time, how it was po≈ø≈øible, that Men ≈øhould place ≈øome Virtue in Letters and Numbers, by gathering and di≈øpo≈øing them, in ≈øuch or ≈øuch a way, and con≈øequently in the pronunciation of ≈øome certain words; for the ≈øame Pythagoras has believed, that the Virtue of the Deity, influenc'd the proportion, and Harmony of Numbers. Now the Letters of the Alphabet being employed to mark the numbers, not only among≈øt the
Greeks and Hebrews, but by all the other Nations that have ≈øome knowledge of Letters, it follows, that ther's not one word, but it can make up a number whence it may rationally be inferr'd, that ≈øuch or ≈øuch a word, compo≈øed in ≈øuch or ≈øuch a manner, of ≈øuch or ≈øuch or ≈øuch Letters, more or le≈øs, has according to their Opinion, more or le≈øs power in Witchcraft.

Third. Be≈øides the ordinary numbers, they u≈øe al≈øo Names and Characters, as it is ≈øeen at this day, e≈øpecially among≈øt the Laplanders and Finlanders, who≈øe enchanted Drums are ≈øpotted with the like Characters, Chap. 6. Sect. 5.

Sect. 12. But I have nor yet ≈øpoken of what is mo≈øt important in the≈øe Conjurations, that are u≈øed, as well for Divination, as Witchcraft, which con≈øi≈øts in this, that they are part of the Pagan Religion, and even make it wholly up among≈øt ≈øome Nations, e≈øpecially in the We≈øt-Indies, Chap. 9. Sect. 6. Chap. 10. Sect. 16. And 'tis almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible it ≈øhould be otherwi≈øe, ≈øince their whole Religion turns upon their Opinion of the Gods, or draws it's Original from thence.

Fir≈øt. They look by no means upon their practices, nor the ≈øcope they aim at, as things evil of their own nature; but only by the bad u≈øe that is made of them, wherefore anciently, the Magi and Diviners, were found among≈øt the King's Attendants, and in the Temples, as are ≈øtill at this day the Brainines, in the Ea≈øt-Indies, the Feti≈ø≈øeros in Guinea, the Baivas or Piais in Peru, and the Country of the Cannibals, &c. and ≈øeveral others of the ≈øame quality, ≈øo that no body is acknowledg'd for Wi≈øe, Doctor, Prie≈øt, Prophet, nor becomes Councellor of State, unle≈øs he be Diviner or Magician, in the ≈øen≈øe that has been ≈øet down. The Holy Scripture ≈øhows the ≈øame in the per≈øons Jannes, Jambres, Balaam, Daniel, and his Companions, of which we
have ≈øaid ≈øomething before, Chap. 4. Sect. 1, 4. And it may be ob≈øerved in the general in≈øtances that have been alledg'd, that the Heathens had publick Schools to teach tho≈øe Arts, that the Prie≈øts e≈øpecially in≈øtructed the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ople in that Mini≈øtry, and trained them up from their Youth, which is ≈øtill practi≈øed among≈øt the bruiti≈øh and dull Laplanders.

Second. We ≈øee at the ≈øame time, for what Rea≈øon the entrails of ≈øacrificed Bea≈øts, and ≈øome Meat and dre≈øs'd Herbs, were imployed in their Witchcraft and Divinations; viz. becau≈øe in their Opinion‚ñ™ ≈øomething divine was mix'd with them.

Sect. 13. 'Tis therefore certain, that all their practices were grounded upon a certain knowledge, and partly upon vain conjectures, and very great errors; for to ≈øeek the Deity and to fear it, is an effect of the natural knowledge of God, which Men keep in the mid≈øt of their greate≈øt corruption. But to admit ≈øo many ≈øorts of Deities, of ≈øuch a low rank, and ≈øuch a contemptible Nature, and to ≈øerve him in ≈øo many different ways, is an effect of the corruption of the mind; which, let it be ≈øaid in reference to tho≈øe that acknowledge one God, or Spirit, and who believe the Immortality of the Soul, to which believe the Opinion of the Epicures is not wholly oppo≈øite th√¥ they ≈øeem to deny both, or at lea≈øt, to call them in que≈øtion; for Epicure and his modern followers, deny not ≈øo much the exi≈øtence of a God and of Spirits, as they are earne≈øt to per≈øwade ≈øuch, as believe both, that their practices bely their Faith, and are not agreeable to their principles; and therefore 'tis impo≈ø≈øible that one ≈øhould be both an Epicure, and a Sorcerer, or a Diviner: And on the contrary, no Heathen ever endeavoured to contradict the Hypothe≈øes of Epicure, without admitting tho≈øe Arts and their effects.

Sect. 14. For a greater certainty, it will be convenient to hear tho≈øe Philo≈øophers ≈øpeak in their own words. Ga≈ø≈øendus has collected part of what they ≈øay, Sect. 11. Chap 6. 'Tis the ≈øame thing that God ≈øhould govern the World by him≈øelf, as ≈øome affirm, or as others a≈ø≈øert, by Mini≈øters generally call'd Genii, or Demons, for when all is done, things go neverthele≈øs their u≈øual way in great part, as th√¥ there were no ≈øuch Mini≈øters. And th√¥ it were granted, that there are ≈øome, they could not be ≈øuch as they are fancyed, viz. of Human ≈øhape, and conver≈øing with us, I will not ≈øay that being for the mo≈øt part wicked they could not lead a long and happy life, becau≈øe malignity is joyned to Ignorance, and tends to ruin; That's what they ≈øay concerning Spirits, let us then ≈øpeak of what is practi≈øed upon that Account, They u≈øe to alledge Divination as a proof both of Providence and of the exi≈øtence of Spirits, but I look with ≈øorrow upon that Human weakne≈øs, which ≈øeeks for Oracles, even in Dreams, as th√¥ God being ≈øet upon Stilts, came by frightful vi≈øions to forewarn Men in their deepe≈øt Sleep, of what is to happen to them; as th√¥ fortune and chance were not ≈øufficient to produce ≈øuch events, without mixing God, not only with the Sun and Moon, and ≈øeveral other kinds of Annimals, but al≈øo with all ≈øorts of Stone and Bra≈øs. Tho≈øe that ≈øpeak ≈øo, make it evident, that they rather have to deny the exi≈øtence of God and Spirits, than to acknowledge them ≈øuch as the other Heathens believed them, and to be obliged to own them≈øelves Sorcerers and Diviners, by granting, that they exi≈øt. So much for Pagani≈øm, 'tis time to proceed further,

div.head: CHAP. XII. What are the Opinions of the Jews, and how nece≈ø≈øary it is to examine them.
div.p:
Sect. 1. WE have hitherto only con≈øidered Pagani≈øm, which has no other light but that of Nature; now we ≈øhall enquire, what tho≈øe that are illuminated with the light of the Holy Scripture, believe or practi≈øe upon that account, In the mean while, it mu≈øt be ob≈øerved, that they are not all of one ≈øen≈øe, being divided into Jews, Mahometans, and Chri≈øtians; which difference proceeds from the inequality of the light they have received, or made u≈øe of; I ≈øhall begin with tho≈øe that are at greate≈øt di≈øtance from Chri≈øtianity, and con≈øequently the neare≈øt to Pagani≈øm. It ≈øeems that the followers of Mahomet, ≈øhould have that place; ≈øo much the more, becau≈øe we have favourable prejudices on behalf of the Jews, as having Anciently been the People of God. But notwith≈øtanding what they have been, they are now ≈øo much degenerated, that the belief of the Mahometans, may be ≈øaid to have more conformity with ours, then theirs hath, both dete≈øt Idolatry, and acknowledge one God, and take his word for the rule of their Faith. The Jews receive only the Old Te≈øtament, but the Mahometans admit al≈øo of the New, adding the Alcoran or Mahomet's Law, to tho≈øe of Mo≈øes and Chri≈øt, in order to correct and perfect them both. The Jews do almo≈øt the ≈øame as to the Law of Mo≈øes, by the Addition of the Talmud, which contains the traditions of the Ancient. But if the Opinions of both
parties were deeply ≈øearched into, perhaps it would be found that tho≈øe of the Mahometans favour more the infalibility of the Law and Go≈øpel, than tho≈øe of the Jews, that of the Law alone. Add to this, that Chri≈øt is acknowledged by the Mahometans for a great Prophet, and honoured in that quality, whereas he is horribly bla≈øphemed by the Jews. For the≈øe rea≈øons I ≈øay, that the Mahometans are halfe nearer to us, than the modern Jews. But what need we any farther proof, ≈øince as to this matter, it is plain that the Jews are le≈øs from Pagani≈øm than the Mahometans, as ≈øhall appear by the proof I ≈øhall produce.

Sect. 2. As long as we have had to do with Heathens only, we needed but to make an inquiry after their Opinions concerning their Gods, the Spirits, and the Souls. Chap. 22. v. 23. and in the Acts, Ch. 23. v. 8. but now the Jews have invented a great many Chimaera's, that powerfully confirmed them in their Magick, and the practice of their Conjurations; for, as it has already been ≈øaid, the Soul ≈øeparated
from the Body mu≈øt wander a whole year about her Corps, during which the wicked Spirits that abide in the Air, and are call'd „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Malachi Chabbalah, or Devils of Torments, and have yet ≈øeveral other Names, find occa≈øion to make them reenter into their Bodies, as they have power to do, when they are required to it by Conjurations. div.head: CHAP. XIII. That the Witchcraft anciently Practi≈øed, and ≈øtill in u≈øe among≈øt the Jews, proceeds from the ≈øame Original.
div.p:
Sect., 1. WE have examined the Opinions of the Jews upon that matter, as much as they differ from the holy writ; for as far as their belief is con≈øonant to it, we receive and approve of the ≈øame. Let's now ≈øee what they practi≈øe as to Witchcraft, the Holy Scripture may fully convince us of the great inclination that People ever had for it; which doubtle≈øs proceeded. Fir≈øt, from the practices they had ≈øeen in Egypt, and of which perhaps they had not ab≈øtained, but had ≈øeen the continuation of them in the Country they inhabited, that was ≈øurrounded and intermixed with ≈øo many Nations addicted to that Art. 'Tis for that Rea≈øon the Law gives them ≈øuch frequent warnings to beware of it, Exodus, 22, 18. Levit. Chap. 18. v. 31. Cap. 5. v. 27. Deuter. Chap. 13, 8, 9, 14. I≈øaiah, Chap. 6. v. 12.20. And that he threatned them ≈øo ≈øeverely, becau≈øe they could not re≈øolve to for≈øake that impious exerci≈øe, as may be ≈øeen, e≈øpecially in Mana≈ø≈øeh King of Judah, 2 Kings, Chap. 21. v. 6. 2. Cron. Chap. 3. v. 6. That Sin became general in the mid≈øt of I≈ørael, or the Kingdom of the 10 Tribes, ≈øo that the Scripture ≈øays, that They u≈øed Divinations, and ob≈øerved the cry of Birds, 2 Kings, Chap. 17. v. 17. In the Apo≈øtles time, there were Seven Sons of the ≈øame Father, one of the high Prie≈øts, who took upon them to be Exorci≈øts and to conjure Devils. Acts, 19. v. 13, 14. But all the≈øe things made
no part of the contents of their Law, and on the contrary were the effects of their Rebellion, ≈øo that Judai≈øm was not properly an≈øwerable for them, until they were taught by the Rabbins them≈øelves, and at la≈øt introduced to make up part of their Religion. Such are the Doctrines, which I have repre≈øented in the preceeding Chapter, to which the practices of the pre≈øent Jews, are perfectly agreeable.

Sect. 2. The inqui≈øitive Lighfoot, has ≈øhewed by many proofs that the Jews at their return from the Babylonian Captivity, having entirely for≈øaken Idolatry, and finding they were de≈øtitute of Prophets‚ñ™ addicted them≈øelves by degrees to Witchcraft and Divination, about the time of our Saviours coming. The writings of the Talmud, that are full of In≈øtructions for that purpo≈øe, and are neverthele≈øs in great credit among them, give upon that ≈øubject a te≈øtimony not advantageous to them, e≈øpecially ≈øince, in the following times, they u≈øed the ≈øame Arts again≈øt Chri≈øtianity. Lightfoot a≈ø≈øures us, That after the De≈øtruction of their City and Temple, there were ≈øeveral Impo≈øtors among≈øt tbem, who eagerly addicted them≈øelves to Magick, by which they got afterwards into great reputation, and that the expounding of Dreams was a pretence they made u≈øe of, to commit a va≈øt number of Deceits and Villanies. We ≈øee, continues that learned Author, in the Book Maar≈øar Shemi, fol. 45. Col. 2, 3. That Rabbi, Jo≈øeph, Ben Calpata, Rabbi I≈ømael, Ben. Jo≈øe, Rabbi Lazarus, and Akiba, made it their whole bu≈øine≈øs, many of their expoundings are related in the place I have quoted out of Lightfoot, and from ≈øeveral things contained therein, it may be infer'd, that they in≈øtructed their Di≈øciples in tho≈øe Arts. In the Book Shabbat, fol. 3. Col. 2. mention is made of a Phanta≈øm, that appeared to one of their Bigots, whil≈øt he was meditating the Law, and fol. 8. Col. 2. fol. 14. Col. 3. all
≈øorts of Conjurations are treated of, ≈øome to cure Wounds, others again≈øt the ≈øting of Serpents, again≈øt Theft, and even again≈øt Enchantments; this I have Collected from the Second part of the works of Lightfoot, page 147. where many other things of that nature are to be found, but not nece≈ø≈øary to relate, and much le≈øs to extract out of the own Books of the Jews.

Sect. 3. However it will not be be≈øides the purpo≈øe, to add, what the ≈øame Lightfoot has gather'd from ≈øeveral of their writings, e≈øpecially from the Book Sanhedrin, concerning their Bathkol or the Daughter of the Voice, which is the name the Jews gave to the Echo, pretending it was an Oracle, that under the Second Temple, ≈øupplyed the want of the ∆≤rim and Thummim, with which the Fir≈øt Temple was honoured. It is as ≈øure that tho≈øe words proceeded from Bathkool, as it is certain, that Elijah is pre≈øent at the Circumci≈øion of the Children of the Jews, as 'tis commonly believed among them and as all the learned know.

Sest. 4. But be≈øides tho≈øe ≈øingularities, we may take notice that all their Witchcraft is founded upon two grounds, the influences of the Stars, and thy apparitions of Spirits, the rea≈øon of the former ground is, that th√¥ they e≈øteem not the Cele≈øtial lights to be Gods; yet they a≈øcribe to them a particular virtue, working upon, and influencing Human Actions, as well external as internal ≈øen≈øes. 'Tis very u≈øual with them to ≈øay, The Planets make ≈øuch a one Wi≈øe, or Rich, as Buxtorf relates it in his Lexicon Talmudicum, out of the Books of the Sabbath, the≈øe are happy influences or Con≈øtellations, that are called Mazzal-toob, but Mazzal-ra is a malignant Star, under which one is born, or who≈øe virtue influences him all his Life. Buxtorf ≈øays again upon the Authority of the ≈øame Book, That the Planet of the Day of ones Birth, influences him not, but only that of the Hour. And even, we find in that Book which is the Genius of every Man, according to the Planet under which he's born, He who is born under the Sun, will be hand≈øom, free, not di≈ø≈øembling, but of an uncon≈øtant humour. Under Venus, he'll be rich and letcherous. Under Mercury, skilful and of a good memory. Under the Moon, ≈øickly, and un≈øtedfa≈øt. Under Saturn, unfortunate. Under Jupiter, ju≈øt; and Under Mars, happy. Which is the ≈øame with all the other Con≈øtellations. In the mean while it is commonly ≈øaid, That there is no Planet in I≈ørael, becau≈øe all the Jews ≈øeem to be born under one Planet, being all of the ≈øame Genius and Conduct; therefore we mu≈øt conclude, that tho≈øe di≈øtinctions concern only ≈øtrangers, and that I≈ørael has the skill of foretelling their good and bad Fortune. However they are much di≈øturb'd when the Moon is Eclip≈øed; becau≈øe they take that accident as an ill pre≈øage to them, which is an evident
proof of the un≈øtedfa≈øtne≈øs of the Jewi≈øh Nation.

Sect. 5. As to the Spirits, Mana≈ø≈øe, Ben I≈ørael, di≈øcovering the true ground of the Jewi≈øh Divinations, leads us to the wicked Spirits, ≈øaying, That ≈øome of them are skilful and ≈øhrew'd, and others fooli≈øh and dull. The mo≈øt skilful, flying from one corner of the World to the other, ≈øometimes learn what is to happen. For this Rea≈øon he acknowledges page 18. That ≈øeveral Conjure up tho≈øe Spirits, and do wonders by help of the black Art. We read even in ≈øome Cabbali≈øtical Books, as in Pirke Chalos, and Rat≈øiel, and in ≈øome others, the names of tho≈øe Spirits, and the form of the Conjurations u≈øed for that purpo≈øe, There are al≈øo to be found all the pre≈øages that may be drawn from the various ≈øorts of Apparitions. If tho≈øe Sprits appear to a Man alone, they forebode nothing good; if they appear to two per≈øons together, they pre≈øage nothing ill; but it never happens, that they ≈øhew them≈øelves to three in a company.

Sect. 6. The ways and means they u≈øe for their Witchcraft and Divinations, are to be ob≈øerved in the Ceremonies of their Fea≈øts, and the whole cour≈øe of their ordinary Life. Every one knows that Marriage is the lawful way to beget Children, which makes them believe one mu≈øt needs know how to pre≈øerve him≈øelf in that occa≈øion, from the wicked Spirits. There is none but has read the Book of Tobit, how he expel'd the Devil A≈ømodee, by the in≈øpiration of the Angel Raphael, and how they took together a Fi≈øh, which as ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe was a Pike, as to the Heart and Liver, ≈øays Raphael, if the Demon, or wicked Spirit di≈øturbs any Per≈øon, whether Man or Woman, he needs but make a perfume before him, and the party ≈øhall be no more vexed, Chap. 6. v. 7. When he was marryed with Sara, he remembred the words of Raphael, and took the A≈øhes of the perfumes, put the Heart and the Liver of the Fi≈øh thereupon, and made
a ≈ømoke with it, which when the Evil Spirit had ≈ømelt, he fled into the utmo≈øt parts of Egypt, and the Angel bound him there, Chap. 8. v. 23.

Sect. 7. If that Narration is e≈øteem'd Apochryphal by the Prote≈øtants, that of Jo≈øephus de≈øerves not a better name, when in the Second Chap. of the 8th Book, of his Jewi≈øh Antiquities, he deduces the Original of Magick from Solomon, and lays the foundation of it, upon the wi≈ødom of that King, nay he a≈ø≈øerts, That God him≈øelf had in≈øpired him with that Art ≈øo powerful again≈øt Demons, for ≈øays he, He has made u≈øe of Witchcraft to expel di≈øea≈øes, and has left in his writings, forms of Conjurations, by which the Devils that mole≈øt mankind are ≈øo far bani≈øhed, that they never dare come back again. And that ≈øort of cure is now in great reque≈øt among≈øt our Nation. We will examine in our 4th Book, how the ≈øight of Jo≈øephus was then di≈øpo≈øed; but in the mean while, we could wi≈øh he had explained to us, whether this Root is the ≈øame with that he mentions in the 28th Chap. of the 7th Book of the Jewi≈øh Antiquities, which he calls Baaras, becau≈øe of the place where it grows, ≈øince he al≈øo a≈øcribes to this la≈øt, the wonderful virtue of expelling Demons; for according to his relation, one needs but touch the po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd with it, and the Devil is forced to run away, but of this more in the 4th Book.

Sect. 8. Here follows how the pre≈øent Jews are mole≈øted all their Life by the wicked Spirits, and how they beware of them. Sect. 9. But what terrour ≈øoever the Devil cau≈øes to them, they neverthele≈øs believe, that if they take their opportunity, they may prevent his endeavours without trouble. Sect. 10. The Cabbala chiefly u≈øes ≈øuch Witchcraft, as is made by numbers and Letters, and is in great reque≈øt among≈øt the Jews. It even teaches to apply to it the ≈øacred word of God, and withal ≈øome ≈øentences and di≈øcour≈øes, or only ≈øome proper words and particular names, to which the Jews a≈øcribe a great Virtue; whether they attribute it to the power of the apparition of ab≈øent bodies, or of incorporeal ≈øub≈øtances, or whether they pre≈øume to effect by that means, ≈øtrange and wonderful things. Sect. 11. To ≈øpeak of the other u≈øes, they make of names in Witchcraft, it mu≈øt be granted, that they make no more difficulty to mix the name of God with it, than that of the Devil. Thus they bla≈øpheme the Second Per≈øon of the Holy Trinity, not being able to deny his power. It is ea≈øy to be inform'd of all the≈øe things in their own writings, and by their own con≈øent. Sect. 12. They al≈øo pretend to find a great Virtue in the reckoning of Letters, and their di≈øpo≈øition into ≈øeveral different orders‚ñ™ They write on the forepart of Hou≈øes, and the Walls of Chambers, ≈øome ≈øtrange Characters of no le≈øs extraordinary names, which they u≈øe to give to tho≈øe Angels, that are e≈øtabli≈øhed over the plague, ≈øuppo≈øing by that means to be ≈øufficiently ≈øe ‚Ä¢ ure from the burning darts of that con≈øuming ≈øcou ‚Ä¢ ge. The word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Diriroon is likewi≈øe an infallible pre≈øervative again≈øt the Pe≈øtilence, when 'tis written 22 or 23 times, that is as many times as there are Letters in their Alphabet, of which they put one every time before that word, beginning with the fir≈øt Letter, and ending with the la≈øt. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
why? becau≈øe that makes People blind, but if one be dry and he drinks, what then? here is the remedy. The Hebrew word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Shebriri, that is, lo≈øt ≈øight or ≈øudden blindne≈øs, being written as it is here in the Margent, and hung about the Neck, cau≈øe the blindne ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
to go off, as much as we ≈øee decrea≈øe the fir≈øt Letters of this word, untill they be altogether vani≈øhed, and the blindne≈øs gone. Tho≈øe In≈øtructions are to be found in the Lexicon Talmudicum of Buxtorf.

Sect. 13. By this ≈øhort Specimen of their Witchcrafts, may be ≈øeen the Relation that there is, betwixt the Practices and Doctrines of their Rabbins, contained in the fore-going Chapter, from which, doubtle≈øs, tho≈øe practices take their Original.

Fir≈øt, Their opinions of the Materiality, as I may ≈øay, of good and bad Spirits, Chap. 12. Sect. 8.10, 14, 15. was the cau≈øe that they a≈øcribe to them, external and vi≈øible ≈øhapes, with effects of the ≈øame nature, as they have been de≈øcribed, Sect. 6.8. Second. It was no hard matter that the ≈øt a ‚Ä¢ ge Thoughts they have of Sammael, Prince of the Devils, and of Lilis his Mother, according to ≈øome Chap. 12. Third. And 'tis no wonder that a Nation, who has lo≈øt the vivifying Spirit of the Letters of the Holy Writ, ≈øhould now ≈øo curiou≈øly, and with ≈øo much trouble, ≈øeek the help of tho≈øe Letters de≈øtitute of the Spirit of Life.

Fourth. It mu≈øt be ob≈øerved, that being antiently u≈øed to Prophe≈øies, Vi≈øions, ∆≤rim and Thummim, they now bethought them≈øelves of the empty ≈øound of Bathcole, and the influences of the Stars, to ≈øupply the want of the advantages they had lo≈øt.

Sect. 14. When we recollect all tho≈øe things, we ea≈øily perceive, that th√¥ the Jews are not partakers of the Pagans Idolatry; yet they have a near Relation to them, as to the Opinions and Cu≈øtoms they have not drawn from the Holy Scripture. Nay, they go farther than the Heathens, and are in a more Diametrical oppo≈øition to the Principles of their own Doctrine, than the Heathens with tho≈øe of their Religion; for the Jews conceiving plainer than they do, that there is but one Creator and Director of all, ≈øufficient to him≈øelf, and having ≈øuch a ≈øtrong prejudice again≈øt all the Gods invented by Men, and again≈øt whatever has any nearne≈øs to Idolatry. 'Tis not ea≈øie to forgive them their dependency upon the Stars; their fear of the great Devil Sammael, nor their Faith for the virtue of Words, Letters, Characters and Numbers; ≈øince the Heathens were obnoxious to tho≈øe faults, only becau≈øe they had not a ≈øufficient knowledge of the Supreme Deity, and did not relye ≈øo much upon him as they ought to have done: whereas they tru≈øted too much upon the Creatures, which they had Deify'd them≈øelves. However, our amazement will dimini≈øh, if we ob≈øerve that all the≈øe Doctrines have been drawn from Pagani≈øm, and have been received among≈øt them, only by an effect of the natural inclination and eagerne≈øs of that People, for ≈øuch Fables and Inventions, without con≈øidering, whether or no they were agreeable to the Rules of the Law. But the utmo≈øt blindne≈øs is to per≈øi≈øt in them to this very day, without reflecting upon the State, in which the
Divine Ju≈øtice has put them, by an entire de≈øtruction of their Common-wealth, and ≈øcattering of their Nation among≈øt the Heathens. In the mean while I de≈øire the Reader to ob≈øerve, that hitherto we have met with nothing, of whatever is called Witchcraft, Phanta≈øms, or Diabolical Apparitions, but it draws its Original from Heatheni≈øm.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. That the Doctrine of the Spirits, and the exerci≈øe of Magick, are al≈øo in reque≈øt among≈øt the Mahometans.
div.p:
Sect. 1. WE cannot ≈øay many things with great certainty, concerning the Mahometans, upon the matter in hand, for we mu≈øt learn it, either in the Alcoran, that is the Law of Mahomet, or from the Precepts of their Doctors, which very much differ from the Law. As to the Alcoran, I would not tru≈øt to any but my ≈øelf, and therefore have read it, ≈øheet by ≈øheet, from the beginning to the end; but could not gather any particulars, relating to our ≈øubject, except that little which I ≈øhall mention hereafter. Be≈øides, there are come to my hands but very few writings of the Mahometans: yet I have read ≈øome very credible Chri≈øtian Authors, that treat of their belief, whom I ≈øhall pre≈øume to make u≈øe of; becau≈øe every one knows, that during their abode among≈øt tho≈øe Nations, they have examined very impartially and narrowly, ≈øuch things as they relate. Now there's none but knows, that the Doctrine and Wor≈øhip of that Sect, as they are contained in the Alcoran and their other Writings, are involved with many Fables
and Fictions, which are generally received as Truth among≈øt them, but explained in a very rational ≈øen≈øe by the Learned, which makes it, that they are not ≈øo intolerable in that re≈øpect, as that they are fal≈øe and groundle≈øs. And therefore, 'tis but rea≈øonable to u≈øe this circum≈øpection that knowing that ≈øort of People to be Men of ≈øen≈øe, as there are many in other Sects, we interpret their Fables only with relation to that, which is clearly and ≈øignificantly expre≈øs'd in other places, and in reference to the tendency they ≈øeem to have, in what is related of their other Opinions.

Sect. 2. It is al≈øo rea≈øonable to relate at fir≈øt, what is to be gathered from the Alcoran, and to joyn to it afterwards, what other Authors ≈øupply us with, either as to the Doctrine of the Spirits taught among≈øt the Mu≈øulmans, that is the Faithful, as they love to call them≈øelves, or as to their practices in Witchcraft and Divinations. But becau≈øe the Book of Laws collected after the death of Mahomet by his Di≈øciples, that are the mo≈øt famous Doctors of the Mu≈øulmans, is not uniform, as to the Order in which it is tran≈ølated in ≈øeveral Languages; for the conveniency of the Reader, I de≈øign to follow the divi≈øion ob≈øerved by du R ‚Ä¢ er, in his French Tran≈ølation, and by le Verrier in his Dutch, who both div ‚Ä¢ de the whole work into 113 Chapters.

Sect. 3. Fir≈øt of all, 'tis among≈øt them a fundamental point, repeated above a hundred times in the Book of the Law, that God is but One, and hath no partner: in which they perfectly agree with the Jews, even in reference to the Holy Trinity, as has been already mention'd, Chap. 12. Sect. 1. Marmol ≈øays however, in the fir≈øt part of his de≈øcription of Africa, Pag. 128. Edit. Paris. That the Morabites, a Sect of Mahometan Arabs, hold that the Heavens, Stars and Elements make up but one God together.
The Sahis, another Sect of the Turks, believe that there is ≈øome Deity in the Sun and Moon, becau≈øe of the influence tho≈øe two great Lights of the Univer≈øe, have upon ≈øublunary Creatures, according to the Relation of Ricaut in his de≈øcription of Turkey, Book 2. Chap. 12. De la Vall in his journey, Book 4. Chap. 17. ≈øays, that among≈øt the Per≈øians, ≈øeveral Mahometans a≈øcribe a≈ø≈øi≈øting Forms and Intelligences to the Sun, Moon and Stars, by which they are quickned and directed, as our Bodies are by our Souls.

Sect. 4. In mo≈øt, or all the pages of the Alcoran, mention is made of the Holy Angels, of the wicked Devil, and of the Original of Devils, far more rationally, than in the Books of the Jews. For they make the Angels immaterial, tho' they believe that they appear in a Corporeal ≈øhape, as is to be read in this pa≈ø≈øage of the 5th, Chapter. The Angels, ≈øay they, are the only con≈øtant and immutable Creatures, there being no others endued with ≈øuch Properties. Thus is this pa≈ø≈øage quoted by Levinius Varnerius in his Mi≈øcellanies, who has extracted it from ≈øome other Book. But this is a rea≈øoning of the mo ‚Ä¢ t thinking part and the be≈øt Philo≈øophers among≈øt them. For Mahomet him≈øelf believ'd that the Angels had been created of ≈øome certain Matter, as he gives us to know in one of his Fables, to be related anon. He often ≈øpeaks too gro≈øly, and gives us occa≈øion to doubt whether he under≈øtands in a proper or figurative Sen≈øe, what he ≈øo frequently ≈øays, that the Angels go to and fro, hear the Law, have Beings, and even are di≈øtingui≈øh'd into Males and Females; for he believes that di≈øtinction of Sexes to be found in every thing; See his 52, Chap. pa. 594. He no le≈øs vilifies the Dignity of Angels, a≈øcribing the cau≈øe of the fall of ≈øome to their refu≈øal of paying an extraordinary Honour to Adam, who was wi≈øer
than they were, and convers'd more familiarly with God. For God taught Adam the Names of all things, and Adam taught them to the Angels, Chap. 2. pa. 5. La≈øtly, the great number of Guardian Angels, whom he gives to every Mu≈øulman, evidently infers, that one of his Di≈øciples was look'd upon by him of greater worth than ≈øeveral Angels.

Sect. 5. Mahomet has very plainly expre≈øs'd, in ≈øeveral places of his Book of the Law, his Opinion upon the Nature and Original of Devils, who at the beginning were created in the rank of the Angels, whence they fell for their envy. Thus in the 6th, Chap. Pag. 109. he introduces God, ≈øpeaking to him. I have created and made thee, I have commanded the Angels to adore Adam, which they have done, ≈øave only the Devil. This place mu≈øt be under≈øtood with the di≈øtinction, brought by Levinius Varnerius, out of a Turki≈øh Book, Adoration belongs to the Great God as a Wor≈øhip, but it may belong to others as a mark of Veneration. In that Sen≈øe it is that Adam was adored by the Angels, and Jo≈øeph by his Father and Brothers. Mahomet proceeds, relating what God ≈øaid to the Devil. What hinders you from adoring Adam, as I have order'd you? The Devil An≈øwer'd, Becau≈øe I am Superior to him, ≈øince thou ha≈øt created me out of Fire, and Man out of Clay. Hereupon I ≈øaid, Go out of Paradi≈øe, 'tis not the abode of the proud; thou ≈øhalt be in the number of tho≈øe that are cover'd with infamy. He replyed, Let me be here till the day of the Re≈øurrection. Why, ≈øaid he, ha≈øt thou tempted me? I ≈øhall, ≈øaid he, turn Men from the right way, I ≈øhall hinder them by all means from believing thy Law, and even let the greate≈øt part fall into ungratefulne≈øs. I ≈øaid to him, Go out of Paradi≈øe, thou ≈øhalt be rejected by all the world, and deprived from the effects of my Mercy, and I ≈øhall fill Hell with tho≈øe that ≈øhall li≈øten to thee,
and follow thee. The ≈øame Relation is repeated in the 14, 16, and 37 Chapters. Pag. 293, 381, and 511. And th√¥ he mentions but one Devil, as the Chief, he neverthele≈øs believes a va≈øt number of good and wicked Angels; for in the 7th, Chapter he ≈øpeaks of thou≈øands of good Angels, whom God ≈øent once from Heaven to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, whil≈øt he prayed; he likewi≈øe mentions the Demons in the plural number, as Chap. 6. We have created Hell to puni≈øh Devils and Men.

Sect. 6. His di≈øtinction betwixt the ≈øtate of Angels and Devils is not to be rejected in all re≈øpects: ≈øuch as they are towards God and the Faithful, ≈øuch he de≈øcribes them to be one towards another: Chap. 7. Pag. 198. God ≈øaid to his Angels, I will be with you, confirm the ≈øteps of the true faithful. Chap. 11.278. The Angels tremble in the pre≈øence of God, Chap. 20. Pag. 360. They are not a≈øhamed to ador ‚Ä¢ him. And again, Chapter 15. Pag. 296. God orders his Angels to go down, and ≈øends his in≈øpiration to whom he plea≈øes. This, as he believes, particularly happens ≈øome certain Nights; Chap, 96. Pag. 284. The Angels de≈øcend at night upon Earth, by the leave of their Lord; and vi≈øit the true faithful, till the break of the day: Chap. 12. Pag. 290. They will vi≈øit the faithful in the Garden of Eden, they will ≈øalute them, and ≈øay, here is the reward of their per≈øeverance; here is the Eternal Grace.

Sect. 7. As he holds that the Angels are always ready to ≈øerve God, on behalfe of the Faithful; ≈øo he believed them no le≈øs forward, in performing his Orders again≈øt the impious. When, ≈øays he, Chap. 5. pag. 155. the wicked are at the point of death, the Angels ≈øtretch out their hands to ≈øeize upon their Souls. And further, P. 172. The Angels of death ≈øhall kill tho≈øe that bla≈øpheme God and his Commandments; Chap. 7. Pag. 203, 204. Thou ha≈øt ≈øeen that the Angels
have put to death the unfaithful, and ≈øtricken them, before and behind. A great power for the executing of God's Judgments, is a≈øcribed to them: for an Angel is ≈øufficient to de≈øtroy all the Inhabitants of the World, as Levinius Varnerius quotes it out of a Turki≈øh Book.

Sect. 8. He forgets not the evils cau≈øed by the Devil for the ≈øeducing of Man. The fir≈øt was his having them bani≈øh'd from Paradi≈øe, Chap. 1. Pag. 7. He cau≈øed Adam and his Wife to ≈øin, and to fall from the Grace in which they were, Chap. 2. Pag. 8. God adverti≈øes Mahomet‚ñ™ that the Devil would make h ‚Ä¢ m afraid of the unfaithful, Pag. 150. The Devil will make them forget my Commandments, Pag. 160. Think upon the day in which I ≈øhall gather all the Peop ‚Ä¢ e, and ≈øay to the Devil, O thou Prince of the Devils, why ha≈øt thou rebelled again≈øt me? Chap. 56. Pag. 608. For the Devil has puft up Man, and made ‚Ä¢ im revolt from the Commandments of God. He ≈øeems even to believe, that the malice of the Devil extends as far as the Stars, with which, he ≈øays, God has adorned the Heavens and which he pre≈øerves again≈øt the attempts of the Devils, Chap. 40. Pag. 534.

Sect. 9. Such are his Opinions as to the Angels in general; but as to their particular Mini≈øtry, Thevenot relates, That the Turks acknowledge Guardian Angels, but in far greater number than we do, for, ≈øay they, God has ordained 70 Angels for an invi≈øible Guard to each Mu≈øulman, and there happens nothing to any per≈øon, but they attribute it to them. Each has his particular Office, one watches over one Member, and th'other over another; one is ≈øo ≈øub≈øervient in this, and the other in that Affair. Among≈øt all tho≈øe Angels, there are two who pre≈øide over all the re≈øt, ≈øitting one on the Right, and th'other on the Left hand, and being call'd Kerim Kiatib, that is to ≈øay, Merciful
Writers: That on the Right hand keeps account of the good Actions, and that on the Left of the bad. They are ≈øo merciful that they ≈øpare him, if he commits any ≈øin before he falls a≈øleep, hoping he ≈øhall repent, if not, they ≈øet it down, but if he repents, they write, E≈øtig fourillah, God forgive. They accompany him every where, unle≈øs when he goes to the Nece≈ø≈øary hou≈øe, whither they let him go alone, waiting for him at the door where they again take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of him. For that rea≈øon, when the Turks go to that place, they go in with the Left Foot, and when they come out, they put the Right Foot foremo≈øt, that the Angel who ≈øets down their good Works, ≈øhould ≈øeize fir≈øt upon them. Mahomet him≈øelf confirms that Fable, ≈øaying, Chap. 52. Pag. 594. Think, O Man, on the day when thou ≈øhalt ≈øee near thee, thy good Angel on thy Right hand, and thy bad Angel on thy Left, who have noted and written whatever thou ha≈øt done.

Sect. 10. 'Tis ob≈øervable, that this Fable has its Original from the immortality of the Soul, and the re≈øurrection of the dead, which the Turks believe, and are plainly expre≈øs'd in the foregoing words and el≈øe-where: as Chap. 12. Pag. 280. The faithful ≈øhall go into the Garden of Eden: but to the unfaithful he ≈øays, Pag. 288. Hell is the place to which you are de≈øtin'd. Chap. 52. Pag. 594. God takes up the Soul of Man, as he thinks fit, to ≈øend her into one of tho≈øe places. But fir≈øt, ≈øhe returns into the Body after its burying, to undergo the ≈øtrict examination of two frightful Angels, Munquir and Guauquir; the Fable which Thevenot relates upon their account, and that of the Bea≈øts, is ≈øo gro≈øs, that I ≈øhould be a≈øhamed to recite it at large.

Sect. 11. In the mean while it will not be un≈øerviceable to our ≈øubject, to give a more particular in≈øtruction of their belief upon the ≈øtate of the Dead. I will not here ≈øpeak of their Carnal Paradi≈øe, becau≈øe I treat not of all the points of the Mahometan Religion, but only of what concerns the the Spirits; they acknowledge that there are appointed two very different places, one for the damned, and the other for the ≈øaved; that is to ≈øay, there are Men, who have done ≈øo many good works, that at the very hour they expire, they are admitted into the happine≈øs of Paradi≈øe; but there are others, who having not a ≈øufficient Faith, are ≈øubjected to I pains for their Sins, until they be all expiated; after which they enjoy in Paradi≈øe, the ≈øame felicity with the others, that are gone in fir≈øt. But as to the unfaithful and wicked, they go to burn forever in Hell, where there bodies are as often repaired by God, as they are reduced to A≈øhes, that their torments may be Eternal: That's the ≈øub≈øtance of what Thevenot writes, Chap. 20 and 31 of his journey, and Ricaut ≈øays almo≈øt the ≈øame thing, Chap. 2.6. and 12.

Sect. 12. The tran≈ømigration of Souls from one body into another, not only of Human Souls, but likewi≈øe of tho≈øe of Bea≈øts, is al≈øo believed by ≈øome Mahometans. Ricaut te≈øtifies, Book 2. Ch. 12. That one of their Sects, called Muna≈øichi, holds that Opinion; and takes occa≈øion from thence to relate how one Roboroski, a Polander, was dealt with by a Drugi≈øt, that was angry with him, becau≈øe he had kick'd his Dog, for they believe, That the Souls of Men after Death, enter into the bodies of ≈øuch Bea≈øts, with which the Nature and temper of the bodies, that were animated by tho≈øe Souls, had mo≈øt relation; that the Soul of a Glutton pa≈ø≈øed into the body of a Hog; that of a Letcherous, into that of a He-goat; that of a Generous per≈øon, is de≈øtin'd to animate a Hor≈øe, and that
of a Watchful Man to quicken a Dog. To this he adds, ≈øeveral circum≈øtances, which the curious may ≈øee in his own Book. He likewi≈øe a≈ø≈øerts that the Sect E≈øchrakin, that is, illuminated, is likewi≈øe Pythagorean, but that it holds not much of the Doctrines of the Alcoran, th√¥ mo≈øt of it's followers are the Schicks, or the Preachers and chief Doctors of the Turks. They have more rational Opinions than the others, concerning the immateriality of Spirits, and the Heavenly happine≈øs.

Sect. 13. For the Sahins or Sahis, of whom mention is made before, ≈øcarce believe that the Soul is immortal. Delavalle in his 4th Book, Ch. 23. de≈øcribes ≈øome Per≈øians that are like them, they are calied elh eltabquid, that is, People of truth or certainty. They con≈øtitute the E≈ø≈øence of the Soul in the mixture and union of the 4 Elements, as far as I can ob≈øerve by the explication he gives of their belief. The Soul returns to God in the ≈øame manner as ≈øhe proceeded from him, for ≈øhe proceeds from him, in as much as he is the Author of that complication, of the 4 Elements, and ≈øhe returns to him, in as much as he ≈øeparates them. That Sect is very numerous, th√¥ look'd upon as Heretical by other Per≈øians.

Sect. 14. Every one of tho≈øe various Opinions, is di≈øcoverable, by the practices of it's followers. Delavalle relates Ch. 17. that the Per≈øians have a great veneration for the greate≈øt and elde≈øt Trees, becau≈øe they per≈øwade them≈øelves, that they are the abode of the Souls of the ble≈ø≈øed; for which Rea≈øon they call them Pir, that is, An Ancient Man, or Scheich, the Elde≈øt, or Iman, Prie≈øt, ≈øuppo≈øing that the Souls of the Prie≈øts and Old Men, dwell in ≈øuch Trees. There are others, who having learned from Pythagoras, to enquire afrer the Virtue and My≈øtery of numbers, are addicted to all ≈øorts of Witchcraft, as the Inhabitants of the Coa≈øt of Coromandel,
Ch. 8 Sect. 5. They boa≈øt ≈øays Marmol, Book 2. Chap. 3. pag. 131. That the Cele≈øtial Spirits appear to them, and communicate to them an entire knowledge of the affairs of this World. They are much feared and reverenced in Africa, as being great ≈øorcerers. The rule they keep was compo≈øed by one Boni, named by the Arabs, The Father of Enchantments and Witchcrafts; the la≈øt of the three Books he has written is called The ≈øecret of the Divine Attributes; and treats of the Virtue of 90 Names of God. But 'tis fit to mention here, a ≈øort of Cabala in great reque≈øt with part of tho≈øe Nations, and like that of the Jews, ≈øave that it is not drawn from the Holy writ, for they name it a natural Science, but ≈øay, that he mu≈øt be an A≈øtrologer who pre≈øumes to put it in u≈øe.

Sect 15. The ≈øame Author adds, That in Great Cairo, and the Towns of Barbary, there is a va≈øt number of People that runs up and down, and pretend to three ≈øorts of Divination; ≈øome divine by the black Art with Draughts and Figures, ≈øome with a gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel full of Water, into which they power a drop of Oyl, that becomes very thin and clear, wherein they pretend to ≈øee Troops of Devils marching in order of Battle, ≈øome by Water, and others by Land; as ≈øoon as they ≈øtop, Queries are put to them, and they an≈øwer by ≈øigns with the Eyes and Hands. But to that Witchcraft, little Children are required, for the great ones ≈øee nothing, whereas the others look into the Oyl, and being asked, whether they ≈øee the ≈øigns which the Devils make, they an≈øwer yes, which gives them great credit, and gets them plenty of Money. The Catoptromancy of the Ancients was ≈øomthing like that, Chap. 3. Sect 10. That ≈øort of People are called in Mauritania, Moralcimines, that is, Enchanters, becau≈øe they boa≈øt of bewitching the Devils by words. The third ≈øort of tho≈øe rambling Diviners, are Women, that make People believe, they conver≈øe with Devils,
≈øome of whom are white, and others red or black. When they are about to Divine, they be≈ømoke them≈øelves with Sulphur and other ≈øtinking drugs; after which the Demon, as they ≈øay, ≈øeizes upon them, and they change their Voice as th√¥ be ≈øpake by their Mouth; then the enquirers approach and ask with great humblene≈øs, what they de≈øire, and having received an An≈øwer, go away leaving a pre≈øent in the Witches Hou≈øe.

Sect. 16. The Bumicils are doubtle≈øs great forcecers too, The≈øe fight again≈øt the Devils, as they ≈øay, and go all brui≈øed and cover'd with blows in a great fright; often at Noon day they counterfeit a Skirmi≈øh before the People, two or three hours long, with Spears or Zagaies, until they fall down all loaden with blows; but having re≈øted a while, they come to them≈øelves again, and walk. I could not hitherto di≈øcover what rule they follow, th√¥ they are held to be Monks. There are others in Barbary maimed exorci≈øts, who boa≈øt of expelling Devils, and when they cannot compa≈øs their end, they ≈øay that the party is credulous; or that it is a Cele≈øtial Spirit. The≈øe draw Circles, or write ≈øome Characters, and make marks on the Hand or Face of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed; then they be≈ømoke him with ≈øtinking ≈ømels, and make their Conjuration. They ask the Spirit how he is entered into that body, whence he comes, what he is, how he is call'd, and at la≈øt order him to be gone.

Sect. 17. I mu≈øt yet relate ≈øomthing out of Ricaut concerning the Turbes. There is a ≈øort of Dervis called Mevelevi, who turn with great skill and ≈øwiftne≈øs at the ≈øound of the Flute, affirming, that it is by devotion and the example of their Patron Mevelava, who always turned in that manner, without taking in any nouri≈øhment during a fortnight, whil≈øt his friend Haraze was playing on the in≈øtrument; at the end of which, he fell into an exta≈øie, wherein he received from Heaven, the rules of his order, with many wonderful revelations. Now his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, who are inclin'd to Lazine≈øs,
and yet cannot be quiet, follow his example in this manner. Some learn Legerdemains to amu≈øe People and apply them≈øelves to Magick and Conjurations, by the help of familiar Spirits. From this place, in which the Author ≈øpeaks of his own Head, it appears that he acknowledges ≈øome ≈øuch Spirits, and argues about them according to his Opinion. Afterwards he makes ≈øome quotations out of Busbeek that are very pertitent to our ≈øubject.

Sect. 18. There is, ≈øays he, in Egypt, a Cloy≈øter con≈øecrated to a Saint, called Kederlei; the Dervis that dwell in it, boa≈øt that by the Virtue of Kederlei they bewitch Serpents and Vipers, and handle them at boldly as innocent Bea≈øts. Others are not afraid of the ≈øtings of Vipers, or A≈øps, and put them with the Hand into bags, as we do worms, where they keep them. Others enchant Snakes by certain words, and make them ≈øtop on a ≈øudden, when they are creeping on the banks of the Nile, ≈øome of them pretend that power to be Hereditary in their Family, and to pa≈øs from Father to Son; and others boa≈øt, that it is a gift of God, in reward of Virtue and Holine≈øs. I have heard ≈øome Travellers ≈øay, there are Men in Per≈øia and the Indies, whom our People look'd upon as great ≈øorcerers, becau≈øe they made Serpents dance and ≈øtand upright in a box at the ≈øound of their Voice, at the winding of a Pipe, or the playing of ≈øome other Mu≈øical In≈øtrument. This will be matter of examination hereafter.

Sect. 19. Whatever has been hitherto ≈øaid of the Mahometans, makes it ≈øufficiently known, that among≈øt them, as among≈øt other Nations, their practices are an≈øwerable to their Doctrines; for if their Witchcraft and Exorci≈øms proceed not all from their ≈øuper≈øtitions, yet they are not incon≈øi≈øtent with them. It is ≈øtrange, that ≈øuch as a≈øcribe a Soul and Life to the Cele≈øtial Lamps, that acknowledge the
Stars to influence, Human Actions, and ≈øearch for My≈øteries, in numbers, letters and names, ≈øhould be addicted to Witchcraft and Divinations, and make them part of their religious wor≈øhip; neither is it ≈øurpri≈øing, that not conceiving Angels, as altogether immaterial, they ≈øhould fancy Apparitions, either waking or dreaming. 'Tis yet le≈øs ≈øtrange, looking upon them, as Creatures of a dignity inferior to their's, ≈øince they e≈øtabli≈øh great numbers of them for the guard of each Mu≈øulman; they ≈øhould invite and call them to their ≈øervice by Witchcraft, con≈øi≈øting in Characters, in which they imagine a ≈øecret virtue for that purpo≈øe; or if they ≈øhould believe, by the ≈øame means and Virtue to be able to expel wicked Angels, their mortal Enemies. But 'tis time to come to the Chri≈øtian World, and to examine in what ≈øtate things are at home.

div.head: CHAP. XV. That ≈øome of the Heathen Opinions upon this ≈øubject, have in proce≈øs of time, crept in among≈øt the Chri≈øtians.
div.p: Sect. 1. WE mu≈øt not wonder that great, part of the Doctrines above mentioned, have not yet been bani≈øhed by the light of the Go≈øpel. For what Man naturally conceives, is not always darkne≈øs, neither is the illumination which the Holy writ affords to the under≈øtanding, always efficacious; ≈øo that a Chri≈øtian, often better knows what he ought to know, then he does what he ought to do. This plainly appears, in that Man is readier to ≈øearch after the Truth by his rea≈øon, than to put it in practice by his Virtue. The cau≈øe of it is, that our natural curio≈øity that has contributed to the fall of our fir≈øt Parents, has been ≈øince increa≈øed and ≈øtrengthned by the effect of the fall it ≈øelf; and that it drives us on ≈øo much the more to de≈øire to know much, as our under≈øtanding is become le≈øs capable of true conceptions.
