Sect. 20. St. Jerom explains him≈øelf openly, as to the Mini≈øtery of the Angels upon the 9th Chap. of Daniel, Angelorum duplex officium e≈øt aliorum qui ju≈øtis praemia tribuunt, aliorum qui ≈øingulis prae≈øunt Cruciatibus. The Angels di≈øcharge 2 ≈øorts of functions, ≈øome are e≈øtabli≈øhed to di≈øtribute rewards to the ju≈øt;
and others, to inflict puni≈øhments on the Damned. It appears by the ≈øeries of his di≈øcour≈øe, and by the pa≈ø≈øage of the Holy Scripture, at which he aims; that he equally a≈øcribes tho≈øe 2 things to the good Angels, according to that Opinion, that there happens neither good nor evil without the Mini≈øtry of the Angels of God, and con≈øequently he attributes nothing to the Devil.

Sect. 21. Lactantius ≈øhows what were the Opinions of his time, concerning the Devil, of whom he makes a very large de≈øcription, in the 7th Book, of his In≈øtitutions, e≈øpecially Sect. 8. which de≈øerves, I ≈øhould give the ≈øhort of here. He ≈øays, That God produced a Spirit altogether like him that was endued with the Virtues of his Father. He ≈øeems, that thereby he ≈øhould under≈øtand our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Afterwards he created another Alterum, not Alium, that pre≈øerved not the perfections of his Cele≈øtial Original, becau≈øe, according to the meaning of
‚Ä¢ actantius, he envyed that fir≈øt Spirit, who remained faithful and obedient to God his Father: Wherefore the latter bears the name of Diabolus, Criminator, Accu≈øer and Slanderer. The Author ≈øtops there and ≈øpeaks no more of it, but Sect. 14. He ≈øays, that God, for that Rea≈øon, has granted to the Devil, power over the Earth, ab initio, from the begining; but to prevent, the Devil from ≈øeducing Men, he ≈øent Angels to defend them, adverti≈øing them withal, not to ≈øtain them≈øelves by their Conver≈øation with Men, but the Devil ≈øeduced the very Angels ≈øo far, that they mixt with Women, and were ca≈øt down from Heaven to Earth. If it were ≈øo, that old proverb would be verified, That there would be no Devils, if there were no hand≈øom Women.

Sect. 22. One thing's e≈øpecially ob≈øervable, that Athana≈øius in his Fir≈øt and Second Book again≈øt the Arrians, is the fir≈øt Author, as far as we know, that
applies to the fall of the Devil, that pa≈ø≈øage of I≈øaiah, Ch. 14. v. 12. How art thou fallen from Heaven, O Morning Star? which is undoubtedly ≈øaid of the King of Babilon, becau≈øe of the great figure he made in the World. Now the Morning Star is called in Greek „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and in Latin Lucifer, which words are ≈øtill to be read in the Greek and Hebrew Bibles, whence ≈øeveral that have followed St. Athana≈øius have taken occa≈øion to give the name of Lucifer to the Prince of the Devils, which name he ≈øtill bears. If tho≈øe who under≈øtand not the Latin Tongue, knew that is the name of the Morning Star, they would never be≈øtow it upon Belial, ≈øince it agrees ≈øo well to our Saviour, who calls him≈øelf the bright and Morning Star, Revel. Ch. 22. v. 16. to which St. Peter undoubtedly alludes in his Second Epi≈øtle, Ch. 1. v. 19. Where he ≈øays, That the Morning Star mu≈øt ari≈øe in our Hearts. And our promi≈øes in another ≈øen≈øe, to give us The Morning Star, Revel. 2.28. So that the name of Lucifer is ≈øo far from being that of the Prince of the Devils, th ‚Ä¢ t it is the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian name to be read in the Bible.

Sect. 23. Let's go back to Lactantius, he ≈øays that Mon≈øters were generated from that odious conjunction of Angels with Women, that are half Angels, or rather, Half Demons, or half Men, thence he infers, Duo genera daemonum, unum caele≈øte, alterum terrenum. That there are 2 ≈øorts of Demons, one of Cele≈øtial Demons, and another of Terre≈øtrial; by Cele≈øtial, he ≈øeems to under≈øtand Aerial; but after the word Terrenum, there follows immediatly, Hi ≈øunt immunedi malorum quae geruntur auctores, quorum idem diabolus e≈øt princeps. The≈øe are unclean Spirits, Authors of all the Evil that happens in the World, the chief of whom is the Devil already mentioned. From this pa≈ø≈øage may be clearly perceived, that he takes for Demons, tho≈øe very ≈øame Spirits whom the Heathens made
their Gods, as has been ≈øeen Ch. 2. Sect. 9 to 13, which ≈øtill confirms more and more what I have a≈ø≈øerted, Ch. 5. Sect. 4, 5. That the Heathen never adored Demons, but in as much as they believed them to be Gods.

Sect 24. The ≈øame Lactantius tells us, that the Demons are indeed Spirits, but Spiritus tenues & incomprehen≈øibiles, Spirits of a thin ≈øubtle matter, and imperceptible. This we have heard before from Origen and Tertullian. He explains him≈øelf very clearly, as to the power he a≈øcribe to their under≈øtanding, ≈øaying, That they know many future things, but that it is not po≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould di≈øcover the depths of the ≈øecrets of God. We have already heard Tertullian confirming this propo≈øition, by his Rea≈øonings. However Lactantius believes, that Divinations by the Contemplation of the Stars, by the In≈øpection of the intrals of Bea≈øts, and by the Ob≈øervation of Birds, of which mention has been made; Ch. 3. Sect. 4, 5, 7. Are Diabolical In≈øpirations, and therefore holds, that they are ≈øtill capable of di≈øcovering to Men many future things.

Sect. 25. St. Jerom as far as I can conceive, con≈øtitutes not the ≈øame difference of places betwixt the Spirits. Yet he believes, Ex Pauli dictis ad Ephe Cap. 2. ver. 2. & 12. colligi Diabolos in aere vagari ac dominari. That from what S. Paul writes to the Ephe≈øians may be inferr'd, That the Devils are wandering in the Air, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ igning there. And writing upon the 6th Ch. v. 12. to the Ephe≈øians, he explains more at large, that propo≈øition, as containing the common Opinion of the Chri≈øtians of that Age. This is the Opinion of all the Doctors, That the Air which is betwixt the Heavens and the Earth, ≈øeparating both from what it call'd the Vacuum, is fil'd with powers contrary to each other. We mu≈øt yet examine hereafter whence the Principalities,
Powers, and Dominions of this World, have received their powert? His Opinion upon this la≈øt Que≈øtion is, that they have it from God him≈øelf, and that they exerci≈øe it more or le≈øs, as a le≈øs and greater pain is inflicted upon 2 different Criminals, according as 'tis re≈øolved to make their life more or le≈øs bitter; he al≈øo ≈øuppo≈øes, that the unclean Spirits, as well as the Holy Angels, are divided into certain Orders; which Opinion of his may be ≈øeen in his Commentary on the 3 Ch. of Habakuk, As Chri≈øt is the head of the Church, and of every particular faithful Man; ≈øo is Belzebub the chief of all the Demons, who exerci≈øe ≈øo many cruelties in this World; and each Troop of Demons has it's particular Chief, and Captain under him.

Sect. 26. Lactantius mu≈øt yet inform us what in his Opinion, the Demons were able to Operate, in reference to Men. We ≈øee Sect. 14. that his Opinion in general, is, That the Corrupted and Contagious Spirits wander'd through the World, endeavouring to comfort them≈øelves under their lo≈øs, by procuring the ruin of Mankind. Immediatly after, he explains in particular, how they hurt Soul and Body, They attack, ≈øays he, The Souls by their craft devi≈øes, and the ≈ønares they lay before them; they ≈øeize upon them by their delu≈øions, and by leading them a≈øtray, they ≈øtick to every private per≈øon, and are always at his elbow, creeping into every hou≈øe, from door to door. And in relation to the bodies, as tho≈øe very Spirits are, according to him partly corporeal, and partly extraordinary ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tle, and con≈øequently imperceptible, They in≈øinuate into Human Bodies, without being perceived, act privately within their Bowels, impair their Health, cau≈øe Di≈øea≈øes, ca≈øt terror into the mind by Dreams, overturn it, make it ≈øtray, and force Men by ≈øuch vexations, to have recour≈øe to them. It ≈øeems however, that he intends to a≈øcribe that power to the Devil, only over the Heathens; becau≈øe he di≈øputes
again≈øt them, and that they were tho≈øe that had recour≈øe to the Demons, as believing them to be Gods; for over the Chri≈øtians, the Ancient Fathers attributed not ≈øo much power to them.

Sect. 27. We may learn from St. Athana≈øius, what were the Opinions of his time, as to the Souls ≈øeparated from their Bodies after Death. In the Book before quoted, que≈øtion 32. he asks, Whether the Souls after their ≈øeparation, have knowledge of what is done among≈øt Men, as the Holy Angels have; he an≈øwers, Yes at lea≈øt as to the Souls of the Saints, but not as to tho≈øe of Sinners; for their continual torments take them ≈øo much up, that they have no lea≈øure to think upon any other thing. The 33th Que≈øtion is, What is the employment of the Souls departed from their Bodies, An≈øwer, The Soul ≈øeparated from the Body, is uncapa? ble of doing either good or evil. However he ≈øays a little after, That the Souls of the Saints, animated by the Holy Gho≈øt, prai≈øe God, and ble≈øs him in the Land of the Living. He a≈ø≈øerts, Que≈øtion 35. That after Death, the Souls never come to bring news of the ≈øtate of the Decea≈øed; which would give occa≈øion to many cheats, becau≈øe wicked Spirits might feign, that they are Souls of the Decea≈øed, that come back to di≈øcover ≈øomthing to the Living. I de≈øire the Reader to ob≈øerve this very attentively, for it will be convenient to reflect upon it hereafter.

Sect. 28. St. Au≈øtin gives us a more large information, for th√¥ he does not expre≈øly reject Purgatory, yet he confutes it every where, as appears from ≈øeveral places of his Writings, that have been quoted by one of my predece≈ø≈øors, Andrew Land≈øman, in his Book of the Apo≈øta≈øy of the Church of Rome: yet this Father in the 69th Chapter of his Manual, expre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf thus, 'Tis not incredible, but ≈øomthing like may happen after this life, and it may rea≈øonably be enquired whether it is ≈øo, and what proof may be
brought for or again≈øt this Opinion, viz. that ≈øome of the faithful, come ≈øooner or later to the Eternal Felicity, pa≈ø≈øing through a certain purging Fire, in which they ≈øtay longer or ≈øhorter, as they are more or le≈øs enamour'd with corruptible things; however in that number, are not comprehended tho≈øe of whom 'tis ≈øaid, that they ≈øhall not po≈ø≈øe≈øs the Kingdom of God, unle≈øs by a convenient Repentance, they obtain forgivene≈øs of their Sins.

Sect. 29. We come down to the 5th Age, in which we meet with Theodoret, who ≈øufficiently explains, as to our de≈øign, the Opinions of the Doctors of his time concerning good and bad Angels; for he propo≈øes to us what he thinks of the Angels, properly ≈øo call'd, as well in reference to their Nature, as to their Under≈øtanding and Admini≈øtration. As to the fir≈øt point he holds, that though they are not Corporeal, yet they are Circum≈øcribed, and contained in a certain determinate place; as he a≈ø≈øerts in his 3d Que≈øtion upon Gene≈øis. The Rea≈øon of this Opinion is, that he ≈øuppo≈øes every Angel has ≈øome proper Admini≈øtration, and is entru≈øted with the care either of a Nation, or Per≈øon; but he makes ≈øtill a more particular di≈øtinction in his 10th Expo≈øition upon Daniel, putting a Man under the guard of a common Angel, and a whole Nation under that of an Angel of a Superior Order. As to their Under≈øtanding, he briefly explains his Mind in the≈øe Words. Let none be ≈øurpri≈øed at what I a≈ø≈øert, as to the Ignorance of the Heavenly Spirits; for they neither know future, nor other things, it only belonging to the Divine Nature; but as to Angels, Archangels, and other Coele≈øtial Spirits, they know no more than what they learn; and therefore the Holy Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaking of them in the the third Chapter to the Ephe≈øians, v. 10. ≈øays, That to Principalities and Powers, in the Heavenly Places, &c. See his Commentary on the 24th P≈øalm.

Sect. 30. Theodoret ≈øpeaks afterwards of the Demons in the ≈øame manner, for he holds them not capable of making true Predictions. He ≈øays, upon Ezekiel, Sect. 8. That the Demons know nothing before it happens, unle≈øs it be by gue≈ø≈øing, and yet they venture to foretell. He neverthele≈øs owns, in his tenth Book of Oracles, that the Spirits have foretold ≈øomething true, but by the Stars: For, ≈øays he, whatever the Gods of the Heathens ≈øay, if it happens that they ≈øpeak agreeably to the Concatenation of things, they mu≈øt needs gather that knowledge from the Stars, which undoubtedly was done by ≈øuch Gods as declared ≈øome things that afterwards fell out. 'Tis evident, that by Demons he under≈øtands in general, wicked Spirits, who cau≈øe them≈øelves to be venerated as Gods, and gave fal≈øe Oracles to keep up their Authority, and the Credit in which they were among≈øt the Heathens. That Opinion was the mo≈øt common among≈øt the Ancients, and is in being even to this day, as we ≈øhall ≈øhow hereafter.

Sect. 31. The Opinion of that time upon the original of the wicked Race, was, that they i≈ø≈øued from the Conver≈øation of the Angels with Women. Severus Sulpitius relates it not as a particular Belief, or, as received by ≈øome Doctors only; but as a Story credited by all Chri≈øtians; for at the beginning of his Eccle≈øia≈øtical Hi≈øtory, he pre≈øumes to a≈ø≈øert it upon the Authority of Jo≈øephus, as much as if he had been pre≈øent. His words are; In that time, that is, after the Birth of Noah, Mankind multiplying exceedingly, the Angels who≈øe abode was in Heaven, being enamour'd with the Beauty of young Virgins, plunged them≈øelves in unlawful plea≈øures, for≈øook the Supream Region, who≈øe Inhabitants they were, and ally them≈øelves by Marriages with mortal Women, by that unhappy Cohabitation, and their depraved Morals, they corrupted Mankind by degrees; and from thence the Giants are
≈øaid to be born; for the mixture of ≈øuch different natures mu≈øt needs produce Mon≈øters.

Sect. 32. As to the ≈øtate of Souls ≈øeparated from their Body, the Angels, and wicked Spirits, this Age affords nothing but what has been ob≈øerved, ≈øpeaking of the foregoing Centuries. Wherefore we de≈øcend to Gregory the Great, who in the 7th Century joyn'd his particular Opinions to the former. He was Bi≈øhop of Rome, and his Memory is ≈øtill in great Veneration in that Church, tho' he took it very ill that John the Father, Bi≈øhop of Con≈øtantinople, and his Contemporary, ≈øhould have pre≈øumed to take upon him the Name of ∆≤niver≈øal Bi≈øhop, to which he believed not that any Bi≈øhop had a right, and even held it for a Mark of Antichri≈øt. Be≈øides, 'tis not without Rea≈øon, that the Roman Church makes ≈øo much of him: For he has taken care to provide her with many Legends ≈øo ≈øuitable to her Humour and Palate, and upon which ≈øhe has put ≈øo great a value, that ≈øhe multiplies them every year. And indeed, St. Gregory was not contented with the Fables of Origen, and other Doctors, of which mention has been made, but he admitted whatever had been propo≈øed hitherto as Doubts and Que≈øtions, which he pa≈ø≈øed into Determinations and Decrees: And, as tho' what had been maintained before had not been ≈øufficient, he thought fit to add ≈øomething of his own: So that ≈øince his time there were not only 9 Orders of Angels, but they knew al≈øo the Degrees of each, viz. Angels, Archangels, Virtue, Powers, Principalities, Dominions, Thrones, Cherubims, and Seraphims; as is to be found in his 34th Homily upon the Go≈øpels. The Schoolmen that have followed him fail not to take much pains to treat of each of the≈øe Angelical orders, and to break their head with them, in which I intend not to imitate them.

Sect. 33. It mu≈øt be ob≈øerved that at that time the curio≈øity to know whither Souls went after Death, gave occa≈øion by degrees to invent Purgatory; the di≈øcovery of which has been ≈øo far fini≈øhed among≈øt the Papi≈øts, that they go now thither by thou≈øands. Boetius, a Roman Con≈øul, who lived about 63 years before the Pontificate of Gregory, begun, in his 4th Book, Pro≈øa 4. to give ≈øome Notion of that place, by the An≈øwer he makes to the following Que≈øtion. Does there in your Opinion remain no puni≈øhment for the Soul after her ≈øeparation from the Body? To which he An≈øwers: Yes doubtle≈øs, and even 'tis not a ≈ølight Pain; for I hold; that ≈øome Souls are very ≈øeverely puni≈øhed, whereas others are purified by Grace. As to Gregory him≈øelf, who from a Souldier became Pope, he blows heat and cold from the ≈øame Mouth, with as much ≈øickline≈øs and levity as the Wind, again≈øt the Cu≈øtom of the Popes, who u≈øe to decide ≈øo po≈øitively and boldly. Upon the 7th Chapter of Job, giving advice to a Sinner, he ≈øaith, That there is no human Eye (that is no Grace of the Redeemer) that ca≈øts looks upon the Soul, after ≈øhe has laid off the Fle≈øh. And farther he adds; That when Holy or wicked Spirit receives at the point of Death, a Soul departing from her bodily Pri≈øon, ≈øhe remains for ever, and without hopes of any Change, in the hands of him that has taken her; ≈øo that when ≈øhe's once rai≈øed to Glory, ≈øhe can never fall again into Pain and Torments; whereas when ≈øhe is once ca≈øt down into the Eternal Aby≈øs, ≈øhe can never come out of it: Upon the 10th Chapter he ≈øays again; He that is Condemned and deliver'd to puni≈øhment by rea≈øon of his Sins, and brought to the place of Execution, has no longer hopes of Mercy or Forgivene≈øs. But this Pope does not always maintain this The≈øis; for he ≈øpeaks thus in the 4th. Book of his Dialogues, Chap. 39. Sed samen de quibu≈ødam levibus culpis e≈ø≈øe Purgatorius Ignis

credendus e≈øt: However it mu≈øt be believed that there is a Purging Fire for ≈øome ≈ømall Faults. Upon the Penitential P≈øalms, he explains him≈øelf more at large. Po≈øt mortem carnis alii aeternis deputantur ≈øuppliciis, alii ad vitam per ignem tran≈øcunt Purgationis. After the death of the Body, ≈øome are condemned to endle≈øs Torments, and others go to Life through a purging Fire.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. That ≈øome of the fir≈øt Chri≈øtians derided the Conjurations of Spirits, and others credited and practi≈øed them.
div.p:
Sect. 1. WE are now to examine, whether the practice of Divination and Witchcraft were in reque≈øt in the fir≈øt time of the Chri≈øtian Church. Both were equally rejected by tho≈øe that were called Catholicks and Orthodox: but we mu≈øt enquire upon what ground; for it was not ≈øo much becau≈øe they believed 'em to he deceiving Arts, the practice of which was impo≈ø≈øible, as that they judge 'em unlawful. Be≈øides, they ackowledg'd ≈øo far the efficacy of Conjurations that they did not at mo≈øt reject 'em, but came in proce≈øs of time to admit them in the Ceremony of Bapti≈øm, which are, ≈øtill call'd Exorci≈øms, generally us'd among≈øt the Papi≈øts, and not entirely aboli≈øhed among≈øt ≈øome Prote≈øtants. Tho' this be not the place to treat at large of this matter, yet it may be premi≈øde, that this is their mo≈øt ancient Original, as the
Writings of ≈øome of their Doctors plainly te≈øtify. But let us hear fir≈øt, how the Laws of the Fir≈øt Chri≈øtians thunder'd again≈øt tho≈øe that dur≈øt meddle with Exorci≈øms and Conjurations.

Sect. 2. Here is the Proclamation of the Emperor Con≈øtantine, in the 9th Book of the Code, Tit. 8. Book 5. De Divinatoribus. Let no body pre≈øume to interrogate Diviners, or to con≈øult Mathematicians and A≈øtrologers. Silence is al≈øo enjoyn'd to Augurers, and Fortune-tellers. Caldees, Magicians, and tho≈øe that are called Sorcerers, becau≈øe of the hainou≈øne≈øs of their crime, ≈øhall not be allowed to undertake or exerci≈øe their Art. The curio≈øity of tho≈øe that con≈øult Oracles, ≈øhall be repre≈ø≈øed. If any obey not our Orders, he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed by the Steel, till he be dead, Given at Milan, January 25. 337. Here is another Proclamation of the Emperors Valentinianus, Theodo≈øius and Arcadius. If any be found guilty of Magick, he ≈øhall be arre≈øted add deliver'd to Ju≈øtice, as an enemy of Mankind, &c. Given at Rome, Aug. 17. 389. The re≈øt may be ≈øeen in tho≈øe Laws, and is ≈øufficiently known to Civilians. Con≈øtantine, in the beginning of his Reign in 312. had ordained the pain of Fire for ≈øuch as ≈øhould be convicted of that Crime, and promi≈øed a Reward to the Informers, Law the 3d. Tit. 8. de Maleficis comprehendendis & ad publicum pertrahendis.

Sect. 3. In the mean while, tho≈øe pains were not inflicted upon that ≈øort of people ≈øo much, becau≈øe, of their Cheats, as has been already ≈øaid; as e≈øpecially, by rea≈øon of their Crimes, and the hurt they were believed to procure to Men and Bea≈øts, by mixing and perturbating the Elements by their Witchcraft, which made them worthy of the mo≈øt cruel puni≈øhments. This plainly appears by the 6th Law made by Con≈øtantine and Julian. Anno 357. There are ≈øeveral who are not afraid of confounding the
Elements by Witchcraft, and a≈ø≈øaulting the Life of Man, who cannot defend him≈øelf again≈øt them; of conjuring up Gho≈øts and asking their advice, to de≈øtroy their Enemies by wicked ways, Whence it appears, a double Power was attributed to Sorcerers and Inchanters; Fir≈øt, of confounding the Elements; and Secondly, of Conjuring up Gho≈øts, making them appear, and di≈øcour≈øing with them. It was therefore believed, that the Crime of that People con≈øi≈øted in their conver≈øe with the Spirits, who≈øe Power and malice they made u≈øe of to torment other Men. So that 'tis no doubt but that Opinion was then general among the Chri≈øtians, and even among≈øt the Mob of the Heathens; or at lea≈øt of the greate≈øt part among≈øt them, who lived and conver≈øed with the Chri≈øtians, ≈øo that either of them addicting them≈øelves to that Conver≈øe, whether they were per≈øwaded of the Power of Spirits or not, made them≈øelves equally guilty, and obnoxious to the ≈øeverity of the Law.

Sest. 4. The chief Doctors of that time teach us the ≈øame, but I ≈øhall quote only a few that will afford us ≈øufficient proofs. I ≈øhall begin with Ju≈øtin Martyr, who lived in the 2d. Age, and ≈øhows in his 2d, Apology, that he acknowledged the efficacy and virtue of the Heathen Witchcraft. In the new Edition of Cologne Pag. 65. The Predictions them≈øelves that are made by the means of the dead, by young innocent Children that ≈øee Objects in a mirror; by the calling up of the Souls of the decea≈øed, and by tho≈øe that are call'd by the Magicians, Expounders of Dreams Paredri A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øores, A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors. In ≈øhort, whatever is operated by tho≈øe that are skilful in tho≈øe practices, mu≈øt per≈øwade you; ≈øays he to the Heathens, that the Souls have ≈øtill ≈øome Sen≈øe after death. What he writes in his Dialogue again≈øt Tripho the Jew, differs not much from that Fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øage, ib. Pag. 311.
That the Demons may be overcome by Conjurations, in the name of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, but that no Jew can do the ≈øame in the name of any King, Prophet or Patriarch; not even perhaps in the name of the God of Abraham, I≈øaac and Jacob. He neverthele≈øs believes, that the Demons, by means of that ≈øort of Diviners, that were called Ventriloqui, gave real Oracles to tho≈øe that Conjur'd them, as may be gather'd from his 33th Que≈øtion, and from the An≈øwer to it.

Sect. 5. Proceeding farther, whatever is needful for our de≈øign, is to learn the Sentiments of the Fathers, as to the power and efficacy of the Conjurations, that were practi≈øed, both by the Heathens and Chri≈øtians. St. Cyprian, in the 3d, Century, ≈øufficiently Declares, that in the Chri≈øtian Religion Bapti≈øm has power, by the Ble≈ø≈øing of Chri≈øt, to expel wicked Spirits, which gives occa≈øion to believe, that they were po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of Men, before their being ca≈øt out by that Holy Sacrament. And indeed he writes in his 7th, Letter of the 1≈øt Book, That as Pharaoh, after much re≈øi≈øtance, was at la≈øt drowned in the water; ≈øo the Devil is yet now a-days abu≈øed and tormented by the Exorci≈øts, who≈øe voice is indeed only human, but attended by the Virtue of God. For a little farther he ≈øays, when by the Saving water we receive the Sanctification of Bapti≈øm, we may be ≈øure that the power of the Devil is overcome, and the per≈øon con≈øecrated to God, freed by his mercy. It happens at the ≈øame time, according to him, that Scorpions and Serpents cannot abide water, ≈øo the infernal Dragon cannot endure the Water of Bapti≈øm.

Sect. 6. He a≈øcribes the ≈øame Virtue to the name of Je≈øus, when in his Sermon upon Bapti≈øm, ≈øpeaks of mercenary Exorci≈øts, de quae≈øtuariis exorci≈øtis Obediunt Daemon ‚Ä¢ s Exorci≈øtis, &c. The
Demons obey Exorci≈øts, ≈øaying, we know who is Chri≈øt, and who is Paul, and being conjured in the name of that Je≈øus, whom Paul Preaches, we withdraw. It ≈øeems to St, Cyprian, that things ought to be ≈øo by the ≈øame rea≈øon that Bapti≈øm was valid, whether admini≈øtred by Paul or Judas: But he ought to have con≈øidered, that we have not the ≈øame certainty that the≈øe Exorci≈øts ≈øhould have received their Office from God, as we are ≈øure that he had e≈øtabli≈øhed Judas in his Apo≈øtle≈øhip.

Sect. 7. Lactantius, in the 4th Century, will yet give us ≈øome in≈øtructions. And Fir≈øt, as to Conjurations, that we treat now of, he believed that they have a great efficacy; for he writes in his Second Book, Sect. 15. That the Devils are afraid of the Ju≈øt that wor≈øhip God, ≈øince being conjured by them in his Name, they go out of Bodies, and being compell'd by their words, as by ≈øtripes, they not only acknowledg'd that they are Demons, but al≈øo declare their Names, that are found to be the ≈øame, under which they are adored in Temples, So that he believes that the wicked Spirit, how great a Lyer ≈øoever he is, cannot lye, when by Conjuration he is forced to ≈øpeak, becau≈øe the Divine Power con≈øtrains him to ≈øay the Truth for that time.

Sect. 8. In the mean while he ≈øticks not to that, but agrees with St. Cyprian, that the modern ≈øorcerers were able to enchant wicked Spirits, and by that argument, pretends to prove to Epicure and his followers, that there are Spirits in the World, and that Human Souls are immortal. To that end, he expre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf in the≈øe words, Book the 7th, Sect. 13. Certainly if Democritus, Epicure, or Dicearchus, ≈øtood by a Magician, they ≈øhould not make bold to maintain by their Rea≈øons, that the Soul is Mortal; what could they an≈øwer? If the Magician by pronouncing ≈øome Ver≈øes, call'd up the Souls' from ≈øubterraneous places
making them appear to Men, ≈øpeak to them, and foretel future things; for if they ≈øtill pre≈øume to per≈øi≈øt in their error, they would be forced to yeild to ≈øuch real proofs, and ≈øuch vi≈øible effects.

Sect. 9. However, I cannot agree to what is read in his 2 Book, Sect. 14. That the Art and Power of Magicians, Magorum, only con≈øi≈øts in the In≈øpirations they receive from the Spirits, that ≈øurprize Men, and deceive their Eyes by Illu≈øions, hindering them from ≈øeeing what is, and making them ≈øee what is not, when 'tis required from them by Magicians. He ≈øeem'd before to believe, that the Demons actually produce ≈øome effects, and here he will per≈øwade us, that there is nothing but illu≈øion: whatever it be, even that very illu≈øion is ≈øtill an Operation of the Demons, and con≈øequently approve of their exi≈øtence and action. In the mean while he agrees with him≈øelf in this, that he believes ≈øorcerers conver≈øe with the wicked Spirit, and that the Conjurations of the former, force the latter to ≈øay and do what is required from them; but that all the effects of Witchcraft are to be a≈øcribed to them, and not to the Magicians.

Sect. 10. Lactantius was per≈øwaded that bad Spirits had a ≈øhare in all tho≈øe Arts, that made up the practices of the Ancient Heathens, and of which mention has been made, Ch. 3. He even believed that they were all invented by tho≈øe Spirits, as appears by his own words, Book 2. Ch. 16. The things that they have invented, viz. The Demons, are predictions, by the Stars, by the in≈øpection of Victims, and by the cry of Birds; the≈øe are the Oracles and Enchantments in u≈øe, to con≈øult the Dead, by Magick, Magia and all the other Evils to which Men addict them≈øelves, either privately or openly. All the≈øe things have nothing ≈øolid nor true in them≈øelves, but are received for ≈øuch, by the credit they borrow from the pre≈øence of their Authors,
who know how to impo≈øe upon the credulity of Men, affecting to make a divine power appear before them, of which however, no profit accrues to them. I might quote here ≈øome Authors of the two following Centuries, but ob≈øerving no change in them that de≈øerves to be related, and fearing to in≈øi≈øt too long upon this: I come to the bottom of the matter, le≈øt I ≈øhould weary the Reader with unprofitable trouble.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. That it is nece≈ø≈øary to compare all tho≈øe various Doctrines and Practices of the Jews, Mahometans, and Chri≈øtians; and to examine wherein they differ, and in what they agree together.
div.p:
Sect. 1. THE 11th Chapter of this Book was de≈øigned to compare together, the Opions and practices of the various Heathens, concerning Spirits. The natural light that remained in our under≈øtanding, notwith≈øtanding the darkne≈øs in which it has been involv'd by Sin, has been able, without the help of the Holy writ, to di≈øcover, whether tho≈øe Opinion and practices, were founded upon true, or fal≈øe grounds. We have ≈øince heard, tho≈øe that acknowledge the Authority of the Holy writ, ≈øpeak very differently, by which means, the light of Rea≈øon may be encrea≈øed, and it's corruption better'd. Let us now ≈øee what they have done as to this, and how far their endeavours have attained. To that end, we ≈øhall Fir≈øt con≈øider, wherein the latter differ from the Heathens, what they have retain'd of Pagani≈øm; and la≈øtly in what points they differ from each other; having always
regard to that difference of Doctrines, and Wor≈øhip, or Opinions and Practices, that have been ≈øet down before.

Sect. 2. The≈øe 3 ≈øorts of People, Jews, Chri≈øtians, and Mahometans, rejecting the plurality of Gods that were believed and adored by the Heathens, and Wor≈øhiping one Only God, have overthrown whatever the others had invented, concerning confederate, inferior, and mean Gods, or familiar Spirits, that were born with Men and outlive them; and at the ≈øame time, have de≈øtroyed whatever Conjurations and Witchcrafts were grounded upon ≈øuch principles, by which Men pre≈øume to acquire ≈øome certain knowledge, and produce ≈øome certain effects. We have found nothing like, among≈øt the Jews and Mahometans; for th√¥ they may have ≈øomthing that appears like it, yet 'tis quite different, as we ≈øhall ≈øhow hereafter. And as to the Chri≈øtians, we ≈øee that they unanimou≈øly reject all the≈øe things, and look upon them as delu≈øions and impieties; and as to what the la≈øt, together with the Jews and Mahometans, have retained of the Opinions and practices of the Heathens, it has been taken from the Philo≈øophy of this la≈øt Sect, and accommodated to the Holy Scripture, or gather'd from it by fal≈øe explications. This I ≈øhall now briefly ≈øhow, concerning the Spirits in general, and the Soul of Man in particular.

Sect. 3. As to the Spirits in general. Fir≈øt, That Opinion, that they are partly corporeal, received of old by the Jews, Ch. 12. Sect. 5, 11, to 15 By the Mahometans, Ch. 14. Sect. 4, 5. and by the Chri≈øtians, Ch. 15. Sect. 5, 14, 15, 23, 24, 31. draws it's Original from the Philo≈øophy of the Heathens, as has been ≈øhown, Ch. 2. Sect. 14, 16. Ch. 11. Sect. 6.

Second. The Opinion that a≈øcribes ≈øome life and under≈øtanding to the ≈øtars, as to the Sun and Moon;
whether it be in≈øignificantly expre≈øs'd, as among the Jews, Ch. 12. Sect. 3, 13. or only darkly as among≈øt the Mahometans; or propo≈øed as a doubt, as it has been by Origen and St. Au≈øtin, among≈øt the Chri≈øtians, Ch. 15. Sect. 11, 19. That Opinion, I ≈øay looks very Heatheni≈øh, and differs not much from the Intelligencies of Ari≈øtotle, Ch. 2, Sect. 5. Nor from the e≈øteem which the modern Heathens have for tho≈øe cele≈øtial Lamps, of which mention has been made, Ch. 6. Sect. 2. Ch. 11. Sect. 2.
Sect. 4. We may al≈øo ea≈øily compare their belief touching Human Souls.

Fir≈øt,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ inion of the tran≈ømigration of Souls, ≈øo common am ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g≈øt the Heathens, Ch. 2. Sect. 17. is not rejected by the Jews, but converted into that of the revolution of the Souls, Ch. 12. Sect. 19. It is publickly t ‚Ä¢ ught by ≈øome Mahometans, Ch. 14. Sect. 12. As to the Chri≈øtians, 'tis true, that they admit it not, th√¥ ≈øomthing like it be found in Origen, Ch. 15. Sect 13. But I mu≈øt ≈øay by the way, that I ≈øee not how tho≈øe that ≈øtill hold, that all Human Souls were created together in the beginning, and afterwards each in his time, introduced into their bodies, could ≈øolidly confute that Opinion of the Metemp≈øycho≈øis.

Second. The Jews, Mahometans, and Chri≈øtians, too ea≈øily credit the apparitions of Souls, which takes place among≈øt the Jews, becau≈øe they ≈øuppo≈øe the Souls to wander for a Year, about the bodies from which they are ≈øeparated, Ch. 12. Sect, 20. Neither can the Mahometans reject that Opinion, ≈øince they hold the Souls to be made up of the Elements, Ch. 14. Sect. 13. and that after their ≈øeparation from the body, they ≈øee and hear in Trees, Sect. 14. As to the Chri≈øtians, we find Ju≈øtin, one of the Fir≈øt, who ≈øays, that a ≈øeparated Soul may yet operate upon living per≈øons, Sect. 5. All the Opinions that are related here, are drawn from Philo≈øophy, or mixed with
Pagani≈øm. But the Holy Writ, either taken in its true Sen≈øe, or mi≈ø-interpreted, has given occa≈øion to the following, which we ≈øhall mention hereafter.

Fir≈øt, The opinion that the Angels have been created from Fire, Air, or the mo≈øt ≈øubtile Elements, which the Jews only hint. Chap. 12. Sect. 15. but what the Mahometans publickly teach, Chap 14, Sect. 4. has likewi≈øe been received by ≈øome Chri≈øtians, Chap. 15. Sect. 4, 5, 24. becau≈øe they thought it con≈øonant to what is ≈øaid, P≈øal. 104. ver. 4. That God makes Spirits his Angels, and flames of fire his Mini≈øters, 2 Kings 2.11. that Elijah was taken up into Heaven in a Chariot with fiery hor≈øes, Chap. 6.17. That they defended Eli≈øha, and that Ezekiel, Chap. 1.4, 5. ≈øaw the likene≈øs of four Animals going out of the mid≈øt of fire; ≈øeveral other mi≈øunder≈øtood pa≈ø≈øages have contributed to the e≈øtabli≈øhing of that Opinion.

Second. The Morning Stars rejoycing together when God ceeated the World, Job 38.7. gave occa≈øion to Philo, as has been ob≈øerved, Chap. 12. Sect. 4. to confirm him≈øelf in that Opinion, that the Stars are ∆≤nder≈øtanding Beings; as has been likewi≈øe proved as to many other Authors.
Sect. 6. It likewi≈øe appears, that tho≈øe that believe Spirits to be corporeal, ground their Opinion upon the Holy Scripture.

Fir≈øt, for having no Idea of other Sons of God, that fell in love with the Daughters of Men, as is mention'd Gen. 6. but of ≈øuch as are di≈øtingui≈øhed and ≈øeparated from Men: And conceiving not the true nature of Spiritual Beings, they fancied that the Angels had begotten tho≈øe Giants, of whom 'tis ≈øpoken in that place; add to this, that they could not think that tho≈øe Nephilim (which word we Tran≈ølate Gyants) ≈øhould be other Creatures, be≈øides
fall'n Angels, who for that rea≈øon are called by that Name, which ≈øignifies as much as Rebels. We have ≈øeen that Opinion received by the Jews, Chap. 12. Sect. 14. By the Mahometans, Chap. 14. Sect. 5. and even by ≈øome Chri≈øtians, Chap. 15. Sect. 5, 31.

Second. I grant that it may be inferr'd from thence, that there are Incubi and Succubi, that is Devils, who now in the ≈øhape of Males, then of Females, lye with Men and Women; that Opinion of the Jews is ≈øtill now a days much di≈øper≈øed among the Chri≈øtians, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed hereafter.

Sect. 7. Such are their Sentiments, as to the nature and fall of the Angels; but as to their di≈øtinction into ≈øeveral Orders, and the ≈øhare they bear in the Government of the World, the ≈øame differences, or very near, are a≈øcribed to them that are atributed to the Heathen Gods and Spirits. Chap. 11. Sect. 6. And that Opinion is ≈øtrengthned by a mi≈øunder≈øtanding of the Holy Scripture.

Fir≈øt, The Jews explain them≈øelves clearly and largely upon the different Orders of Angels. Chap. 12. Sect. 4, 7, 11. The Mahometans treat of it more confu≈øedly and ob≈øcurely Chap. 14. Sect. 16, 17, 18, 25, 32. but the Chri≈øtians ≈øpeak of it, as tho' it could not be doubted but the Holy Writ under≈øtands ≈øuch a Hierarchy of Angels, by the different names it gives them.

Second. As the Heathens fill'd the Air with Spirits, or placed them above, under, and in the midle of the World, Chap. 2. Sect. 6. Chap. 7. Sect. 2.5, 8. So have the Jews, according to Philo, Chap. 12. Sect. 5, 12. Neither do the Chri≈øtians di≈øagree from them. Chap. 14. Sect. 25. Suppo≈øing that Opinion to be confirmed in the Scripture, Ephe≈ø. Chap. 2.2. Chap. 6.12. and by ≈øeveral pa≈ø≈øages in the Hi≈øtory of Job.

Third. They agree together again, in that they acknowledge as many Guardian Angels of Men and Nations, as the Heathens did their Titular Gods. The Opinion of the Jews, as to this point, may be in ≈øome manner perceived by the quotations that are ≈øet down Chap. 12. Sect. 4.10. That of the Mahometans, is more clearly expre≈øs'd, Chap. 14. Sect. 9. But that of the Chri≈øtians ≈øtill plainer. Chap. 15. Sect. 6, 17, 18, 29. to which they have applyed the pa≈ø≈øages of the Holy Writ already mention'd.

Sect. 8. It goes, even ≈øo, with their belief of the Devils; Fir≈øt, we hear the Jews, Chap. 12. Sect. 13, 16. The Mahometans, Chap. 14. Sect. 5. and the Chri≈øtians, Chap. 15. Sect. 21, 31. All ≈øpeaking in a manner the ≈øame Language, as to their Original and Fall. The la≈øt commonly quote the Scripture, Gene≈ø. 3.6. and I≈øai. 14.12. to maintain their Opinions, but they quote it, no le≈øs adorned with their fooli≈øh fancies, upon the Nature and Creation of Spirits, than the others do by their fabulous Tales.

Second. The Opinion of the Jews concerning the malice of the Devils, their Virtue and Power to hurt, partly appears, Chap. 12. Sect. 12, 15, 18, 20. And that of the Mahometans ≈øeems to be almo≈øt the ≈øame. As to the Thoughts of the Ancient Chri≈øtians, they are explained more at large, Chap. 15, Sect. 7, 12, 23, 26. In the mean while I find not that they have a≈ø≈øerted any thing contrary to the Opinion of the others.
Sect. 9. It is convenient to ≈øay al≈øo ≈øomething of Purgatory, the ≈øpring of a va≈øt number of Apparitions and Witchcrafts.

1, Whether the Jews, Mahometans, and ancient Chri≈øtians ≈øpeak clearly upon that ≈øubject, or ob≈øcurely and doubtful; yet they all agree in e≈øtabli≈øhing a purging Fire, or ≈øome ≈øuch other Pain to be endured. Such are the Pains which the Devils of Torments inflict upon the Jews at the time of Gilgul, or the Revolution of Souls, Chap. 12. Sect. 20. The Mahometans are not remote from that Opinion, Ch. 14. S. 11. but the Chri≈øtians, Ch. 15. Sect. 27, 28, 34. or at lea≈øt, part of them, have blown up that Fire from under the A≈øhes, though the others, who≈øe number is far greater, have not the lea≈øt inclination to credit it.

2. However, tho≈øe that are not altogether remote from them, reject not wholly the Apparitions of the Souls ≈øeparated from their Bodies, nor their various Operations, to which Ju≈øtin and Irenaeus have traced out the way for them, as we have ≈øeen, Ch. 15. S. 7.
Sect. 10. But neither the Jews nor the Mahometans, carry Exorci≈øms and Conjurations to ≈øo great a height as the Chri≈øtians; in the mean while they all agree in this.

1. That they are powerful upon the Spirits, by the means of Names, Words, and Signs, that they have ≈øo much virtue as to force them to an≈øwer, to ca≈øt them out, or to turn them off. The Practices of the Jews, Ch. 13. Sect. 6.11. Tho≈øe of the Mahometans, Ch. 14. Sect. 14, 18. and the Declaration of the Chri≈øtian Writers, Ch. 16. Sect. 5.10. make it ≈øufficiently evident that their Opinions are not much different as to this Point, though the la≈øt bring not them into Practice.

2. The Reader ≈øhall not find in my Quotations a very particular explication of Magick, properly ≈øo call'd, which, as 'tis ≈øuppo≈øed, cau≈øes ≈øo many di≈øturbances to Men upon Earth; unle≈øs it be this, that ≈øince on the one ≈øide, the evils produced by
tho≈øe wicked Spirits are granted, and on the other their obedience to Exorci≈øts; it is ea≈øie to infer, that all the damage that Magicians cau≈øe by the help of the Devil, mu≈øt likewi≈øe be a≈øcribed to them.

Sect. 11. When we compare all the≈øe things together, we ≈øee the Heathens and Jews delivering their Opinions, as from hand to hand, to the Mahometans and Chri≈øtians; ≈øo that we ea≈øily perceive that both Jews and Chri≈øtians, have by degrees, and in≈øen≈øibly, received the Opinions of the Heathens, by whom they were ≈øurrounded, among≈øt whom they were mixed, and from whom the Chri≈øtians are de≈øcended: And that the la≈øt have al≈øo borrowed much from the Jews, who have delivered to them the Sacred Writings, with mo≈øt of their particular Interpretations, that have been greedily ≈øwallow'd down, and ≈øince increa≈øed to a great exce≈øs. As to the Mahometans, who≈øe Law is a mixture of Heathen, Jewi≈øh, and Chri≈øtian Doctrines, and more compo≈øed of what is evil in them all than of what is good; and therefore ≈øtored with more Errors than Truth; It is not ≈øtrange they ≈øhould have ≈øo much agreement with tho≈øe of the Nations we ≈øpeak of. We may ob≈øerve hereafter how all the≈øe Opinions have in≈øen≈øibly been cheri≈øhed and increa≈øed by Popery, and have i≈ø≈øued not only for the ≈øame Spring, but al≈øo from another, whence Mahomet has drawn ≈øomething for the making up of his Sy≈øtem. But as I have ended the 11th Chapter of this Book with the Opinion of the Epicures, I think it convenient to make a particular Chapter of tho≈øe of the Manichees.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. That the Doctrines a≈øcribed to the Manichees, are a mixture of all the preceeding, and the original of the Opinions mo≈øt common at this day.
div.p: S. 1. IF it were ab≈øolutely requi≈øite to know the Opinions of the ancient Hereticks, at lea≈øt of tho≈øe that are call'd ≈øo, we would be at the ≈øame Pains as tho≈øe that endeavour to di≈øcover them: For their own Books that were then condemned, being lo≈øt, 'tis not rea≈øonable blindly to believe whatever their Adver≈øaries ≈øay of them, who≈øe Zeal for the Truth was often mixed with human Pa≈ø≈øions: So that they may ≈øometimes impute to their Antagoni≈øts Opinions that were not ≈øo bad as they gave out, either mi≈øunder≈øtanding or wre≈øting them. Perhaps St. Au≈øtin has increa≈øed the number of Here≈øies to a hundred, for fear he ≈øhould diminish that of ≈øeventy which Epiphanius had before e≈øtablished in his Preface, and 57th Chapter of the Here≈øies. For if Cel≈øus could mark, in the mo≈øt remote Antiquity, and from the fir≈øt times that we have any knowledge of Books, but 100 principal Doctors of Heatheni≈øm, each of whom made not a particular Sect, but only followed the foot≈øteps of his Predece≈ø≈øors; how can it be imagin'd that Chri≈øtianity, that has the Word of God for it's Rule, ≈øhould have been in much le≈øs time more divided than Pagani≈øm, that was founded on ≈øuch weak and uncertain Grounds.

Sect. 2. St. Au≈øtin it ≈øeems ≈øhould be chiefly con≈øulted, as to the Doctrine of the Manichees, ≈øince he him≈øelf had been infected with their poi≈øon, and has particularly treated of that matter in his 46 Ch. of the Here≈øies; however, I ≈øhall do it with great caution, by the Rea≈øons ju≈øt now alledged: be≈øides that the≈øe words of his Preface, Ad quod vult Deum, made him extreamly ≈øu≈øpected; for he ≈øays, that in his little Book of Here≈øies, he ≈øhows a way, ∆≤nde po≈ø≈øit omnis haere≈øis, & quae nota e≈øt, & quae ignota vitari. To avoid all Here≈øies, whether known or unknown. For how can one provide him≈øelf again≈øt what is unknown, and con≈øequently ≈øignifies nothing? nay, I may boldly ≈øay, that what is unknown cannot be called Here≈øy, ≈øince whatever de≈øerves that name, mu≈øt be known; or perhaps St. Au≈øtin's meaning mu≈øt be under≈øtood in this ≈øen≈øe; that di≈øcovering the nature and Genius of ≈øuch Here≈øies, as are already known, he has furnished us with light, and weapons again≈øt tho≈øe that are yet unknown, but may become manife≈øt hereafter. However this being not the place to in≈øi≈øt longer upon this Rea≈øoning, we ≈øhall return to our ≈øubject. The ≈øame Father in his Book again≈øt the Manichees, imputes to them ≈øome things, Quantumlibet negent ad ≈øe pertinere. Th√¥ they deny them ever ≈øo much. But as he treats not di≈øtinctly enough of all their Opinions, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that belong to our de≈øign, I ≈øhall rather follow Danaeus, who has gathered the chief points of their belief, as well out of the Book of St. Au≈øtin before quoted, and the re≈øt of his works, as out of many other Authors, from whom I ≈øhall only relate what may be ≈øub≈øervient to our ≈øubject.
Sect. 3. As to God and the Spirits, they are ≈øaid,

Fir≈øt. To have e≈øtabli≈øhed two principles, contrary to each other, one of which was good, and the Author and Original of all good; and the other
bad, the Author of all Evil, and the Prince of darkne≈øs. That the fir≈øt as they ≈øay, is the God that has formed all things, and that the other is Hyle, that is the matter from which all things have been formed, and which is e≈øteem'd by them to be the Devil. Some di≈øtingui≈øh the Devil from the Prince of darkne≈øs, and tran≈ølate not as we do the la≈øt words of the 44th v. of the 8th Ch. of St. John. He is the Father of lies; but his Father is a lie, namely the Father of the Devil.

Second. As to the good God, they ≈øay, that his E≈ø≈øence is di≈øper≈øed as by portions, through all the Creatures, and inherent to them, which they explain by many wonderful Commentaries. This is what they think of God and the Devil, in relation to their E≈ø≈øence and Exi≈øtence, what follows concerns their Operations.

Sect. 4. Third. The People of darkne≈øs formerly warr'd with the People of light. The good God went him≈øelf to attack, the Prince of darkne≈øs, by ≈øome certain principal Spirits, which he had produced of his own E≈ø≈øence, who however, being too weak, were taken Pri≈øoners; but Chri≈øt came to repair that di≈øorder, having been begotten by ≈øome certain fir≈øt Man, who had been the promoter of this War, and had begun it.
Fourth. That in the mean while, Chri≈øt him≈øelf is the Serpent that ≈øeduced Adam and Eve.
Fifth. That Chri≈øt is now fixed among≈øt the Stars, e≈øpecially, in the luminous Globe of the Sun, in which ≈øen≈øe they explain his A≈øcen≈øion to Heaven.

Sect. 5. Sixth. They believe the Metemp≈øycho≈øis in this manner; That the Souls ≈øhall pa≈øs into the bodies of ≈øuch a kind of living Creatures, as they have mo≈øt loved or abu≈øed, during their Life. He that has killed a mou≈øe or a fly, ≈øhall pa≈øs in puni≈øhment, into the body of a mou≈øe or a fly, the ≈øtate in which he ≈øhall be put after death, ≈øhall likewi≈øe be oppo≈øed to that, in which he was during his Life. He that is rich ≈øhall be poor, and he that is poor ≈øhall be rich.

Seventh. They al≈øo give two Souls to every Man, one of which, is always contrary to the other. But enough of their Doctrines, we leave the re≈øt to Danaeus, who a≈øcribes to them 21 in all, becau≈øe what he and other Authors ≈øay, belongs not to our ≈øubject.

Sect. 6. However I am not apt to a≈ø≈øert, that they have believed and taught ≈øuch gro≈øs Doctrines, as are imputed to them, and have been now related. For ≈øuppo≈øing the common Opinion, concerning the Doctrine of the Manichees, that they were chiefly extracted from the Philo≈øophy of the Per≈øians, (≈øince Manes, their Fir≈øt Author, was undoubtedly a Per≈øian,) and that they are ≈øtrangely mingled with the Chri≈øtian Divinity; It is unrea≈øonable to have the ≈øame Opinion of that People, that we have of other Nations, who never cultivated the ≈øtudy of Nature and Human learning; ≈øuch as tho≈øe we have met with in the Northern parts of Africa, and the Southern of America. It may well be, that the Manichees a≈øcribe to the whole ∆≤niver≈øe, a principle like that which is ob≈øerved in it's parts, viz. The active cau≈øe, and the matter, which Ari≈øtotle e≈øtabli≈øhed to be eternal as well as the World; and that afterwards, matter con≈øidered as in≈øen≈øible by a mi≈øinterpretation of the words of Mo≈øes, that ≈øpreads in the beginning, darkne≈øs over the Aby≈øs, and the Spirit of God moving over it, ≈øhould have produced tho≈øe mon≈øtrous thoughts, of which we have given ≈øome in≈øtances.

Sect. 7. Suppo≈øing they have e≈øtabli≈øhed two principal cau≈øes, one of good and the other of evil; but yet, ≈øo as that the Fir≈øt is unconte≈øtably ≈øuperior to the Second, as much as light is above darkne≈øs, and the workman above the matter he works upon; 'tis probable, that they had an Idea of God, as a Soul infu≈øed through the whole ∆≤niver≈øe, that con≈øider'd by them as the body, in which that Fir≈øt
cau≈øe continually operates. And as the contrary motions of corporeal pa≈ø≈øions ri≈øe again≈øt the Empire of Rea≈øon that ought to govern them, ≈øo they might believe, that the Animal Spirits proceeding from matter, perpetually rebel again≈øt God, the Fountain of all Rea≈øon. Whence it would follow, that God ≈øhould not be more ab≈øolute ma≈øter of the ∆≤niver≈øe, than Man is of his body; thence has proceeded that Idea of two different Gods, one good, and the other bad; the latter being ≈øtill inferior to the former, who is indeed the workman, but has not an arbitrary Government, there being a power in the World, ≈øo great, that it is able to re≈øi≈øt him.

Sect. 8. But whether I have made a ju≈øt conjecture, or whether the Manichees had other Opinions, then tho≈øe I imagine; it ≈øeems neverthele≈øs, that I may rea≈øonable ≈øuppo≈øe it, upon this foundation, that no Opinions ≈øo gro≈øs as tho≈øe that are a≈øcribed to them; not only are not admitted, but not ≈øo much as moved or propounded, as we ≈øhall ≈øee very ≈øoon in the ≈øeries of this work; becau≈øe the principal points of tho≈øe ≈øorts of belief with their dependencies, have a great relation with my Second and Third Book, as I hope to ≈øhow at the end of the Second. And therefore whether any one treats of the Devil and Spirits according to the Holy Scripture; or whether he only follows his own ≈øen≈øe and right, it may „Äà‚óä„Äâ a≈ø≈øured, that all his Rea≈øonings will turn upon this notion of his; that God and the Devil have each an Empire, one contrary to the other, and that th√¥ the Devil be ≈øubject to the power of God; yet his Empire is more apparent. It is denyed, that God now works any miracles, but ≈øome are ra≈øhly a≈øcribed to the Devil, that ≈øurpa≈øs all tho≈øe that are mentioned in the Holy writ. We believe that there are Angels, and gather from the Holy Scripture, that they encamp about the faithful, and
the Devil likewi≈øe is ince≈ø≈øantly active to do them hurt, if po≈ø≈øible he can, but his abode is in Hell. However it is very rare to hear any one ≈øay, he has ≈øeen an Angel in a vi≈øion, whereas the Devil appears almo≈øt continually. If any thing has been either ≈øignified or foretold, we never believe it to be the Operation of an Angel, but of the Devil: one is po≈ø≈øe≈øt by him, and another bewitch'd; by his means, unknown Tongues are ≈øpoken, ≈øtrange things are ≈øaid, others no le≈øs wonderful are perform'd, and the mo≈øt hidden ≈øecrets di≈øcover'd. But you will ≈øcarce meet with any that has ≈øo good Opinion of the power of an Angel; if we have any Holy thought, or good in≈øpiration, how incon≈øiderable ≈øoever it may be, we a≈øcribe it to the Holy Gho≈øt, and ≈øeem not to believe, that the Angels are ≈øo much as capable of contributing to it; ≈øince it ne'er comes in our mind to think upon them. But the Devil penetrates the mo≈øt ≈øecret thoughts of Men, overthrows their be≈øt de≈øigns, and ince≈ø≈øantly excites them to Evil, if they are accu≈øed and convicted of any crime, the excu≈øe is always at hand, for the Devil has done it, or at lea≈øt has tempted them ≈øo to do.

Sect. 9. And therefore ≈øince neither the Ancient Heathens nor the moderns; neither the Jews, the Mahometans, nor the Fir≈øt Chri≈øtians, ever entertained any ≈øuch Opinions; and that 'tis manife≈øt, they have a greater relation with tho≈øe of Manes, I cannot but believe that this Doctrine which begun to ≈øpring up in the Third Century, was immediatly oppo≈øed on all ≈øides by Orthodox Doctors, but yet ≈øpread very far into A≈øia, whence it having pa≈ø≈øed into Europe, it has maintained it ≈øelf there longer then 'tis believed. This will not appear ≈øtrange, if we make a ≈øerious reflection upon this, that Men writing again≈øt errors, often aim at nothing
el≈øe, but their own reputation and the glory of having confuted them, whil≈øt they them≈øelves cheri≈øh tho≈øe errors, and keep them in their bo≈øom, ≈øo that when they come, to examine them≈øelves they find at bottom, that they agree with tho≈øe, who≈øe evil Doctrines they fancy as heartily to dete≈øt, as they appear outwardly incen≈øed again≈øt them.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. That the Opinions and practices already mentioned, have been mo≈øt or all introduced in Popery, which has added to them new inventions of Men.
div.p:
Sect. 1. 'TIS now time to approach nearer our Age, and Fir≈øt to con≈øider the Papi≈øts, and then our ≈øelves; for we now know, that the chief points of the doctrines to be examined, have Anciently made part of the religion of the Heathens, Jews, and Mahometans, and even have been admitted by the Fir≈øt Chri≈øtians, who≈øe purity is ≈øo much commended. Afterwards, it was ea≈øy to ob≈øerve in the la≈øt Chapter where we ≈øpake of the Manichees, that great part of the Doctrines a≈øcribed to them, have in≈øen≈øibly been introduced into the Chri≈øtianity of latter Ages. But Popery was not ≈øatisfied with this, and has invented many new ones, to which Gregory the great, that would ≈øeem to oppo≈øe Antichri≈øtianity, with which he ≈øuppo≈øed the Ea≈øt to be infected, has traced out a plain way. For having him≈øelf u≈øurped a great Authority over the Churches of the We≈øt, it was no hard matter, for him, to let his own imaginations and vain, in≈øtitutions be received, and to tran≈ømit them to his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors. Since
that time it became u≈øual in mo≈øt Churches, to believe whatever Rome taught, and to do whatever ≈øhe wrote them by way of command; at la≈øt ≈øhe changed that cu≈øtom into a right to her, and an obligation upon the other; neither Scripture nor right Rea≈øon were con≈øulted, when the determinations and Authority of the Roman Bi≈øhop, upon Articles of Faith, were only allowed. Tho≈øe determinations were ≈øub≈øtituted in≈øtead of Rea≈øon; and when they needed writings to maintain them, tho≈øe of the Fir≈øt Doctors of the Church were ready at hand, which gave too fair a pretence, of crediting whatever had been invented; for how ≈øtrange ≈øoever tho≈øe new Doctrines appeared, yet they were ea≈øily ≈øwallow'd down, provided they were contained either in the writings of tho≈øe Doctors, or in others that were ≈øpurious and forged at plea≈øure, and fal≈øly a≈øcribed to them, if they were but declared authentick by the See of Rome. It happened with this matter as with all others, in which ≈øome change in the Wor≈øhip and Doctrine, has in≈øen≈øibly been made, or ≈øomthing new introduced, which continued in the Church till the beginning of the latter Age, when part of the We≈øt was reformed, and re-e≈øtabli≈øhed in it's fir≈øt ≈øtate.

Sect. 2. We mu≈øt now con≈øider two things, viz. how far Popery has brought, in proce≈øs of time, it's unlawful Opinions; and then how far proceeded the rejection made by tho≈øe that reformed them≈øelves as to the Doctrine and Wor≈øhip. For this rea≈øon, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak in this Chapter of what the Papi≈øts believed upon the ≈øubject I treat of, and ≈øhall relate their Wor≈øhip and practices in the following Chapter. I intend not to gather tho≈øe Opinions from, the decrees of the Popes, nor the Canons of their Councils
‚Ä¢ nd Synods, as I have not done it, in what I have related concerning other Religions; but I ≈øhall collect
them from the writings of their principal Authors and Doctors, and from ≈øentiments clearly expre≈ø≈øing them, few of which were ever contradicted or confuted by any private per≈øon. So that whatever I ≈øhall alledge, being generally received for Articles of Faith, by tho≈øe of that Communion; they will have no rea≈øon to complain of, or exclaim again≈øt this method, ≈øince in the following Chapter, I ≈øhall ≈øhow, that tho≈øe manifold Opinions a≈øcribed to them, are confirmed by the proof of a general practice. But if I was to read over all their Authors to extract their Opinions, it would prove too long and tedious a task; and therefore I ≈øhall only follow one of their writers, who is fallen into my hands by chance, becau≈øe he has read all the others, and extracted from them whatever is ≈øub≈øervient to our ≈øubject, having put it in order, without omitting any thing, as th√¥ he had done it on purpo≈øe: ≈øince therefore, not only he is not of our Communion, but a Papi≈øt, and a Je≈øuit too, I think the choice I have made, will not be blamed. This Author is Ga≈øpar Schottus, who is ≈øufficiently known by the learned writings he has publi≈øhed of late, and which he is not afraid to expo≈øe to our cen≈øure, ≈øince in 1662, he dedicated his Phy≈øica curio≈øa, to the Elector Palatine, Charles Lewis of glorious memory, who was of our Communion: this Book and another entituled, Magia ∆≤niver≈øalis, or ∆≤niver≈øal Magick, of which he is likewi≈øe the Author I de≈øign to make u≈øe of, laying a≈øide all the others that I had collected, and partly read for that purpo≈øe, for the glory of being an in≈øatiable reader is not what I aim at.

Sect. 3. Following the ≈øame order, I have before e≈øtabli≈øhed, and which is almo≈øt agreeable to that of Schottus. I ≈øhall fir≈øt relate the Opinions of the Doctors of the Church of Rome, concerning Angels
and Devils, and afterwards touching human Souls, either in this Life or after Death. However, I undertake not to make an ab≈øtract of whatever they ≈øay, but only to illu≈øtrate the matter in hand, in order to prove what I have a≈ø≈øerted. To that end I di≈øtingui≈øh again the Angels into good and bad, to examine what concerns either of tho≈øe two ≈øorts. But fir≈øt I ≈øhall ≈øpeak in general of their Original, Number, Nature, Equalities, and Power. As to their Original: Upon the Que≈øtion, of what Nature Spirits are, I ≈øhall reject the Opinion commonly received by ≈øeveral Chri≈øtian Doctors; That Spirits are in ≈øome ≈øort Corporeal, becau≈øe the Council of Lateran, cap. firmiter, ≈øeems to e≈øtabli≈øh, that they are altogether immaterial; but all agree in this, that they have been created by God, and con≈øtituted in a ≈øtate of Grace, Phy≈øic. Cur. Book 1. Pag. 7. Though this la≈øt expre≈ø≈øion be ≈øomewhat different from that of our Churches; yet I will not in≈øi≈øt upon it; but in the following propo≈øition I ≈øhall ob≈øerve what I intend afterwards to make ≈øub≈øervient to my de≈øign.

Sect. 5. Thomas Aquinas makes the Angels innumerable. Others, following ≈øome ancient Fathers, e≈øtabli≈øh 99 to one Man. Our Schottus makes their number amount to 1000,000,000,000 a Thou≈øand Thou≈øand Millions, more of whom are good then bad, though he undertakes not to determine the number of each, pag. 9, 10. This va≈øt number of Angels, as well bad as good, are divided by way of degrees into ≈øome certain orders, which are explained in particular, ≈øomewhat further in that ≈øame Book.

Sect. 6. As to the power a≈øcribed to good and bad Angels; 1. They can neither penetrate the ≈øecret thoughts of one another, nor tho≈øe of Men; yet they can much better pierce into futurities then Men can do by the help of natural Cau≈øes, and know
for in≈øtance, whether the year ≈øhall be fruitful, whether it will freeze very hard, whether it will Rain or blow, pag. 12, 13, 14.

2. 'Tis ob≈øervable, that he a≈øcribes to them the faculty of moving from one place to another, tho' it be not done in an in≈øtant, and that of extending and contracting them≈øelves locally, pag. 17. 18.
3. He admits the Opinion of Ignatius Erkenne≈øs, that it is not nece≈ø≈øary an Angel ≈øhould have a Body to move another Body, pag. 20. &c.
4. That neverthele≈øs neither Angel nor Devil can act upon each other, unle≈øs they meet both in the ≈øame place, pag. 21.

5. It is the common Opinion, that a Spirit may a≈ø≈øume a Body in ≈øuch a manner as outwardly to be ≈øeen in a Bodily ≈øhape, by a Per≈øon who≈øe Eyes are conveniently di≈øpo≈øed, without being perceiv'd by another near him, tho' his Eyes be as fit for it as tho≈øe of the former, pag. 24.
6. 'Tis likewi≈øe the common Opinion, that each Per≈øon has his particular Angel and Devil, p. 37, 38.

Sect. 7. As to the Holy Angels in particular, the Opinion of Lombard concerning their Orders and different Mini≈øtries, has been always much credited among the Papi≈øts; They believe that he ≈øpeaks according to the Scripture, when he con≈øtitutes nine Orders of them. Angels, Archangels, Principalities, Powers, Virtues, Dominions, Thrones, Cherubims, and Seraphims. Lombard a≈ø≈øerts, that Diony≈øius the Areopagite has di≈øtingui≈øhed them ≈øo, but I have ≈øhewed before, Chap. 15. Sect. 3. that it is Pope Gregory, who has e≈øtabli≈øhed that number, tho' not altogether in the ≈øame Order. The≈øe nine Orders have been ≈øince divided into three times three, the three ≈øuperiour Orders are the Seraphims, Cherubims, and Thrones, and ≈øo forth, a≈øcending again, and reckoning all nine. Lombard explains this thought more
at large, ≈øaying, That as the Martyrs are one Order, and the Apo≈øtles another, and yet one Apo≈øtle is above another, as one Martyr above another, he rea≈øonably believe the ≈øame to be with the Angels.
Sect. 8. As to the wicked Spirits in particular, 'tis believed,
1. That they have not all been precipitated into Hell, immediately after their Fall; but that part of them remained rambling without, and ≈øometime return upon Earth, or abide in the Air, p. 26, 27.

2. That there are ≈øix different places where the Devils commonly dwell, and whence they effect their Malice and Power, and therefore are called in relation to tho≈øe places, 1. Ignean, or Superaereal Devils, 2. Aereal Devils. 3. Terre≈øtrial. 4. Aquatick. 5. Subterraneous. 6. Tho≈øe that hate the Light. The Abbot Trithemius, Delrio, and Agrippa, are quoted by our Author on that account, pag. 28. 31.

3. They are as well as the Angels divided into ≈øeveral Orders: But the Papi≈øts agree not together upon this matter; neither our Author, nor Agrippa, who has treated at large of this matter, agree together, nor with others; but after all, I relate here what is mo≈øt generally received; to which I add, that the Opinion of Thyleus, who divides the Devils into three Spiritual Dominions, and nine Quires, is not rejected, pag. 36, 37.

Sect. 9. Their Power and Effects have always been much exalted among≈øt the Papi≈øts; They hold for certain, that the wicked Spirits can do great wonders; either by their Knowledge or Power. Mira hoc loco vocamus, (≈øays Schottus) quorum cau≈øas etiam ≈øapientes ignorant, & digna admiratione cen≈øent, ≈øive de ‚Ä¢ aetero natura facultates tran≈øcendunt, ≈øive non. I give here the name of wonders to tho≈øe Effects, the cau≈øes of which even the Wi≈øe are ignorant of, and judge them worthy Admiration, whether or no they ≈øurpa≈øs the forces of Nature, pag. 39, 40. 'Tis therefore his Opinion,
That the Devils can produce Effects that are above the power of Nature: For though he declares afterwards, That they produce, but apparently and not really, ≈øome Effects that are peculiar to God only; yet he believes that frequently they really operate others, which indeed are not proper to God, but which neither Men nor the ordinary cour≈øe of Nature are capable of effecting without the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of tho≈øe Spirits. To prove this The≈øis, he quotes many Popi≈øh Authors, and ≈øhows that they are all of the ≈øame Opinion. In the mean while he di≈øtingui≈øhes what the Devils are able to effect of them≈øelves, from what they cannot do, but by the means of Magicians and Witches, Pag. 40. to 50.
Sect. 10. The Con≈øequence he draws from what has been ≈øaid, is, That the Devils operate ≈øome things by motion, others by the active virtue of Natural Cau≈øes, and others by Illu≈øion.

1. They alledge 15 ≈øorts of their Operations by their Motion from one place to another, of which the five fir≈øt con≈øi≈øt in real Operations, and the nine la≈øt, in meer Repre≈øentations. Tho≈øe of the fir≈øt Cla≈ø≈øis, are, Fir≈øt, They cau≈øe Fire to de≈øcend from Heaven, as 'tis related in the fir≈øt Chapter of Job. Second. According to the ≈øame Hi≈øtory, they may rai≈øe Storms and Tempe≈øts. Third. They may likewi≈øe cau≈øe Rain, bring fair weather, make Winds blow upon the Sea, ≈øtop the cour≈øe of Ve≈ø≈øels, and overturn them. Fourth. They may produce Earthquakes. Fifth. They may tran≈øport through the Air, or in ≈øome other manner, the Bodies of Men, and all other ≈øorts of Bodies.
Sect. 11. Our Author afterward relates what they operate by motions of meer Repre≈øentation to the internal and external Sen≈øes;
1. They render vi≈øible things invi≈øible, by ≈øuddenly ≈ønatching them from the ≈øight of Men.
2. They make Statues, and other inanimate Objects move and walk.
They make them ≈øpeak.
4. They make appear Man and Bea≈øt in their dead Bodies, as tho' they were alive.
5. They take upon them Aereal Bodies, and by that means produce ≈øeveral Effects.
6. They repre≈øent the Figure of all ≈øorts of matter, either Gold, Silver, precious Stones, or others.

7. They direct in ≈øuch a manner the Animal Spirits of Men, that they maks appear to them, pa≈øt, pre≈øent and future things in their own ≈øhape, and per≈øwade them that they ≈øee, hear, and do things that are not real.
8. They cau≈øe pineings and violent Di≈øea≈øes in human Bodies.
9. By Dreams they pre≈øent to People, ≈øuch objects as are ab≈øent and remote, and forewarn them of future things.
10 They produce in Men the pa≈ø≈øions of Love, Hatred, Anger and Fury, from Pa. 51. to 54.

Sect. 12. The 2d ≈øort of Diabolical Operations is no le≈øs credited; it con≈øi≈øting in the active virtue of Natural things; and therefore 'tis believed, that by the power of the Devil, whether he acts immediately, and by him≈øelf, or by Wizards and Witches; Herbs, Fruits, Waters, and mo≈øt other matters may be mixed in ≈øome ≈øort and degree, and with the proportions requi≈øite for it, whereby Food, Drink, Phy≈øick, or ≈øome other potion may be made up, that ≈øhall cau≈øe a great deal of hurt to Man and Bea≈øt. 'Tis al≈øo believed that all the≈øe things may be done by natural ways, but that they are more ea≈øily, readily, and efficaciou≈øly performed by the power and craft of the Devil, without being perceived by the mo≈øt skilful Men, who can never do the like, Pag. 55.

Sect. 13. As to the illu≈øions, they mu≈øt be under≈øtood in this Sen≈øe, that the Devils indeed do ≈øome thing, but not whatever they ≈øeem to operate. For 'tis not doubted but the Devil can do whatever is po≈ø≈øible to be done by natural means and which may happen in proce≈øs of time, by the ordinary cour≈øe of nature, without the cooperation of that wicked Spirit, as we ≈øhall ≈øay anon, but he has this power by God's permi≈ø≈øion, to imploy all the forces of nature, for the producing of what effect he de≈øires; whence often proceeds, that Men either by ignorance, or becau≈øe ≈øome extraordinary objects and events come before them, believe things that are not in being, or per≈øwade them≈øelves, that the Devil performs ≈øome certain effects that are not natural, In the mean while it remains con≈øtant and undoubted, that the Devil has power to do whatever has been already mentioned, as al≈øo whatever I am going to ≈øay.

Sect. 14. I mean to ≈øpeak of illu≈øions, which Schottus together with Delrio and Molina declares to be of Three ≈øorts; tho≈øe that are made by the change of the objects, tho≈øe that are made by the change of the Air, and tho≈øe that happen by the change of the Organs of the ≈øen≈øes.

Fir≈øt, Illu≈øions are made by the change of the Object, when one thing is ≈øub≈øtituted in≈øtead of another, that has been ≈øuddenly and imperceptibly ≈ønatched away; or when an object is pre≈øented to the Eyes, in ≈øuch a ≈øtate and manner as that, it produces a fal≈øe vi≈øion; or when any object made up of Air, or of ≈øome other Element, offers it ≈øelf to the ≈øight; or la≈øtly when there appears any thing compo≈øed of different matters, mingled together; ≈øo skilfully prepared, that what exi≈øted before, receives thereby another form and figure.

Second. The change of the Air is made by the≈øe ways, when the Devil hinders, le≈øt the object ≈øhould pa≈øs through the Air, and hit our Eyes; when he di≈øpo≈øes the Air that is betwixt the object and the Eye in ≈øuch a manner, that the object appears in another figure then really it is, when h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thickens the Air to make the object appear greater then it is, and to hinder it from being ≈øeen in other places, but the place he de≈øigns; when he moves the Air in the place through which the object is to hit the Eye, that the object going through that part of the Air, may al≈øo be moved, and that it's figure may be pre≈øented to the Eye, otherwi≈øe then it is; and la≈øtly, when he mingles and confounds together ≈øeveral different figures, in order that in one only object, there may appear many together, pag. 55.

Third. The Organs of the Sen≈øes are changed, when they are either transfer'd from their places and alter'd; when their humours and active particles are corrupted or thickned, or when ≈øuch a ≈øhining brightne≈øs pa≈ø≈øes before the Eyes, that they are dazled, ≈øo that it ≈øeems, that a Man raves waking, p. 55, 56.
Sect. 15. As a con≈øequence of all the≈øe things, 'tis held as an undoubted truth, that the Devil can perform miraculous effects upon all ≈øorts of creatures, e≈øpecially upon Men, viz.
Fir≈øt, That he can give life to Dead in≈øects, and make them perfect Animals, which however is again≈øt the meaning of Schottus, p. 129,
Second, And con≈øequently, that he can produce and make appear true Frogs and Serpents as was done in Egypt in the time Mo≈øes, p. 57, 58. 59.

Third. That he may di≈øcover and bring to Men, hidden trea≈øures, and even if occa≈øion ≈øerves, make Money, p. 116. however Schottus ≈øays with rea≈øon,
that he is ≈øo ill natur'd, as ≈øeldom to do, as to this, all that is in his power.

Sect. 16. Concerning Man in particular, 'tis believed, that unclean Spirits can Copulate in the ≈øhape of Men with Women, and in the ≈øhape of Women with M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øo that as from that communication Children may be begotten, pag. 61. to 67.
2. That the Devil, as by a kind of Tran≈ømutation, may change Women into the likene≈øs of Men, and Men into that of Women, pag. 113.
3. That he transforms Men into the figure of Wolves, Cats, and other Bea≈øts, pag. 94.
4. That he may ≈øtrengthen the memory of Man, and enlighten his under≈øtanding, pag. 114.
5. That he may re≈øtore Youth to old Men, and repair their Faces.
6. That he may po≈ø≈øe≈øs him≈øelf of the Body and Sen≈øes of a Man, and make him as Ex≈øtatick.
7. That he may plunge Men into a deep Sleep, and make them capable of Fa≈øting whole years, pag. 104, 107.

Sect. 17. I have kept the chief Article for the end; that is, That the Devil carries over by night, through Windows and Chimnies, Magicians, Sorcerers, and Witches, to the Sabbat, or their A≈ø≈øembling Place; though after all, many Popi≈øh Writers deny it. But ≈øince it is the common Opinion, on which the very Judges of Sorcerers partly lay the foundation of their Sentences, I intend not to put it on the reckoning of the Papi≈øts in general, though our Author takes it upon his own, pag. 67. and 80. For I will not wrong the Papi≈øts ≈øo much, as to call it their own Sentiment, ≈øince there are Men among≈øt us that have the ≈øame Opinion, as we ≈øhall hereafter:
Yet there is one that is particular to them, of which I have been informed of late by People that have lived among≈øt them, and have ≈øeen a very, frequent practice of it, I mean the Monitores. When any one has ≈øu≈øtained a lo≈øs, or when 'tis de≈øired to di≈øcover an important Affair, or even a Trifle, a Monitory is obtained from the Bi≈øhop; which is an act wherein the thing or the fact enquired after is ≈øpecified. This Monitory is publi≈øhed at the end of Parochial Ma≈ø≈øes, before all the People, and fa≈øtned to the Doors of Churches, and at the corners of Streets, and after the expired time, and nece≈ø≈øary publications, they come to the ceremony of thundring it out. After which it is certain, that three parts of the People believe and are firmly per≈øuaded, that tho≈øe who knew any thing of the matter, and have not gone in time to reveal it to the Rector, or other Prie≈øt commi≈ø≈øion'd by the Bi≈øhop, never fail to fall into the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Devil, to whom the Monitory delivers them, after it's being thunder'd out, and that the Devil transforms them mo≈øt, or all the Nights, into Dogs, Cats, Wolves, Goats, and other Animals, which is called to whurry as a Wolf. If one meet in the night ≈øome Wild-Bea≈øt or a Dome≈øtick ≈øtraying, he fancies to have met the Wolf-man, and is ready to ≈øwear it. Some of the mo≈øt thinking and le≈øs ≈øuper≈øtitious part, at lea≈øt believe that the Excommunication contained in tho≈øe Monitories, cuts off from the Communion of their Church, and delivers to the Demons tho≈øe that have not ≈øubmitted to it, by revealing ≈øuch things, as 'tis often very convenient and u≈øeful to conceal.

Sect. 18. As all the≈øe things are ≈øaid in general concerning the power of wicked Spirits; ≈øo certain places are a≈ø≈øigned to them, where they u≈øually produce their Effects: The co ‚Ä¢ mon Opinion?
is, that there are familiar Spirits, Dome≈øtick, and Mountanous Devils.

1. The familiar Spirits, Spiritus Familiares, are tho≈øe who always keep by a Man, even when he calls not for them, whether they do it of their own accord, or that they have been hired very cheap for that purpo≈øe. They ≈øerve him faithfully, at lea≈øt outwardly, whether or no he calls for them. They ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be ≈øhut up in Rings, Chry≈øtals, Che≈øts, and the like, and to be carried away whither ≈øoever one plea≈øes; The≈øe are the very words of Schottus, pag. 134. Tho≈øe Demons in Gla≈øs or Rings are according to the common Opinion, ≈øhut in or fa≈øtned to them with ≈øome certain ceremonies u≈øed in that ca≈øe; and not by the virtue of any Conjurations or Exorci≈øms, nor by the power of him that carries them, as 'tis believed by ≈øome; but they undergo this willingly, or by the ab≈øolute order of the Prince of the Devils, whom they blindly obey; or la≈øtly, to deceive Men more ea≈øily. When they are in tho≈øe ≈øorts of Pri≈øons, and have been carried through ≈øeveral places, que≈øtions are put to them, and ≈øometimes they are forced to ≈øpeak. Then they di≈øcover to Men hidden Things, and foretell tho≈øe that are to come. It is believed, that in our days a great and victorious Prince carried one of the≈øe Spirits with him in his Ring, and that he lo≈øt his ≈øight in a Battle, a little after the Stone that was in the Ring was broken into two pieces, pag. 143.

Sect. 19. Schottus and D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ io relate out of Meletius, what is ordinarily ≈øaid concerning Dome≈øtick Devils. They withdraw into the mo≈øt hidden places of the hou≈øe, upon piles of Wood, where they are kept with the mo≈øt delicious Meat, becau≈øe they carry to their Ma≈øters Corn that they have ≈øtolen from other People's Barns. When tho≈øe Spirits intend to ≈øettle in any Hou≈øe, they make it known by leaping up ≈øticks of Wood, or throwing
Dung into Pails of Milk. If the Ma≈øter of the Hou≈øe, taking notice of it, lets alone tho≈øe‚ñ™ Sticks and the Dung in the Milk, or even if he drinks of the Milk into which the Dung hat been thrown, the Spirit appears to him, and lives with him. Tho≈øe ≈øorts of Spirits are called by the French Gobelins, by the Dutch Guldelkens, and Kabautermannekens, and by the Engli≈øh Hobgoblins. They appear in the ≈øhape of Men and Women, as little as Dwarfs, or ≈øuch as Pigmies were formerly imagin'd to be. Schottus, ≈øays, That it was u≈øual in former times to ≈øee many of tho≈øe Spirits in Hou≈øes, where they did whatever was nece≈ø≈øary. They dr e≈ø≈øed Hor≈øes, they ≈øwept the Hou≈øe, carried Wood and Water, and did all ≈øorts of Service, pag. 145. he did well by ≈øaying 'twas formerly done, left he ≈øhould be put to a proof in this curious Age.

Sect. 20. He has taken from Georgius Agricola, the de≈øcription he makes of Mountanous Devils, ≈øaying, That they dwell in the Mines under the Mountains; that they are cruel and frightful; that they make unea≈øie‚ñ™ and perpetually vex tho≈øe that work in the Mines: Some call them the little Hollanders, becau≈øe they ordinarily appear little, ≈øcarce three foot high, with an old wrinckled Face, and in the ≈øame ≈øhape with the Miners, clothed with a Wa≈øtecoat and Apron. Neverthele≈øs, he ≈øays, that they are not ≈øo wicked as they love to play Tricks, and to be merrily Rogui≈øh, e≈øpecially when they will per≈øuade that they do the greate≈øt part of the work in the Mines. When all's done, his Opinion comes at la≈øt to this, that there are two ≈øorts of that kind of Spirits, ≈øome are good and the other bad; The latter are feared and dete≈øted by the Workmen, whereas they look with plea≈øure upon the former, believing them to be of good Augury. But Schottus being willing to grant that they are of a mean Order betwixt Men and Spirits, holds them for bad Spirits, what good
≈øoever they may do, believing that when it happens ≈øo they are forced to it by God, or that they do it Craftily, to delude Men, Pag. 114. and 149.

Sect. 21. There is ≈øtill more illu≈øions made in relation to the ≈øhapes the Devils take on, than in the other occa≈øions above-mention'd. I will not now ≈øpeak of whole Armies that are believed frequently to appear in order of Battle, of which Schottus treats at large in the addition to his ≈øecond Book‚ñ™ p. 336. but of tho≈øe that are called Hobgoblins and Fairies. Formally our People ≈øpeak almo≈øt of nothing el≈øe. Schottus writes thereupon, p. 339. Delrio ≈øays, That there is a ≈øort of Spectres that appear as Women all in white, in Woods and Meadows; Some are ≈øeen in Stables with Wax Candles lighted, ≈øome drops of which they let fall upon the Mains of Hor≈øes, combing and twi≈øting them very neatly; tho≈øe white Women are al≈øo call'd Sybils, and 'tis ≈øaid, that one of 'em named Haband, is as the Queen of the others, and commands them. People believe their Apparitions to be of good Omen; but the Doctors look on ≈øuch pre≈øages as old Womens Tales, acknowledging in the mean while, that the thing is true, or at lea≈øt po≈ø≈øible: And Schottus relating, p. 215. what Cornelius of Kempen ≈øays, a≈ø≈øures us, that in the time of the Emperor Lotarius, that is about 830. ≈øeveral of tho≈øe Fairies were to be found in Fri≈øeland, where they dwelt in Grotes, or on the tops of Hills and Mountains, whence they de≈øcended at night, to carry away Shepherds from their Flocks, Children from their Cradles, and ≈ølip both into their Caverns.
