div.head: CHAP. XX. What is the Doctrine of Popery concerning Apparitions of Spirits, and how they torment Men, either by them≈øelves, or by the Mini≈øtry of other Men.
div.p: Sect. 1. IN ≈øpeaking of this la≈øt kind of Demons we are de≈øcended by degrees, even to Specters and Phanta≈øms. But Fir≈øt, we have ob≈øerved that there were yet two things to treat of, touching Spirits, that is, their Apparitions to Men, and their Operations in the ≈øame. It is upon this ≈øubject of Apparitions, that there is room to ≈øpeak of Phanta≈øms; which, according to the opinion of the Papi≈øts, are good and bad Angels, or Souls of the decea≈øed, which become vi≈øible, or which are under≈øtood without being ≈øeen; either that they ≈øpeak intelligibly, or that they make only ≈øome ≈øound and noi≈øe. There is yet this difference in their Apparitions, that there are ≈øome Souls, which whether they manife≈øt them≈øelves vi≈øibly, or whether they are only heard, work ≈øome effects, whereas there are others, that operate nothing. Schottus freely teaches us many things, which relates to them, that is, Fir≈øt, in what places Specters chiefly u≈øed to appear; Secondly, what Specters and Phanta≈øms are; Thirdly what they act; Fourthly, to whom they particularly appear; Fifthly, what means there are to avoid them, and be rid of them.

Sect. 2. Tho≈øe places where Phantoms appear, Schottus per≈øuades him≈øelf, that there is no place in
the World but that may happen. However, that there are ≈øome, where it happens more frequently than el≈øewhere. As,
1. In De≈øarts‚ñ™ and in ≈øolitary places, he grounds his opinion upon Scripture, I≈øai. 33.14. Apoc. 18.2. Tob. 8.3. And confirms it by the con≈øideration of that which hapned to our Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf, St. Matthew, Chap. 4. St. Luke, Chap. 4. It is for this rea≈øon that the good St. Anthony was ≈øo hardly dealt with in the De≈øart, by all ≈øorts of Hobgoblings and Spirits, Pag. 226.
2. If one were in the humor al≈øo, to believe a ≈øort of Water Demons, our Author would very often make them appear in Ponds and Mar≈øhes, Pag. 227.
3. If the Pagans have had, ≈øince a long time, Gods of the Groves, the Chri≈øtians will not deny but that there are ≈øuch, for they ≈øay that there are particular Phantoms in Woods and Meadows, Pag. 229.
4. When they are to fight any bloody Battle, or after it has been fought, many Specters have often been ≈øeen in the field of Battle, Pag. 230.
5. Phanta≈øms often appear in Baths and Stoves, Pag. 232.
6. Which happens al≈øo in Fortre≈ø≈øes and Ca≈øtles, Pag. 234.
7. In Mines and Caverns, as it has been ≈øaid before concerning Mountain Gods. Pag. 235.
8. There are ≈øeen more Apparitions in places where Murderers and Thieves haunt, than in other places. Pag. 235.
9. Holy Cloy≈øters, Churches, and Temples of God's Wor≈øhip, are not al≈øo exempted. Pag. 237. As for me, I am very much per≈øwaded that there is no place in the World, where there are more Delu≈øions and Apparitions made, or rather, deceitful Vi≈øions, than in tho≈øe places.
10. So it is no marvel, that the ≈øame happens to every particular per≈øon in his Hou≈øe. Pag. 238.

Sect. 3. If one asks, what it is that appears, or What the≈øe Fantomes are, you will not fail to be immediately ≈øatisfied. Sometimes they are good Angels but mo≈øt frequently evil Spirits, Souls of the decea≈øed. However, in this occa≈øion there is ≈øaid touching Angels very little, and that very uncertain; forta≈ø≈øis etiam Angeli boni; ≈øometimes perhaps good Angels, ≈øays Schotus. Pag. 247. But concerning Demons he affirms very neatly, and with a great a≈ø≈øurance, that they are not all alike wicked. Becau≈øe Phanta≈øms are di≈øtingui≈øhed in mites & tetric ‚Ä¢ s ≈øeu truculentos; in good and cruel: that which is found explained in the ≈øame place by the≈øe words taken out of Ca≈ø≈øien, touching ≈øome unpure Spirits, as are ordinarily called Faunos, Faunes, Kabautermannakens, or Hobgoblins; it is notorious that they delude Men, as by way of ≈øport and pa≈øtime, ≈øo that in certain places they po≈øt them≈øelves ordinarily in the way, and take them up, however, without tormenting the pa≈ø≈øengers; they are contented to laugh at them, and make raillery, and play them ≈øome plea≈øant pranks. And they ≈øeem rather to have a de≈øign to tire them, than to give them any di≈øplea≈øure. But it is al≈øo known, there are others ≈øo evil and ≈øo cruel, that it does not ≈øatisfie them to torment People, and cruelly to tear them where they come, (this ought to be under≈øtood of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed) But they will attack tho≈øe who pa≈øs by, altho' at the ≈øame time they are a great way off, and horribly treat them. See one that ≈øays he knows them very well him≈øelf; and further, that no body is ignorant of it, he relyes upon his own per≈øwa≈øion, and does applaud him≈øelf for it. Would it not be more mi≈øchievous than the Will with a wisp him≈øelf, that ≈øets upon pa≈ø≈øengers to ≈øu≈øpect and confute his belief? However, he is but a little while to be quiet, for we
cannot avoid troubling him, and ≈øhewing his Error.

Fourth. The Souls of the decea≈øed are either ≈øaved or damned, it is held for certain, that tho≈øe that are happy, are often ≈øeen to appear to holy Men for their good, and that they appear ≈øtill. The Legends contain an infinite number of examples, which have been compiled from all ≈øorts of Hi≈øtories, even of tho≈øe which are the lea≈øt worthy of credit, and that are enriched with a great many new ornaments that have been lent them in compiling of the work. But there are none which appear ≈øo worthy of remark as the≈øe apparitions of Souls, which happen in con≈øequence of Covenants, that have been made betwixt Holy People in their life time, that is, when two or more have mutually promi≈øed, that who ≈øhould die fir≈øt, ≈øhould appear to the other, and come and tell him news of the e≈øtate he was in, whether in Purgatory or in Heaven. The Author makes no doubt, but the thing happens as it is agreeds; but he dares not decide, whether ≈øuch an agreement be lawful, in which ca≈øe he believes, it mu≈øt be made by a particular in≈øpiration from God, p. 333.

Sect. 5. There is no more doubt of the apparitions of Souls that are damned, and they are grounded upon proofs of the ≈øame certainty, as the former. Schottus reports an example drawn from Bencius and Delrio, which appears ≈øo ≈øtrong and convinceing, that he expre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf thus at the end. It is a ≈øtory which is confirmed by the belief generally given to it, it is publickly in all places, by many Books, and by a great number of letters, and the thing has happened in the time and place mentioned. It is a Que≈øtion to know, if any thing may not be fal≈øe or mixed with any fal≈øity, becau≈øe it has been publi≈øhed a long time without being contradicted, either in word or
writing? but it would be too long to treat upon this Que≈øtion here, it will be proper in another place. However, if this Hi≈øtory be true, it might confirm the ≈øentiments of the Papi≈øts, which ≈øay, That the Souls of the damned appear here upon Earth to the living, to pre≈øent to them, in a frightful manner, the torments they ≈øuffer in Hell, to the end, they may bring them by that, to repent and leave off Sinning.

Sect. 6. Our Je≈øuit is too wi≈øe to ≈øpeak much him≈øelf of Purgatory, he leaves that to others; he held neverthele≈øs with tho≈øe of his Faith, That the Souls of the decea≈øed de≈øire often of the living, the help of their Prayers and good works, and that by con≈øequence, the Souls in what≈øoever place they may be, expect tho≈øe that are entred into Heaven, or into Hell, appear to Men, p. 253. We ≈øee that he will not much trouble us with Purgatory, and in≈øtead of perplexing him≈øelf with a determin'd place, he choo≈øes rather to be at large, in placeing Souls in loco di≈øpen≈øationis, in a place of di≈øpen≈øation; ≈øuch as the Schoolmen have forged it, who≈øe Opinion, ≈øome of ours find not condemnable, in what place ≈øoever tho≈øe Souls may be, the Papi≈øts believe certainly, that they appear often to Men, to the ends that have been mentioned. It is al≈øo the common Opinion, that the greate≈øt part of the Souls, are not tho≈øe that are in Paradi≈øe or in Hell; but tho≈øe that dwel between tho≈øe two places, or in Purgatory; for frequent journeys from Heaven to Earth would too much di≈øturb the repo≈øe of the Souls, that are there; and Hell keep its Captives too clo≈øely confin'd, to give them ≈øo much liberty; and if it be permitted me to divert the publick, I ≈øhall ≈øay, it would bring no profit to the Churches Coffers, who≈øe fire of Purgatory makes the pot boyl much better, then all the flames of Hell do, or all the heat of the Cele≈øtial fire.

Sect. 7. If one would know what all tho≈øe fantoms do in the World, Schottus will not fail to inform you, and even to mark with a great deal of care and exactne≈øs, many different manners, in which they ≈øhew them≈øelves p. 269, &c.
Fir≈øt. They appear to the ≈øight under divers figures, as well of Men, as of Bea≈øts, or frightful Mon≈øters.
Second. The Ears are often ≈øtruck without ≈øeeing any thing, and even ≈øometimes in ≈øuch an extraordinary manner, that it cau≈øes a≈øtoni≈øhment and fear: p. 271.

Third. The touch has it's ≈øhare in it, if what the Author ≈øays be true, That they move them ≈øometimes to touch Men without doing them any harm, but at other times, they pu≈øh them ≈øo, that they drive them with violence, they make them fall down, brui≈øe them and beat them, that they even trouble them, and tempt them to Letchery. p. 273.

Sect. 8. It is likewi≈øe nece≈ø≈øary to know that which is written Concerning the figure of bodies, in which Phanta≈øms appear, he ≈øays, p. 287. That the Abbot Trithemeus, Thyreus, Delrius, and others, (whence it apperrs, that it is the common Opinion,) relate, Certain ≈øigns, by which one may know, if whether Spirits who pre≈øent them≈øelves in a corporeal form, are Angels or Men, good Angels or Devils; Souls of the ble≈ø≈øed or damned; or Souls which are in Purgatory to be purified there. However, he affords not a very ample in≈øtruction upon this point, for the chief matter that he ≈øays of it, is, That the Souls of the ble≈ø≈øed appear with an Air of content and joy; that the Souls which are in Purgatory have a more doleful countenance; but that tho≈øe of the damned, have a more frightful a≈øpect with ≈øigns of de≈øpair. And th√¥ it be the common Opinion, that there are always ≈øome defects, or ≈øomething disfigured in the body,
in which the Devil pre≈øents him≈øelf; notwith≈øtanding, neither our Je≈øuit, nor Delrius, holds it for certain; ≈øee that which the fir≈øt puts for certain, and as generally believed, p. 291. It is that when the Devil appears and ≈øpeaks, he always ≈øpeaks the language of the Country where he is, ≈øo that he mu≈øt under≈øtand more languages than Mithridates; or every Devil can appear but in his proper Country. But the voice of a Specter is always perplex'd, trembling, weak, and as muttering, as th√¥ it were under≈øtood through a Tub, or through the cheft of an Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel, for ≈øays Schottus, The Devil can ≈øpeak no better. See according to this Author, and tho≈øe of his belief, a good mark to know him.

Sect. 9. We mu≈øt not omit that which is given out as a thing certain, that a Phanta≈øm feels always cold when one touches it, Cardan & Alexander ab Alexandro, are witne≈ø≈øes, that affirm it, and Cajetan gives a rea≈øon, that he has learned from the Devil's own mouth, who being asked by a Witch concerning this ≈øubject, an≈øwer'd, that the thing mu≈øt needs be ≈øo, and that it could not be otherwi≈øe; the Cardinal explained the words of the Devil in this ≈øen≈øe, that he will not communicate to a body he takes, that moderate heat which is ≈øo agreeable, or that God will not permit him. The Witch was contented with that po≈øitive an≈øwer, without putting the Que≈øtion further.

Sect. 10. The Que≈øtion now is to know, who they are which oftene≈øt ≈øee Specters? our Author an≈øwers pertinently to this Que≈øtion, p. 292 and 293. And his words de≈øerve very well to be reported, as they are. The Souls which are in Purgatory, appear rather to the Faithful then to the Excommunicated, or to Infidels; and among the≈øe fir≈øt, they appear rather to their Parents, to their Allies,
and to tho≈øe which belong to them, in any manner what≈øoever, then they do to Strangers, becau≈øe that they hope for ≈øuccor from them, which they cannot hope from others. The Souls of the damned appear particularly to tho≈øe which have been the cau≈øe of their lo≈øs, and of the torments they ≈øuffer. The apparitions of Devils are made al≈øo with reference to the ruins of tho≈øe they per≈øecute, and their ill will for Mankind, whom they take plea≈øure to torment. On the fir≈øt re≈øpect, tho≈øe who are charged with a greater number of Sins have mo≈øt to ≈øuffer, in the ≈øecond, the mo≈øt Virtuous Men are the more expo≈øed to their attacks.

Sect. 11. After the Specters, let us come to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe≈øt, refering the remedies again≈øt the≈øe two accidents, to the following Chapter. That which happens to the po≈ø≈øe≈øt, gives occa≈øion to know more particularly what the Devil can act, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing, ≈øays Schottus, is an inevitable torment to Man from the Devil, which is in his body, who acts there, and keeps him in his power for a certain time. p. 521. Which he unfolds more particularly afterwards, but as there has been lately publi≈øhed, an Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun, and of a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion very famous, ≈øaid to have happened in the Town, the circum≈øtances of which, give a great deal of light upon this point, we will alledge that which will be proper for this ≈øubject, referring a more ≈øtrict examination to our 4th Book, which we ≈øhall not be afraid to do, nothwith≈øtanding the Author appears to be a Prote≈øtant, becau≈øe that the mo≈øt part of the ≈øtories this Hi≈øtory contains, are gathered from many Eccle≈øia≈øtick Books, where they are grounded upon Authentick publick acts; and that the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion was declared true by a decree of the Bi≈øhop. It was al≈øo confirm'd by the blood of a Prie≈øt, who was executed for a Magician, after having been condemn'd by an act made by a ≈øentence of Judges Commi≈ø≈øioner ≈øent by the French
King, to examine this affair, ≈øee then yet what Schottus ≈øays. p. 533. &c.

Fir≈øt. That a Man may be po≈ø≈øe≈øt by all ≈øorts of evil Spirits, of what order ≈øoever they may be, for it has been ≈øaid in the 19th Ch. Sect. 8. That the Devils are divided into different orders, and the Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun, ≈øhews us, that one Elizabeth Blancheard, ≈øaid to be po≈ø≈øe≈øt by ≈øix Devils; by A≈øtaroh and the coal of uncleanne≈øs, by the order of Angels; by Belzebub and the Lion of Hell, of the order of Archangels; by Perou and Marou, of the order of Cherubins. p. 255.
Second. That all per≈øons of what Sex, Age, Condition, or Religion ≈øoever they may be, what≈øoever kind of life they lead, either good or bad, may be po≈ø≈øe≈øt by Devils.

Third. Alth√¥ the mo≈øt part are po≈ø≈øe≈øt without their con≈øent, and in ≈øpight of them, by evil Spirits, it is believed, ≈øometimes, that there are ≈øome which con≈øent to it, there are tho≈øe to whom are attributed Spirits of Pithon, who divine by means of the Devil. Schottus p. 550.
Sect. 12. This Author explains to us more preci≈øely, in what manner the Devil enters into Men, and how he works.

Fir≈øt. Granting he can cloath all ≈øorts of bodies as he plea≈øes, and according as God permits him, he can ≈øometimes go and come, enter into Man, and come out invi≈øibly, and ≈øometimes, al≈øo vi≈øibly and under the figures of ≈ømall Bea≈øts, or in≈øects, as Ants, Flies, Spiders, or under tho≈øe little birds. This is the common Opinions of Popi≈øh writers, alth√¥ Schottus is not very much for it. p. 539. But he is in the wrong, for here's a proof, at lea≈øt, as to his invi≈øible going in, and coming out, in the Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun; where it is ≈øaid, that a Devil called Bihemot, being gone out to ≈øeek a new Covenant, the guardian
Angel of the Nun that he po≈ø≈øe≈øt, ≈øeized upon him and bound him for a Month, under the Picture of St. Jo≈øeph in the Church. p. 405. And that this Religious fancyed, as tho I know not what ≈øhould have gone out from her head, which removed from her, as the Devil retired farther; and afterwards the Devil him≈øelf declared, that after having been tied in his body not to part from it, he had at pre≈øent, as well as his companions, the liberty of coming too and fro. p. 408.

Second. Schottus howevever agrees, that evil Spirits give to the po≈ø≈øe≈øt, the faculty of ≈øpeaking ≈øtrange languages that they never learned, and of revealing ≈øecrets, which they could not know of them≈øelves. p. 540. So it is that the Nun of Loudun ≈øpoke Latin the be≈øt he could, a≈ø≈øuring that ≈øhe had never learned it. Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun. And ≈øo it is that the Demons di≈øcovered to the Je≈øuit surin, ≈øecret matters, in his thought or in his per≈øon. p. 273. or that they went to ki≈øs the right hand of one of the exorci≈øts, for that the Duke of Orleance had ≈øo de≈øired it, and had declared his de≈øire to another exorci≈øt. p. 297. Upon which one of them hath writ, that the Devils an≈øwered often to interrogatories, made to them by the exorci≈øts, without expre≈ø≈øing them otherwi≈øe then by the inferior direction of their thoughts. p. 104. See there the la≈øt effort of Divination to divine thoughts hidden, and in no ways expre≈ø≈øed.

Third. Schottus ≈øays in other places, that the principal operations of the Devil, are made in the body of the po≈ø≈øe≈øt, and that they art little or nothing upon the Soul; and that for this rea≈øon, they cannot make a Man loo≈øe his Faith, nor Hope, nor Charity p. 534. But the Devil I≈øaacarum who knew more of it then our Author, ≈øays, that Behemet had not only vex'd Job in his body, but that he had al≈øo
troubled his Soul: and that it is for this rea≈øon, that he ≈øinned not in all that he ≈øaid: Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun. Pag. 374.

Sect. 13. See what the Devil can do, and what he does very often, according to the opinions of the Roman Catholicks; be it that he makes u≈øe of the Mini≈øtry of Men in the≈øe occa≈øions, or that he u≈øes them nor; tho≈øe that he imployes in his Mini≈øtry, are called Sorcerers, Enchanters, and Magicians. 'Tis ≈øtedfa≈øtly believed, that tho≈øe People have given them≈øelves to the Devil, and have covenanted with him, and ≈øigned it with their own Blood; That the Devil on his part is ob≈øerved to do all they de≈øire during the cour≈øe of their life, and that the Magicians on their part give them≈øelves to the Devil, and put them≈øelves into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion all their days, or for a certain time that they have mutually agreed together. If you would ≈øee an example very particular of ≈øuch a contract, you need but read the Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun, Pag. 271. but you cannot read it without being amazed. The Magicians, in con≈øequence of their Covenants, are to enjoy a great deal of plea≈øure, which will be procured to them by the Devil, to do a great deal of mi≈øchief to others, and cau≈øe a great deal of damage to their Cattle, and to their other Goods. Their plea≈øure con≈øi≈øts in ≈øolemn A≈ø≈øemblies, which are held in the night in places the Devil appoints, and where he appears in all ≈øorts of Figures: there they dance, drink and eat in exce≈øs, and the Men and Women mix them≈øelves carnally together, and with the Devil him≈øelf, who for that purpo≈øe, ≈øometimes transforms him≈øelf into a Man, ≈øometimes into a Woman. The Wizards and Witches are tran≈øported thro the' Windows, to places where they a≈ø≈øemble, by virtue of a certain Ointment they anoint them≈øelves with; they ride
mounted upon the Devil, as upon a Hor≈øe, for he is obliged to ≈øerve them; and for this purpo≈øe he transforms him≈øelf into a Goat, or ≈øome other Animal. Sometimes there are in tho≈øe A≈ø≈øemblies, ≈øtrange Sacrifices, for the Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun writes, Pag. 153. That they force the Devil Leviathan to ≈øurrender a Contract written upon the fle≈øh of the Heart of an Infant, taken in a Sabbat, held at Orleans, and of the A≈øhes of a burnt Ho≈øt.

Sect. 14. The di≈øorders that they cau≈øe to Men, are to mi≈øchief their per≈øons, or their Cattle, to ≈øtir up Tempe≈øts, to ≈øpoil the Corn of the field, to breed Di≈øputes, to di≈øturb the Society of Men, by a thou≈øand means; ≈øome times they do good with an eye to proper advantage; for ≈øome Money they di≈øcover things lo≈øt; they declare if one is bewitch'd, or if not, and by whom it has been; they teach what mu≈øt be done to cure them that are ≈øo, or they cure them them≈øelves. Of this, Bodin in his Book, intituled Daemonamania ≈øhall fully in≈øtruct, the reader, that will take the pains to read him. For no Authors are more large upon that ≈øubject, than he and Delrio. In the mean while we will look into their Sentiments, related by Schotus, more plainly than in their own Books.

Sect. 15. He defines this unlawful Magick, upon which ≈øubject the Reader will not forget the di≈øtinction heretofore made, Chap. 4. Sect 2. & 7. A Power by which Man works certain wonders, which ≈øurpa≈øs ordinary ∆≤nder≈øtanding, which is done, not by any Art, nor by the force of his proper Faculties, nor by the application of natural Cau≈øes, but by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtanc of tha Devil, by virtue of an agreement made with him. Mag. ∆≤niver≈øe. Pag. 1. Lib. 1. in Proleg. Chap. 7. he e≈øtabli≈øhes the≈øe ≈øorts of Covenants as certain, di≈øtingui≈øhing them into two kinds; tho≈øe
which are made expre≈øly with intention, and of deliberated purpo≈øe; And tho≈øe which are tacitely made. But we ≈øhall hereafter hear Sennertus explaining him≈øelf more at large upon this ≈øubject. However, we find in the ≈øame place, as well as in Schotus's Books this Maxime e≈øtabli≈øhed as certain, Quod Magicae hujus vis omnis nititur pacto, vel tacite vel expre≈ø≈øo cum Demone, ut probat Delrius, &c. That all the force of this Magick, depends on an agreement made tacitely or expre≈øly with the Devil, as Delrius proves it, &c.

Sect. 16. This Author ≈øays further, That from the con≈øideration of the ends the Magicians have, viz. to act marvelous things by the Devils power, chiefly proceed three ≈øorts of Witchcraft; for they have ≈øometimes, no other end but to acquire the Art and Indu≈øtry of producing miraculous effects for their proper advantage or plea≈øure; or that of others: they ≈øometimes endeavour to di≈øcover things to come, or to know things pa≈øt, and ≈øuch pre≈øent at are ≈øecret and hidden, and cannot be di≈øcovered by any human power; ≈øometimes they have no other end but to acquire the Power, the Art, and the Means to hurt Men. This is not the place to tell what the Papi≈øts believe Magicians are able to do, and what in effect they do; becau≈øe, in the preceding Chapter, one has ≈øeen what is the power that Popery attributes to the Devil, who are likewi≈øe capable to effect by the Mini≈øtry of Men, that is to ≈øay, of Wizards and Witches, according to the conditions of their Leagues, all that they effect them≈øelves.

Sect. 17. It will not be, however, be≈øides the purpo≈øe, to cite Bodin, who tells you in very preci≈øe terms, the Second Book, Chap. 4. how Men expre≈øly make Leagues with the Devil. And I grant that if it be true, that they are ≈øuch as he ≈øays, I am obliged to hold with him; the≈øe People for the mo≈øt
execrable of all Men, ≈øince they renounce God and his wor≈øhip, if they are in the Communion of the Church; or that they abjure their Faith, if they acknowledge not the true God, or if they are of ≈øome particular Sect, and ingaged in Super≈øtitions, which is done in an expre≈øs Covenant, to acknowledge the Devil, and to adore none but him. He adds a little after, Sometimes the expre≈øs Obligation is but verbal, and without any writing; but ≈øometimes it is al≈øo confirmed by writing, for the Devil re≈øolving to be ≈øure of them who ≈øeek him before he propo≈øes any Covenant between him and them, he makes them give a promi≈øe in writing (if they can write) and ≈øign it with their own Blood. He adds, further, that this obligation is made either for two, years, or for a longer time; And as if the Devil feared that tho≈øe that are wholly obliged to him, ≈øhould come to retract this, he is not contented to make them renounce God in terms very preci≈øe; but be≈øides, he makes an impre≈ø≈øion upon them.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. That ≈øeveral means are practi≈øed again≈øt Attacks, and the Illu≈øions of the Devil and Magicians.
div.p: Sect. 1. I Know not whether I mu≈øt put the re≈øt I have to ≈øay upon the account of the Papi≈øts only, there being but very few of our Profe≈ø≈øion who do not believe it as they do, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew in the next Chapter. I ≈øhall report only in this, what means Popery affords to avoid all ≈øorts of Devils and Specters, and to divert them from us. The Fir≈øt means con≈øi≈øts in the re≈øi≈øtance, which is ≈øufficient again≈øt their Malice. The Second, con≈øi≈øts in the finding out of tho≈øe that are guilty of the≈øe Abominations. And the Third, in the Puni≈øhments that the≈øe People are thought to de≈øerve. Schottus ≈øhall furni≈øh me with that which I have to ≈øay touching the fir≈øt of the≈øe means: And I ≈øhall take from other Writings what I am to relate concerning the ≈øecond and third, to which I ≈øhall joyn that which may be learned by experience.

Sect. 2. Our Author, who warrants that which he ≈øays, rejects divers means, and e≈øtabli≈øhes many others; we mu≈øt hear him as well upon tho≈øe which he rejects, as tho≈øe he e≈øtabli≈øhes. See the≈øe he rejects.

1. Malignant Injuries and Outrages never drive away Spirits, but ≈øome in≈øulting terms that are made u≈øe of in Exorci≈øms, which have been introduced into the Church, contribute very much to expel them, pag. 304.
2. Neither Pike nor Sword, nor any other ≈øort of Arms will oblige them to retire, pag. 305.
3. Neither Fire nor Light that are not Con≈øecrated, have any virtue for this purpo≈øe, p. 308.
4. Neither will they withdraw, though they find the Doors and Windows open before them, p. 308.

5. Though 'tis the Opinion of many People, who are of the Author's Profe≈ø≈øion, that Spirits may be driven away by Smoak, by Perfumes, by certain Herbs, and by Blows with Stones, they hold neverthele≈øs, That no natural Virtue that may be in material Subjects, can act directly upon Spirits, and that by con≈øequence there are no ≈øen≈øible ≈øubjects, ≈øuch as tho≈øe (as have been ju≈øt now mentioned) which may always expel Spirits from the places where they are, nor drive them far from Men, pag. 308. and 312.
Sect. 3. On the contrary, he holds that the means following are ab≈øolutely effective.

1. At fir≈øt he ≈øtabli≈øhes two, again≈øt which there is nothing to ≈øay; which are, a ≈øtedfa≈øt Faith, and an ardent Prayer, p. 214, 215. for they are conform to the Maxims of Scripture. This ≈øort of Devils cannot be ca≈øt out but by Prayers and Fa≈øtings, St. Matth. 17.20, 21.

2. But he e≈øtabli≈øhes five others, which are invented purely by Popery. Fir≈øt, The Relicks of Holy Bodies; or, to ≈øay better, of tho≈øe who are taken for ≈øuch. Secondly, The Sign of the Cro≈øs. Thirdly, Holy Water. Fourthly, Agnus Dei, that is, the Lamb of God, imprinted upon a little round figure of Wax, and con≈øecrated by the Pope. They have, ≈øays Schottus, a ready virtue and efficacious, virtutem prae≈øtanti≈ø≈øimam, to put the Devil to flight, p. 322. Fifth, To pronounce the name of Je≈øus, and to call upon the Virgin Mary his Mother, p. 324. All the≈øe means are explained, every one in particular, in the ≈øame place. They are al≈øo de≈øcribed,
but a little more abridged, although in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, by John Davidi, Je≈øuit, in his Book Intituled, the Buckler, printed at Balduc, in the year 1619. I ≈øhall report his own Words, le≈øt the Roman Catholicks ≈øhould accu≈øe me of impo≈øing upon them: See what he writes in the 10th Chapter. Among≈øt the Con≈øecrated things which have power again≈øt the ambu≈øhes of the Enemy, we mu≈øt rank the≈øe here. Holy Water, which is every Sunday con≈øecrated in the Church, and has its name from that Con≈øecration. The Bapti≈ømal Water that is Con≈øecrated on the Vigils of Ea≈øter and Whit≈øuntide. The Holy Water, that is called Gregory Water, that the Bi≈øhops con≈øecrate with Salt, A≈øhes, and Wine, therewith to con≈øecrate Altars, and for other Holy ∆≤≈øes. The Candels that are wont to be Con≈øecrated upon the Fea≈øts of the Purification. The Branches Con≈øecrated on Palm Sunday; Every one of tho≈øe operates its effect in being u≈øed in the ≈øame manner that they have been Con≈øecrated, be≈øprinkling with Water, lighting of Candles, and putting or planting the Branches in ≈øome particular place. The Agnus Dei's that are worn about the Neck, or other places, according to the veneration due to them, being Con≈øecrated by the Pope him≈øelf, have al≈øo a Soveraign virtue to keep the Chri≈øtian from the Snares, and from all the evil de≈øigns of the Enemy, or to pre≈øerve him by Sea and Land, from Fire or Water, and all other Perils. The ≈øign of the Cro≈øs is al≈øo of a Marvellous u≈øe on the≈øe occa≈øions; It being the Chri≈øtians Duty to be always ready to make again≈øt all the Temptations the Enemy can give them, as well within as without. The Church makes a profitable u≈øe of it in all its Con≈øecrations, in its Ble≈ø≈øings, in the Admini≈øtration of the Holy Sacrament; but e≈øpecially in the Exorci≈øms of Evil Spirits, and in the Conjurations which are made upon People tormented by them: All which things are practi≈øed to re≈øi≈øt the Wiles
and Mi≈øchiefs of the Devil; and to repul≈øe his Attacks, to weaken his Force, and de≈øtroy his Power.

Sect. 4. The Roman Church alone, according to this Author, has the power to u≈øe effectually the≈øe means, which it calls Spiritual. For ≈øee what he ≈øays, All that which is not efficacious of it ≈øelf, nor by ≈øome natural Virtue, nor by the In≈øtitution and Power of God, both which are found in the Sacraments; nor by the Ordinance of the Church, which acts but according to the Word of God, and by the Virtue he communicates to her: All that, I ≈øay, which is not efficacious by ≈øome one of the≈øe means, from which alone the Remedies imployed in any occa≈øion what≈øoever can draw their force; If one dares undertake to make u≈øe of the≈øe things, and to apply them for Remedies, it is an action ba≈øely Super≈øtitious and oppo≈øite to the Will of God and his Word. Afterwards he begins the 11th Chapter in the≈øe Terms. As to the Sacred Word, who≈øe power affects the Enemy, the Exorci≈øms, or the Conjurations which are ordain'd by the Church, have a particular Virtue: Such are the Exorci≈øms that are made u≈øe of by the Ritual of Rome, and tho≈øe that are found in the Manual made for the Archbi≈øhoprick of Malines, ≈øeen and approved by the Doctors of the ∆≤niver≈øities of Lovain. If one has the curio≈øity to ≈øee all the≈øe Doctrines reduced into practice, he needs but Read the Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun, which has been already cited, where he will ≈øee from one end to the other, the u≈øages of the Roman Church concerning Conjurations and Exorci≈øms, which are unknown to all other Religions, and of which tho≈øe that read them have cau≈øe to be ≈øurpri≈øed.

Sect. 5. See how they proceed to find out the guilty, and particularly in Germany. It is ≈øufficient only to have the reputation of being a Sorcerer, and you are a≈ø≈øoon impri≈øoned, and interrogated; if you deny it, you are put to the Torture, even two
or three times; if you confe≈øs, you pronounce your own Sentence, even of Condemnation. It is a long time ≈øince they take for a mark of Conviction, when the Accu≈øed being in the hands of Ju≈øtice, cannot cry, which proof was found in the Proce≈øs of the Curate that was burnt at Loudun, Hi≈øtory of the Devils of Loudun, &c. Pag. 201. for the Exorci≈øt told him, Praecipio ut ≈øi ≈øis innocens, effin ‚Ä¢ das lachrymas. I command you to ≈øhed tears if thou art in ocent, which not having done, they reported it for a proof of his crime, that he ≈øhed no tears in ≈øuffering the wrack, nor after having ≈øuffered it, when he was exorci≈øed with the Exorci≈øme and Magicians. But, becau≈øe it is believed that the Devil will ≈øerve his ≈øubjects or confidents, with all the skill and power he is capable of, there is a great deal of care taken to leave nothing upon the Criminals, for fear that there ≈øhould remain upon them ≈øome hidden charm, by which means they may deliver them≈øelves. For this rea≈øon they take from them all their Cloaths, and examine at the ≈øame time, whether they have the Devils mark. So the Men and the Women are ≈øtript naked, and all the Hair is ≈øhaved off their Bodies: after this manner they u≈øed the Curate of Loudun, for to prevent the help that he might hope to have from the Devils. A Capucin Frier exorci≈øed the Air, the Earth, and other Elements, Pag. 207. The Corners, the Woods, and the Hammers of the Rack 208. they took off his Cloaths and gave him others, Pag. 205. he was ≈øhaved all over, and ≈øearched to find out the Devil's marks upon his Body, Pag. 130. But not to be deceived in the judgment, that ≈øhall be made of the crime, or of the innocence of the Accu≈øed; the Je≈øuit Davids reports four principal manners of making proofs, which is to the purpo≈øe to mention here. They u≈øe a red hot Iron, hot Water, or cold Water, and a Ballance.

Sect. 6. I find the three fir≈øt means in the fir≈øt Book of the de≈øcription of America, of A Mountanus which appears to be taken from Boxhoorneus, thus they are related. The Ordallia (which is the name given to this way of poof) was Preached in the Low-Countries after this manner, when any was accu≈øed for not being a good Catholick or of being a Sorcerer, he fa≈øted three days, in the ≈øight of the Prie≈øt, at the end of which, he went to Church, the Prie≈øt cloathed in his ≈øacredotal Habits put upon burning Coals near the Altar, an Iron wedge be≈øprinkled with Holy Water. He ≈øung the Song of the three Children in the fiery Furnace, he ≈øaid Ma≈øs, he put the Ho≈øt in the mouth of the accu≈øed, and prayed to God that it would plea≈øe him to di≈øcover the crime of Magick, of which he was ≈øu≈øpected, in ≈øuffering that his Hand in which he was puting the red hot Iron, might be burnt, or that he might not receive any hurt, if he were innocent. The≈øe Prayers being fini≈øhed, the accu≈øed was to go nine ≈øteps in carrying the burning Iron in his Hand, after which the Prie≈øt wrapt up has Hand, and ≈øeal'd the covering that was put to it. The third day he took off the ≈øeal to con≈øider his Hand, whether it was ≈øound and without wound, otherwi≈øe the unhappy accu≈øed had but to re≈øolve to be burnt alive all covered with Paper, painted all over with Devils.

Sect. 7. The Ketelvang was no le≈øs painful, they had in the Church a Caldorn full of boyling Water, upon which they had made the mo≈øt terrible Conjurations, that can be imagin'd, after which, to come to the conviction or to the ju≈øtification of the accu≈øed, he was obliged to put his Arm naked up to the elbow, in the boyling Water, as hot as could be. This u≈øage mu≈øt be very Ancient, and proceeded from Pagani≈øm, according to that which has been remarked hereupon, touching the Ancients. Chap. 3. Sect. 18.

Sect. 8. We have a little more knowledge of the proof by cold Water, which has been more common
common than the others, and has been practi≈øed long ago in the We≈øt of England, of which we ≈øhall have occa≈øion to ≈øpeak hereafter. Montanus has made likewi≈øe a ≈øhort de≈øcription of it. It was al≈øo cu≈øtomary to make u≈øe of a proof by cold water in Canals, Brooks and Ditches; the Prie≈øt conjured the Water, he tyed the Thumb of the accu≈øed to his great Toe, one upon another in form of a Cro≈øs, and threw him in to the water; if he ≈øunk, to the bottom, he was declared innocent; but if he was buoy'd up on the water, he was condemned as guilty.

Sect. 9. There is as yet a more particular proof, which is practi≈øed in Holland, alth√¥, not upon the Dutch them≈øelves, but upon ≈øtranger, that are weighed in a Ballance. The Papi≈øt inhabitants of the Bi≈øhoprick of Mun≈øter, Cologne, and Paderborne, and many other more di≈øtant places have made u≈øe, ≈øince the time of the Emperor Charles, to this day, of the publick weights of the Town D'Oudewater in this ≈øame Province. It is what I am going to tell you more preci≈øely by the contents of a Letter written by one of the Bourgoma≈øters of Oudewater to a friend of his, and related at the beginning of a little Book, entituled (Sure means not to pa≈øs ≈øentence of death unju≈øtly.) The Bourgoma≈øter ≈øays chiefly in his Letter, an≈øwering to que≈øtions that had been put to him: That all tho≈øe that came from that Country for this purpo≈øe, unanimou≈øly complain'd, that they had been unju≈øtly accu≈øed of Magick in their Country, and that if they were ≈øo unhappy as not to find proofs of their innocence in the weights of the Town of Oudewater, with which it was nece≈ø≈øarily required, their Bodies ≈øhould be in equal weight, for their ju≈øtification; they ran a danger upon their return of loo≈øing their Life and E≈øtate: Becau≈øe the common belief of that Country is, that tho≈øe, who weigh le≈øs than the weight that is put again≈øt them into the other part of the
ballance, (≈øuch as agreed upon, as will be pre≈øently ≈øeen) are undoubtedly Sorcerers. The Burgoma≈øter adds, that the late Secretary Hoy had told him, that in his time there was a certain Inhabitant of the upper Country, who having had a difference with one of his Companions, he cau≈øed a di≈øcour≈øe thro' the Country, that the other was a Wizard: Some advi≈øed this pretended Sorcerer to go into Holland, and to be weighed with the weights of Oudewater, to the end he might take off, by this means, the calumny. He goes thither, but whether out of ≈øtupidity, imprudence, or fear, or for not being well informed of what mu≈øt be practi≈øed, he returned into his own Country without being weighed. They did not fail to aske him whether he had undergone this Tryal, which he could not ≈øhew; upon which ≈øu≈øpicions being increa≈øed, it was believed he was found too light, and that he was guilty. The di≈øcour≈øe being come to the Ears of the Judge of the place, he gave order to take him up; but he ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ed, and was concealed with a per≈øon to whom had happen'd very near the like adventure, who advi≈øed him to return to Oudewater; and indeed they went thither together. The accu≈øed was weighed in the Scales of the Town, and returning into his Country, brought with him, at this time, all the Certificates of the proof he had undergone, And then he was re-e≈øtabli≈øhed into his good Fame; and his E≈øtate that was ≈øeized by the Judge, was re≈øtored to him.

Sect. 10. Upon the ≈øecond Que≈øtion which was made to the Burgoma≈øter of Oudewater, he an≈øwered, That there is no fi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d weight for to weigh people; but they look upon their bulk, and at ≈øight they proportion the weight to it. Upon the Third demand to know where this practice had taken its Original; He an≈øwered, that he could di≈øcover nothing of it. But that neverthele≈øs, it appeared from all the≈øe matters of fact, that „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lla ‚Ä¢ c of the Town of Oudewater is in reputation in the Country, as has been ≈øpoken of, to produce this effect,
≈øo that there are often per≈øons that come thither to be weighed, who have brought particular recommendations from the Town or Country they lived in. They ≈øay further, that the Emperor Charles the Fifth gave this Privilege to the Town of Oudewater, gave becau≈øe of the faithfulne≈øs that is made u≈øe of upon this occa≈øion; and becau≈øe they had di≈øcovered a certain Cheat, which was practi≈øed in the neighbouring Village. However, it is but a publick di≈øcour≈øe, and without certainty.

Sect. 11. I approve very much the judgement the Author makes of this practice, but 'tis a thing I ought not to ≈øay here, to the end, not to create in the Mind of any, prejudice upon the ≈øubject I treat of. However, this ≈øame Author which has furni≈øhed me with all this Relation, and has not put his name but by N. B. A. ≈øays, That during two years that he has lived at Oudewater, they have weighed many per≈øons for the ≈øame purpo≈øe. I have learned likewi≈øe ≈øince, that this u≈øe ≈øtill continues as yet, and pretended Sorcerers are there ≈øtill.

Sect. 12. There are not many things to ≈øay touching the puni≈øhment inflicted upon Wizards and Witches in Popi≈øh Countries, more e≈øpecially in Germany. It being undeniable, and generally received, that they de≈øerve to be burned alive; it is rarely ≈øeen that they are treated with le≈øs rigor. If the number of tho≈øe which have lo≈øt their lives in divers places, and at divers times upon this occa≈øion, might be brought together, and put in Arms, they would be more than ≈øufficient to de≈øtroy the enemy of the Chri≈øtian name, and entirely de≈øtroy its Empire. We ≈øhall make this examination in our Third Book, and the review of the proceedings of the Magicians, to which the ≈øame Treati≈øe of Sure means, &c. will be of great u≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. That neither the Opinions that are received among us' nor our Practices go u≈øually ≈øo far; and that is for that rea≈øon, that our Authors are not found to agree ≈øo well together, upon this ≈øubject.
div.p:
I will at pre≈øent leave the Papi≈øts and pa≈øs to the Prote≈øtants, who≈øe Religion and Doctrine is more pure. They ≈øuffer not them≈øelves to ≈øtray ≈øo much as others, about the matter in hand; for neither believing Purgatory, nor admitting the invocation of Angels and decea≈øed Saints, they cannot likewi≈øe agree in their Opinions with the Papi≈øts, concerning apparitions and the operations of Spirits, more e≈øpecially in relation to the≈øe two points; and the con≈øequences that are nece≈ø≈øarily drawn from thence, when they are admitted. However it mu≈øt be ob≈øerved, that the belief and practices of the Lutherans upon this ≈øubject, come much nearer tho≈øe of Popery than the belief of the People of our Communion. It is al≈øo to be con≈øidered, that there is among the Prote≈øtants in general, a great deal of difference between the common People and the learned; it is true, that there is likewi≈øe to be di≈øcovered ≈øome difference between tho≈øe two kinds of People‚ñ™ among the Papi≈øts, and even among the Pagans. There appears no le≈øs among the Men of Letters in particular, ≈øome holding the common belief and helping it, others rejecting it, and others at lea≈øt taking a kind of a medium between tho≈øe
two parties; ≈øo there are found among us People, who believe almo≈øt all that is ≈øaid of Witchcraft and Specters. There are others, who deny all mo≈øt all, but the greate≈øt part, partly admit that which is ordinarily ≈øaid, and partly reject it. That being ≈øuppo≈øed, we mu≈øt ≈øtill under≈øtand with relation to this di≈øtinction, what I have to ≈øay in this work touching that of the reformed Religion. But however, to abridge my di≈øcour≈øe rather than extend it, it will be nece≈ø≈øary, fir≈øt to propo≈øe the common Opinion and the ordinary practice; and afterwards the Opinion of People the mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible, and the mo≈øt thinking part.

Sect. 2. We frequently hear People make a great deal of di≈øcour≈øe concerning Apparitions, Phantomes, Witchcraft, and things of that nature. It is believed in general, that Angels have been from the beginning all created by God, of which one part having revolted again≈øt him, are become Devils. But afterwards continuing to ≈øpeak of the Devil, he is ≈øpoken of as ≈øingly as the Enemy of Mankind, and chiefly of the faithful, hunting continually after occa≈øions of doing ill. There is every where had a high Opinion of his under≈øtanding, power, and action; he is conceived, or at lea≈øt ≈øpoken of as one, and yet they make him to be pre≈øent in all places, he acts every where, he ≈øpies and ≈øets his Hand to every thing. I'll explain this here ≈øomething more particularly.

Sect. 3. They attribute to him ≈øuch an extraordinary knowledge, that 'tis pretended he under≈øtands better all the my≈øteries of the Go≈øpel, than all the mo≈øt learned and mo≈øt under≈øtanding Divines, that he ob≈øerves all our thoughts, that he mixes with and acts upon them, from him proceed apparitions, and pre≈øages, by which Men are advi≈øed of future things, before they happen to them, more particularly
when they are threatned with the death of ≈øome of their friends, or ≈øome other evil accident. It is believed further, that a Divine may declare where one ≈øhall find what is lo≈øt, whether a Man is bewitch'd, and who is the Author of the mi≈øchief, and what means there are to deliver him and many other ≈øuch like things.

Sect. 4. The Opinion of the power of the Devil, has been doubtle≈øs urged to exce≈øs, for neither God nor Je≈øus Chri≈øt have ever done any thing great or marvellous but the People a≈øcribe to the Devil, I have ≈øhewn before in ≈øome manner, Ch. 18. Sect. 6. That tho≈øe thoughts proceeded from the Manichees. When God permits him he can appear to Men in all ≈øorts of figures, not only in tho≈øe of good and bad Men living or Dead, but al≈øo in tho≈øe of ≈øeveral Bea≈øts; from this ≈øame principle comes the belief that is ≈øtill in being, that wicked debauched People transform them≈øelves al≈øo by the power of the Devil, making u≈øe of means de≈øigned for this purpo≈øe, into many ≈øhapes of Bea≈øts, as of Wolves, but particularly into that of Cats, and being ≈øo tran≈øfigured they pa≈øs though the quarrel of a gla≈øs window, or the hole of a Bell, to go in the night to the Sabat, as I have already ≈øaid; or rather they ride on Hor≈øeback upon a ≈øtick up the Chimney, and this belief to this time cannot be rooted out among us, from the mind of the People; further it is imagined, that the≈øe ≈øame People may, with the cooperation of the Devil, ≈øtir up tempe≈øts, ≈øhut the wind up into a Handkerchief, and let it out when they will, which however is ≈øeldom attributed but to the Laplanders and to Finlanders, to which the ≈øtories that are made of their practices, have given occa≈øion, ≈øo great is the credulity of the People, even for the mo≈øt ab≈øurd thing; they per≈øwade them≈øelves al≈øo, that the≈øe People devoted to the Devil, learn of
him the ≈øecret of making certain oyntments, by which they make them≈øelves invulnerable again≈øt Swords or Mu≈øquets; and that they obtain likewi≈øe great many other advantages from their Ma≈øter.

Sect. 5. It is not doubted but leagues are made between the Devil and Magicians, by which means all the≈øe accident happen; People are even per≈øwaded of the effect of the proofs by Water, into which the accu≈øed are thrown, and of a great many otherlike things; above all of the u≈øefulne≈øs of the advice the exorci≈øts give, as that endeavouring to cau≈øe the per≈øon bewitch'd, to be ble≈øt by him that has done the mi≈øchief, which is held for an remedy infallible; if the pretended Sorcerer refu≈øes to do it, he may be forced to it by blows, and by violencies Another remedy is to bake ≈øome certain things in ≈øome certain Pot, for a certain number of hours, to a certain hour of the Day or Night. The guilty is forced by this means, to come to the hou≈øe, and con≈øequently make him≈øelf known, or the bewitch'd per≈øon ≈øwallows what has been baked, or carries ≈øomthing about his Neck, or hanging upon his Brea≈øt. In ≈øhort there are a thou≈øand other things which would be unprofitable and tedious to relate.

Sect. 6. The u≈øe that is made of all the≈øe Opinions, and the con≈øequences that are drawn from them, are to attribute to the in≈øpirations and ≈øollicitations of the Devil, all the≈øe extraordinary events, and almo≈øt all the ≈øins that are committed, e≈øpecially, tho≈øe that are mo≈øt enormous. If a ≈øudden tempe≈øt ari≈øes, and that there is ≈øome in our company who is not very much our friend, and is a little ≈øu≈øpected of being a Witch, we do not fail of imputing to him this di≈øorder. If any one gives a little Cake, a Sugar plum, an Apple, or other fruit to a Child, who comes very ≈øuddainly after to fall into a langui≈øhing
condition for a long time, he that has made this pre≈øent is immediatly ≈øu≈øpected of having bewitched the Child, and the means are made u≈øe of as we have told you before, as a proof to di≈øcover the truth; if the Child recovers pre≈øently after the tryal, it is no more doubted, but that the di≈øea≈øe was the effect of Witchcraft, and that the ≈øu≈øpition again≈øt the Magician was well grounded.

Sect. 7. I have ≈øpoken hitherto of the Opinions and practices of the common People only, I ≈øhall now ≈ønow, that which our Doctors and our Men of letters believe upon this point. There are none ≈øo credulous as the Vulgar; however there is a very con≈øiderable difference to be ≈øeen in their Opinions, ≈øome believing almo≈øt every thing, and others almo≈øt nothing at all. The≈øe two Opinions ≈øo different, ought to be attributed to two Scots; to the one an Illu≈øtrious King of Great Brittain, which is, King James, the Sixth King of Scotland, and Fir≈øt King of England of that name; and the other, to one of his Scotch Subjects, a Scot by birth as by name, being call'd Reynard Scot; the King held the affirmative as to the popular Opinion of Witchcraft, and Apparition of Spirits, which his ≈øubject had already confuted. John Wierus who lived in the begining of the Reformation made by means of Luther and Calvin, had from that time publi≈øhed his Opinion upon the delu≈øion of Spirits and upon the impo≈øtures of Witches, and he had taken a part which held in the middle between tho≈øe two Opinions; ≈øo King James in his Book of Demonology conte≈øted with the≈øe two Authors, according to his expre≈øs Declaration in the Preface.

Sect. 8. What is mo≈øt important in his Book comes very near to this. In the ≈øixth Chapter of the fir≈øt Book, there are de≈øcriptions ≈øo exact of
leagues that Magicians make with the Devil, that it ≈øeems as if the King him≈øelf had ≈øeen the Original, or that they had been reported in the Council. In the fourth Chapter of the ≈øecond Book, the King puts for certain, that evil Spirits may carry Men through the Air, or a≈ø≈øume divers forms, to vi≈øit the Magicians, when they are in Pri≈øon. In the ≈øeventh Chapter, he ≈øays, that in the time of Popery and Pagani≈øm, there was a great many more Apparitions; but that it was ob≈øerved, that ≈øince this la≈øt Reformation of the Chri≈øtian Church, there have been fewer Apparitions, and a great many more Witchcrafts. Concerning the apparitions of Hobgoblins and Phantoms, of which he treats in the Third Book, there are ≈øcarce any kind to which this Prince gives not credit, even to Incubu≈ø≈øes and Succubu≈ø≈øes, which are Spirits, who, as Men, mix them≈øelves carnally with Women, and as Women with Men. In reference to the po≈ø≈øe≈øt, the King agrees that the Popi≈øh Prie≈øt may drive out the Devil; but upon the proofs that he has to convince one of the crime of Magick, he only ≈øays, there mu≈øt be no le≈øs than twelve witne≈ø≈øes, among≈øt which may be admitted, Infants, infamous People, and even tho≈øe that are taken to be Magicians.

Sect. 9. Now alth√¥ the learned, as I have already ≈øaid, extol not ≈øo much all the≈øe things, nor teach them ≈øo expre≈øly; and that by con≈øequence, they credit not ≈øo much what is ordinarily believed and ≈øaid touching the power and Operations of the Devil upon Men, and concerning that which they effect by the means of Men; we mu≈øt however ob≈øerve, that they give ≈øo much extent to his power and actions, that not only they help not to de≈øtroy the general Opinion that is had of him; but al≈øo maintain it by different expre≈ø≈øions they make u≈øe of, and by the in≈øtructions they give. It is what
is ≈øeen, e≈øpecially in the works of two Engli≈øh Authors, who explain them≈øelves more plainly, and preci≈øely than all others upon this matter, which they treat from the foundation; whereas others keep the ≈øame language only by occa≈øion, and when treating of other ≈øubjects, they are obliged to ≈øpeak of them. The fir≈øt of the≈øe Authors is, William Gurnal in his great Book upon the Ephe≈øians, 6.11.18. entituled, The Chri≈øtian in compleat Armour, the fir≈øt Edition is in the Year 1655. And ≈øince there has been Printed at London in folio in 1679. the ≈øixth Edition, He ≈øays, That the Devil being a ≈øpiritual being, extreamly evil, the≈øe two con≈øiderations ought to cau≈øe a great deal of fear to a Chri≈øtian, p. 94. Becau≈øe he is a great Prince who ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes Man very much in power and craft, that his craft is ob≈øerved by his marvelous knowledge, fir≈øt, in ≈øpying proper occa≈øions to tempt Men, p. 36. Secondly, in his ≈øubtle and artificial conduct, and in all the vices he makes u≈øe of for this effect, p. 37. Thirdly, in the care he takes to make all the preparations nece≈ø≈øary to attack us to his advantage, every time he finds opportunity to do it, p. 43. Fourthly, In the trouble that he ≈øtirs up in our Con≈øciences, in reproaching us with our Sins, and in the artifices that he u≈øes, and the ambu≈øhes he lays p. 44. As to what concerns the power and Virtue of the Devil, the Author holds in the fir≈øt place, That he has power not only on the Elements and corporeal ≈øen≈øes, but al≈øo upon ≈øpiritual ≈øub≈øtances of the World, and upon the Souls of Men, p. 74. Afterwards he declares what is the time and place of his Empire over his ≈øubjects, viz. the time, in this life, over people of Darkne≈øs; the place, in the World, for as much as it is plung'd into impiety, p. 79.

Sect. 10. The other Engli≈øh Author is Jo≈øeph Glanvill, the title of which Book is Saduci≈ømus Triumphatus, Saduci≈øm defeated, a Book, wherein he imploys
a great deal of Learning, to prove that Witchcrafts, Inchantments, Apparitions, and Phantoms, are po≈ø≈øible; and afterwards that they are things practi≈øed, and which actually happen. The fir≈øt Edition of it has been al≈øo in Engli≈øh at London in 1661. after the death of the Author. He pretends, that what he e≈øtabli≈øhes as a certain Truth, is grounded upon Rea≈øons and Examples: And I grant, that as to the force of Rea≈øoning, I do not know any Writer who has better ≈øucceeded than he has. Here are his ≈øuppo≈øed Truths; That among other effects, which are attributed to Magicians of both Sexes. Fir≈øt, Being anointed with certain Magical Ointments they pa≈øs through the Chimney, and are tran≈øported into very di≈øtant places. Secondly, That they are turned into Cats, Hares, and divers other Creatures and Figures. Thirdly, That they feel in their own Bodies the ≈øame wounds that are made in the Bodies they borrow. Fourthly, That in muttering certain unintelligible Words, and in making certain Ge≈øtures extraordinary and ridiculous, they rai≈øe Tempe≈øts. Fifthly, That they are ≈øucked by familiar Spirits in the mo≈øt ≈øecret parts of their Bodies. The Author believes that the more the≈øe things are incredible and ridiculous, the more certain they are. I ≈øhall examine his Rea≈øons in my ≈øecond and third Book, and his In≈øtances in my la≈øt, with more exactne≈øs than what other Authors have written upon this Subject, for the con≈øideration I have already alledged; that he carries it above all others, as to the force of his Rea≈øoning.

Sect. 11. All that has hitherto been ≈øa ‚Ä¢ d, re≈øpects, fir≈øt, the Devil, and afterwards Men, that are believed to have Commerce with him, con≈øidered di≈øtinctly and ≈øeparately from him. But an union mu≈øt be made betwixt them. For which effect, the Leagues already mention'd were invented, Sect 5. of this Chapter, and heretofore Chap. 20. Sect. 13.
Moreover, the Opinions which have been reported having pa≈ø≈øed from Popery among≈øt us, and been admitted by many Doctors of our Communion; yet I know not any who has taken their part ≈øo much as Daneus, which is chiefly ob≈øerved in two Points in his De≈øcription of the Leagues, and in the effects he attributes to Sorcerers and Witches; for the≈øe two things are found very amply treated of in his little Book, De Sortiariis, Of Witches; but e≈øpecially the fir≈øt is de≈øcribed with more circum≈øtances than I have read in any Popi≈øh Author. So ≈øeeing this Doctor has been one of the mo≈øt con≈øiderable among us, and that having lived a little after the time of Calvin and Luther, his Book, which was written 116 years ago, has not been attacked nor contradicted that I know of by any Prote≈øtant Writer, but only by Schottus; from thence may be inferr'd, that the≈øe Doctrines are not unknown to us, nor rejected by the Prote≈øtant Churches. I am going to relate in ≈øhort the contents of this Author's Writings.

Sect. 12. See what he ≈øets down in his fourth Chapter, Nullum non Sortiarum cum Satana foedus inii≈ø≈øe, ≈øeque ei devovi≈ø≈øe, That there is no Sorcerer but he has made agreement with the Devil, and devoted him≈øelf to him: See the de≈øcription he makes of the≈øe contracts.

Fir≈øt, To ≈øecure the Per≈øon of the Magician, the Devil imprints a mark either under the Eye-lids, or between the Buttocks, or the Pallat of the Mouth, that it may not be perceived in tho≈øe places. The Author believes that there are none exempt from carrying it: It is for this Rea≈øon, that the Judges order the whole Body of tho≈øe that are accu≈øed of this Crime, to be ≈øhaved, to know the place that is marked, as I have told you.

Secondly, The Conditions of the≈øe Contracts imply that they ≈øhall renounce God, and acknowledge Satan, and adore him for their God, and in Recompence he ≈øhall
a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, and ≈øhall come to their ≈øuccour as oft as they apply them≈øelves to him, which he will never fail to do no more than the Witches on their part fail to obey all his Commands.

Thirdly, After the Covenant has been thus mutually agreed upon, the Magician, the morrow after, ≈øacrifices to the Devil, a Dog, a Cat, or a Hen, that belongs to him, by which means the Contract is confirmed a new.

Fourthly, Afterwards the Devil cau≈øes in proper time and place, all the Magicians to a≈ø≈øemble where ever he pre≈øcribes; there he makes every one of them give an account of the Mi≈øchiefs he has done by his Power and Means.

Fifthly, He ≈øometimes takes the trouble to get them together, a≈ø≈øuming a human ≈øhape for that purpo≈øe, and making him≈øelf known to the Magicians only: At other times he imploys ≈øome of them to go and Convene the A≈ø≈øembly, ≈øhewing them the time and place: This A≈ø≈øembly is not always general, ≈øometimes there are but a certain number which he has cho≈øen to plea≈øe him≈øelf.

Sixthly, If there are ≈øome, who through weakne≈øs of Body cannot go, he gives them a Stick, or a Hor≈øe, of ≈øome Oyntment to anoint them≈øelves, by the virtue of which being become invi≈øible, he tran≈øports them through the Air.
Seventhly, He appears him≈øelf as Ma≈øter of the Club, in ≈øhape of a Man, or in ≈øome ugly He-Goat, or in whatever Form he plea≈øes.
Eightly, There they repeat their Oaths made to him, after which they ≈øing and dance in honour of their new God.

Ninthly, Afterwards he furni≈øhes them with ≈øuch means as they de≈øire, to do mi≈øchief to ≈øuch as they plea≈øe. He teaches them to make up their Poi≈øons, and promi≈øes them to continue his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to them, and his ≈øervice for their occa≈øions.

Tenthly, By virtue of the≈øe Agreements Satan fails not to work wonders in favour of his Magicians, as oft as they make the ≈øign that he has taught them, and ordered them to do, in which ≈øign con≈øi≈øts not the operative and active faculty, as the Magicians believe, but it re≈øides in the Devil, who operates when warned by the ≈øign.

Sect. 13. There is already a great deal, but however there are more things which the Author a≈øcribes to the Devil, and which may be gathered and inferred from divers places of this Book, where they are expre≈øsly contained, as:
Fir≈øt, That he often appears in human ≈øhape.

Secondly, That he ≈øometimes troubles, and ca≈øts ≈øuch a Mi≈øt over the Sen≈øes of tho≈øe that are ingaged with him, that they fancy to have been in certain places, and to have acted ≈øeveral things, though there is no truth or reality in the≈øe Imaginations.
Thirdly, But he really carries them through the Air whither he plea≈øes.
Fourthly, That by the Mini≈øtry of Wizzards and Witches, he can Poi≈øon Men ≈øecretly from far, without touching them.
Fifthly, That the Devil, or the Magicians by his means, may rai≈øe Tempe≈øts, and cau≈øe Rain.

Sixthly, He rejects the Opinion of tho≈øe who believe the power of the Devil has no longer any effect upon the Magicians, nor can act in their behalf, as ≈øoon as they are in the Hands and Power of Ju≈øtice; on the contrary, he ≈øuppo≈øes, that the virtue of Witchcraft may be exerted even in Pri≈øons; and that oftentimes the Devil breaks there the Necks of tho≈øe who belong to him: The≈øe are Daneus's his Doctrines.

Sect. 12. Furthermore, the mo≈øt common Opinion of the Doctors of our Communion, is, That the Devil does not know things to come, but only of him≈øelf he forms conjectures; that neverthele≈øs the
greate≈øt part of Divines con≈øult him for their Predictions. That it is from him they learn what they di≈øcover to other Men of things pre≈øent, things hidden; as when there has been ≈øomething ≈øtoll'n, or ≈øome body bewitch'd, they declare the Thief or Magician. They likewi≈øe a≈øcribe to him ≈øome knowledge of the Thoughts of Men, ≈øince they fancy that he di≈øturbs and ≈øeduces them, and that he incites them to mi≈øchief. For that is properly what we under≈øtand when we pray in our Churches for tho≈øe that are tempted and troubled in their Con≈øciences. There are no errors produced, there ari≈øes no Here≈øies in the Church, it is not afflicted with any per≈øecution, but the Devil has contributed thereto. All the places of Scripture, that ≈øpeak of the Devil, are under≈øtood with relation to the≈øe Ideas: And it is upon the≈øe interpretations that the≈øe Opinions are grounded. It is al≈øo by the ≈øame rea≈øon, that not only the Prote≈øtants, but almo≈øt all the Chri≈øtian Writers a≈ø≈øert, That it is not allow'd to con≈øult the Devil, who is the enemy of God, and of Men, nor to ≈øeek his help: They however agree, that the Pagan Oracles have not always been given by the Devil, but that often they have been the effect of the impo≈øtures of Prie≈øts, which has ≈øo often appear'd, that it is impo≈ø≈øible not to know it.

Sect. 13. The power of the Devil is extreamlv boa≈øted of, for there are very few Doctors who doubt but he can a≈ø≈øume a Body, and po≈ø≈øe≈øs the Bodies of Men, and tran≈øport and torment them ≈øeveral ways, as effectively, as he had actually the impudence to do the≈øe things to our Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf, and to a great many people, of which the Go≈øpel tell us that being po≈ø≈øe≈øt by evil Spirits, they were delivered by our Saviour. They al≈øo ≈øuppo≈øe, that the opinion of the apparitions of
Specters, is confirmed by Scripture, and that it was the ‚Ä¢ Devil (at lea≈øt, according to the opinion of ≈øome) who appeared under the Figure of Samuel. They think that it cannot be deny'd, but that he has power over the Air and Winds, over Armies, over the Goods of Men, their Bodies, and their Lives, which is proved by the example of what happen'd to Job. And by the effects that the Magicians of Egypt produc'd in the time of Mo≈øes, which are as ≈øo many ≈øure marks of the power of the Devil, either to produce In≈øects, as Frogs and Serpents, and to make a Tran≈ømutation of the Elements, either to repre≈øent with an inconceivable readine≈øs, things that are to be fetch'd from far, or at lea≈øt, ≈øo to dazle the eyes of Men, to ≈øee what is not.

Sect. 14. As to the means which Magicians, Diviners, and Inchanters make u≈øe of, ≈øcarce is there a per≈øon of good Sen≈øe, that believes they are efficacious of them≈øelves, but they will have it to be effected by the Devil, who operates all that tho≈øe mi≈øerable wretches imagine to act; and that the Covenants made between him and them, oblige him to execute that which they require of him; provided only, that they make u≈øe of Signs and that they imploy circum≈øtances de≈øtin'd for that purpo≈øe, ≈øuch as he has taught them. It is very prudently ob≈øerved, as is believed, that tho≈øe Leagues are made two ways, which I ≈øhall expre≈øs in the words of Sennertus, taken from his Treati≈øe upon this Que≈øtion. Whether one may be render'd invulnerable to the point of a Sword, and to Mu≈øquets? where he ≈øays, That the Contract with the Devil is of two kinds, mediate or immediate; expre≈øs or tacite. The immediate, or expre≈øs Contract, is when any makes u≈øe of means, that he has been immediately furni≈øhed with by the Devil. The mediate or tacite Contract is, when one makes u≈øe of the means, which in truth have been
ordain'd by the Devil; but not having been ≈øupply'd by the Devil him≈øelf, comes to him by the hand of ≈øome other per≈øon; which is directly contrary to the Law of God, that forbids us to have other Gods but him: For he ≈øays a little further, The con≈øent is not altogether excluded from the tacite agreement, becau≈øe, who≈øoever is not as yet deprived of Rea≈øon, as not to avoid the Precipices of Rocks, or the mouth of a Pit, he cannot but ≈øee that ≈øuch Words and Characters have not in them≈øelves any virtue; and that by con≈øequence, before making u≈øe of them, we are obliged to examin by what virtue they may produce ≈øuch effects: for if one neglects to do it, it is certain a tacite Contract with the Devil, who has promi≈øed to execute all the clau≈øes and conditions of his writing in favour of tho≈øe who make u≈øe of the Words and Characters therein contained, in con≈øequence of which, he who makes u≈øe of it, cannot pretend him≈øelf innocent of the crime of Magick. Such is Sennertus's opinion, and as I may judge from my own experience, will not be confuted by our Doctors, for I hear them generally hold ≈øpeaking the ≈øame Language. Doctor Wierius, a famous Man, who had very much meditated upon this matter, and had ≈øtudied it very much, e≈øtabli≈øhes all the≈øe things a little more confu≈øedly, but yet very near upon the ≈øame foot.

Sect. 15. I have ≈øomething to add here concerning Dreams. The common Language of our Divines, is, that there are four ≈øorts; Natural, Civil, or ≈øuch as are occa≈øion'd by the preceding conver≈øation and actions, without Nature or Temper having any ≈øhare in them; La≈øtly, Divine or Diabolical. They hold that the≈øe la≈øt proceed from the in≈øpiration of the Devil, who di≈øturbs the imagination of Man, and repre≈øents to him fearful Figures, to di≈øquiet or fright him, or to tran≈øport him for ≈øome time into ≈øome place
where he plea≈øes: as we have ≈øeen before, that he tran≈øports the Witches to their ≈øeveral meetings. In con≈øequence of this Doctrine, there are ≈øome of opinion, that the Dream that Pilate's Wife ≈øuffered ≈øo much becau≈øe of Chri≈øt, was a Diabolick Dream.

Sect. 16. But I find not any of the≈øe Doctors who have heretofore ever attributed ≈øo little under≈øtanding and Power to the Devil; as to the knowledge and effects already de≈øcribed, as Reynold Schot has, before quoted. We have at this time Anthony Van Dalen, who a≈øcribes no more to him in his Book of Oracles: the≈øe two Authors hold that there is no other efficient cau≈øe of all the things which are practi≈øed, or which are operated, but the impo≈øtures of Men; the Devil having no part in them. I learn al≈øo, whil≈øt I am taken up in this pre≈øent Work, that the mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible among us, attribute but very little power and knowledge to the Devil: and that there are a great many more than I conceived, who, as to the actions of the po≈ø≈øe≈øt and bewitched are of the ≈øame opinion with Mr. Daillon, who in a French Book concerning Demons, maintains all that which is contained in the Scripture, touching evil and unclean Spirits, is not otherwi≈øe to be under≈øtood, than of certain Di≈øea≈øes to which the Jews u≈øed to give ≈øuch names, believing, however that it might happen, evil Spirits medl'd with them at the ≈øame time. There's lately come to my hands very conveniently, a little Book of Mr. Orchard's an Engli≈øhman, Preacher in the New-Netherlands, as I am told, in which the ancient and common opinion upon this ≈øubject is confuted, as being directly oppo≈øite to the Doctrine and belief of the Prote≈øtant Churches.

Sect. 17. But let us leave off ≈øpeaking of the≈øe People, becau≈øe, that of one ≈øide there is no nece≈ø≈øity here to handle them and becau≈øe I intend to do it
afterwards. It is not nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øpeak of them here, becau≈øe my intention is not to ≈øet down here what is not ≈øaid of the Devil, and what is not attributed to him; but my de≈øign is to relate that which is ≈øaid of him, and to examine whether it be true or no. 'Tis ≈øufficient for me to hold the la≈øt Negative with the Engli≈øh Writer, becau≈øe I am much aver≈øe from maintaining the opinion which a≈øcribes ≈øo much power and virtue to Spirits; and e≈øpecially to the bad. And further, I ≈øhall be obliged to enter the Li≈øt with Schot, Van Dalen, and many others, who oppo≈øe the common belief that they had of this Power, when I ≈øhall come afterwards to examine the rea≈øons and proofs upon which it is founded. However, before I fini≈øh this Fir≈øt Part, I ≈øhall rehear≈øe all that has been ≈øaid, and compare the opinions of Infidels with tho≈øe of the Chri≈øtians.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. That of all the≈øe Opinions put together, there re≈øult ≈øome certain propo≈øitions, in which they differ, and others in which they agree.
div.p:
Sect. 1. I have from time to time conferr'd the Opinions that I have related, fir≈øt tho≈øe of the Ancient and modern Pagans, in the 11th Chapter, and afterwards tho≈øe of the Jews, Mahometans, and Chri≈øtians of the ≈øix fir≈øt Ages, in the 17th Chapter. There remains now to compare tho≈øe of the Papi≈øts and Prote≈øtants, after which we will confer them all together; to that end, we mu≈øt break off the order that we have kept hitherto, and begin with the la≈øt; they will furni≈øh us with very certain proof, that there is no Opinion to which the World is more engag'd, than to that which is almo≈øt generally every where taught and received concerning Spirits; for the Prote≈øtants have retained all that which cannot be look't upon as a pure invention of Popery in particular; and there are even ≈øome, who≈øe belief upon this ≈øubject, go farther than tho≈øe of the Papi≈øts. The Chri≈øtians in general believe all that is not particular to the Jews and Pagans; the Jews and the Mahometans believe all that, according to them, is not incon≈øi≈øtant with the belief of one only God; ≈øome will tell me perhaps, that we mu≈øt not wonder at it, and that naturally it ought to be ≈øo. This is what
we have now to examine, and there will be as yet room to ≈øpeak more plainly and fully afterwards.

Sect. 2. Notwith≈øtanding it is convenient to adverti≈øe the Reader, that relating here the difference or the conformity of the Opinions of all Nations, I mean only the Opinions of the more learned and are remarked among≈øt the Doctors, or who are taken for wi≈øemen in their Country, and capable of in≈øtructing others in matter of Faith‚ñ™ and Religion. I intend not to ≈øpeak of particular Opinions, but of tho≈øe generally received, taught, and confirmed by practices; for as to the common People, either Papi≈øts, Jews, or Pagans, they know nothing for the mo≈øt part, but a little by hear-≈øay; ≈øo that there is no relying upon them, and it is ≈øure without mi≈øtake, that for the mo≈øt part, what the mo≈øt illiterate believe and practice, is contrary to the ≈øen≈øe of Divines, and of all tho≈øe that under≈øtand any thing in the Holy Scripture. I will have nothing to do with them upon this ≈øubject, having often tryed my ≈øelf how many follies our own People ≈øay and believe, upon this account.

Sect. 3. So it is nece≈ø≈øary to e≈øtabli≈øh here as certain and undoubted, that every Opinion that proceeds from Pagani≈øm as from it's Original, cannot at the ≈øame time be founded upon the Holy Scripture. It is true, there never was a Doctor either Chri≈øtian or Jew, who has not applied ≈øome place in Scripture to what he has propo≈øed, but the Que≈øtion is to know, whether the applications were ju≈øt, and whether the Scripture may be expounded in the ≈øen≈øe put upon it; for it may be that the≈øe Doctors having their imagination fill'd with their own Ideas, believe in reading, to ≈øee things there which are not there, and that their own prejudice cau≈øes ‚Ä¢ o be ≈øound there; of this the Reader may at fir≈øt judge him≈øelf, if he will but mind with attention what
follows, where I remark briefly what every Sect rejects, and what every one admits; and afterwards what the one have borrowed of others, and what they have retained to this time.

Sect. 4. Alth√¥ the Prote≈øtant Churches, with one common con≈øent, deny Purgatory and all the places where they put Souls, except Paradi≈øe and Hell; the≈øe two points, are Opinions of Popery. There has been ≈øome mention made of them among≈øt the primitive Chri≈øtians, neither the Jews nor the Mahometans reject them, and they have been taken from Pagani≈øm‚ñ™ Who≈øoever rejects them, he mu≈øt reject together all the Doctrines and practices that are grounded upon them. For this rea≈øon,
Fir≈øt. We do not believe among us, that the Souls of the Decea≈øed are never wandering, nor that they appear to the living, under any figures what≈øoever, to obtain help and comfort from them.

Second. It is not believed that the Souls of the ble≈ø≈øed come back from Heaven upon Earth, nor that tho≈øe of the damned come back from Hell. It is not believed, that either the one or the other appears to Men, to comfort or afright them; and far le≈øs as yet, that the living can make agreements together, to come back after Death and vi≈øit tho≈øe they had agreed with, who have ≈øurviv'd them.
Third. By this rea≈øon, the Dead are never ask'd any Que≈øtions, nor any religious wor≈øhip paid to them.

Sect. 5. The Virtue of Conjurations is likewi≈øe unknown among us, either to drive the Souls of the decea≈øed, or to expel evil Spirits, with whom any ≈øhould be tormented. No other means is known ≈øufficient for this effect, but Prayer and fa≈øting, taught by our Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt, St. Matthew, Ch. 17 v. 21.

Fir≈øt. For this Rea≈øon it is not believed, that there is any body either Prie≈øt or Exorci≈øt, which is authori≈øed to make ≈øuch Conjurations, nor ought to meddle with them, alth√¥ a like practice was admitted in the fir≈øt time of Chri≈øtianity; whether it had ≈øucce≈øs by the power of God, or it was the meer effect of the Artifices of Men, and that it has been a cu≈øtom among the Jews, Mahometans and all the Pagans.

Second. Neither is it believed, words, names, ≈øigns, ge≈øtures, and po≈øtures, even th√¥ they were taken from the Holy Scripture, have any power for this effect, either of them≈øelves or in≈øtitution of the Church; becau≈øe ≈øhe has not received any power from God, to give her Authority as to this point.

Third. They Conjure not the Devil in the Bapti≈øm of Children, as the Papi≈øts to do; the Lutherans do the like, but not with the ≈øame intent, as the fir≈øt, that is, that the Devil is in the Infant, or that he is driven out by the Virtue of words, which are pronounced; for they only retain this practice, becau≈øe of it's antiquity, it being indifferent of it ≈øelf, at lea≈øt ≈øuch is their pretence or excu≈øe.

Sect. 6. Now that the Doctrines of the Prote≈øtants have been conferr'd with tho≈øe of Popery in particular; it remains to ≈øee what difference there is between the Chri≈øtians in general, and the Infidels.

Fir≈øt, The Pagans, the Jews, and the Ancient Chri≈øtians have believed that there is another kind of Spirits, which are placed between God and the Angels, or which are in ≈øome ≈øort corporeal, but it is not granted any more at this time by Chri≈øtians.

Second. Likewi≈øe it is not u≈øual among them, to a≈ø≈øociate God, or the Spirits to the Stars. As touching God, it was an Opinion purely Pagan; and
ouching Spirits, it was a Jewi≈øh Opinion; I know not whether it may be ≈øaid, that the Ancient Chri≈øtianity had not ≈øome tincture of it.

Third. This difference of nature in the Angels, propo≈øed by the Jews, is not believed any more; it draws its Original from Ancient Pagani≈øm, and is admitted to this day, by the modern Pagans; It's true, that the Papi≈øts acknowledge a difference of Order, but they put none in the e≈ø≈øence of the≈øe Spirits. Likewi≈øe, th√¥ they make generally appear all ≈øorts of Spirits, neverthele≈øs the difference is only in re≈øpect of places, of Per≈øons, and effects, as we have ≈øhewn more fully, Ch. 19 Sect. 7.17. Ch. 20. Sect. 1.2.3. but it is no way in re≈øpect of their nature, nor of their Original.

Fourth. There is not a Chri≈øtian, be he Prote≈øtant or Papi≈øt, who believes, that Spirits are truly capable of engendering; which is neverthele≈øs the common belief of all the Pagans, which is received among the Jews, and has not been confuted ≈øufficiently by the primitive Chri≈øtians, among whom are found, ≈øome who have expre≈øly taught it.
Sect. 7. But the Pagans differ from the Mahometans and Chri≈øtians chiefly in two points.

Fir≈øt, That they mix and confound together the ≈øupream God with other ≈øuperior and inferior Gods good and bad; and al≈øo the Souls of Men with all tho≈øe Gods, in ≈øuch a confu≈øed manner, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to comprehend any thing, and that it is a Labyrinth from whence they cannot extricate them≈øelves. On the contrary, the Jews and Mahometans agree with the Chri≈øtians, in this point, that there is one only God, and that all that is be≈øides him has been created by him.

Second. In that, that not only they make no great difficulty to deify Men, but that they make al≈øo the Gods return to the condition of Men, and
that they believe there are Men, the i≈ø≈øue of the Gods; there are ≈øome of the≈øe errors, which the Papi≈øts cannot boa≈øt of being entirely free from; for they may rea≈øonably be reproached, that they have ≈øub≈øtituted their Saints to the≈øe imaginary Gods, and to tho≈øe Demons of the Pagans; That they ≈øpeak of Saints as the Pagans do of their Gods; that they make them act in the ≈øame manner, that the≈øe fal≈øe Deities were ≈øuppo≈øed to act. But pure Chri≈øtianity, ≈øuch as has been in all times upon this point, never make Gods a Man, nor never rai≈øes Man to the dignity of God.

Sect. 8. There is notwith≈øtanding ≈øome point upon which the Prote≈øtants are not agreed, and upon which, neverthele≈øs the Papi≈øts, the primitive Chri≈øtians, the Jews, the Mahometans, and all the Pagans agree, viz. The Tutelary Gods of the Pagans, who were the guardian Angels in the fir≈øt Chri≈øtianity. We have lately ≈øeen they are admitted without conte≈øtation among the Papi≈øts; the Prote≈øtants in general, are not di≈øpo≈øed to receive this Opinion; tho≈øe of the profe≈ø≈øion of France, Holland, and Swi≈ø≈øerland, reject it; and neverthele≈øs there are ≈øome, but very few, that admit it, or at lea≈øt believe, not that there are ≈øufficient rea≈øons to oppo≈øe it; we ≈øhall examine afterwards, which is the ≈øounde≈øt of the≈øe Opinions.
