In the mean while we mu≈øt take notice before hand, that what the Papi≈øts teach upon this ≈øubject, together with ≈øome of other Chri≈øtians that are not of their Communion, relates more to the light and knowledge which they ≈øuppo≈øe that tho≈øe Spirits communicate to them, than real help they can expect in their actions, and in their manner of living; for it is rarely ≈øeen, or to ≈øay better, it is never ≈øeen, that the People a≈øcribe a con≈øiderable deliverance, or a great oppre≈ø≈øion, that befal them to an Angel, either their
keeper or their enemy; but they never fail to a≈øcribe it immediatly to the providence of God; or if they ≈øometimes turn their Eyes to another ≈øide, the Papi≈øts as to their particular refer all the good that happens to them, to the protection of ≈øome great Saint, e≈øpecially to that of the Virgin Mary; but the Prote≈øtants, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øeem to favour the belief of the Popi≈øh Saints, would rather ≈øay, if occa≈øion ≈øerves, that the Devil was the Author of it,

Sect. 9. There is al≈øo a difference to be taken notice of, betwixt the Heathens on one ≈øide, the Jews and the Mahometans on the other, and all the Chri≈øtians on another; it is chiefly in the practice of Witchcraft and Divination; which, according to the principles of the fir≈øt, is a laudable practice in it ≈øelf, alth√¥ often abu≈øed, as a great many good things are; according to the principles of the ≈øecond, it is only allow'd and u≈øeful in many occa≈øions; and according to the la≈øt it is directly oppo≈øite to Chri≈øtianity. The rea≈øon of it is, that the Pagans hold for Gods, or at lea≈øt for Mini≈øters and Amba≈ø≈øadors of the Gods, Spirits, which are lookt upon by Chri≈øtians as unpure Spirits; and that the Jews and the Mahometans cau≈øe to proceed from the Virtue of the Caballa‚ñ™ and the influences of the Stars, whatever the Chri≈øtians take to be Magick, Witchcraft, or Enchantments. It is true, that in the time of Ancient Pagani≈øm, the Mathematicians have been put into the rank of Poi≈øoners, and that both were treated as per≈øons equally pernicious, to whom it was forbidden to exerci≈øe their art, as being unlawful. But the occa≈øion of the≈øe prohibitions, was only founded upon the ill u≈øe that was made of this Art, which had been before not only permitted, but even much e≈øteem'd. At this time the Chri≈øtians have no longer any aver≈øion for the name of Mathematician, but that of Poy≈øoner never received any good interpretation; no that words are
here to be di≈øputed, for 'tis of things that we treat; and we are to examine them, and not words. Perhaps there will be occa≈øion to have ≈øome regard to them, in our third Book; where without doubt, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øpeak fully of the≈øe terms, and of many others.

Sect. 10. Let's now ≈øee what conformity is found among all the≈øe People together, Pagans, Jews, Mahometans, Chri≈øtians, both Ancient and Modern, Roman Catholicks, Prote≈øtants and others. They all confe≈øs,

Fir≈øt. That there are Spirits di≈øtinct from God, and bodies: for th√¥ ≈øome contrive yet another kind of Spirits, as we have ≈øaid; it is one of the points in di≈øpute among them, and now we are about to ≈øeek wherein they agree together.
Second. That there natures are different, ≈øome ab≈øolutely ≈øub≈øi≈øting without body, as Angels; and others being united to a body, as Souls.
Third. That, however, both are mortal.
Fourth, That of ≈øuch Spirits as are united to a body, ≈øome are good to Men and others bad.
Fifth. That therefore, Man has rea≈øon to ≈øeek the friend≈øhip of good Spirits, that is, the Angels, and to take all po≈ø≈øible care to divert from him evil Spirits, which are Devils.
Sixth. That an infinite happine≈øs or mi≈øery attends Men after this life.

Seventh. That likewi≈øe of the Souls of the decea≈øed, ≈øome are bad, and ≈øome good and holy; th√¥ they ≈øeem not to explain them≈øelves always in the ≈øame manner, ≈øometimes upon one of the points, and ≈øometimes upon the other; it i ‚Ä¢ neverthele≈øs certain‚ñ™ con≈øidering the bottom of the matter, that their ≈øentiments are agreeable; ≈øee then in what con≈øi≈øts the conformity of the Opinions in general of all Nations, and in what they differ. We have
now to examine, what is true or what not, in all that has been related; and it is for that purpo≈øe, I de≈øign my ≈øecond and third Book, according to the divi≈øion I have e≈øtabli≈øhed before, Chapter the fir≈øt, Sect. 8. However we ≈øhall yet ≈øee, what cautions may be drawn from all that has been ≈øaid.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV. That all that has been related, ≈øhews upon what foundation the Chri≈øtians in general, and the Prote≈øtants in particular, ≈øay, ≈øuch extraordinary things of the Devil.
div.p:
Sect. 1. Sect. 2. S. 3. Sect. 4. Sect. 5. And as to the Holy Writ, I think not that it may be taken for the cau≈øe of the Opinions Men have of the Devil. Sect. 6. If we de≈øire more particularly to examine how the Notion of the≈øe things is formed in Men of Learning, by the means of Learning it ≈øelf, and how it is increa≈øed; I am ready to declare what I have ob≈øerved for a long time, by the experiments I have made. The fir≈øt prejudices of Man are as ancient as his knowledge, and begin from his mo≈øt tender youth the≈øe two ways. Sect. 9. I hope that what I have ju≈øt now ≈øaid will ea≈øily be credited, if attention be given to what follows. Sect. 14.
